VMA was evaluated by histopathological analysis and immunohistochemistry. Results showed a significant decrease in retinal tissue oxygen levels after RBVO, indicating local tissue hypoxia. Furthermore, VMA characterized by neovascularization and capillary proliferation was observed in RBVO eyes. This study provides valuable insights into the pathogenesis of RBVO and suggests potential therapeutic targets for preventing vision loss in patients.

Vitamin C and cancer prevention: the epidemiologic evidence.  Epidemiologic evidence of a protective effect of vitamin C for non-hormone-dependent cancers is strong. The role of vitamin C in cancer prevention has been studied extensively, and epidemiologic evidence suggests a protective effect against non-hormone-dependent cancers. Several studies have investigated the association between vitamin C intake and the risk of various types of cancer. In a meta-analysis of 45 cohort and 57 case-control studies, high dietary intake of vitamin C was found to be associated with a significantly reduced risk of gastric, pancreatic, and esophageal cancers. Furthermore, a dose-response relationship was observed, indicating that higher levels of vitamin C intake were associated with a greater reduction in cancer risk. Additionally, several studies have shown a potential protective effect of vitamin C against lung, colorectal, and breast cancers. Mechanisms by which vitamin C may exert its anticancer effects include antioxidant activity, immune system enhancement, and regulation of DNA repair. In conclusion, the epidemiologic evidence supports the role of vitamin C in cancer prevention, particularly for non-hormone-dependent cancers, and highlights the importance of including adequate vitamin C in the diet for overall health and cancer risk reduction.

Hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists. H2-receptor antagonists are commonly used in the treatment of gastric acid-related disorders. Despite their widespread use, their potential hemodynamic effects are not well understood. In this study, we investigated the hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists in a group of healthy volunteers. Hemodynamic parameters including heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output were measured before and after administration of H2-receptor antagonists. Our results showed no significant differences in any of the hemodynamic parameters following H2-receptor antagonist administration. These findings suggest that H2-receptor antagonists do not exert clinically relevant hemodynamic effects in healthy individuals. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists in specific patient populations.

The Los Angeles experience with laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  Surgeons should be competent in diagnostic laparoscopy before performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC). Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) has become the gold standard for the treatment of symptomatic gallbladder disease. The experience of a single center in Los Angeles with LC is described in this review. The importance of surgeons being competent in diagnostic laparoscopy prior to performing LC is emphasized. The surgical technique, patient selection, and outcomes were evaluated in this study. The results demonstrate a high success rate with LC and a low complication rate, indicating the safety and efficacy of this approach. The learning curve for LC is discussed, emphasizing the need for appropriate training and mentorship. It is recommended that surgeons undergo extensive training and gain sufficient experience in diagnostic laparoscopy before attempting LC. This review highlights the importance of surgical expertise and proper training in achieving optimal outcomes in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Removal of large symptomatic intrauterine growths by the hysteroscopic resectoscope.  Fifty-three patients underwent 55 procedures with a resectoscope for the removal of large symptomatic intrauterine growths. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of hysteroscopic resectoscope in the removal of large symptomatic intrauterine growths. A total of 53 patients underwent 55 procedures using the resectoscope. The patients presented with various symptoms including abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain. The majority of growths were polyps (81.8%) and submucosal fibroids (16.4%). The resectoscope successfully removed the intrauterine growths in all procedures without any major complications. Postoperative follow-up showed a significant improvement in symptoms and no recurrence of intrauterine growths during the study period. This study demonstrates that hysteroscopic resectoscope is an effective and safe method for the removal of large symptomatic intrauterine growths, providing positive clinical outcomes for patients.

Analysis of side-effects of medium- and low-dose cyclosporin maintenance therapy in psoriasis.  The side-effects of long-term cyclosporin A (CyA) treatment in 26 patients with severe psoriasis were evaluated. This study aimed to evaluate the side-effects of long-term cyclosporin A (CyA) treatment in 26 patients with severe psoriasis. The patients received either medium- (4 mg/kg/day) or low-dose (2 mg/kg/day) CyA maintenance therapy for a mean duration of 2.5 years. Adverse events were monitored and documented. The most common side-effects observed were renal impairment (42.3%), hypertension (34.6%), and hyperlipidemia (30.8%). Other reported side-effects included tremors, gingival hyperplasia, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Renal impairment was more frequent in the medium-dose group compared to the low-dose group (61.5% vs 23.1%). There were no cases of CyA-induced malignancies or opportunistic infections. In conclusion, long-term CyA therapy in psoriasis patients can lead to renal impairment, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia as the most common side-effects. Careful monitoring and management of these side-effects are essential for the safe use of CyA as a maintenance therapy in psoriasis.

Survivorship analysis of total knee arthroplasty. Survivorship analysis is crucial in evaluating the long-term outcomes of total knee arthroplasty (TKA). In this study, we aimed to determine the survivorship rate and identify factors influencing implant longevity in patients who underwent TKA. A total of 402 patients with TKA were followed up for a median duration of 10 years. Kaplan-Meier analysis was conducted to estimate the survivorship rate. The overall survivorship rate at 10 years was 88.5%. Factors associated with implant failure included older age, higher body mass index, and presence of comorbidities such as diabetes and osteoporosis. Infection and aseptic loosening were the main reasons for implant failure. These findings highlight the importance of careful patient selection and preventative measures to improve the longevity of TKA implants. Future studies should focus on optimizing surgical techniques and postoperative management to further improve survivorship outcomes.

The effect of dopexamine HCl upon collateral perfusion of the acutely ischemic myocardium in anesthetized dogs. The effect of dopexamine HCl on collateral perfusion of the acutely ischemic myocardium was investigated in anesthetized dogs. Fifteen dogs were studied using a coronary occlusion model. Collateral blood flow to the ischemic region was measured using radioactive microspheres. Dopexamine HCl was administered intravenously, and its effect on collateral perfusion was assessed. The results showed that dopexamine HCl significantly increased collateral blood flow to the ischemic myocardium. This suggests that dopexamine HCl may have a beneficial effect on the perfusion of ischemic tissues by enhancing collateral circulation. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential therapeutic implications of dopexamine HCl in the treatment of myocardial ischemia.

Visual illusions in a patient with lateral medullary syndrome. Lateral medullary syndrome (LMS), also known as Wallenberg syndrome, is a neurological disorder caused by an infarction in the lateral medulla. We present a case study of a patient with LMS who experienced visual illusions. The patient, a 52-year-old male, presented with typical clinical manifestations of LMS, including vertigo, ataxia, dysphagia, and sensory deficits. Along with these symptoms, he reported various visual distortions, such as size and shape misperception, object movement, and color aberrations. These visual illusions persisted throughout the patient's recovery from LMS, indicating a direct association with the syndrome. While visual disturbances in LMS have been previously reported, the specific phenomenon of visual illusions adds important insights into the visual processing deficits associated with this syndrome. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment strategies for visual illusions in LMS patients.

Low dose amitriptyline in chronic pain: the gain is modest.  In the double-blind placebo-controlled study presented here, the effects were investigated of a low dose of amitriptyline (75 mg) in patients with chronic pain of various origins. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a low dose of amitriptyline (75 mg) in patients with chronic pain. A double-blind placebo-controlled study was conducted on patients with chronic pain from various causes. The results showed only modest improvement in pain symptoms with amitriptyline compared to placebo. No significant differences were found in pain intensity, analgesic consumption, or quality of life between the two groups. However, amitriptyline was well-tolerated with only mild adverse effects. In conclusion, the use of a low dose of amitriptyline may provide limited relief in chronic pain conditions, but its overall clinical impact is modest. Further research is needed to explore other treatment options for chronic pain.

Early identification of hearing loss: listen to parents. Early identification of hearing loss is crucial for effective intervention and treatment. This study aimed to determine the role of parental observation in detecting early signs of hearing loss in children. A total of 200 parents of children aged 0-5 years were surveyed using a questionnaire that assessed their awareness of potential hearing loss symptoms, their ability to recognize these symptoms in their children, and their action taken upon recognizing them. The results showed that 40% of parents reported observing at least one symptom related to hearing loss in their child. The most commonly reported symptoms were delayed speech development, difficulty understanding speech, and lack of response to sounds. Interestingly, parents who reported having a family history of hearing loss were more likely to recognize and take action upon observing these symptoms. Overall, this study highlights the importance of involving parents in the early identification of hearing loss and emphasizes the need for increased education and awareness among parents regarding the signs and symptoms of hearing loss in children.

Early carcinoma of the gallbladder: macroscopic features and US findings. This retrospective study aimed to analyze the macroscopic features and ultrasound (US) findings of early carcinoma of the gallbladder. A total of 45 patients diagnosed with early gallbladder carcinoma were included in the study. Macroscopic analysis revealed various features, including mucosal irregularities, nodularity, thickening, and ulceration. US findings showed that 31 patients had gallstones, 17 had gallbladder wall thickening, and 12 had intraluminal polyps. Four patients had localized wall thickening without gallstones or polyps. The most common US finding was gallstones, followed by gallbladder wall thickening. In cases with localized wall thickening, early detection was challenging. Among the different macroscopic features observed, mucosal irregularities and nodularity were correlated with wall thickening on US. Based on these findings, it can be concluded that US plays a crucial role in the early detection of gallbladder carcinoma as it can identify most cases with associated gallstones or wall thickening. However, cases with localized wall thickening require further evaluation due to the difficulty in diagnosis.

Push-enteroscopy for diagnosis of patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. Gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin is a diagnostic challenge that often requires invasive procedures for identification and localization of the bleeding source. Push-enteroscopy has emerged as an effective method for evaluating patients with this condition. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the diagnostic yield and safety of push-enteroscopy in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. A total of 72 patients underwent push-enteroscopy, and the bleeding source was identified in 45 patients (62.5%). Small bowel lesions were the most common cause of bleeding, accounting for 42.2% of cases. The diagnostic yield of push-enteroscopy was higher in patients with ongoing or recent bleeding compared to those with intermittent bleeding. Complications were rare, with minor bleeding being the most common adverse event. In conclusion, push-enteroscopy is a safe and effective diagnostic tool for patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin, providing valuable information for appropriate management and treatment decisions.

Impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. Enteritis necroticans is a severe gastrointestinal disease caused by the potent toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens type C. This study aimed to assess the impact of active immunization against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. Two thousand individuals were vaccinated with a formalin-inactivated vaccine, while an equal number served as controls. Over a 3-year follow-up period, the incidence of enteritis necroticans in vaccinated individuals was significantly lower compared to controls (p<0.05). Vaccine efficacy was estimated to be approximately 75%, providing substantial protection against the disease. Furthermore, the severity of illness and mortality rate among vaccinated cases was significantly lower compared to non-vaccinated cases (p<0.01). These findings demonstrate that active immunization against enteritis necroticans can have a significant impact on the prevention and control of this life-threatening disease.

Relative accuracy of three scintigraphic methods for determination of right ventricular ejection fraction: a correlative study with ultrafast computed tomography.  The accuracy of three scintigraphic methods for determination of right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF) was tested in 29 patients using ultrafast computed tomography (UFCT) as the gold standard.  RVEF measurements by the ECG-gated first-pass approach showed excellent correlation with the UFCT results (r = 0. This study aimed to compare the accuracy of three scintigraphic methods in determining the right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF) with ultrafast computed tomography (UFCT) as the gold standard. The study included 29 patients, and the RVEF measurements were obtained using the ECG-gated first-pass approach. The results demonstrated a strong correlation between the RVEF measurements obtained by the ECG-gated first-pass approach and the UFCT results (r = 0.79, p < 0.001). In contrast, the two other scintigraphic methods, the equilibrium method and the gated equilibrium method, showed weaker correlations with UFCT (r = 0.60, p < 0.001 and r = 0.43, p = 0.035, respectively). Therefore, the ECG-gated first-pass approach was found to be the most accurate method for determining RVEF compared to UFCT.

Development of acute myelocytic leukemia in patients with Crohn's disease. Crohn's disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal tract, and it has been associated with an increased risk of developing acute myelocytic leukemia (AML). We aimed to investigate the incidence and characteristics of AML in patients with CD. A total of 76,489 CD patients were identified from a large population-based database and followed for a mean duration of 7.5 years. The incidence rate of AML was found to be 3.22 per 10,000 person-years. CD patients who developed AML were older, had longer disease duration, and were more likely to have received immunosuppressive therapy compared to CD patients without AML. In conclusion, CD patients have an elevated risk of developing AML, particularly those with longer disease duration and exposure to immunosuppressive therapy.

Pulmonary tumor embolism to alveolar septal capillaries.  A prospective study of 12 cases. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence and clinical implications of pulmonary tumor embolism (PTE) to alveolar septal capillaries in 12 cases. Patients with confirmed PTE were included and underwent a thorough examination of their clinical and pathological characteristics. The median age of the patients was 58.5 years, and the most common primary tumors associated with PTE were lung cancer (5 cases) and breast cancer (2 cases). The most frequent clinical presentation was dyspnea (75%), followed by cough (66.7%). Histopathological examination revealed embolized tumor cells in the alveolar septal capillaries in all cases. Additionally, vascular invasion of the tumor was observed in all cases. The presence of PTE to alveolar septal capillaries was associated with a poor prognosis, with a median survival time of 4.5 months. These findings suggest that PTE to alveolar septal capillaries may represent an important mechanism of tumor spread and should be considered in the evaluation and management of patients with malignant tumors.

Diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus. We report a case of diphenylhydantoin (Dilantin)-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The patient presented with recurrent infections despite being on antiretroviral therapy. Laboratory investigations revealed decreased levels of immunoglobulins, particularly IgG and IgM. Diphenylhydantoin, which the patient had been taking for seizure control, was identified as the cause of the hypogammaglobulinemia. Upon discontinuation of Dilantin and initiation of immunoglobulin replacement therapy, the patient's recurrent infections resolved and immunoglobulin levels improved. This case highlights the importance of considering drug-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in HIV-infected patients presenting with recurrent infections, and prompt management with discontinuation of the offending agent and immunoglobulin replacement therapy.

Rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias with high-dose oral amiodarone.  To shorten the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect when using amiodarone for the conversion of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, 19 patients were given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of high-dose oral amiodarone in rapidly controlling refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Nineteen patients with refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias were administered oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. ECG monitoring was used to assess the conversion of tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm. The results showed that high-dose oral amiodarone effectively shortened the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect. Sinus rhythm was achieved in 89% of patients within 24 hours of treatment initiation. The protocol was well-tolerated, with no serious adverse events reported. High-dose oral amiodarone may therefore be considered as an effective and safe option for rapidly controlling refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Is there a place for conservative surgery in the treatment of renal carcinoma? Since 1981, 31 patients have undergone conservative surgery for malignant renal tumours and have been followed up for at least 2 years.  The techniques included enucleation or resection (wedge resection or partial nephrectomy). The role of conservative surgery in the treatment of renal carcinoma remains a topic of debate. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 31 patients who underwent conservative surgery for malignant renal tumors between 1981 and present. The surgical techniques employed included enucleation or resection, such as wedge resection or partial nephrectomy. The patients were followed up for a minimum of 2 years postoperatively. Our study demonstrates that conservative surgery can be a viable option for selected patients with renal carcinoma, as evidenced by a favorable long-term survival rate and low incidence of complications. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and determine the optimal patient selection criteria.

Deposits of crystalline material containing silicon in surgically excised human valves.  Ninety-seven surgically excised natural cardiac valves were examined by scanning electron microscopy and x-ray energy spectroscopy to assess the occurrence of crystalline deposits that contain the element silicon. In this study, we investigated the presence of crystalline deposits containing silicon in surgically excised human valves. Ninety-seven natural cardiac valves were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy and x-ray energy spectroscopy. Our findings revealed the occurrence of these crystalline deposits in the valves. The identification of these deposits suggests a potential role of silicon in valve pathology. Further research is needed to determine the significance of these findings and the mechanisms involved in their formation. Understanding the presence and impact of silicon-containing deposits in cardiac valves may have implications for the management and treatment of valvular diseases. This study contributes to the growing body of knowledge regarding the etiology and pathogenesis of valve disorders.

Cervical rotation flaps for midface resurfacing.  The midface has long served as a focus for creativity in surgical reconstruction. Cervical rotation flaps have been widely used for midface resurfacing in surgical reconstruction. This technique allows for the restoration of facial contour and function in individuals with midface deformities. The procedure involves mobilizing a flap of cervical tissue and rotating it to cover the defect in the midface region. The advantages of this technique include a reliable blood supply, good aesthetic outcomes, and minimal donor site morbidity. However, complications such as flap necrosis, infection, and scarring may occur. Several modifications and variations of the technique have been described to address specific patient needs and anatomical considerations. Overall, cervical rotation flaps provide a valuable option for midface reconstruction, offering improved quality of life and psychological well-being for patients.

Oncocytic glomus tumor of the trachea.  An oncocytic variant of glomus tumor of the trachea occurred in a 47-year-old woman. We present a rare case of oncocytic glomus tumor of the trachea in a 47-year-old woman. The patient presented with a 2-year history of progressive dyspnea and a persistent cough. Imaging studies revealed a 2.5 cm mass in the trachea. Surgical resection of the mass was performed, and histopathological examination revealed a glomus tumor composed predominantly of oncocytic cells. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for smooth muscle actin and vimentin, confirming the glomus tumor diagnosis. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery and remained asymptomatic at the one-year follow-up. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of an oncocytic variant of glomus tumor occurring in the trachea. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and clinical characteristics of this rare tumor type.

Retrovirus from human T-cell leukemia virus type I-associated myelopathy is the same strain as a prototype human T-cell leukemia virus type I. Human T-cell leukemia virus type I (HTLV-I) is associated with various diseases, including myelopathy. It has been hypothesized that the retrovirus responsible for HTLV-I-associated myelopathy (HAM) is a distinct strain from the prototype HTLV-I virus. However, our study provides evidence to suggest that the retrovirus found in HAM patients is actually the same strain as the prototype HTLV-I virus. Analysis of viral genomic sequences from HAM patients revealed no significant differences compared to the prototype strain. Our findings highlight the importance of accurately characterizing the viral strains associated with HTLV-I and its associated diseases, which can have implications for the development of targeted therapies and vaccines.

Safe performance of difficult laparoscopic cholecystectomies. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) is a common surgical procedure for gallbladder removal. However, in certain cases, LC can become challenging and pose risks to patient safety. This study aimed to assess the safe performance of difficult LCs. A total of 167 patients who underwent LC for acute or chronic cholecystitis were included. Difficult LCs were defined based on various factors such as anatomical variations, adhesions, and inflammation. The rate of conversion to open surgery, operative time, blood loss, and postoperative complications were analyzed. Overall, 24.6% of LCs were classified as difficult. The rate of conversion to open surgery was 8.4%. Despite the complexity, the procedure was performed safely, with low rates of complications (12.6%) and minimal blood loss (mean of 20 ml). In conclusion, difficult LCs can be safely performed with proper surgical techniques and expertise. Increased awareness and understanding of the challenges associated with difficult LCs can help improve patient outcomes.

Surgical management of renal cell carcinoma with extensive intracaval involvement using a venous bypass system suitable for rapid conversion to total cardiopulmonary bypass. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with intracaval involvement poses a surgical challenge due to the risk of tumor embolization. A venous bypass system that allows rapid conversion to total cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) can be utilized to facilitate safe tumor removal. We present a case of a 56-year-old male with RCC and extensive intracaval tumor thrombus involving the right atrium. The patient underwent a successful surgical resection using a venous bypass system, which was readily converted to CPB when needed. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course with complete tumor resection and preservation of cardiac function. The use of a venous bypass system with the ability for rapid conversion to CPB offers a safe and effective approach for managing RCC with extensive intracaval involvement.

Skeletal muscle depressed calcium and phosphofructokinase in chronic heart failure are upregulated by captopril--a double-blind, placebo-controlled study.  The effects of the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor captopril, after treatment for 5-6 weeks with 25 mg t. In patients with chronic heart failure (CHF), skeletal muscle abnormalities such as depressed calcium and phosphofructokinase (PFK) activity have been observed. This double-blind, placebo-controlled study sought to investigate the effects of the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor captopril on these skeletal muscle abnormalities. A total of 30 CHF patients were randomized to receive either captopril (25 mg orally, twice daily) or placebo for 5-6 weeks. Skeletal muscle biopsies were obtained before and after treatment. The results showed that captopril treatment significantly upregulated calcium and PFK activity in skeletal muscle compared to placebo. These findings suggest that captopril has a positive effect on skeletal muscle function in CHF patients, possibly contributing to the improvement in exercise tolerance often seen with this medication.

Retroviral recombination and reverse transcription. Retroviral recombination and reverse transcription are critical processes in the life cycle of retroviruses, including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Recombination allows for the exchange of genetic material between two distinct retroviral genomes, resulting in the generation of new viral strains with altered characteristics. Reverse transcription is the conversion of the viral RNA genome into DNA by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. This DNA is then integrated into the host cell genome, leading to persistent viral infection. Both processes play crucial roles in viral evolution, drug resistance, and immune evasion by retroviruses. Understanding the mechanisms and regulation of retroviral recombination and reverse transcription is essential for the development of effective antiretroviral therapies and vaccines against retroviral infections, particularly HIV. Further research is needed to elucidate the factors influencing these processes and explore their potential as targets for therapeutic intervention.

Seizure disorders in Down syndrome. Seizure disorders are commonly seen in individuals with Down syndrome (DS), with a prevalence of up to 13%. The pathogenesis of seizures in DS is multifactorial, involving both genetic and environmental factors. The risk of seizures is higher in individuals with DS compared to the general population, and the age of onset is usually earlier. The seizures in DS are often refractory to treatment and may require polytherapy. There is limited data regarding the efficacy of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) in this population, and individualized therapy is often necessary. Both the choice and dosing of AEDs should be carefully considered to ensure optimal seizure control while minimizing side effects. Non-pharmacological interventions such as behavioral interventions and early intervention programs also play an important role in managing seizures in individuals with DS. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of seizures in DS and to improve treatment outcomes.

Rupture of atheromatous plaque as a cause of thrombotic occlusion of stenotic internal carotid artery. Thrombotic occlusion of the internal carotid artery is a leading cause of ischemic strokes. This study aims to investigate the role of rupture of atheromatous plaque in the development of thrombotic occlusion in stenotic internal carotid arteries. Sixteen patients with stenotic internal carotid artery were included in this study. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound and angiography were performed to assess the presence of atheromatous plaque and measure the degree of stenosis. Histological examination of the excised plaque was done to identify ruptured plaques and analyze their composition. It was found that 10 out of the 16 patients had ruptured atheromatous plaques, and all of them had complete thrombotic occlusion of the stenotic internal carotid artery. The ruptured plaques showed higher lipid content and inflammatory cell infiltration compared to non-ruptured plaques. These findings suggest that rupture of atheromatous plaque plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of thrombotic occlusion in stenotic internal carotid arteries.

Chronic hyperglycemia increases the density of glucose transporters in human erythrocyte membranes.  We investigated the effect of chronic hyperglycemia on glucose transporters in erythrocytes of subjects with and without diabetes mellitus. Chronic hyperglycemia has been shown to have an impact on glucose transporters in human erythrocyte membranes. This study aimed to investigate the effect of chronic hyperglycemia on glucose transporters in erythrocytes of individuals with and without diabetes mellitus. Erythrocytes from diabetic and non-diabetic subjects were analyzed for glucose transporter density using immunofluorescence staining and quantitative image analysis. The results demonstrated a significant increase in glucose transporter density in erythrocyte membranes of individuals with chronic hyperglycemia compared to those without diabetes mellitus. These findings suggest that chronic hyperglycemia may contribute to alterations in glucose transporter expression and function in erythrocytes, potentially impacting glucose metabolism and homeostasis. Further research is warranted to explore the implications of these findings in diabetic complications and management.

The management of mid-face fractures with intracranial injury.  Recent advances have radically changed the management of facial fractures. Mid-face fractures often occur in conjunction with intracranial injuries, posing a challenge in their management. This study aims to evaluate recent advances in the management of mid-face fractures with intracranial injury. The study included 50 patients who presented with mid-face fractures and associated intracranial injuries between 2015 and 2020. The patients were divided into two groups: Group A received traditional treatment methods, while Group B received the updated management techniques. The results demonstrated that the updated management techniques yielded superior outcomes in terms of reduced overall complications, shorter hospital stays, and improved patient satisfaction. The updated techniques included the use of virtual surgical planning, three-dimensional printing, and miniplate osteosynthesis. Furthermore, early surgical intervention was found to be beneficial in preventing complications such as cerebrospinal fluid leakage and infection. In conclusion, recent advances in the management of mid-face fractures with intracranial injury have revolutionized patient care, leading to better outcomes and improved quality of life.

Identification of transforming growth factor beta family members present in bone-inductive protein purified from bovine bone. This study aimed to identify the transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β) family members present in bone-inductive protein purified from bovine bone. The bone-inductive protein was extracted and purified using a combination of solubility testing, ammonium sulfate fractionation, ion exchange chromatography, and gel filtration chromatography. The purified protein was then subjected to sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and Western blot analysis to detect the presence of TGF-β family members. The results revealed the presence of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2 in the purified bone-inductive protein, suggesting their potential role in bone induction. Further studies are needed to explore the mechanism of action and therapeutic potential of TGF-β family members in bone regeneration.

Endovascular occlusion of vertebral arteries in the treatment of unclippable vertebrobasilar aneurysms. Endovascular occlusion of vertebral arteries is a treatment option for unclippable vertebrobasilar aneurysms. This retrospective study aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of this procedure in 48 patients with unclippable aneurysms. Angiographic follow-up was performed at 6, 12, and 24 months to evaluate aneurysm occlusion and vessel patency. The procedure was successful in 45 patients (93.8%) with complete aneurysm occlusion achieved in 41 cases (85.4%). Minor complications occurred in 12 patients (25%) and major complications in 3 patients (6.3%). No symptomatic ischemic events were reported. Follow-up angiography demonstrated stable occlusion in 38 cases (79.2%) and recanalization in 10 cases (20.8%). Overall, endovascular occlusion of vertebral arteries appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for unclippable vertebrobasilar aneurysms. However, long-term follow-up is needed to assess the durability of aneurysm occlusion.

Oral contraceptives and breast cancer. The relationship between the use of oral contraceptives (OCs) and the risk of breast cancer remains controversial. A meta-analysis was conducted to assess this association. A comprehensive search was performed to identify relevant studies, and a random-effects model was used to estimate the pooled odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). A total of 37 studies involving 12,893 cases and 101,990 controls were included in the analysis. The overall pooled analysis showed that OC use was associated with a slightly increased risk of breast cancer (OR=1.08, 95% CI=1.02–1.14). Subgroup analysis revealed that the increased risk was mainly observed in women younger than 45 years old (OR=1.13, 95% CI=1.05–1.21). However, no significant association was found in women aged 45 years or older (OR=0.99, 95% CI=0.92–1.07). Sensitivity analysis confirmed the robustness of the results. In conclusion, the use of OCs is associated with a modestly increased risk of breast cancer, particularly in younger women. Further studies are needed to explore potential underlying mechanisms.

Abscess of the sphenoid sinus after transsphenoidal surgery. Transsphenoidal surgery is a common procedure used to remove pituitary tumors. However, complications can occur, including the formation of abscesses in the sphenoid sinus. We present a case of a 53-year-old male who developed a sphenoid sinus abscess three weeks after undergoing transsphenoidal surgery. The patient presented with severe headache, fever, and nasal congestion. Imaging revealed a well-defined lesion within the sphenoid sinus, and pus culture confirmed the presence of an abscess. The patient underwent endoscopic sinus surgery for drainage and received intravenous antibiotics. He experienced significant improvement with resolution of the abscess. Sphenoid sinus abscess is a rare but potentially serious complication of transsphenoidal surgery. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment are essential to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

The pathology of heart allograft rejection. Heart allograft rejection remains a significant complication in cardiac transplantation. Understanding the underlying pathology is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. In this study, we aim to review the current knowledge on the pathology of heart allograft rejection.

Various histopathological features have been identified in heart allograft rejection, including cellular infiltrates, myocardial necrosis, and vascular changes. The predominant cellular infiltrate consists of T lymphocytes, macrophages, and natural killer cells. These infiltrates are often found within the myocardium and can lead to myocyte damage and subsequent functional impairment.

The severity and extent of these histological changes are typically graded using established classification systems, such as the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT) grading system. This grading system helps clinicians assess the severity of rejection and guide treatment decisions.

Additionally, immunohistochemical staining and molecular techniques have advanced our understanding of the immunological mechanisms involved in allograft rejection. Detection of specific immune markers, such as CD3 and HLA molecules, can aid in the identification and characterization of rejection.

In conclusion, heart allograft rejection is a complex process involving various histological features and immune mechanisms. Accurate pathological assessment is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management of rejection episodes in cardiac transplant recipients. Further research is needed to improve our understanding of the pathology and develop targeted therapies to prevent and treat heart allograft rejection.

Cerebral blood flow in progressive aphasia without dementia. Progressive aphasia is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the gradual loss of language function. While it is typically associated with dementia, there is a subset of patients who experience progressive aphasia without dementia. The aim of this study was to investigate the cerebral blood flow patterns in individuals with progressive aphasia without dementia. Using single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging, regional cerebral blood flow was measured in a group of progressive aphasia patients and compared to healthy controls. Results showed significant hypoperfusion in the left hemisphere, predominantly in the frontal and temporal lobes, in patients with progressive aphasia compared to controls. These findings suggest that cerebral blood flow abnormalities may underlie the language deficits observed in progressive aphasia without dementia. Understanding these patterns of hypoperfusion may aid in the early diagnosis and management of progressive aphasia and provide insights into the pathophysiology of the disorder.

Definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates.  Mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery continue to provide challenges to head and neck surgeons. Reconstruction plates are commonly used for definitive mandibular replacement following radical cancer surgery. These surgeries often result in significant mandibular defects, which pose challenges for head and neck surgeons. Reconstruction plates provide stability and support for mandibular function and aesthetic outcomes. The procedure involves the placement of metal plates and screws to mimic the jaw's anatomical structure. Despite their effectiveness, complications such as infection, hardware failure, and improper alignment can occur. Additional procedures, such as bone grafts or tissue flaps, may be required to achieve optimal functional and cosmetic results. Preoperative planning, accurate intraoperative measurements, and meticulous surgical technique are crucial for successful outcomes. Long-term follow-up is necessary to monitor for complications and ensure patient satisfaction. Innovative techniques and further research are needed to improve the outcomes of mandibular reconstruction using reconstruction plates.

Intra-abdominal abscesses in Crohn's disease.  We reviewed 22 patients who had intra-abdominal abscesses secondary to Crohn's disease. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of intra-abdominal abscesses in patients with Crohn's disease. A total of 22 patients were included in the analysis. It was found that intra-abdominal abscesses were a common complication of Crohn's disease, with 18 out of the 22 patients experiencing this complication. The abscesses were identified through imaging studies such as computed tomography or ultrasound. The majority of the abscesses were located in the ileocecal region. Surgical intervention was required in most cases for the treatment of the abscesses. In conclusion, intra-abdominal abscesses are a significant concern in patients with Crohn's disease, and timely diagnosis and management are crucial for the favorable outcome of these patients.

Systemic mast cell disease associated with primary mediastinal germ cell tumor. We present a rare case of a 32-year-old male with concurrent systemic mast cell disease and primary mediastinal germ cell tumor. The patient initially presented with symptoms of shortness of breath and chest pain. Imaging studies revealed a large anterior mediastinal mass, which was surgically resected. Histological examination confirmed the presence of a mixed germ cell tumor. Further evaluation revealed the presence of systemic mast cell disease, with multiple involved organs and elevated serum tryptase levels. The coexistence of these two rare conditions raised questions regarding their potential association. Mast cells have been implicated in tumorigenesis and inflammation, and their presence in the tumor microenvironment may contribute to tumor progression and metastasis. This case highlights the importance of considering systemic mast cell disease in the evaluation and management of patients with mediastinal germ cell tumors. Further investigations are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms linking these two conditions.

Inflammatory pseudotumor of intra-abdominal lymph nodes manifesting as recurrent fever of unknown origin: a case report. Inflammatory pseudotumor is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs including the lymph nodes. We report a case of a 45-year-old female who presented with recurrent episodes of fever of unknown origin. Imaging studies revealed multiple enlarged intra-abdominal lymph nodes. Biopsy of the lymph nodes demonstrated features consistent with inflammatory pseudotumor. The patient was treated with corticosteroids and experienced resolution of symptoms. Inflammatory pseudotumor should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with recurrent fever and enlarged lymph nodes. Awareness of this condition can help guide appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions, avoiding unnecessary surgeries or treatments for malignancy. Further research is needed to understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this condition.

Antibiotic use among children in an urban Brazilian slum: a risk factor for diarrhea? [published erratum appears in Am J Public Health 1991 Apr;81(4):417] Among a cohort of children in a poor urban setting in Brazil, the relative risk for the occurrence of a new episode of diarrhea in the two weeks following antibiotic use vs all other weeks was 1. 44 (95% confidence interval (CI) = 1. This study investigates the relationship between antibiotic use and the risk of diarrhea in children living in a Brazilian slum. The researchers found that there was an increased risk of diarrhea in the two weeks following antibiotic use, compared to other weeks. The relative risk was 1.44, suggesting that antibiotic use may be a risk factor for diarrhea in this population. The findings highlight the need for cautious antibiotic prescribing practices in this vulnerable population.

Acquired Lutembacher syndrome or mitral stenosis and acquired atrial septal defect after transseptal mitral valvuloplasty. Acquired Lutembacher syndrome, characterized by the presence of both mitral stenosis and an acquired atrial septal defect (ASD), is a rare condition usually associated with rheumatic heart disease. We present a case of acquired Lutembacher syndrome following transseptal mitral valvuloplasty. A 55-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic fever underwent a successful transseptal mitral valvuloplasty for severe mitral stenosis. However, post-procedure echocardiography revealed the development of an acquired ASD. Despite the absence of symptoms, the patient underwent surgical closure of the ASD to prevent potential complications. This case highlights the importance of monitoring for acquired cardiac abnormalities following mitral valvuloplasty, particularly in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease. Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms underlying such acquired defects.

A controlled trial of community based coronary rehabilitation. Coronary rehabilitation programs have been shown to improve outcomes and reduce cardiovascular mortality. However, the majority of studies have been conducted in hospital settings, and there is limited evidence on the effectiveness of community-based coronary rehabilitation programs. This study aims to evaluate the impact of a community-based coronary rehabilitation program on long-term cardiovascular outcomes. 

A randomized controlled trial will be conducted, enrolling patients with recent myocardial infarction or stable angina. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the community-based coronary rehabilitation program or usual care. The primary outcome will be a composite of cardiovascular mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, and hospitalization for unstable angina. Secondary outcomes will include changes in physical activity levels, cardiovascular risk factors, and health-related quality of life. 

It is anticipated that the community-based coronary rehabilitation program will result in improved cardiovascular outcomes and increased adherence to secondary prevention measures. This study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of community-based coronary rehabilitation programs and inform future guidelines for the management of patients with coronary artery disease.

Treatment of ventricular tachycardia induced cardiogenic shock by percoronary chemical ablation.  Incessant ventricular arrhythmias pose an especially challenging therapeutic dilemma. Ventricular tachycardia-induced cardiogenic shock is a complex condition that requires prompt and effective treatment. In this case report, we present a unique approach to managing incessant ventricular arrhythmias through percoronary chemical ablation. A 62-year-old patient presented with cardiogenic shock due to ventricular tachycardia and was unresponsive to conventional antiarrhythmic therapies. Percoronary chemical ablation was performed using ethanol infusion into the culprit coronary artery, resulting in successful termination of the arrhythmia. The patient's hemodynamic status improved immediately following the procedure, with resolution of cardiogenic shock. The use of percoronary chemical ablation in the management of ventricular tachycardia-induced cardiogenic shock offers a promising alternative for patients who are refractory to standard antiarrhythmic treatments. Further studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this approach in larger patient populations.

Poisoning with equine phenylbutazone in a racetrack worker. Equine phenylbutazone (PBZ) is a commonly used nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) in horses. However, its use in humans is limited due to various adverse effects. This case report presents a case of PBZ poisoning in a racetrack worker who accidentally ingested the drug. The worker experienced symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and lethargy. Laboratory tests revealed renal impairment and hepatic dysfunction. Prompt medical intervention was initiated, including supportive care and administration of activated charcoal. The patient gradually improved and was discharged after a week of hospitalization. This case highlights the potential toxic effects of PBZ in humans and emphasizes the need for awareness and caution when handling equine medications in occupational settings.

Reduction of post-traumatic swelling and compartment pressure by impulse compression of the foot. This multicentre international trial investigated the use of a pneumatic impulse device to artificially activate a powerful venous pump in the foot that is activated by weight-bearing. The device was found to effectively reduce post-traumatic and postoperative swelling, as well as alleviate pain. Additionally, the study demonstrated that the device can reduce dangerously high compartment pressures, potentially eliminating the need for fasciotomy. The clinical effects of activating the venous footpump are explained based on improved understanding of microcirculation physiology. Notably, the hyperaemic response following the release of endothelial-derived relaxing factor (EDRF) due to sudden changes in pressure after weight-bearing or impulse compression is highlighted as a significant mechanism. Further research is warranted to fully explore the potential benefits of this treatment.

Variations on the temporoparietal fascial flap. Research on the use of temporoparietal fascial flaps in reconstructive surgery has been steadily growing. However, there is a lack of consensus on the optimal technique and variations of this procedure. This review aims to summarize and analyze the various modifications of the temporoparietal fascial flap technique reported in the literature. Common variations include the use of different incision patterns, flap design, and donor sites. Each modification has its own advantages and limitations, with factors such as recipient site characteristics and patient preference influencing the choice of technique. The overall success rates and complications associated with these variations are also discussed. Further research is needed to establish standardized guidelines for the application of temporoparietal fascial flaps, taking into consideration factors such as patient demographics, anatomical considerations, and surgical outcomes. This will aid in improving the efficacy and reliability of this valuable reconstructive option.

Features of "near-death experience" in relation to whether or not patients were near death The medical records of 58 patients, most of whom believed they were near death during an illness or after an injury and all of whom later remembered unusual experiences occurring at the time, were examined. This study examines the medical records of 58 patients who believed they were near death and experienced unusual experiences during their illness or after an injury. The researchers aimed to determine whether these "near-death experiences" differed based on whether or not the patients were actually near death. The findings revealed that features of near-death experiences were reported by patients regardless of their proximity to death. This suggests that these experiences may not solely be associated with imminent death, but instead may be related to other factors such as physiological or psychological changes.

Leukemias of indeterminant lineage. Leukemias of indeterminate lineage pose a challenge in clinical practice due to their ambiguous classification. These leukemias lack definitive immunophenotypic markers and present with overlapping features, making their accurate diagnosis difficult. Flow cytometry is a valuable tool for their classification, relying on a combination of markers and characteristic aberrant antigen expression patterns. Additionally, molecular and genetic studies play a crucial role in identifying specific chromosomal abnormalities and fusion genes associated with these leukemias. Further advancements in gene expression profiling and next-generation sequencing technologies have provided insights into the molecular basis of these diseases. Consensus guidelines and comprehensive diagnostic algorithms are crucial in ensuring accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment selection for patients with leukemias of indeterminate lineage.

Efficacy of percutaneous mitral balloon valvuloplasty with the inoue balloon.  Percutaneous mitral balloon valvuloplasty has become an accepted technique for use in selected patients with severe, symptomatic mitral stenosis.  Recently, a new balloon catheter with an "hourglass" shape and specially designed guidewires and dilators has become available (Inoue balloon). Percutaneous mitral balloon valvuloplasty (PMBV) using the Inoue balloon has emerged as an effective treatment option for patients with severe symptomatic mitral stenosis. The Inoue balloon catheter, with its unique "hourglass" shape and specially designed guidewires and dilators, allows for precise and controlled dilation of the stenotic mitral valve. The procedure involves percutaneous transluminal balloon dilation of the valve, leading to an increase in the mitral valve orifice area and a decrease in the pressure gradient across the valve. PMBV with the Inoue balloon has shown excellent short-term and long-term outcomes, with significant improvements in symptoms, valve area, and valve function. Complications associated with PMBV are generally rare but can include mitral regurgitation, cardiac perforation, and embolic events. However, careful patient selection and procedural expertise are crucial to ensure optimal outcomes and minimize risks.

Thallous chloride uptake and DNA profile in parathyroid adenomas.  Thallium isotope scintigraphy is used to localize parathyroid adenomas but the mechanism underlying the technique is poorly understood. The uptake of thallous chloride and the DNA profile in parathyroid adenomas were investigated to better understand the mechanism of thallium isotope scintigraphy in localizing these adenomas. Thallium scintigraphy is a commonly used technique for localizing parathyroid adenomas; however, the mechanism underlying the specific uptake of thallous chloride in these adenomas is not well understood. In this study, thallous chloride uptake was measured in parathyroid adenomas and compared to normal parathyroid tissue. Additionally, the DNA profile of the adenomas was analyzed to identify any genetic differences that could be associated with thallium uptake. The results showed that parathyroid adenomas had significantly higher thallous chloride uptake compared to normal parathyroid tissue. Furthermore, the DNA profile analysis revealed no significant genetic differences between the adenomas with high thallous chloride uptake and those with low uptake. These findings suggest that factors other than genetic differences may play a role in the specific uptake of thallous chloride in parathyroid adenomas.

Fetal alcohol syndrome in adolescents and adults.  Fetal alcohol syndrome is a specific recognizable pattern of malformation. Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is a well-defined constellation of physical abnormalities resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure. However, the effects of FAS can extend into adolescence and adulthood, leading to various behavioral, cognitive, and psychological issues. This review aims to explore the manifestations of FAS in adolescents and adults to raise awareness among healthcare providers and improve diagnosis and management. The physical abnormalities associated with FAS may persist into adulthood, including growth deficiencies, facial dysmorphology, and organ dysfunction. Additionally, individuals with FAS may face difficulties in social interactions, cognitive impairments, learning disabilities, mental health disorders, and increased risk of substance abuse. Understanding the long-term impact of FAS is crucial for timely intervention and support for affected individuals. Further research is needed to develop effective strategies for managing the complex challenges faced by adolescents and adults with FAS.

Colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age.  From 1973 to 1985, 105 patients under 40 years of age were treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute. This study aimed to assess the clinicopathologic features and outcomes of colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 105 patients treated at a cancer institute between 1973 and 1985. The median age at diagnosis was 35 years, with a slight male predominance (53%). Most patients presented with advanced stage disease (74% stage III or IV). The majority of tumors were located in the rectum (57%) and were moderately differentiated (60%). Surgery was the primary treatment modality, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy in select cases. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 37%, with a median survival of 28 months. These findings suggest that colorectal adenocarcinoma in young patients has distinct clinical characteristics and poor outcomes compared to older patients. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and improve therapeutic strategies for this patient population.

Specificity of affective and autonomic symptoms of depression in Parkinson's disease. Depression is a common non-motor symptom in Parkinson's disease (PD), but the specificity of affective and autonomic symptoms of depression in PD is not well understood. This study aimed to evaluate the specificity of these symptoms in PD patients with and without depression. A total of 150 PD patients were assessed for depression using the Beck Depression Inventory-II. Affective and autonomic symptoms were measured using the Affective Section and the Autonomic Symptom Checklist, respectively. The results showed that PD patients with depression had significantly higher scores on both affective and autonomic symptoms compared to those without depression. Furthermore, after controlling for the severity of motor symptoms, the affective symptoms remained significantly associated with depression, while the autonomic symptoms did not. These findings suggest that affective symptoms may be more specific markers of depression in PD, warranting further investigation for better understanding and management of depression in this population.

Late recurrence of varus deformity after proximal tibial osteotomy.  One hundred thirteen knees with medial gonarthrosis in 95 patients were treated by valgus-producing proximal tibial osteotomy and followed clinically and roentgenographically for a minimum of five years (mean, 6. Varus deformity recurrence after proximal tibial osteotomy is a known complication, but the timing and risk factors for its occurrence remain unclear. In this study, 113 knees in 95 patients with medial gonarthrosis were treated using valgus-producing proximal tibial osteotomy and followed for at least five years. The mean follow-up period was 6.8 years. Late recurrence of varus deformity was observed in 18 knees (16%). The median time to recurrence was 3.3 years. The presence of preoperative varus deformity of more than 20 degrees and undercorrection of the osteotomy were identified as risk factors for recurrence. These findings highlight the importance of ensuring appropriate correction and close follow-up after proximal tibial osteotomy to minimize the risk of varus deformity recurrence.

Myocardial infarction prognostic scoring system. A new prognostic scoring system for myocardial infarction (MI) is proposed based on clinical and laboratory parameters. The study included 500 patients with acute MI who were followed up for a median duration of 1 year. The scoring system assigns points to various factors such as age, gender, presence of comorbidities, peak troponin level, and left ventricular ejection fraction. The total score ranges from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating a worse prognosis. The scoring system was found to be significantly associated with major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and all-cause mortality. Furthermore, it outperformed existing prognostic models in terms of predictive accuracy and discrimination. In conclusion, this new scoring system provides a reliable tool for risk stratification and prognostication in patients with MI.

Silent myocardial ischemia and infarction in diabetics with peripheral vascular disease: assessment by dipyridamole thallium-201 scintigraphy. The prevalence of silent myocardial ischemia and infarction was evaluated in diabetics with peripheral vascular disease using dipyridamole thallium-201 scintigraphy. Out of 120 consecutive patients, 36% exhibited reversible or fixed thallium defects suggestive of myocardial ischemia or infarction. Among these patients, 28% were asymptomatic and had no previous history of cardiac disease. The occurrence of silent ischemia and infarction was significantly higher in patients with peripheral vascular disease compared to those without. These findings suggest that dipyridamole thallium-201 scintigraphy is a valuable tool for identifying silent myocardial ischemia and infarction in diabetics with peripheral vascular disease, particularly in those without symptoms or known cardiac disease.

Celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. This case report describes a 72-year-old female with a long-standing history of celiac disease who presented with progressive cognitive decline and memory impairment consistent with dementia. MRI imaging revealed significant brain atrophy, especially in the frontal and temporal lobes. Neuropsychiatric evaluation showed deficits in attention, memory, and executive function. Extensive laboratory investigations ruled out other potential causes of dementia. The patient's symptoms improved with a strict gluten-free diet, highlighting the importance of celiac disease management in preventing cognitive decline. This case emphasizes the need for heightened awareness of the neurological manifestations of celiac disease, as early recognition and treatment can significantly impact patient outcomes.

Parathyroid hormone-like peptide in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells. Parathyroid hormone-like peptide (PTHrP) is a protein that regulates cellular processes such as proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. In a study investigating the expression of PTHrP in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells, it was found that PTHrP mRNA and protein were present in both types of cells. However, the expression levels were significantly higher in neoplastic mesothelial cells compared to normal cells. Additionally, PTHrP expression was associated with increased proliferation and decreased apoptosis in neoplastic mesothelial cells. These findings suggest that PTHrP may play a role in the growth and survival of neoplastic mesothelial cells. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of PTHrP in mesothelioma.

Further mapping of an ataxia-telangiectasia locus to the chromosome 11q23 region. Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive neurodegeneration and immune dysfunction. Previous studies have mapped the A-T locus to the chromosome 11q23 region, but the exact location remains unclear. In this study, we report additional genetic mapping data that further supports the presence of an A-T locus in this region. We performed linkage analysis on DNA samples from 12 affected individuals and their families and observed a strong linkage signal near the marker D11S880. This finding strengthens the evidence for an A-T locus on chromosome 11q23 and provides a potential target for further gene identification. Understanding the genetic basis of A-T is essential for advancing our knowledge of this disorder and developing targeted therapies. Continued efforts to map the precise location of the A-T locus will contribute to these goals.

Ganglioglioma: a clinical study with long-term follow-up. Ganglioglioma is a rare type of brain tumor that primarily affects young individuals. This clinical study aims to present the long-term follow-up and outcomes of patients diagnosed with ganglioglioma. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with a mean follow-up period of 10 years. The majority of patients presented with seizures as the initial symptom, followed by headaches and focal neurological deficits. Radiological evaluation revealed the presence of well-defined tumors with contrast enhancement. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with gross total resection achieved in 80% of cases. Postoperative adjuvant therapy was administered in selected cases. The overall survival rate at 10 years was 85%, with a recurrence rate of 15%. The study highlights the importance of surgical resection in achieving favorable outcomes for patients with ganglioglioma. Long-term follow-up is crucial for monitoring disease progression and detecting potential recurrences.

Intraoperative scintigraphy for active small intestinal bleeding. Active small intestinal bleeding can be difficult to localize and diagnose, often requiring exploratory laparotomies or angiography. Here, we present a case series of three patients with active small intestinal bleeding who underwent intraoperative scintigraphy using technetium-99m-labeled red blood cells. In all cases, the bleeding source was successfully identified and localized with scintigraphy, leading to targeted surgical intervention. Scintigraphy was able to accurately identify the site of bleeding, allowing for quicker and more precise surgical management. No perioperative complications were reported. In conclusion, intraoperative scintigraphy using technetium-99m-labeled red blood cells is a valuable tool for the localization of active small intestinal bleeding, guiding surgical intervention and potentially reducing the need for exploratory laparotomies or angiography. Further studies are needed to validate and optimize this technique.

Patient perception of tics and other movement disorders. This study aimed to investigate patient perception of tics and other movement disorders. A total of 100 patients with various movement disorders were included in the study. Patients were asked to complete a questionnaire regarding their perception of their own movements and the impact those movements had on their daily lives. The results showed that patients with tics often had a poor understanding of their condition and how their movements were perceived by others. Additionally, they reported feelings of embarrassment, frustration, and anxiety due to their movements. Patients with other movement disorders, such as dystonia or myoclonus, also reported similar negative experiences. Furthermore, patients expressed a desire for more education and information about their condition, as well as greater support from healthcare professionals. These findings highlight the importance of patient education and support in the management of tics and other movement disorders, in order to improve patient well-being and quality of life.

Clinical efficacy of flosequinan in heart failure. Flosequinan, a novel vasodilator, has shown promising clinical efficacy in the treatment of heart failure. We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate its effectiveness in improving clinical outcomes in heart failure patients. A total of 250 patients with New York Heart Association class II-IV heart failure were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either flosequinan or placebo in addition to standard heart failure therapy. After a follow-up period of 12 months, the primary endpoint of all-cause mortality or hospitalization for heart failure was significantly reduced in the flosequinan group compared to the placebo group (p=0.02). Furthermore, flosequinan was associated with a significant improvement in exercise tolerance, as assessed by the six-minute walk test (p<0.001). Adverse events were similar between the two groups. These findings support the clinical efficacy of flosequinan as an adjunctive therapy in heart failure patients, offering potential improvement in morbidity and mortality outcomes.

Foci of increased T2 signal intensity in MR images of healthy elderly subjects. The aim of this study was to investigate the prevalence and potential significance of foci of increased T2 signal intensity in magnetic resonance (MR) images of healthy elderly subjects. T2 hyperintensities were found in 32% of the subjects, with a higher prevalence observed in older individuals. These foci were predominantly located in the white matter, particularly in the subcortical regions. An association was observed between the presence of T2 hyperintensities and age, hypertension, and cardiovascular risk factors. Furthermore, these foci were correlated with cognitive impairment and gait disturbances in elderly subjects. The findings suggest that these T2 hyperintensities may represent microvascular ischemic changes and can serve as potential biomarkers for age-related cerebral small vessel disease.

Surgery for acute and chronic cholecystitis.  Cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy remain appropriate and effective therapy for acute and chronic cholecystitis. Surgery, including both cholecystostomy and cholecystectomy, has proven to be a suitable and efficient treatment for both acute and chronic cholecystitis. The management of cholecystitis involves either the placement of a cholecystostomy tube or the complete removal of the gallbladder through a cholecystectomy procedure. Cholecystostomy is often performed in the setting of acute cholecystitis to drain the infected gallbladder and provide relief of symptoms. On the other hand, cholecystectomy is the preferred treatment for chronic cholecystitis, as it eliminates the risk of recurrent episodes and associated complications. Both approaches are generally well-tolerated and lead to successful outcomes in the majority of cases. Therefore, surgery remains the recommended approach for the management of both acute and chronic cholecystitis.

Fludarabine: a new agent with marked cytoreductive activity in untreated chronic lymphocytic leukemia. This study evaluated the efficacy of fludarabine, a novel agent, in the treatment of untreated chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). A total of 82 patients with CLL were enrolled in the study and treated with fludarabine as initial therapy. The overall response rate was 82%, with 23% achieving a complete response. Fludarabine demonstrated marked cytoreductive activity and led to significant improvement in hematologic parameters. Adverse events were relatively minor, with cytopenias being the most common toxicity. The authors concluded that fludarabine is a highly effective and well-tolerated treatment option for patients with untreated CLL. Further studies are needed to determine its long-term effects and compare it with other treatment modalities.

Chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia: a manifestation of visceral vasculitis? Gastrointestinal involvement occurs frequently in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, and most often involves the liver and spleen. This case study examines the association between chronic diarrhea and essential mixed cryoglobulinemia (EMC), specifically exploring whether it is a manifestation of visceral vasculitis. Gastrointestinal involvement is common in EMC, with the liver and spleen being the most affected organs. The researchers analyzed a series of cases and found that chronic diarrhea was present in a substantial number of patients with EMC. Histological examination of intestinal biopsies revealed evidence of vasculitis in these patients, suggesting a link between visceral vasculitis and chronic diarrhea in EMC. These findings highlight the importance of considering EMC as a potential underlying cause of chronic diarrhea and emphasize the need for further research to explore this association.

An objective appraisal of the role of computed tomographic (CT) guided drainage of intra-abdominal abscesses. This study aimed to evaluate the role of computed tomography (CT) guided drainage in treating intra-abdominal abscesses. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients who underwent CT-guided drainage for intra-abdominal abscesses between 2015 and 2019. The success rate of the procedure, defined as complete resolution of the abscess and improvement in symptoms, was assessed. The overall success rate was found to be 86%, with a mean drainage time of 5 days. Complications were observed in 8% of cases, including catheter dislodgement and bleeding. The study concluded that CT-guided drainage is a safe and effective method for treating intra-abdominal abscesses, providing a minimally invasive alternative to surgery. Further studies are recommended to optimize the technique and identify risk factors for complications.

Development of language in six hemispherectomized patients. This study investigated the development of language in six patients who had undergone hemispherectomy, a surgical procedure in which one hemisphere of the brain is removed. Language skills were assessed using linguistic tests and neuroimaging techniques. Results showed that despite the removal of one hemisphere, all patients demonstrated remarkable language abilities. Language development was found to be primarily localized in the remaining hemisphere, with some compensatory mechanisms observed in the contralateral hemisphere. Neuroimaging data revealed functional and structural changes in the remaining hemisphere, including increased activation in language-related areas and white matter reorganization. These findings suggest that the human brain has a remarkable capacity for language plasticity and can reorganize its language functions following hemispherectomy. Understanding the mechanisms underlying this plasticity may have implications for neurorehabilitation strategies in patients with language impairments.

Veterans Administration Cooperative Study Group on Hypertensive Agents: effects of age on treatment results. The effects of age on treatment outcomes were examined in the Veterans Administration Cooperative Study Group on Hypertensive Agents. A total of 1,873 patients with hypertension were randomly assigned to receive either a diuretic, a beta-blocker, or a placebo. The patients were stratified into three age groups: less than 60 years, 60-69 years, and 70 years or older. The primary outcome measures were reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, incidence of adverse events, and change in quality of life. The results showed that the efficacy of the antihypertensive agents varied with age. Patients aged 70 years or older showed a greater reduction in blood pressure compared to the younger age groups. However, they also experienced a higher incidence of adverse events. These findings suggest that age should be taken into consideration when choosing antihypertensive therapy in older patients.

Lower extremity revascularization via the lateral plantar artery. Lower extremity revascularization procedures are commonly performed to restore blood flow to the lower limbs in patients with peripheral artery disease. The lateral plantar artery is an underutilized option for revascularization due to its small diameter and variable anatomy. In this study, we present our experience with lower extremity revascularization using the lateral plantar artery as a conduit. A retrospective analysis of 72 patients who underwent lateral plantar artery revascularization was conducted. The procedure was found to be technically feasible in all cases, with successful restoration of blood flow in 90% of patients. Postoperative complications were minimal and mainly related to wound healing. The lateral plantar artery proves to be a reliable conduit for lower extremity revascularization, offering a viable alternative to more commonly utilized vessels. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare it to other revascularization techniques.

The J-curve phenomenon and the treatment of hypertension. The J-curve phenomenon has been observed in the treatment of hypertension, suggesting that both low and high blood pressure levels can be associated with increased cardiovascular risk. This review aims to explore the relationship between blood pressure levels and cardiovascular outcomes in hypertensive patients. Various studies and meta-analyses have demonstrated that both low systolic and diastolic blood pressure levels below a certain threshold are associated with increased risk of cardiovascular events and mortality. On the other hand, higher blood pressure levels above a certain threshold are also associated with increased risk. This J-curve trend highlights the importance of maintaining blood pressure within a target range to optimize cardiovascular outcomes. However, the precise threshold for optimal blood pressure control remains unclear and further research is needed to determine the ideal blood pressure range. Individualized treatment plans based on patient characteristics and comorbidities are essential to achieve optimal blood pressure control and reduce cardiovascular risk.

Direct visualization of ruptured chordae tendineae by transesophageal two-dimensional echocardiography. This study aimed to prospectively investigate the perianal appearances associated with constipation in 136 children (mean age 3.9 years, 67 boys, 69 girls). Various perianal features including anal dilatation, fissures, tags, warts, oedema, redness, blueness, and veins were assessed.
