These findings highlight the importance of investigating both the patient and their consort in cases of acute epididymitis, as the consort may be an asymptomatic carrier and a potential source of reinfection.

Mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches. The mucosal characteristics of pelvic ileal pouches were investigated in a sample of patients who had undergone ileal pouch-anal anastomosis surgery for ulcerative colitis or familial adenomatous polyposis. The study aimed to evaluate the histopathological features and clinical significance of the pouch mucosa. The results indicated that the majority of patients had normal or near-normal pouch mucosa. However, a subset of patients demonstrated various degrees of inflammation and architectural abnormalities, such as glandular distortion and cryptitis. These findings suggest that there is a spectrum of mucosal changes in pelvic ileal pouches, which may have implications for patient outcomes and the development of complications, such as pouchitis. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and clinical implications of these mucosal characteristics. The findings from this study contribute to the knowledge base regarding the long-term outcomes and management of patients with pelvic ileal pouches.

Diabetic retinopathy in blacks. Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes that can lead to vision loss. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and severity of diabetic retinopathy in a population of black individuals. A total of 500 black patients diagnosed with diabetes were included in the study. The prevalence of diabetic retinopathy was found to be 45%, with 15% having mild, 20% moderate, and 10% severe retinopathy. Proliferative retinopathy was observed in 5% of the patients. The presence of retinopathy was significantly associated with longer duration of diabetes, higher HbA1c levels, and higher blood pressure. These findings highlight the high burden of diabetic retinopathy in the black population and underscore the need for regular screening and aggressive management of diabetes in this group to prevent vision loss.

Microdochectomy for discharge from a single lactiferous duct. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of microdochectomy for the treatment of discharge from a single lactiferous duct. Our retrospective analysis included patients who underwent microdochectomy from January 2010 to December 2018. A total of 60 patients were included, with a mean age of 45.2 years. The main presenting symptom was nipple discharge, which was unilateral in all cases. Microdochectomy was performed under local anesthesia, and the lactiferous duct responsible for the discharge was identified and excised. Postoperative complications were minimal, with no cases of infection or hematoma observed. At a mean follow-up of 24 months, complete resolution of nipple discharge was achieved in 95% of patients. Microdochectomy appears to be a safe and effective procedure for the management of discharge from a single lactiferous duct, offering a high success rate and minimal complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to corroborate these findings.

1990 AcroMed Award in basic science.  Cauda equina anatomy. The anatomy of the cauda equina, a bundle of nerve roots located at the lower end of the spinal cord, was investigated to further our understanding of its structure. Detailed dissections were performed on 50 human cadavers, focusing on the cauda equina and its surrounding structures. The results revealed several key findings. First, the length of the individual nerves within the cauda equina varied greatly, with an average length of 13.6 cm. Second, the average number of nerves in the cauda equina was 19, ranging from 14 to 24. Third, the pattern of branching and convergence of the nerves was complex and showed significant individual variability. Finally, the relationship between the cauda equina and surrounding structures, such as the dura mater and filum terminale, was well-defined and elucidated. This study provides valuable insights into the anatomy of the cauda equina and may have implications for surgical interventions and treatments of related conditions. The 1990 AcroMed Award in basic science recognizes the significance of these findings in advancing our knowledge of spinal anatomy.

Retrospective application of prognostic indices to pancreatitis discovered at necropsy. In this retrospective study, the authors investigated the prognostic value of different indices in patients with pancreatitis discovered at necropsy. The study included a total of X patients who were diagnosed with pancreatitis and subsequently underwent necropsy. The retrospective analysis focused on the application of various prognostic indices, including the Ranson criteria, Glasgow-Imrie criteria, and APACHE-II score. The results revealed that the application of these indices retrospectively provided important prognostic information regarding the severity and outcome of pancreatitis. Specifically, higher scores on these indices were associated with worse prognosis and increased mortality. These findings suggest that the use of prognostic indices can aid in the identification of patients with pancreatitis who are at higher risk for poor outcomes, and may help in guiding appropriate management strategies. Further prospective studies are needed to validate these results.

Ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue: a comparison of 65 patients. Impotence is a common condition that can have various etiologies, including structural abnormalities in penile tissue. This study aimed to characterize the ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue and compare these changes across 65 patients. Penile tissue samples were obtained via biopsy from impotent patients undergoing evaluation for erectile dysfunction. Electron microscopy was used to examine the ultrastructural features of the tissue. The results revealed distinct alterations in the microarchitecture of the penile tissue, including fibrosis, smooth muscle hypertrophy, and endothelial cell damage. These changes were observed in varying degrees among the patients, suggesting a heterogeneous etiology for impotence. Understanding the ultrastructural changes in impotent penile tissue may provide insights into the pathophysiology and aid in the development of targeted treatments for erectile dysfunction. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to validate these findings.

Transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis after M-VAC (methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin) chemotherapy. We report a case of transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis following M-VAC chemotherapy in a patient with advanced bladder cancer. The patient presented with symptoms of headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed elevated protein levels, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and malignant cells consistent with transitional cell carcinoma. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spine demonstrated leptomeningeal enhancement, confirming the diagnosis of carcinomatous meningitis. The patient received intrathecal chemotherapy and high-dose systemic corticosteroids, with improvement in symptoms and normalization of cerebrospinal fluid analysis. M-VAC chemotherapy, which consists of methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin, is known to have neurotoxic effects; however, transitional cell carcinomatous meningitis is a rare complication. This case highlights the importance of considering carcinomatous meningitis in the differential diagnosis of patients who develop neurologic symptoms after M-VAC chemotherapy. Early recognition and treatment are crucial for improving patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare complication.

Safe use of codeine in the recovering alcoholic or addict. The safe use of codeine in recovering alcoholics or addicts was investigated in a retrospective study. A total of 150 patients who were using codeine for pain management were included. The study evaluated the occurrence of codeine misuse or addiction relapse in this population. The results showed that 12% of patients experienced codeine misuse or addiction relapse during the study period. The risk was higher in individuals with a history of alcohol or substance abuse. Additionally, patients with comorbid psychiatric disorders were also at a higher risk. It is crucial to consider the potential risks associated with codeine use in this specific population and to closely monitor patients for signs of misuse or relapse. Alternative pain management strategies should be considered when possible.

Surgical complications with the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant: experience at Hannover and Melbourne. The cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant has revolutionized the management of profound deafness. However, surgical complications associated with it remain a concern. This study aims to evaluate the experience of two renowned centers, Hannover and Melbourne, with this implant. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent implantation between 2000 and 2020. Results showed that a total of 250 patients were included, with a mean age of 47 years. The overall incidence of surgical complications was found to be 18%. The most common complications encountered were device migration, electrode malposition, and infection. Revision surgeries were required in 10% of cases. Age was found to be a significant predictor of complications, with older age associated with a higher risk. In conclusion, while the cochlear multiple-channel intracochlear implant is greatly beneficial, it is important to remain vigilant about potential surgical complications and be prepared for subsequent management.

Incidence and survival rates of children and young adults with osteogenic sarcoma.  Gender-specific and race-specific incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma over a 14-year period are presented for persons aged 0 to 24 years from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries. This study examines the incidence and survival rates of osteogenic sarcoma in children and young adults aged 0 to 24 years over a 14-year period. Data from eight Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registries were analyzed to determine gender-specific and race-specific rates. The results show that osteogenic sarcoma is more common in males than females, with higher incidence rates among white individuals compared to other races. Survival rates have improved over the years, with a 5-year relative survival rate of approximately 67% for the overall population. However, survival rates varied based on gender and race, with better outcomes observed in females and white individuals. Further research is needed to explore the factors influencing these disparities in incidence and survival rates.

Racial differences in the anterior circulation in cerebrovascular disease. Racial differences in the anterior circulation have been observed in cerebrovascular disease, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. This study aimed to investigate such racial differences using transcranial Doppler sonography. Subjects included 100 Black and 100 White patients with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack. The peak systolic velocity (PSV) and mean flow velocity (MFV) of the anterior circulation vessels, including the middle cerebral artery (MCA), anterior cerebral artery (ACA), and internal carotid artery (ICA), were measured. Results showed that Black patients had significantly higher PSV and MFV in the MCA and ACA compared to White patients, indicating increased arterial flow velocity in the anterior circulation. Additionally, Black patients exhibited a higher prevalence of intracranial arterial stenosis and a higher degree of stenosis in the ICA. These findings suggest that racial differences in the anterior circulation, particularly increased arterial flow velocity and higher prevalence of intracranial arterial stenosis, may contribute to the pathogenesis and clinical presentation of cerebrovascular disease in different populations. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and implications of these racial disparities.

Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in a pelvic pouch. Dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are significant factors that contribute to the development of malignancy in pelvic pouches. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and clinical significance of dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in patients with a pelvic pouch. The study included 78 patients who underwent endoscopic evaluation and biopsy of their pelvic pouch. Dysplasia was identified in 18 patients (23.1%), with 9 cases showing low-grade dysplasia and 9 cases showing high-grade dysplasia. DNA aneuploidy was detected in 24 patients (30.8%). Patients with dysplasia were more likely to have DNA aneuploidy compared to those without dysplasia (odds ratio, 5.43; 95% confidence interval, 2.15-13.75). Furthermore, patients with DNA aneuploidy had a higher risk of developing dysplasia than those without DNA aneuploidy (odds ratio, 4.68; 95% confidence interval, 1.92-11.37). These findings indicate that dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy are common in patients with a pelvic pouch and may be valuable markers for predicting the risk of malignancy in these individuals. Further studies are warranted to investigate the long-term outcomes and management strategies for patients with dysplasia and DNA aneuploidy in pelvic pouches.

Survival after hypertonic saline resuscitation from hemorrhage.  There has been recent increased interest in hypertonic saline resuscitation from shock and hemorrhage. Hypertonic saline resuscitation has emerged as a potential therapeutic option for shock and hemorrhage. This method involves the administration of hypertonic saline solutions to rapidly restore intravascular volume and improve hemodynamic stability. Several studies have reported improved survival rates and decreased organ dysfunction following hypertonic saline resuscitation compared to traditional isotonic crystalloid resuscitation. The mechanism of action of hypertonic saline involves the mobilization of extravascular fluid into the intravascular space, thus improving tissue perfusion and oxygenation. Additionally, hypertonic saline may exert anti-inflammatory effects and enhance immune function, leading to reduced systemic inflammation and organ injury. However, the optimal hypertonic saline concentration, volume, and rate of administration are still topics of debate. Further research is needed to elucidate the long-term benefits and potential adverse effects of hypertonic saline resuscitation in different patient populations.

The cellular composition of basal cell adenoma of the parotid gland: an immunohistochemical analysis. Basal cell adenoma (BCA) is a common benign tumor of the parotid gland, but its cellular composition remains poorly understood. In this study, we aimed to determine the cellular composition of BCA through immunohistochemical analysis. 

We analyzed 30 cases of BCA and identified the expression of various markers including cytokeratin 14 (CK14), cytokeratin 7 (CK7), p63, and vimentin. Our results showed that BCA consisted predominantly of two distinct cell populations: basaloid cells and stromal cells. The basaloid cells exhibited strong expression of CK14 and p63, indicating their basal cell origin. In contrast, the stromal cells displayed positive staining for vimentin but negative staining for CK14 and p63, suggesting their myoepithelial or fibroblastic nature.

Furthermore, we observed that BCA showed heterogeneity in cellular composition, with some cases exhibiting a predominance of either basaloid or stromal cells. Overall, our findings provide valuable insights into the cellular composition of BCA, which may contribute to better understanding and classification of this common parotid gland tumor.

Mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty. This study aimed to assess the changes in mammographic measurements before and after augmentation mammaplasty.  Forty-five women who underwent breast augmentation surgery were included in the study. Mammograms were obtained before and after surgery, and several measurements were recorded, including breast thickness, parenchymal pattern, breast density, and nipple position. The results showed a significant increase in breast thickness (p < 0.001) and breast density (p = 0.004) after surgery. There was also a significant change in the parenchymal pattern (p < 0.001) and nipple position (p = 0.009) postoperatively. However, no significant correlation was found between the changes in mammographic measurements and the volume of the implant. These findings suggest that augmentation mammaplasty leads to significant changes in mammographic measurements, which should be considered when interpreting mammograms in women who have undergone this procedure. Further studies are needed to investigate the long-term effects of breast augmentation on mammographic measurements and breast cancer detection.

Postoperative hypertension: a prospective, placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind trial, with intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride.  Nicardipine hydrochloride, a new calcium channel blocker for intravenous use, has been compared with placebo in a prospective, randomized, double-blind trial on postoperative hypertension. A study was conducted to examine the efficacy of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride, a calcium channel blocker, in treating postoperative hypertension. This prospective, randomized, double-blind trial included a placebo control group. The results showed that nicardipine hydrochloride was effective in reducing postoperative hypertension compared to placebo. The study highlights the potential of intravenous nicardipine hydrochloride as a treatment option for postoperative hypertension. Further research is needed to explore its long-term effects and potential side effects.

Two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle. This study aimed to describe the two-dimensional echocardiographic features of double outlet left ventricle (DOLV) and their correlation with surgical outcome. A retrospective analysis of echocardiographic data from 20 patients diagnosed with DOLV was conducted. The most common associated cardiac abnormalities were ventricular septal defect and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Other findings included malalignment of the great arteries, abnormal valve morphology, and abnormal coronary artery anatomy. Patients with abnormal valve morphology had a higher incidence of surgical complications. This study provides valuable insights into the echocardiographic features of DOLV and their potential impact on surgical outcomes, aiding in the management and treatment of this complex congenital heart defect.

Cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the association between cholecystectomy and right colon cancer in Puerto Rico. Data from 267 patients with right colon cancer and 267 matched controls were analyzed. The results showed a significantly higher prevalence of gallbladder pathology, including cholelithiasis and cholecystitis, in the colon cancer group compared to the control group (p < 0.001). The odds ratio for right colon cancer in patients with a history of cholecystectomy was 3.72 (95% confidence interval: 1.65-8.35). Furthermore, the risk of right colon cancer was found to be 5.89 times higher (95% confidence interval: 2.48-13.94) in patients who underwent cholecystectomy within two years prior to the cancer diagnosis. These findings suggest a potential link between cholecystectomy and the development of right colon cancer in Puerto Rico, highlighting the importance of further investigation to elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

Late cholangitis after successful surgical repair of biliary atresia.  Bacterial cholangitis is a frequent complication of successful surgical repair of biliary atresia, occurring in 93% of patients before the age of 1 year, but thought to be rare after 2 years of age. Late cholangitis is a rare but possible complication following successful surgical repair of biliary atresia. In this study, the incidence of bacterial cholangitis after the age of 2 years was evaluated in patients who had undergone surgical repair of biliary atresia. Among the patients studied, 93% had experienced cholangitis before the age of 1 year. However, our findings demonstrate that late cholangitis can occur in patients beyond the age of 2 years. This emphasizes the need for continued monitoring and follow-up care in these patients, even after successful surgical intervention. Further research is required to better understand the factors that contribute to the development of late cholangitis in this population and to develop strategies for prevention and management.

Hyperplastic polyps seen at sigmoidoscopy are markers for additional adenomas seen at colonoscopy.  Asymptomatic individuals undergoing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were prospectively studied. In this prospective study, asymptomatic individuals who underwent screening flexible sigmoidoscopy were evaluated to determine if hyperplastic polyps seen during the procedure could serve as markers for additional adenomas seen during subsequent colonoscopy. A total of [number] participants were included in the analysis. The presence of hyperplastic polyps during sigmoidoscopy was found to be significantly associated with the presence of additional adenomas during colonoscopy. [Percentage] of participants with hyperplastic polyps had at least one additional adenoma detected during colonoscopy. These findings suggest that the identification of hyperplastic polyps during sigmoidoscopy may warrant further evaluation with colonoscopy to ensure the detection of additional adenomas. Implementing this approach could improve the accuracy and efficiency of colorectal cancer screening and prevention strategies. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings and assess their potential clinical implications.

Interventional radiology of the biliary tract. Interventional radiology plays a crucial role in the treatment of biliary tract diseases. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of interventional radiology procedures for biliary tract conditions. A total of 304 patients with various biliary tract diseases were included in the study. The procedures performed included percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography, biliary drainage, and stent placement. The success rate of these interventions was 95.4%, with minimal complications observed. Furthermore, significant improvement in symptoms and laboratory parameters was achieved in the majority of patients. This study highlights the importance of interventional radiology in the management of biliary tract diseases, providing an effective and safe alternative to surgical interventions.

Does age affect outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation? We examined the relation between age and outcomes in patients treated for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Seattle, Wash. We conducted a study to determine the impact of age on outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in Seattle, Washington. The study included patients who experienced a cardiac arrest and received treatment in the prehospital setting. Data on patient characteristics, including age, were collected and analyzed. Our findings revealed a significant association between age and outcomes of CPR. Older patients had lower rates of successful resuscitation and survival to hospital admission compared to younger patients. Additionally, older age was associated with a higher likelihood of poor neurologic outcomes among survivors. These results suggest that age is an important factor to consider when predicting outcomes of out-of-hospital CPR and should be taken into account when developing strategies for resuscitation in the elderly population.

Increased microvascular permeability in vivo in response to intradermal injection of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) in rabbit skin. This study aimed to investigate the in vivo effects of intradermal injection of neutrophil-activating protein (NAP-2) on microvascular permeability in rabbit skin. The permeability response was evaluated by measuring the extravasation of tritiated albumin and Evans blue dye. The results showed a significant increase in microvascular permeability following NAP-2 injection compared to the control group. The effects were dose-dependent, with higher doses of NAP-2 resulting in greater permeability. Additionally, pretreatment with a specific receptor antagonist significantly attenuated the NAP-2-induced increase in permeability, suggesting the involvement of specific receptors in mediating this response. Histological analysis revealed widened interendothelial gaps and increased endothelial fenestrations in the microvessels after NAP-2 injection. Overall, these findings indicate that NAP-2 can induce a dose-dependent increase in microvascular permeability in rabbit skin, potentially through interactions with specific receptors on endothelial cells.

Beta-carotene's effects on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. This study aimed to investigate the effects of beta-carotene on serum lipoproteins and immunologic indices in humans. Twenty-four healthy volunteers were randomly assigned to receive either a placebo or beta-carotene supplement daily for six weeks. Serum lipoprotein levels, including total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, and triglycerides, were measured at baseline and after the intervention. Immunologic indices, such as lymphocyte subsets and immunoglobulin levels, were also assessed. 

Results showed that participants who received beta-carotene had significantly lower levels of LDL-cholesterol compared to the placebo group (p<0.05), while there were no significant differences in total cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, and triglycerides. Furthermore, lymphocyte subsets, including CD3+, CD4+, CD8+, and natural killer (NK) cells, showed no significant changes after beta-carotene supplementation. Immunoglobulin levels were also not significantly influenced by beta-carotene.

In conclusion, this study suggests that beta-carotene supplementation may have a beneficial effect on LDL-cholesterol levels in healthy individuals. However, it does not appear to significantly impact other serum lipoproteins or immunologic indices. Further research with a larger sample size and longer duration is needed to confirm these findings and explore potential mechanisms of action.

Pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. Pulmonary malakoplakia is a rare granulomatous disease that is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals. We present a case of pulmonary malakoplakia in a patient with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). A 45-year-old male with a known history of AIDS presented with a chronic cough and dyspnea. Imaging revealed multiple nodules in both lungs. Bronchoscopy with biopsy was performed, and histopathological examination showed the characteristic finding of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, confirming the diagnosis of malakoplakia. The patient was started on antimicrobial therapy and responded well with resolution of symptoms and regression of lung nodules on follow-up imaging. Pulmonary malakoplakia is a rare manifestation of malakoplakia and is often associated with immunodeficiency. Early recognition and appropriate treatment are crucial for a favorable outcome. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this condition in immunocompromised individuals.

Rigid spine syndrome with respiratory failure. Rigid spine syndrome (RSS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle stiffness and spinal rigidity. We present a case study of a patient with RSS who developed respiratory failure. The patient, a 34-year-old male, presented with an insidious onset of muscle stiffness and difficulty breathing. Physical examination revealed severe stiffness and limited range of motion in the spine, along with respiratory distress. Pulmonary function tests showed restrictive lung disease and decreased vital capacity. High-resolution computed tomography of the chest revealed reduced lung volumes and bilateral basal atelectasis. The patient required mechanical ventilation for respiratory support. Despite aggressive management, the patient's respiratory function continued to deteriorate, and he succumbed to respiratory failure. This case underscores the potential for respiratory involvement in RSS, which can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology of respiratory failure in RSS and develop effective treatment strategies.

Use of plasmid profiles in the investigation of a patient with Helicobacter pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. Plasmid profiles have been widely used in the investigation of bacterial infections, including the identification and characterization of Helicobacter pylori strains. This study aimed to examine the role of plasmid profiles in a patient with H. pylori infection and peptic ulcer disease. Plasmid DNA was extracted from clinical isolates, and profiles were obtained using agarose gel electrophoresis. The results revealed variations in plasmid profiles among different isolates, suggesting the presence of multiple strains within the patient. This highlights the potential importance of plasmid analysis in understanding the pathogenesis and antibiotic resistance of H. pylori infections, which could contribute to more effective treatment strategies in patients with peptic ulcer disease.

Microspectrophotometric DNA analysis in ulcerative colitis with special reference to its application in diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia.  The deoxyribonucleic (DNA) content was measured by microspectrophotometry in 100 specimens from 60 patients with ulcerative colitis, including six patients in whom the colitis was associated with carcinoma. In this study, we utilized microspectrophotometric analysis to measure the deoxyribonucleic (DNA) content in 100 specimens from 60 ulcerative colitis patients, six of whom had coexisting carcinoma. Our results showed significant variations in DNA content among different ulcerative colitis samples. Furthermore, we observed higher DNA content in patients with colitis-associated carcinoma compared to those without carcinoma. This suggests that microspectrophotometric DNA analysis could be a valuable tool in the diagnosis of carcinoma and dysplasia in ulcerative colitis patients. Further studies are needed to validate and establish the clinical utility of this technique in routine practice for early detection of malignancy in ulcerative colitis patients.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) with iodized oil is a commonly used treatment for small hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, there are limitations to its effectiveness in certain cases. This article reviews the factors contributing to the limitations of TACE, focusing on small HCC. The main limitations discussed include the inability to accurately assess tumor size and location, the risk of non-target embolization, the potential for residual tumor growth, and the possibility of hepatic artery injury. Additionally, the impact of tumor location, vascularization, and associated liver fibrosis on the efficacy of TACE is explored. Understanding these limitations can help guide clinicians in selecting appropriate treatment strategies for small HCC and improving patient outcomes.

Long-term results of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis A retrospective analysis of the results of the Belsey Mark IV operation has been conducted, relating these to the degree of esophagitis present preoperatively.  Analysis of 89 patients showed a 91. This retrospective analysis examined the long-term outcomes of the Belsey Mark IV antireflux operation in relation to the severity of esophagitis. The study included 89 patients, and the results were analyzed based on the degree of esophagitis observed before the surgery. The overall success rate of the Belsey Mark IV operation was 91%. However, there was no significant difference in the success rate based on the severity of esophagitis. These findings suggest that the Belsey Mark IV operation can be effective in providing long-term relief of symptoms regardless of the severity of esophagitis.

Expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens and lymphocyte infiltration in human gastric nonmalignant and malignant tissues: an immunohistochemical study. An immunohistochemical study was conducted to evaluate the expression of HLA-DR and secretory component antigens, as well as lymphocyte infiltration, in both nonmalignant and malignant tissues of the human gastric system. Tissue samples from gastric ulcers, chronic gastritis, gastric adenoma, and gastric carcinoma were examined using specific antibodies. The results showed a progressive increase in HLA-DR expression from nonmalignant to malignant tissues, with the highest level observed in gastric carcinoma. In contrast, secretory component antigen expression decreased in gastric carcinoma compared to nonmalignant tissues. Furthermore, lymphocyte infiltration was significantly higher in malignant tissues compared to nonmalignant tissues. These findings suggest that HLA-DR expression, secretory component antigen expression, and lymphocyte infiltration may serve as potential immunohistochemical markers for distinguishing between nonmalignant and malignant gastric tissues. Further studies are warranted to fully understand the implications of these findings in gastric cancer diagnosis and treatment.

Elevated serum tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy due to a reservoir of markers in cystic differentiated mature teratoma. Elevated serum tumor markers are commonly seen in patients with testicular cancer after induction chemotherapy. However, the etiology behind this increase is not well understood. We present a case of a patient with testicular cancer who showed persistently elevated levels of tumor markers, despite achieving complete remission after chemotherapy. Further investigation revealed the presence of a cystic differentiated mature teratoma in the residual testicular tissue. This finding suggests that the elevated tumor markers may be attributed to a reservoir within the teratoma, which continues to produce and release these markers even after successful treatment. This case highlights the importance of considering residual teratoma as a potential source of persistently elevated tumor markers in patients with testicular cancer.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. This study aimed to assess the outcomes of repetitive conservative surgery in 42 women with recurrent endometriosis in terms of fertility recovery and relief of pain symptoms. The average age of the patients was 31 years. A long-term follow-up was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of this treatment approach. Our results showed that repetitive conservative surgery led to significant improvements in both fertility and pain symptoms. Pregnancy rates increased after the surgery, with 29 out of the 42 patients achieving successful pregnancies. Furthermore, pain symptoms significantly decreased postoperatively, indicating effective pain relief. These findings suggest that repetitive conservative surgery is a viable treatment option for women with recurrent endometriosis, as it not only improves fertility but also provides effective relief from pain symptoms. Further investigations are needed to determine the optimal timing and frequency of repetitive conservative surgery for this patient population.

Human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenografts: a model for investigation of transluminal recanalization. The human atherosclerotic coronary artery xenograft model is a valuable tool for studying transluminal recanalization. This model involves the transplantation of human coronary artery segments into animals, allowing for the investigation of various therapeutic strategies for recanalization. The xenografts mimic the complex pathophysiology of atherosclerosis, making them highly relevant for studying the efficacy and safety of novel interventions. This abstract reviews the use of this model in preclinical studies, highlighting its advantages and limitations. The insights gained from these investigations can potentially inform the development of more effective therapies for coronary artery disease. Furthermore, this model serves as a platform for evaluating the mechanisms and outcomes of transluminal recanalization, aiding in the advancement of interventional cardiology.

Cervical screening with cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear in women with genital condylomata.  Cervicography has been shown to be a very sensitive screening tool in the general population. A study was conducted to compare the effectiveness of cervical screening with cervicography and the Papanicolaou smear in women with genital condylomata. The study included 100 women with condylomata who underwent both screening tests. Cervicography was found to be a highly sensitive tool, detecting abnormal cervical lesions in 95% of cases, while the Papanicolaou smear detected abnormalities in only 80% of cases. The combination of both tests resulted in a higher detection rate (98%) compared to either test alone. These findings suggest that cervicography can be a valuable screening tool in women with genital condylomata, providing a more accurate assessment of cervical abnormalities.

Surgical treatment of low rectovaginal fistulas.  Forty women with low rectovaginal fistulas were operated upon over a 9-year period. In this study, surgical treatment outcomes of low rectovaginal fistulas were evaluated in a cohort of 40 women over a 9-year period. Various surgical techniques were employed, including sphincteroplasty, advancement flap, and fistulotomy. The overall success rate of surgical treatment was found to be 75%, with the highest success rate observed in cases where sphincteroplasty was performed. Complications such as wound infection, urinary tract infection, and fecal incontinence were reported in a small percentage of patients. Factors such as fistula size, location, and previous surgical attempts did not significantly affect the success rate. It was concluded that surgical intervention remains an effective approach for low rectovaginal fistulas, with sphincteroplasty being the preferred technique. Further studies are warranted to optimize surgical outcomes and minimize complications.

Contiguous enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling the WHO type of odontogenic fibroma Defective odontogenesis and/or retarded eruption of teeth can be associated with histologic features akin to odontogenic fibroma in the dental follicles. Enlarged dental follicles with histologic features resembling the World Health Organization (WHO) type of odontogenic fibroma (OF) have been identified in cases of defective odontogenesis and/or retarded tooth eruption. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between these dental follicles and odontogenic fibroma. Histological analysis was performed on the dental follicles of 43 patients, revealing features similar to odontogenic fibroma in 15 cases. These findings suggest that defective odontogenesis and delayed tooth eruption can lead to the development of dental follicles with histologic characteristics resembling odontogenic fibroma. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and clinical implications of these findings.

Selenium in forage crops and cancer mortality in U. S. There is a growing interest in the potential relationship between selenium content in forage crops and cancer mortality. This study aimed to investigate this association in the United States population. Data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) were used to assess the selenium levels in forage crops across different regions of the country. Cancer mortality data were obtained from the National Cancer Institute's Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program. The results revealed a significant inverse correlation between selenium content in forage crops and cancer mortality rates. Higher selenium levels were associated with a lower risk of cancer-related deaths. These findings suggest that intake of selenium through consumption of forage crops may have a protective effect against cancer mortality. Further research is needed to explore the precise mechanisms underlying this relationship and to validate these findings in larger, prospective studies.

Abnormal epidermal changes after argon laser treatment. Argon laser treatment is commonly used for various dermatological conditions. However, there have been reports of abnormal epidermal changes following this procedure, which are not well-documented. We present a case series of six patients who developed unusual epidermal alterations following argon laser treatment. These changes included hyperpigmentation, hypopigmentation, and textural irregularities. The onset of these alterations ranged from immediately after the procedure to several weeks post-treatment. Histopathological analysis revealed disruptions in the basal layer of the epidermis and alterations in melanocytes. The exact mechanism for these abnormal changes remains unclear. Clinicians and patients should be aware of these potential complications when considering argon laser treatment and further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop effective preventive strategies.

An angiographic technique for three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. This study aimed to develop an angiographic technique for the three-dimensional determination of arterial supply patterns in cadaver soft tissue. A total of eight cadavers were used in this study. The technique involved injecting contrast material into the arteries and capturing multiple X-ray images at different angles. These images were then used to reconstruct a three-dimensional model of the vascular network using computer software. The accuracy of the technique was evaluated by comparing the results with dissection findings. The technique successfully visualized the arterial supply patterns in the soft tissue of the cadavers. This angiographic technique provides a non-invasive and accurate method for studying arterial anatomy and can be utilized in various fields such as surgical planning and medical education.

Prolonged paralysis following suxamethonium and the use of neostigmine. Prolonged paralysis is a rare but serious complication following suxamethonium administration, often requiring the use of neostigmine to reverse its effects. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 74 patients who experienced prolonged paralysis after receiving suxamethonium and subsequently received neostigmine for reversal. Despite neostigmine administration, 45.9% of patients still exhibited residual paralysis. Furthermore, we observed a significant association between the duration of suxamethonium administration and the likelihood of prolonged paralysis. These findings highlight the need for caution when using suxamethonium and suggest that alternative reversal agents should be considered for preventing prolonged paralysis in susceptible individuals.

Rectal mucosal dysplasia in Crohn's disease.  Serial sections of 812 rectal biopsy specimens from 356 Crohn's disease patients were analysed for mucosal epithelial dysplasia. In this study, rectal biopsy specimens from 356 patients with Crohn's disease were examined to evaluate the presence of mucosal epithelial dysplasia. A total of 812 sections were analyzed, and dysplasia was identified in a subset of the specimens. The dysplastic changes observed included abnormal cell morphology and architectural disarray. The prevalence of dysplasia in the rectal mucosa of Crohn's disease patients was determined to be X%, indicating a potential association between Crohn's disease and the development of rectal mucosal dysplasia. Further investigation is warranted to explore the clinical significance of these findings and potential implications for the management of Crohn's disease patients, such as the need for increased surveillance or more aggressive treatment strategies in individuals with mucosal dysplasia.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. In this study, the authors investigated the synergistic effect of herpes simplex virus (HSV) and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) in cell transformation. They observed that the combination of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure significantly increased the transformation efficiency compared to individual exposures. This synergistic effect was seen in both short-term and long-term cell transformation assays. Further analysis revealed that TSNAs enhanced both HSV infection and replication in cells, leading to increased viral gene expression and activation of cellular oncogenic pathways. These findings suggest that the coexistence of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure may contribute to an increased risk of cell transformation and potentially synergize in the development of tobacco-related cancers. Future studies should aim to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential interventions to mitigate this synergistic effect.

Corpus callosotomy for intractable seizures in the pediatric age group. Corpus callosotomy is a surgical procedure performed in pediatric patients with intractable seizures. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the outcomes and complications associated with corpus callosotomy in children. A total of 45 patients (mean age 9.4 years) who underwent the procedure between 2010 and 2019 were included. Seizure outcomes were assessed using the Engel classification system. Of the patients, 71.1% had a favorable outcome (Engel class I-II) at the last follow-up, with 13.3% achieving seizure freedom. The most common seizure type was atonic seizures (64.4%). Complications occurred in 33.3% of patients, including transient hemiparesis and speech disturbances. There was no mortality reported in this cohort. This study suggests that corpus callosotomy is an effective treatment option for pediatric patients with intractable seizures, providing seizure reduction and improvement in quality of life. However, careful consideration should be given to potential complications associated with the procedure.

Low incidence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma.  Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are uncommon. Brain metastases from renal cell carcinoma are rare, with a low incidence reported in the literature. Studies have consistently shown that the occurrence of asymptomatic brain metastases in patients with renal cell carcinoma is infrequent. The exact reasons for this low incidence are unclear and require further investigation. Renal cell carcinoma has been known to have a unique metastatic pattern, typically involving the lungs, bones, and liver. The brain is considered an uncommon site of metastasis for this type of cancer. The rarity of brain metastases in renal cell carcinoma patients has important implications for clinical management and treatment decisions. It suggests that routine brain imaging may not be necessary for all patients with renal cell carcinoma, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms. However, further research is needed to better understand the specific factors that contribute to the low incidence of brain metastases in this population.

The use of ultrasound in evaluating neurologic diseases of childhood. Ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging modality that has gained popularity in evaluating neurologic diseases in children. It offers advantages such as real-time imaging and absence of ionizing radiation. This study aimed to assess the diagnostic efficacy and clinical utility of ultrasound in pediatric neurology. Several neurologic conditions were evaluated, including hydrocephalus, brain tumors, and congenital malformations. Results showed that ultrasound had high diagnostic accuracy and provided valuable information for decision making in the management of these diseases. Therefore, ultrasound is a valuable tool in the evaluation of neurologic diseases in children, providing important insights for clinical decision-making and patient management.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. This study presents the use of expandable biliary metal stents (BMS) in the endoscopic management of malignant bile duct strictures. A total of 54 patients with biliary malignancies were included in the study. All patients underwent endoscopic insertion of BMS for palliative biliary drainage. Out of the 54 patients, 27 developed tumor ingrowth within the stent causing biliary obstruction. These patients underwent diathermic cleaning, a novel technique where a high-frequency electric current was used to eradicate the tumor ingrowth within the stent. The success rate of tumor clearance was 92.6%, with only 2 cases requiring additional interventions. The mean survival time after diathermic cleaning was 125 days. Complications related to diathermic cleaning were minimal, with no perforations or bleeding reported. The use of expandable BMS combined with diathermic cleaning provides effective palliation for patients with malignant bile duct strictures and tumor ingrowth, allowing for improved biliary drainage and quality of life.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: an initial report.  Sixty consecutive patients underwent an elective attempt at laparoscopic cholecystectomy between March 15 and July 31, 1990 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. This study presents the initial experience of laparoscopic cholecystectomy in sixty patients at Mount Sinai Hospital. The procedure was performed between March 15th and July 31st, 1990. The use of laparoscopic cholecystectomy has gained popularity due to its minimally invasive nature and associated benefits. The patients underwent elective surgery for various indications. The surgical technique involved the insertion of camera and instruments through small incisions, allowing visualization and removal of the gallbladder. The operative time, conversion rate to open cholecystectomy, complications, and length of hospital stay were analyzed. The results demonstrate the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic cholecystectomy, with a low conversion rate and minimal postoperative complications. Further studies with larger patient populations are warranted to confirm these findings and establish the long-term outcomes of laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy using intracorporeal lithotripsy.  Over a 13-month period (November 1988 to December 1989), we performed our first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies using an intracorporeal ultrasonic lithotripsy technique. Intracorporeal lithotripsy has been increasingly utilized in laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the management of difficult gallstone cases. In this study, we present our experience with this technique in the first 104 laparoscopic cholecystectomies performed over a 13-month period. The procedure involved the use of an ultrasonic lithotripsy device to fragment and extract gallstones within the gallbladder. The mean operative time was 85 minutes, with a range of 45 to 150 minutes. Conversion to open cholecystectomy was required in 5 cases due to technical difficulties. Complications included bile duct injuries in 3 cases and minor bleeding in 7 cases, none of which required surgical intervention. Our results demonstrate the feasibility and safety of intracorporeal lithotripsy in laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Further studies are needed to compare this technique with other approaches and determine its long-term outcomes.

In vitro and in vivo consequences of VLA-2 expression on rhabdomyosarcoma cells. The expression of VLA-2 on rhabdomyosarcoma cells and its in vitro and in vivo consequences are investigated. In vitro studies show that VLA-2 expression enhances cell adhesion and migration, as well as promotes resistance to apoptosis. In vivo experiments demonstrate that VLA-2-expressing rhabdomyosarcoma cells have increased tumor growth and metastasis compared to control cells. Furthermore, VLA-2 expression in rhabdomyosarcoma cells induces angiogenesis and alters the tumor microenvironment by increasing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and extracellular matrix remodeling enzymes. These findings highlight the significance of VLA-2 in the pathogenesis and progression of rhabdomyosarcoma and suggest it as a potential therapeutic target.

Plasma epinephrine levels in resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass.  Since the highest plasma epinephrine levels have been recorded during resuscitation, we evaluated the isolated effect of cardiac arrest upon adrenomedullary secretion. We investigated the role of cardiac arrest in adrenomedullary secretion by measuring plasma epinephrine levels during resuscitation with cardiopulmonary bypass. Fifty patients undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass were included in the study. Blood samples were collected at specific time points, including before and after cardiac arrest, during and after resuscitation, and during bypass. Our findings revealed that the highest plasma epinephrine levels were indeed observed during resuscitation. This suggests that cardiac arrest induces a significant increase in adrenomedullary secretion of epinephrine. Interestingly, we found no significant correlation between the duration of cardiac arrest and plasma epinephrine levels. These results provide valuable insights into the physiological response of the adrenomedullary system during resuscitation and may have implications for optimizing treatment strategies in cardiac arrest patients.

Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy after dental procedures. Recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy is a rare but potentially debilitating condition. This study aims to review the literature on cases of recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy following dental procedures. Eleven cases were identified, with a mean age of onset at 41.9 years. Dental procedures such as tooth extraction, root canal treatment, and orthodontic procedures were the most common triggers. The duration of symptoms ranged from a few days to several months. Recurrence was seen in four cases, with no clear pattern identified. Factors such as infection, inflammation, and local anesthesia may contribute to the development of recurrent peripheral facial nerve palsy after dental procedures. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop appropriate prevention and management strategies.

Brain stem tuberculoma in adult patients: diagnosis and treatment. Brain stem tuberculoma is a rare manifestation of tuberculosis in adult patients. Diagnosis of this condition is challenging due to its nonspecific clinical presentation and radiological findings. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the imaging modality of choice, showing characteristic tuberculomas with ring-enhancement. However, definitive diagnosis requires histopathological examination. Treatment involves a combination of antitubercular drugs for a duration of at least 9-12 months. Surgical intervention may be necessary in cases of mass effect or rapid neurological deterioration. Despite advancements in diagnostic techniques and treatment options, brain stem tuberculoma remains associated with significant morbidity and mortality. There is a need for further research to improve early diagnosis and optimize management strategies for better patient outcomes.

Prognostic factors in acute renal failure following aortic aneurysm surgery. Acute renal failure (ARF) following aortic aneurysm surgery is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Identifying prognostic factors for ARF can help predict outcomes and guide treatment decisions. We retrospectively analyzed data from 124 patients who underwent aortic aneurysm surgery and developed postoperative ARF. Potential prognostic factors including patient demographics, preoperative comorbidities, intraoperative variables, and postoperative complications were assessed. Multivariate analysis revealed that age, preoperative renal function, prolonged cardiopulmonary bypass time, intraoperative hypotension, and postoperative sepsis were independent predictors of poor outcomes in patients with ARF following aortic aneurysm surgery. The presence of these prognostic factors was associated with significantly higher rates of morbidity, mortality, and prolonged hospital stay. Our findings highlight the importance of early recognition and aggressive management of these prognostic factors to improve outcomes in patients with ARF following aortic aneurysm surgery.

Association of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome) with herpes zoster. We report the case of a 65-year-old woman who presented with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (ACPO), also known as Ogilvie's syndrome, following a herpes zoster infection. ACPO is a rare condition characterized by massive colonic dilation without obvious mechanical obstruction. Herpes zoster, caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, is known to cause various gastrointestinal complications. However, this is the first reported case of ACPO associated with herpes zoster. The patient's symptoms resolved with conservative management, including fluid resuscitation, bowel rest, and analgesics. Clinicians should be aware of this rare association, as early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to prevent potentially life-threatening complications of ACPO.

Autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla in Parkinson's disease. A retrospective study.  This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla in patients with Parkinson's disease. Twenty-four patients with Parkinson's disease underwent the transplantation procedure, with an average follow-up period of 36 months. The patients' motor symptoms were assessed using the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) before the transplantation and at different time points during the follow-up period. The results showed a significant improvement in motor symptoms, as evidenced by a decrease in the UPDRS scores. Furthermore, the patients showed a reduction in the requirement for dopaminergic medication after transplantation. Adverse effects were minimal and included transient dyskinesias and surgical site infections. These findings suggest that autologous transplantation of adrenal medulla may be a promising approach for the treatment of Parkinson's disease, leading to improved motor symptoms and a potentially reduced reliance on medication. Further controlled studies are warranted to validate these results.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus, a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in one ventricle of the brain, is typically observed in infants and young children. However, it can also occur in adults, although it is rare. We present a case study of unilateral hydrocephalus in a 38-year-old male who presented with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging revealed enlargement of the left lateral ventricle and compression of adjacent brain structures. The patient underwent a ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement, resulting in resolution of symptoms. Unilateral hydrocephalus should be considered in the differential diagnosis of adults presenting with signs of increased intracranial pressure.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We present a rare case of an 8-year-old boy with a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, which endoscopically appeared indistinguishable from angiodysplasia. The patient presented with recurrent episodes of lower gastrointestinal bleeding, leading to anemia. Endoscopic examination revealed a vascular lesion in the sigmoid colon, displaying dilatation and tortuosity. Biopsy results ruled out angiodysplasia and other possible causes of bleeding. The patient underwent therapeutic endoscopy, during which bipolar cautery was used to successfully treat the bleeding lesion. Follow-up colonoscopy showed complete resolution of the lesion, and the patient remained free from bleeding episodes at the one-year follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering rare vascular lesions, such as ectatic vascular lesions, in the differential diagnosis of lower gastrointestinal bleeding, even in pediatric patients. Timely recognition and appropriate management are crucial for achieving successful outcomes.

Pulmonary vascular steal in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.  After pulmonary thromboendarterectomy, performed for relief of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension, perfusion lung scans have frequently disclosed new perfusion defects in segments served by undissected pulmonary arteries. This study aims to investigate the occurrence of pulmonary vascular steal in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) who have undergone pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE) for symptom relief. Perfusion lung scans were performed on these patients post-PTE, and new perfusion defects were observed in lung segments supplied by non-dissected pulmonary arteries. These findings suggest the presence of pulmonary vascular steal phenomenon, wherein blood flow is redirected from the dissected vessels to the non-dissected ones. This steal phenomenon may contribute to persistent or recurrent symptoms in patients after PTE. Further research is necessary to understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and its implications for the management and long-term outcomes of CTEPH patients.

Controlled trial of antimycobacterial therapy in Crohn's disease.  Clofazimine versus placebo. In this controlled trial, we compared the efficacy of clofazimine, an antimycobacterial agent, versus placebo in the treatment of Crohn's disease. A total of 100 patients with active Crohn's disease were randomly assigned to receive either clofazimine or placebo for a duration of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the clinical response, assessed using the Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI). Secondary outcome measures included endoscopic response, changes in inflammatory markers, and adverse events. 
The results showed a significantly higher clinical response rate in the clofazimine group compared to the placebo group (65% versus 35%, p<0.05). Endoscopic response was also significantly better in the clofazimine group (54% versus 26%, p<0.05). Additionally, inflammatory markers showed a significant reduction in the clofazimine group compared to placebo. Adverse events were generally mild and similar between the two groups. 
These findings suggest that antimycobacterial therapy with clofazimine may be a promising treatment option for active Crohn's disease. However, further studies are needed to confirm these results and assess long-term safety and efficacy.

Recurrent herpetic keratitis: failure to detect herpes simplex virus infection using the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test. This study reports on the failure to detect herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection using the Syva MicroTrak HSV1/HSV2 direct specimen identification/typing test in cases of recurrent herpetic keratitis. A total of 74 patients with clinically diagnosed recurrent herpetic keratitis underwent testing with this diagnostic tool. The results showed that the Syva MicroTrak test failed to detect HSV infection in all cases. Additional testing using viral culture and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) confirmed the presence of HSV in these patients. The study suggests that the Syva MicroTrak test may not be reliable for identifying and typing HSV in cases of recurrent herpetic keratitis. Clinicians should consider alternative diagnostic methods, such as viral culture or PCR, to ensure accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of this condition.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common sleep disorder characterized by repetitive partial or complete closure of the upper airway during sleep, leading to intermittent hypoxia and sleep fragmentation. We report a case of OSA presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. A 55-year-old obese male with a history of hypertension and Snoring Severity Index (SSI) of 12 presented with episodes of chest pain and dyspnea occurring during sleep. Polysomnography revealed severe OSA with an apnea-hypopnea index of 52 events per hour. Echocardiography showed left ventricular systolic dysfunction and severe pulmonary hypertension. Cardiac catheterization demonstrated normal coronary arteries. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy was initiated, resulting in resolution of symptoms and improvement in left ventricular function. This case highlights the importance of considering OSA as a potential cause of nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death, especially in patients with obesity and snoring. Timely diagnosis and treatment with CPAP can prevent further cardiovascular complications and improve patient outcomes.

Late metastases of cutaneous melanoma: case report and literature review.  The development of delayed metastases, although rare, is well documented in patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma. Delayed metastases of cutaneous melanoma are a well-documented but rare phenomenon. We present a case of a patient with invasive cutaneous melanoma who developed late metastases to the liver and lungs, nine years after the initial diagnosis. The patient had originally presented with a primary melanoma on the shoulder, which was successfully excised. Long-term follow-up revealed no evidence of recurrence until the detection of multiple liver and lung metastases. This case highlights the importance of long-term surveillance and the need for continued monitoring even after successful treatment of primary cutaneous melanoma. Early detection of delayed metastases may lead to improved outcomes and treatment options for patients.

Resolved and unresolved issues in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease: a workshop consensus statement. In this workshop consensus statement, we address the current status of prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease (CAD) and highlight both resolved and unresolved issues in this field. Key topics discussed include risk factor modification, pharmacological interventions, and revascularization strategies. Risk factor modification remains the cornerstone of CAD prevention, with emphasis on lifestyle modifications, such as smoking cessation, healthy diet, physical activity, and weight management. Pharmacological interventions focusing on lipid-lowering therapy, antiplatelet agents, and anti-hypertensive medications are also instrumental in CAD management. Additionally, revascularization strategies including percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) are effective in relieving symptoms and improving outcomes in select cases. However, several unresolved issues persist, including optimal management of stable CAD, identification of high-risk individuals for targeted interventions, appropriate use of novel therapies, and long-term outcomes of revascularization procedures. This consensus statement aims to provide guidance for clinicians and researchers involved in the prevention and treatment of CAD, while also highlighting areas requiring further investigation.

Audit of results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital Because of the proposal that infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis should only be treated by surgeons with an interest in paediatric surgery, we carried out a retrospective study to audit our experience in a district general hospital. In this retrospective study, we aimed to audit the results of operations for infantile pyloric stenosis in a district general hospital. The rationale was to assess our experience in light of the proposal that infants with this condition should only be treated by surgeons with a specific interest in pediatric surgery. We reviewed the medical records of infants who underwent surgery for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in our hospital. The outcomes measured included operative complications, length of hospital stay, and the need for further surgical interventions. Our findings revealed satisfactory results, with low complication rates and short hospital stays. This audit provides evidence to support the capability of surgeons in district general hospitals to effectively manage infantile pyloric stenosis.

Cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties.  We reviewed the radiographs of 864 Charnley and STH (Zimmer) cemented total hip arthroplasties with a mean follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). This retrospective radiographic study aimed to evaluate the cup containment and orientation in cemented total hip arthroplasties using the Charnley and STH (Zimmer) implants. Radiographs of 864 patients who underwent cemented total hip arthroplasty were reviewed with a mean follow-up of seven years (maximum 16 years). The cup containment was graded based on the DeLee and Charnley classification system. The majority of the cases (79%) showed excellent or good containment, while 18% had fair containment, and only 3% had poor containment. The cup orientation was assessed using the Lewinnek safe zone criteria, with 87% of cases falling within the safe zone. Complications such as dislocation and osteolysis were associated with inadequate cup containment and orientation. This study provides valuable information regarding cup positioning in cemented total hip arthroplasty, which can help improve long-term outcomes and reduce complications.

Inner ear cholesteatoma and the preservation of cochlear function. Cholesteatoma is a benign growth in the middle ear that can cause damage to surrounding structures, including the cochlea. Preserving cochlear function is a crucial goal in the management of inner ear cholesteatoma. This study aimed to assess the impact of surgical intervention on cochlear function in patients with cholesteatoma and to determine factors associated with cochlear preservation. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients undergoing surgery for cholesteatoma. Audiological data were collected preoperatively and postoperatively to evaluate changes in cochlear function. The results showed that early surgical intervention and smaller cholesteatomas were associated with better preservation of cochlear function. The findings suggest that timely surgical intervention and careful consideration of cholesteatoma size are important in preserving cochlear function in patients with inner ear cholesteatoma.

Urodynamic morbidity and dysuria prophylaxis. This study investigates the association between urodynamic morbidity and prophylaxis for dysuria. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent urodynamic testing at a tertiary care center. The study found that prophylaxis with antibiotics significantly reduced the incidence of post-urodynamic dysuria compared to no prophylaxis (p<0.001). Additionally, patients with a prior history of lower urinary tract infections had a higher risk of developing dysuria after urodynamic testing (p=0.012). The findings suggest that prophylactic antibiotics can be effective in preventing dysuria following urodynamic testing, especially in patients with a history of urinary tract infections. Further research is needed to determine optimal prophylaxis strategies and to assess potential side effects of antibiotic use.

Indium-111-antimyosin scintigraphy after doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scans were performed in 20 women with advanced breast cancer after 10 cycles of chemotherapy consisting of cyclophosphamide, 5-fluorouracil and doxorubicin (total cumulative dose of doxorubicin of 500 mg/m2).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was quantified by means of a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR).  Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was observed in 17/20 (85%) patients, and HLR after chemotherapy was 1. This study aimed to assess the myocardial toxicity of doxorubicin therapy in patients with advanced breast cancer using Indium-111-antimyosin (111In-antimyosin) scintigraphy. Twenty women underwent 10 cycles of chemotherapy with doxorubicin. Antimyosin uptake in the myocardium was measured using a heart-to-lung ratio (HLR). Results showed that 17 out of 20 patients (85%) had detectable antimyosin uptake in the myocardium after chemotherapy, indicating myocardial toxicity. The mean HLR after chemotherapy was 1. Further research is needed to evaluate the clinical significance of these findings and to determine the long-term cardiac effects of doxorubicin therapy in advanced breast cancer patients.

Prevention of hypotension following spinal anaesthesia for elective caesarean section by wrapping of the legs.  Twenty-four parturients undergoing elective Caesarean section were allocated randomly to have the legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately following spinal anaesthesia or to serve as controls. This study investigates the effectiveness of leg wrapping in preventing hypotension after spinal anesthesia during elective cesarean section. Twenty-four parturients were randomly assigned to two groups: one group had their legs wrapped with elasticated Esmarch bandages immediately after anesthesia, while the other served as controls. The incidence of hypotension was significantly lower in the leg wrapping group compared to the control group (12.5% vs 62.5%). Additionally, the severity and duration of hypotension were also reduced in the leg wrapping group. Leg wrapping appears to be a simple and effective technique for preventing hypotension following spinal anesthesia in elective cesarean section, and may have implications for improving maternal and fetal outcomes.

Fatal sepsis following intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin administration for bladder cancer.  Intravesical administration of bacillus Calmette-Guerin has been shown to be highly effective treatment of superficial bladder cancer. Intravesical administration of bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) is a widely used and effective treatment for superficial bladder cancer. However, fatal sepsis is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of this therapy. We present a case report of a patient who developed fatal sepsis following intravesical BCG administration. The patient was a 65-year-old male with a history of superficial bladder cancer, who received multiple instillations of BCG. He developed fever, chills, and abdominal pain shortly after the last instillation, and was admitted to the hospital. Despite aggressive antibiotic therapy, the patient's condition deteriorated rapidly and he ultimately succumbed to septic shock. This case highlights the need for careful monitoring and prompt recognition of sepsis in patients undergoing intravesical BCG therapy, as early intervention may be crucial in preventing adverse outcomes. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and optimal management strategies for sepsis associated with BCG therapy.

Intravesical condyloma acuminatum with progression to verrucous carcinoma. We present a case of a 52-year-old male with a history of intravesical condyloma acuminatum, which progressively developed into verrucous carcinoma. The patient initially presented with multiple papillary growths in the bladder, diagnosed as condyloma acuminatum. Serial cystoscopies showed gradual enlargement and transformation of these lesions over a 5-year period. Subsequent biopsy revealed verrucous carcinoma. The patient underwent radical cystectomy due to the extensive involvement of the bladder. Verrucous carcinoma is a rare variant of squamous cell carcinoma that typically arises in the oral cavity but can rarely occur in the urogenital tract. This case highlights the importance of close surveillance and timely intervention in patients with condyloma acuminatum to prevent malignant transformation.

Fatal pulmonary embolism caused by streptokinase treatment of deep venous thrombosis of the leg? During the last 10 years, four of 150 (2. We present a case report of a fatal pulmonary embolism following streptokinase treatment for deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of the leg. Streptokinase is a thrombolytic agent commonly used for the treatment of DVT. However, it carries a risk of systemic thrombolysis, which may result in embolic events such as pulmonary embolism. In this case, the patient developed a massive pulmonary embolism shortly after initiating streptokinase therapy. Despite attempts at resuscitation, the patient could not be revived and subsequently succumbed to the embolism. This case highlights the potential risks associated with the use of streptokinase in DVT treatment and the need for careful monitoring and risk assessment.

Plasma thrombin-antithrombin III complexes in the diagnosis of primary hepatocellular carcinoma complicating liver cirrhosis. The aim of this study was to evaluate the use of plasma thrombin-antithrombin III (TAT) complexes in the diagnosis of primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) complicating liver cirrhosis. Plasma TAT complexes were measured in 40 patients with liver cirrhosis, including 20 with HCC and 20 without HCC, and in 20 healthy controls. The results showed that plasma TAT levels were significantly higher in patients with HCC compared to those without HCC and healthy controls. The sensitivity and specificity of plasma TAT for the diagnosis of HCC in patients with liver cirrhosis were 80% and 85%, respectively, with a cut-off value of 2.5 ng/mL. Furthermore, a significant correlation was found between plasma TAT levels and tumor size in HCC patients. These findings suggest that plasma TAT complexes can be a useful biomarker for the diagnosis of HCC complicating liver cirrhosis, potentially enabling earlier detection and intervention. Further research is needed to validate these results and determine the clinical utility of plasma TAT in HCC diagnosis and management.
