Eosinophilic fasciitis is a rare connective tissue disorder characterized by thickening and inflammation of the fascia. It is thought to be an inflammatory response triggered by autoimmunity or exposure to certain medications or environmental factors. We present a case of eosinophilic fasciitis associated with tryptophan ingestion, which adds to the growing evidence linking this dietary supplement to eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS). EMS is a potentially severe disorder characterized by eosinophilia, myalgia, and various systemic manifestations. It has been primarily associated with the ingestion of contaminated tryptophan supplements. Our patient developed eosinophilic fasciitis following tryptophan intake, and her symptoms completely resolved after discontinuation of the supplement. This case highlights the importance of considering tryptophan ingestion as a potential trigger for eosinophilic fasciitis and emphasizes the need for careful scrutiny of dietary supplements. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and better understand the relationship between tryptophan and eosinophilic fasciitis.

Dysphagia following fundoplication: "slipped" fundoplication versus achalasia complicated by fundoplication. This study aimed to compare the incidence and clinical outcomes of dysphagia following "slipped" fundoplication versus achalasia complicated by fundoplication. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 348 patients who underwent fundoplication for either gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or achalasia. Dysphagia was observed in 15.9% of patients overall, with a higher incidence in the slipped fundoplication group (23.5%) compared to the achalasia complicated by fundoplication group (11.8%). The severity of dysphagia was also greater in the slipped fundoplication group. Additionally, the success rate of various interventions for dysphagia was significantly higher in the achalasia complicated by fundoplication group. These findings emphasize the importance of differentiating between slipped fundoplication and achalasia complicated by fundoplication in the management of dysphagia.

Total hip arthroplasty with cement.  A long-term radiographic analysis in patients who are older than fifty and younger than fifty years. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of total hip arthroplasty (THA) with cement in patients older than fifty and younger than fifty years. The radiographic analysis included 150 patients, with a mean age of 62 years, who underwent THA with cement and were followed up for an average of 10 years. The radiographic measurements included acetabular inclination, femoral offset, and component loosening. The results showed satisfactory outcomes in both age groups, with significant improvement in pain and functional scores. The acetabular inclination and femoral offset were within acceptable ranges in both age groups. Component loosening was observed in 10% of patients, with higher rates in the younger age group. The overall survival rate of THA with cement was 89% at 10 years. These findings suggest that THA with cement is a viable treatment option for patients older than fifty and younger than fifty years, providing long-term pain relief and functional improvement. Further studies are needed to evaluate the impact of age on component longevity.

Malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli. Juvenile polyposis coli (JPC) is a rare gastrointestinal disorder characterized by the presence of multiple juvenile polyps in the colon and rectum. Although considered a benign condition, recent evidence suggests that JPC may have malignant potential. This case report describes a patient with JPC who developed colorectal adenocarcinoma. The patient presented with iron deficiency anemia and was found to have multiple juvenile polyps on colonoscopy. Histopathological analysis revealed high-grade dysplasia in one of the polyps, consistent with the development of malignancy. This case highlights the importance of close surveillance and regular screening in patients with JPC, as early detection and treatment of malignancy can significantly improve outcomes.

Recurrence of resected esophagogastric adenocarcinoma: results of re-resection.  Isolated local recurrence following potentially curative resection for carcinoma of the esophagus or esophagogastric junction does not necessarily imply pending systemic disease and early demise. The recurrence of esophagogastric adenocarcinoma after resection is a concerning issue. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of re-resection in cases of isolated local recurrence following curative resection for esophagogastric carcinoma. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent re-resection for isolated local recurrence between 2005 and 2015. Of the 32 patients included in the study, the median overall survival was found to be 20 months, while the median disease-free survival was 10 months. Five-year survival rates were 36% for overall survival and 18% for disease-free survival. Interestingly, patients who underwent re-resection within 1 year of initial surgery had better survival outcomes compared to those who underwent re-resection after 1 year. These findings suggest that isolated local recurrence does not necessarily indicate impending systemic disease and poor prognosis, highlighting the potential benefits of re-resection in selected cases.

Extrageniculate vision in hemianopic humans: saccade inhibition by signals in the blind field. This study investigated extrageniculate vision in hemianopic humans by examining saccade inhibition in the blind field. Participants with hemianopia were instructed to make saccades towards visual targets presented in their blind hemifield while maintaining fixation on a central target. Results showed significant saccade inhibition when the visual target was presented in the blind field compared to when it was presented in the intact field. This inhibitory effect was found to be robust and occurred even in the absence of any visible cue. These findings suggest the presence of residual visual processing in the blind field, potentially mediated by extrageniculate pathways. Understanding extrageniculate vision in hemianopic individuals has important implications for rehabilitative strategies and visual compensation in these patients.

Sensory ataxic hemiparesis in thalamic hemorrhage. Sensory ataxic hemiparesis (SAH) is a rare condition characterized by a combination of sensory deficits, ataxia, and hemiparesis. Thalamic hemorrhage is a known cause of SAH, but little is known about the clinical characteristics and outcomes of this specific subgroup. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the clinical data of 25 patients with SAH due to thalamic hemorrhage. The majority of patients presented with sudden-onset hemiparesis and sensory deficits, with most lesions located in the posterior thalamus. Neuroimaging revealed hematoma compression of the posterior limb of the internal capsule and disruption of the sensory fibers. The prognosis of SAH due to thalamic hemorrhage was generally favorable, with most patients showing significant improvement in motor and sensory functions. However, a small proportion of patients experienced persistent disability. Our findings contribute to the understanding of SAH secondary to thalamic hemorrhage and highlight the importance of early diagnosis and management in improving patient outcomes.

IgD immune complex vasculitis in a patient with hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever. IgD immune complex vasculitis is a rare manifestation in patients with hyperimmunoglobulinemia D and periodic fever (HIDS). HIDS is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent fevers, abdominal pain, lymphadenopathy, and arthritis. The majority of patients with HIDS have elevated serum IgD levels, although the pathogenic role of IgD is not well understood. We present a case of a 10-year-old male with HIDS who presented with palpable purpura and joint pain. Skin biopsy revealed leukocytoclastic vasculitis consistent with IgD immune complex vasculitis. This case highlights the importance of considering IgD immune complex vasculitis in the differential diagnosis of vasculitis in patients with HIDS. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis of IgD immune complex vasculitis and its association with HIDS.

Repetitive conservative surgery for recurrence of endometriosis.  We evaluated the recovery of fertility and the relief of pain symptoms in a long-term follow-up of 42 women undergoing repetitive conservative surgery for recurrent endometriosis.  The mean age of the patients was 31. Repetitive conservative surgery is commonly used for the management of recurrent endometriosis. We aimed to assess the outcomes of fertility and pain relief in a long-term follow-up of 42 women who underwent this surgical approach. The mean age of the patients was 31 years. Our findings showed that repetitive conservative surgery had a positive impact on fertility, as indicated by a successful pregnancy rate of 62%. Additionally, a significant reduction in pain symptoms was observed in the majority of patients, with 81% reporting symptom relief. However, there were cases of disease recurrence requiring further surgery, with 24% of patients undergoing repeat procedures. In conclusion, repeat conservative surgery appears to be an effective strategy for managing recurrent endometriosis, providing both improved fertility outcomes and relief of pain symptoms in the majority of cases.

The single-breath nitrogen test, mortality, and cancer.  The relationship between indices of the single-breath nitrogen test and mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence was examined in a cohort of 876 men, 46 to 69 yr of age, examined in 1974 and followed until June 1985. The relationship between single-breath nitrogen test (SBNT) indices and mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence was investigated in a cohort of 876 men, aged 46 to 69 years, who were examined in 1974 and followed until June 1985. The SBNT indices, which measure pulmonary diffusing capacity, were found to be associated with increased mortality, overall cancer incidence, and respiratory cancer incidence. Specifically, lower SBNT indices were linked to higher risks of mortality and cancer incidence. These findings suggest that impaired pulmonary diffusing capacity, as indicated by SBNT indices, may serve as a potential marker for adverse health outcomes in men, particularly in relation to mortality and cancer incidence.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. Part III. A case report. This case report describes a patient with acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty (TCA) and the placement of a coronary reperfusion catheter. The patient, a 57-year-old male, presented with chest pain and was diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Initial treatment included TCA, but this was unsuccessful in reopening the occluded coronary artery. Subsequently, a coronary reperfusion catheter was placed to achieve reperfusion. The catheter was left in place for a total of 75 minutes. The patient experienced immediate relief of chest pain and improvement in myocardial perfusion as evidenced by the resolution of ST-segment elevation on electrocardiogram. No complications related to the catheter placement were observed. This case report highlights the potential benefit of prolonged catheterization in patients with failed TCA and acute coronary occlusion. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal duration of catheter placement in this population.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common complication of ischemic heart disease and are associated with increased morbidity and mortality. A comprehensive understanding of the underlying mechanisms and risk factors is essential for appropriate management and prevention of these arrhythmias. This review provides an overview of the pathophysiology and clinical significance of ventricular arrhythmias in the context of ischemic heart disease. Ischemia-induced electrical and structural remodeling, as well as sympathetic and parasympathetic modulation, play important roles in the development and progression of ventricular arrhythmias. Risk stratification models, such as the use of electrocardiographic markers, imaging techniques, and invasive electrophysiological studies, have been developed to identify patients at high risk for ventricular arrhythmias. Additionally, antiarrhythmic medications, implantable cardioverter-defibrillators, and catheter ablation have shown efficacy in managing these arrhythmias. Ongoing research is focused on identifying novel therapeutic targets and interventions to further improve outcomes in patients with ventricular arrhythmias and ischemic heart disease.

The acute and insidious onset of pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma. Pulmonary metastatic transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) can present with both acute and insidious onset. A retrospective analysis of 23 patients diagnosed with pulmonary metastatic TCC revealed that 13 cases presented acutely with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and hemoptysis. These patients had a higher prevalence of larger tumor size and more extensive metastasis. On the other hand, 10 cases presented insidiously with chronic cough, fatigue, and weight loss. These patients were more likely to have smaller tumor size and limited metastasis. Clinicians should be aware of the varying presentation of pulmonary metastatic TCC to ensure early diagnosis and appropriate management.

Using a state cancer registry to increase screening behaviors of sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients. This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of utilizing a state cancer registry to increase screening behaviors among sisters and daughters of breast cancer patients. A total of 100 participants were enrolled in the intervention group, where they received personalized reminders and educational materials about breast cancer screening. The control group consisted of 100 participants who did not receive any intervention. Results showed that the intervention group had significantly higher rates of breast self-examinations, clinical breast examinations, and mammography screenings compared to the control group. Utilizing a state cancer registry as a tool to promote screening behaviors in high-risk individuals can be an effective strategy to improve early detection and potentially reduce breast cancer-related mortality.

A tongue force measurement system for the assessment of oral-phase swallowing disorders. A tongue force measurement system is proposed as an effective tool for evaluating oral-phase swallowing disorders. The system allows for the quantification of tongue strength and coordination during swallowing, providing valuable information for diagnosing and monitoring this type of dysfunction. This system utilizes sensors and computer algorithms to accurately measure the forces exerted by the tongue during various swallowing tasks. Preliminary studies have demonstrated the feasibility and reliability of this system in assessing tongue function in individuals with swallowing disorders. By providing objective measurements, this tongue force measurement system has the potential to enhance the assessment and treatment of oral-phase swallowing disorders, leading to improved patient outcomes.

Misdiagnosis of the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome due to hyperlipidemia. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a rare disorder characterized by gastrin-secreting tumors in the pancreas or duodenum, leading to excessive gastric acid production and resulting in peptic ulcers. Misdiagnosis of ZES due to hyperlipidemia, a common comorbidity in patients, can occur due to overlapping symptoms and misleading laboratory findings. Elevated fasting lipid levels can cause falsely elevated serum gastrin levels, mimicking the characteristic hypergastrinemia seen in ZES. This can lead to unnecessary diagnostic workup and delay in appropriate management. Clinicians should be aware of this potential pitfall and consider ruling out or correcting hyperlipidemia before making a definitive diagnosis of ZES, in order to prevent unnecessary interventions and improve patient care.

Heart transplantation in patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance.  Irreversibly increased pulmonary vascular resistance is a contraindication for cardiac transplantation. Heart transplantation is considered an effective treatment for end-stage heart failure. However, patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) are traditionally excluded due to concerns about the potential adverse effects on post-transplant outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of heart transplantation in patients with irreversibly increased PVR and severe pulmonary hypertension. A retrospective analysis of 128 patients with severe pulmonary hypertension who underwent heart transplantation was conducted. The results showed that patients with increased PVR had comparable short-term and long-term survival rates compared to those with normal PVR. These findings suggest that heart transplantation can be a viable option for patients with severe pulmonary hypertension and increased PVR, challenging the traditional contraindication criteria. Further studies are needed to validate these results and explore potential factors influencing post-transplant outcomes in this patient population.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections among Guatemalan ambulatory preschool children.  Acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) were studied during a 2-year period in 521 preschool children living in a marginal area of Guatemala City. During a 2-year period, the epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) was investigated among 521 preschool children living in a marginalized area of Guatemala City. ARI episodes were monitored through biweekly home visits and medical examinations. The overall incidence rate of ARI was found to be 44.3 episodes per 100 child-years. The highest incidence rate was observed among children aged 12-23 months. The most common pathogens detected in respiratory samples were respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), rhinovirus, and adenovirus. Co-infections were also prevalent. Risk factors associated with ARI included overcrowded living conditions, exposure to cigarette smoke, and lack of exclusive breastfeeding. The study highlights the burden of ARI among preschool children in marginalized urban settings and emphasizes the need for targeted interventions to prevent and manage these infections.

Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis for sternal tumor defect: an autopsy report. This autopsy report presents the case of a patient who underwent a Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis implantation for a sternal tumor defect. The patient had a history of recurrent chondrosarcoma of the sternum, which required repeated surgical resections. A Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis was used to reconstruct the sternal defect after the last resection. However, the patient developed complications postoperatively, including infection and prosthesis displacement. The patient eventually succumbed to sepsis and multisystem organ failure. Autopsy findings revealed the presence of a large abscess at the site of the prosthesis, as well as widespread dissemination of infection. The Dacron fabric-enveloped hydroxyapatite prosthesis was found to be surrounded by fibrous tissue, but there was no evidence of osseointegration. This case highlights the potential risks and limitations associated with the use of this specific prosthesis for sternal tumor defects, necessitating further investigation and improvements in surgical techniques and prosthetic materials.

Recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulation after autologous bone marrow transplantation and chemotherapy. The recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulations after autologous bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and chemotherapy was assessed in this study. The study included 30 patients who underwent BMT and chemotherapy for various hematological malignancies. The levels of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocytes were monitored at regular intervals after transplantation. The results showed a significant decrease in CD3+ lymphocytes immediately after transplantation, followed by a gradual recovery over time. However, the levels of CD5- lymphocytes remained low throughout the study period. These findings suggest that autologous BMT and chemotherapy have a differential impact on the recovery of CD3+ and CD5- lymphocyte subpopulations, with CD5- lymphocytes showing slower and incomplete recovery. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

MRI findings in neuro-Behcet's disease. Neuro-Behcet's disease is a rare neurological manifestation of Behcet's disease characterized by inflammation of the central nervous system. This report presents the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings of 15 patients with neuro-Behcet's disease. MRI revealed various patterns of abnormalities, including parenchymal lesions, meningeal enhancement, and cranial nerve involvement. Most commonly, parenchymal lesions were observed in the brainstem, basal ganglia, and thalamus, exhibiting hyperintensity on T2-weighted images and hypointensity on T1-weighted images. Meningeal enhancement was frequently detected in the basal cisterns and leptomeninges, while cranial nerve involvement mainly affected the cranial nerves III, V, and VII. These MRI findings are essential for the diagnosis and monitoring of neuro-Behcet's disease, contributing to the understanding of its pathophysiology and guiding appropriate treatment strategies.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. These symptoms are rarely observed clinical manifestations of this type of tumor. The patient initially reported a persistent metallic taste in his mouth, which then progressed to gustatory sweating on the left side of his face whenever he ate. He also experienced involuntary tearing while eating, a condition known as crocodile tears syndrome. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a cerebellopontine angle meningioma, which was surgically removed. Subsequently, the patient's symptoms resolved completely. Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome are believed to be caused by aberrant reinnervation of the facial nerve, resulting from damage to the nervus intermedius due to tumor compression. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual manifestations when evaluating patients with cerebellopontine angle meningiomas.

Islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas presenting as bleeding from isolated gastric varices.  Report of a case and review of the literature. This report presents a case of islet cell carcinoma of the pancreas that presented as bleeding from isolated gastric varices. The patient, a 50-year-old male, had a history of heavy alcohol consumption and presented with melena and hypovolemic shock. Diagnostic imaging revealed a hypervascular mass in the head of the pancreas, and endoscopy identified bleeding varices in the fundus of the stomach. The patient underwent a Whipple procedure, and histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of islet cell carcinoma. Islet cell carcinoma is a rare pancreatic tumor usually associated with hormonal hypersecretion. This case highlights the importance of considering islet cell carcinoma as a differential diagnosis in patients with bleeding gastric varices.

The long-term effects of radiation therapy on patients with ovarian dysgerminoma.  A retrospective chart review and questionnaire study was undertaken to look at the long-term effects of radiation therapy in ovarian dysgerminoma patients. A retrospective study was conducted to assess the long-term effects of radiation therapy in patients with ovarian dysgerminoma. Medical records and questionnaires were reviewed for a cohort of ovarian dysgerminoma patients who had received radiation therapy. The study aimed to evaluate the impact of radiation therapy on patient outcomes and identify any long-term side effects. The results showed that the majority of patients experienced favorable outcomes with no evidence of disease recurrence. However, some patients reported complications such as infertility and hormonal imbalances. The study highlights the importance of monitoring and managing the potential long-term effects of radiation therapy in ovarian dysgerminoma patients. Further research is needed to better understand and mitigate these effects to improve patient care and outcomes.

Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder. Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder is a benign condition characterized by hyperplasia and hypertrophy of the gallbladder wall, resulting in the formation of intramural diverticula termed Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. This condition is typically asymptomatic but may present with non-specific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain or discomfort. Diagnosis can be made through imaging modalities such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP). Treatment is usually not required unless symptoms are present, in which case cholecystectomy may be considered. Adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder is generally a benign condition with a low risk of malignant transformation, and long-term follow-up is not typically necessary.

Evidence of heterogeneous mechanisms in lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women. Hyperandrogenic women often exhibit dyslipidemia, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity of lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women. A total of 50 hyperandrogenic women and 50 age-matched controls were enrolled. Lipoprotein profiles were determined using nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Hyperandrogenic women displayed significant increases in very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) particle concentration, VLDL-cholesterol (VLDL-C), and VLDL-triglycerides (VLDL-TG) compared to controls. Additionally, levels of small low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles and LDL-TG were significantly higher in hyperandrogenic women. Interestingly, not all hyperandrogenic women exhibited these lipid alterations, suggesting heterogeneous mechanisms at play. Subgroup analysis revealed that insulin resistance was associated with elevated VLDL particle concentration and VLDL-C, while testosterone levels were positively correlated with small LDL particle concentration and LDL-TG. These findings highlight the diverse mechanisms underlying lipoprotein lipid alterations in hyperandrogenic women and suggest that individualized treatment approaches may be necessary to effectively manage dyslipidemia in this population.

Brain abscess associated with congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistula. Congenital pulmonary arteriovenous fistula (CPAVF) is a rare condition that can lead to various complications. This case report describes a unique presentation of CPAVF with a brain abscess. A 45-year-old male presented with headaches, confusion, and fever. Initial imaging revealed a brain abscess, and further investigations discovered a CPAVF. The patient underwent successful embolization of the fistula, followed by a course of antibiotics for the brain abscess. The association between CPAVF and brain abscess is uncommon and may be attributed to a paradoxical embolism. This case emphasizes the importance of considering CPAVF in patients with unexplained brain abscesses and highlights the need for prompt diagnosis and management to prevent further complications.

Impaired awareness of behavioral limitations after traumatic brain injury.  Sixty-four traumatically brain injured patients were divided into three groups. This study aimed to investigate impaired awareness of behavioral limitations in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI). Sixty-four TBI patients were divided into three groups based on awareness levels: intact awareness (Group A), partially impaired awareness (Group B), and severely impaired awareness (Group C). The patients' awareness was assessed using the Awareness Questionnaire, which measured their perception of cognitive, behavioral, and emotional changes. The results showed that 25% of the patients had intact awareness (Group A), 52% had partially impaired awareness (Group B), and 23% had severely impaired awareness (Group C). The severely impaired awareness group (Group C) demonstrated significantly lower scores on all subscales compared to the other groups. This study highlights the importance of assessing awareness levels in TBI patients, as impaired awareness may affect their ability to recognize and address behavioral limitations.

Beneficial effects of colestipol-niacin on coronary atherosclerosis.  A 4-year follow-up. In this study, the long-term effects of colestipol-niacin treatment on coronary atherosclerosis were evaluated. A total of 264 patients were randomly assigned to receive colestipol-niacin or placebo for a period of 4 years. Coronary angiograms were performed at baseline and at the end of the study to assess the progression of atherosclerosis. The primary endpoint was the change in percent stenosis. 

Results showed a significant reduction in the progression of percent stenosis in the colestipol-niacin group compared to the placebo group (p<0.001). Furthermore, the colestipol-niacin group had a lower incidence of cardiovascular events (p<0.05) and a decreased need for coronary revascularization procedures (p<0.01) compared to the placebo group. Subgroup analysis also showed a significant reduction in the progression of percent stenosis in patients with high LDL cholesterol levels (p<0.05).

In conclusion, colestipol-niacin treatment for 4 years demonstrated beneficial effects on coronary atherosclerosis, reducing its progression and lowering the risk of cardiovascular events.

Mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate this mechanism through electrophysiological studies and assess its clinical significance. A total of 52 patients with WPW syndrome and intermittent preexcitation were included in the study. Electrophysiological studies revealed two distinct mechanisms of intermittent preexcitation: concealed accessory pathway (AP) and intermittent block in the AV node. Of the patients, 42% had concealed AP, while 58% showed intermittent block in the AV node. The presence of concealed AP was associated with a higher frequency of supraventricular tachycardia. Additionally, patients with intermittent block in the AV node had longer PR intervals during sinus rhythm. In conclusion, the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome can be attributed to either concealed AP or intermittent block in the AV node. The presence of concealed AP is associated with a higher risk of supraventricular tachycardia. Further studies are needed to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

The reproducibility of intravascular ultrasound imaging in vitro. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) imaging is a valuable tool for assessing coronary artery disease, but its reproducibility in vitro is not well established. We conducted a study to evaluate the reproducibility of IVUS measurements in an in vitro model. A total of 10 different vessels, simulating various pathological conditions, were imaged using IVUS by four different operators. Measurements of lumen diameter, external elastic membrane (EEM) diameter, and plaque plus media (P+M) area were performed. The results showed good intra-observer reproducibility, with intraclass correlation coefficients of 0.86 for lumen diameter, 0.89 for EEM diameter, and 0.92 for P+M area. Inter-observer reproducibility was also satisfactory, with intraclass correlation coefficients ranging from 0.77 to 0.88. Our findings suggest that IVUS imaging has good reproducibility in vitro, which supports its reliable use in clinical practice for evaluating coronary artery disease.

Window operation: an alternative treatment method for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses Recently, we developed the "window operation" as a more effective way to treat Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses. The traditional treatment methods for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses have limitations in terms of effectiveness and recurrence. This study introduces a new treatment method called the "window operation" which aims to improve the outcomes of these conditions. The window operation involves creating a small opening in the cyst or abscess to allow drainage and prevent re-accumulation. A retrospective analysis of 50 patients who underwent the window operation showed favorable results, with a lower recurrence rate compared to traditional treatments. The procedure was found to be relatively simple and quick, and the postoperative recovery was satisfactory. The window operation represents a promising alternative treatment option for Bartholin gland cysts and abscesses.

Hepatitis B virus nucleocapsid/pre-S2 fusion proteins expressed in attenuated Salmonella for oral vaccination.  Hybrid HBV nucleocapsid-pre-S(2) fusion proteins were stably expressed in several aromatic-dependent attenuated Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin strains. Several strains of attenuated Salmonella typhimurium and Salmonella dublin were used to express hybrid hepatitis B virus (HBV) nucleocapsid-pre-S(2) fusion proteins. These proteins were stable and expressed in the aromatic-dependent Salmonella strains, allowing for potential oral vaccination against HBV. The development of an effective oral vaccine for HBV is important due to its global impact and the need for a cost-effective and easily administrable prophylactic. The fusion proteins expressed in these Salmonella strains may provide a promising platform for the development of an oral vaccine against HBV infection. Further research is needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this approach.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. We present a study on the prognosis of lateral medullary infarction (LMI) in an unselected series of 43 patients. The study includes data from a population-based stroke registry spanning from 1982 to July 1988. The aim was to evaluate both the acute and long-term prognosis of LMI. Clinical characteristics and outcomes were analyzed, including mortality rates, functional outcomes, and recurrence rates. The results showed that LMI had a variable course, with a higher mortality rate compared to other types of stroke. However, a substantial number of patients experienced partial or complete recovery over time. Recurrence of LMI was identified in a small proportion of patients. These findings provide valuable insights into the prognosis of LMI and can help guide clinical decision-making and management strategies for this condition.

Why are autism and the fragile-X syndrome associated? Conceptual and methodological issues. The association between autism and Fragile-X syndrome has been widely documented, but the underlying reasons remain unclear. This review aims to address the conceptual and methodological issues surrounding this association. Firstly, the definition and diagnostic criteria for autism and Fragile-X syndrome are discussed, highlighting the challenges in distinguishing between the two. Secondly, various genetic and molecular mechanisms are explored, including the role of the FMR1 gene and its protein product, fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP). Additionally, the influence of other factors such as environmental and epigenetic factors are considered. Ultimately, further research and improved methodologies are needed to unravel the complex relationship between autism and Fragile-X syndrome.

The modified superior based pharyngeal flap. The modified superior based pharyngeal flap is a surgical technique used to treat velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) in patients with cleft palate. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of this procedure in 33 patients with VPI. The patients underwent the modified superior based pharyngeal flap and were followed up for a mean duration of 18 months. Objective assessment of speech intelligibility was performed using various speech tests. Subjective assessment of speech quality and patient satisfaction was also obtained. The results showed a significant improvement in speech intelligibility after the surgery, with 87% of patients achieving normal or intelligible speech. Complications such as nasal regurgitation and obstructive sleep apnea were observed in a small percentage of patients but were successfully managed. Overall, the modified superior based pharyngeal flap was found to be an effective technique for treating VPI and improving speech outcomes in patients with cleft palate.

Upper gastrointestinal pathology in familial adenomatous polyposis: results from a prospective study of 102 patients.  Multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens from 102 asymptomatic patients with familial adenomatous polyposis, taken during a prospective endoscopic screening programme were examined. This study aimed to evaluate the upper gastrointestinal pathology in 102 asymptomatic patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) using multiple gastric and duodenal biopsy specimens. The patients were part of a prospective endoscopic screening program. The results showed that 43% of the patients had pathological findings in their gastric biopsies, with the most common finding being chronic gastritis. In the duodenal biopsies, 33% had pathological findings, with duodenal adenomas being the most frequently observed. The presence of gastric adenomas and duodenal adenomas significantly increased with age. The study concluded that upper gastrointestinal pathology is prevalent in patients with FAP, even in the absence of symptoms, emphasizing the importance of regular screening and surveillance for early detection and management of lesions in these patients.

Influence of otitis media on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures.  In a noninterventional, controlled, single-blinded trial, 251 children were examined in a university hospital emergency department setting to study the influence of acute otitis media on the relationship between rectal and auditory canal temperatures. In this study, we investigated the impact of acute otitis media (AOM) on the correlation between rectal and auditory canal temperatures in children. A total of 251 children were enrolled in a noninterventional, controlled, single-blinded trial conducted at a university hospital emergency department. We found that AOM had a significant effect on the relationship between rectal and auditory canal temperatures. AOM was associated with a higher correlation between these temperatures, indicating that the presence of AOM influenced the accuracy of using auditory canal temperature as a proxy for core body temperature. These findings suggest that clinicians should be cautious when using auditory canal temperature measurements in children with AOM, as it may not accurately reflect the true body temperature in these individuals.

Systolic Hypertension of the Elderly Program (SHEP).  Part 10: Analysis. The Systolic Hypertension in the Elderly Program (SHEP) was a large-scale clinical trial conducted to determine the efficacy of antihypertensive treatment in reducing the incidence of stroke in elderly individuals with isolated systolic hypertension. This paper is part 10 of the analysis of the SHEP trial and focuses on the treatment outcomes and adverse effects. The results showed that antihypertensive treatment with a low-dose diuretic was effective in reducing the risk of stroke, cardiovascular events, and all-cause mortality in elderly individuals with isolated systolic hypertension. However, there was an increased risk of adverse effects such as hypokalemia, electrolyte abnormalities, and metabolic disturbances. The authors conclude that the benefits of antihypertensive treatment in this population outweigh the potential risks.

Chronic arterial occlusion with PGE1-resistant skin lesions treated by glycosaminoglycan compound--case reports. This report presents two cases of chronic arterial occlusion with prostaglandin E1 (PGE1)-resistant skin lesions treated with a glycosaminoglycan compound. Both patients had long-standing arterial occlusion and non-healing skin ulcers despite PGE1 treatment. The glycosaminoglycan compound was applied topically to the skin lesions in combination with conventional wound care. In both cases, a significant improvement in skin lesions and wound healing was observed within a few weeks of treatment initiation. The glycosaminoglycan compound appeared to promote angiogenesis and improve blood flow to the ischemic areas, leading to tissue regeneration and wound healing. No adverse effects were reported during the treatment period. These cases suggest that the glycosaminoglycan compound may be a promising therapeutic option for PGE1-resistant skin lesions in patients with chronic arterial occlusion. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this treatment approach.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. The study examined the recurrence rate in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after stopping long-term mebendazole therapy. The average duration of treatment was 4.6 years. Follow-up assessments were conducted for a mean follow-up period of 2.3 years after discontinuation of therapy. Recurrence of alveolar echinococcosis was identified in 7 out of the 19 patients (36.8%). The time interval between treatment discontinuation and recurrence varied from 6 months to 4 years. This preliminary analysis suggests a substantial recurrence rate after mebendazole therapy cessation, highlighting the importance of long-term follow-up in patients with alveolar echinococcosis. Further research is warranted to evaluate potential strategies to reduce the risk of recurrence and optimize treatment outcomes in these patients.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. We present a case of a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt and subsequently developed life-threatening complications during anesthesia due to pulmonary hypertension. The presence of a ventriculo-atrial shunt poses an increased risk for complications during anesthesia, particularly in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Awareness of this potential complication is crucial for anesthesiologists to ensure appropriate monitoring and management during the perioperative period. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of anesthesia in patients with ventriculo-atrial shunts and pulmonary hypertension.

Increase in native valve endocarditis caused by coagulase negative staphylococci: an Anglo-French clinical and microbiological study. This study aimed to investigate the increase in native valve endocarditis (NVE) caused by coagulase negative staphylococci (CONS) and compare the clinical and microbiological characteristics between British and French patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on data from 246 patients with NVE caused by CONS, with 131 patients from the UK and 115 from France. The results showed a significant increase in the proportion of NVE cases caused by CONS over the study period in both countries. British patients were found to be younger and have a higher prevalence of prosthetic valves compared to French patients. Furthermore, British patients had higher rates of complicated infections and a higher mortality rate compared to French patients. Microbiological analysis revealed a higher prevalence of CONS species associated with biofilm production in British patients. These findings suggest a growing clinical and microbiological significance of NVE caused by CONS, particularly in the UK, highlighting the need for improved preventive measures and treatment strategies.

Endoscopic laser surgery.  A single-center comprehensive experience. This study presents the outcomes of endoscopic laser surgery in a single-center setting. A total of [insert number] patients who underwent endoscopic laser surgery between [insert dates] were included in the analysis. The majority of patients underwent surgery for [insert indication], with [insert percentage] of cases being therapeutic and [insert percentage] being diagnostic. The overall success rate of endoscopic laser surgery was [insert percentage], with [insert number] patients experiencing complete resolution of their symptoms. Complications were observed in [insert percentage] of cases, primarily consisting of [insert types of complications]. The findings of this study highlight the safety and efficacy of endoscopic laser surgery in the management of [insert indication], supporting its continued use in clinical practice.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. This study aimed to investigate the alterations in T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis (AH). Peripheral blood samples were collected from 30 patients with AH and 30 healthy controls. Flow cytometry was used to analyze the percentages of T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells. The results revealed a significant decrease in the percentages of Tc, Ts, and Tsi cells in the AH group compared to the control group. Additionally, the AH group showed a higher percentage of Th cells and IL2 receptor-bearing cells. These findings suggest that there are distinct alterations in T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients with AH, indicating potential immune dysregulation in the pathogenesis of AH.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia in the Chiari type II malformation. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a common finding in Chiari type II malformation. Chiari type II malformation is a congenital condition characterized by caudal displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, as well as hydrocephalus and myelomeningocele. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a neurological disorder involving impaired adduction of the affected eye with associated contralateral abducting nystagmus upon attempted horizontal gaze. It is caused by damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus, a fiber tract that connects the abducens nucleus and oculomotor nucleus, resulting in a disruption of coordinated eye movements. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is commonly observed in Chiari type II malformation due to the presence of associated brainstem abnormalities. Early recognition and appropriate management of internuclear ophthalmoplegia in patients with Chiari type II malformation are crucial for optimizing visual function and overall patient outcomes.

Xeroderma pigmentosum: review and report of a case. Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation and a high risk of developing skin cancer. This review provides an overview of the clinical features, pathogenesis, and management of XP. Additionally, a case of a 10-year-old male with XP is presented. The patient had a history of severe sunburns, freckling, and skin lesions. A diagnosis was confirmed through genetic testing, which revealed a mutation in the ERCC3 gene. The patient underwent regular dermatological monitoring, strict sun protection measures, and genetic counseling. Despite these precautions, he developed multiple basal cell carcinomas on sun-exposed areas. Treatment involved surgical excision and photodynamic therapy. This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and comprehensive management to minimize UV exposure and prevent malignancy in patients with XP.

Radiation therapy for intraductal carcinoma.  Is it an equal alternative? Of 213 consecutive patients with intraductal carcinoma, 109 were selectively treated with mastectomy and 104 with radiation therapy. The optimal treatment for intraductal carcinoma remains controversial, with mastectomy being the standard approach. In this study, we compared the outcomes of 109 patients who underwent mastectomy and 104 patients who received radiation therapy for intraductal carcinoma. The median follow-up was 5 years. The two groups were similar in terms of age, tumor size, and presence of comedonecrosis. The 5-year overall survival rates were 87% in the mastectomy group and 84% in the radiation therapy group, with no statistically significant difference. However, the local recurrence rate was higher in the radiation therapy group (13%) compared to the mastectomy group (5%). In conclusion, radiation therapy appears to be a viable alternative for the treatment of intraductal carcinoma, with similar overall survival outcomes but a higher risk of local recurrence compared to mastectomy. Further studies with longer follow-up are needed for a more definitive conclusion.

Antibiotic pharmacokinetics in surgery Pharmacokinetics is the study of variables that affect drug concentrations at the effector site. Understanding the pharmacokinetics of antibiotics in surgery is crucial for optimizing their efficacy and minimizing the development of resistance. Factors such as tissue perfusion, drug distribution, metabolism, and elimination play a critical role in determining drug concentrations at the site of infection. Different surgical procedures may have unique influences on antibiotic pharmacokinetics, including alterations in blood flow and tissue barriers. Knowledge of these factors can guide dosing strategies, such as adjusting drug doses based on body weight, renal function, and surgical site. Additionally, therapeutic drug monitoring may be beneficial to ensure therapeutic drug levels are achieved.

The use of molecular probes to distinguish new primary tumors from recurrent tumors in gynecologic malignancies. The ability to distinguish between new primary tumors and recurrent tumors in gynecologic malignancies is crucial for appropriate management and prognosis. This study aimed to evaluate the use of molecular probes in this differentiation process. A total of 43 patients with suspected gynecologic tumor recurrence were included. Molecular probes specific for various mutations commonly found in gynecologic malignancies were utilized. Results showed that the molecular probes were able to successfully differentiate between new primary tumors and recurrent tumors in 82% of cases. This highlights the potential utility of molecular probes as a non-invasive tool for accurate tumor identification and subsequent treatment planning in gynecologic malignancies. Further research and larger studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Reinforcement of incontinent stools in the treatment of encopresis. Encopresis is a common pediatric condition characterized by the involuntary passage of feces in children who have already achieved bowel control.  Traditional treatment approaches focus on stool softening and behavioral modification.  This case report describes a novel treatment approach using reinforcement of incontinent stools as a therapeutic strategy for encopresis.  The patient, a 6-year-old boy, received a reward each time he had an incontinent bowel movement, which led to improved stool control and decreased episodes of encopresis.  This treatment approach offers a new perspective in the management of this challenging condition. Further studies are needed to validate its effectiveness.

Articulatory impairment associated with tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia is a neurological disorder characterized by involuntary, repetitive movements. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of articulatory impairment in patients with tardive dyskinesia. A sample of 65 patients diagnosed with tardive dyskinesia underwent a comprehensive speech evaluation. The results revealed a significantly higher prevalence of articulatory impairment in the patient group compared to a control group of 40 individuals without the disorder. The impairment primarily affected speech intelligibility and oral motor coordination. These findings suggest that tardive dyskinesia can lead to articulatory deficits, which may contribute to communication difficulties in affected individuals. Understanding these impairments can guide targeted interventions to improve overall patient outcomes.

Comparison of pulse oximeters: accuracy at low arterial pressure in volunteers. The accuracy of pulse oximeters at low arterial pressure was evaluated in a group of volunteers. A total of 50 subjects participated in the study. The pulse oximeters were compared using the standard arterial pressure measurement as a reference. The results showed that the accuracy of pulse oximeters varied among different brands. Overall, the mean difference between the pulse oximeter readings and the standard measurement was 2.5%. However, at low arterial pressure levels, the accuracy of the pulse oximeters decreased significantly. The findings suggest that caution should be exercised when using pulse oximeters, especially in situations where low arterial pressure is expected. Further research is needed to explore ways to improve the accuracy of pulse oximeters in these conditions.

Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors are characterized by trisomy 12. Ovarian granulosa-stromal cell tumors (OGSCTs) are rare ovarian neoplasms that are characterized by the presence of trisomy 12. This study aimed to evaluate the frequency of trisomy 12 in OGSCTs and its potential clinical significance. A total of 45 OGSCT cases were included in the analysis. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis was performed to assess the status of chromosome 12. Trisomy 12 was detected in 27 out of 45 cases (60%). No significant correlation was found between trisomy 12 and clinicopathological parameters such as patient age, tumor size, and stage. These findings suggest that trisomy 12 is a common genetic alteration in OGSCTs and may play a role in the pathogenesis of these tumors. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the functional significance of trisomy 12 in OGSCTs.

Pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy. The understanding of pharmacodynamics in cancer therapy is crucial for optimizing treatment outcomes. This review focuses on the interplay between drug pharmacodynamics and tumor biology in the context of cancer therapy. Various mechanisms of drug action, including cytotoxicity, target inhibition, and immunomodulation, are discussed. The importance of drug-drug interactions, dose-response relationships, and individual patient factors in determining pharmacodynamic effects is highlighted. Additionally, the role of pharmacodynamic biomarkers in guiding treatment decisions and monitoring therapy response is explored. Molecular pathways involved in cancer cell growth, survival, and metastasis are examined, with a focus on drug targets and potential resistance mechanisms. By elucidating the pharmacodynamics of anticancer drugs, this review aims to provide insights into their mechanisms of action and potential strategies for overcoming resistance, leading to improved therapeutic outcomes in cancer patients.

Delayed presentation of intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia, an unusual cause of colon obstruction. Intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia is a rare condition that can present with various clinical features and is often difficult to diagnose. Delayed presentation, particularly as a cause of colon obstruction, is even more uncommon. We report a case of a 53-year-old male who presented with acute abdominal pain and signs of colon obstruction. Imaging studies revealed a herniated colon into the pericardial sac. Emergent surgical intervention was performed, confirming the diagnosis and repairing the diaphragmatic defect. Awareness of this rare entity is important to facilitate early diagnosis and prompt management. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal treatment strategy for delayed presentation of intrapericardial diaphragmatic hernia.

Polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction: POLIP syndrome. POLIP syndrome is a rare, inherited disorder characterized by a combination of polyneuropathy, ophthalmoplegia, leukoencephalopathy, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction. This syndrome has been reported in only a few cases worldwide. The cause of POLIP syndrome is currently unknown, but it is believed to involve mitochondrial dysfunction. Clinically, patients with POLIP syndrome present with a range of symptoms, including progressive muscle weakness, difficulty moving the eyes, cognitive impairment, bowel dysfunction, and neurological abnormalities. Diagnostic evaluation typically includes neuroimaging studies, nerve conduction studies, and genetic testing. Treatment options for POLIP syndrome are limited and aimed at managing symptoms and improving quality of life. This abstract provides an overview of POLIP syndrome, highlighting the key clinical features and diagnostic considerations. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic approaches for this rare disorder.

A case of classical mycosis fungoides associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I. We present a case of classical mycosis fungoides (MF) associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I). MF is a rare type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by skin lesions with an indolent course. HTLV-I infection has been implicated in the development of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma and can also be associated with MF. The patient in this case had a history of chronic HTLV-I infection and presented with erythematous, pruritic patches on the skin. Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of MF, and further testing revealed the presence of HTLV-I antibodies and proviral DNA. This case highlights the potential association between MF and HTLV-I infection, emphasizing the importance of considering HTLV-I screening in patients with MF.

Indigenous cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina. Lyme disease cases have been detected in North Carolina, despite it being considered a non-endemic region. This study presents three indigenous cases of Lyme disease diagnosed in North Carolina, with a focus on the clinical manifestations and diagnostic challenges. The patients had an initial presentation of erythema migrans, which is the characteristic skin rash associated with Lyme disease. Laboratory testing confirmed the presence of Borrelia burgdorferi, the etiological agent of Lyme disease, in all three cases. The study highlights the importance of considering Lyme disease as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with compatible clinical manifestations, even in non-endemic areas. Timely identification and appropriate management of these cases are crucial for preventing complications associated with Lyme disease.

Photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in Arabs. We conducted a study to investigate the prevalence of photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses in Arabs. A total of 150 patients with epilepsy were included in the study, and their electroencephalogram (EEG) records were analyzed. Of these, 12 patients (8%) demonstrated photosensitivity on EEG, with photosensitive epilepsies being more common in females (75%) than males (25%). Photoconvulsive responses were observed in 5 patients, accounting for 3.33% of the total sample. Among the patients with photoconvulsive responses, the majority were females (80%). The most common seizure type associated with photosensitivity was generalized tonic-clonic seizures (67%). These findings suggest that photosensitive epilepsies and photoconvulsive responses are relatively common among Arabs, particularly in females. Therefore, it is essential to consider photosensitivity as a potential trigger for seizures and provide appropriate counseling and precautions to patients with epilepsy.

Embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies after infertility therapy: obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits are related to operative strategy.  To assess the benefits that can be expected from embryo reduction of multiple pregnancies after infertility therapy, we report 58 consecutive cases of selective termination using either a transcervical or a transabdominal approach. This study evaluates the outcomes of embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies following infertility therapy. A total of 58 cases were included, with selective termination performed either transcervically or transabdominally. The obstetrical risks and perinatal benefits were analyzed in relation to the operative strategy. The results showed that both approaches were effective in reducing the number of fetuses, with a reduction in obstetrical complications observed. However, the transabdominal approach was associated with a higher risk of miscarriage and preterm birth compared to the transcervical approach. These findings suggest that operative strategy plays a crucial role in determining the outcomes of embryo reduction in multifetal pregnancies, and should be considered when making clinical decisions in infertility therapy.

Management decisions in laryngeal carcinoma in situ. The management of laryngeal carcinoma in situ (CIS) remains controversial. We reviewed the available literature to evaluate the various treatment options and their outcomes for patients with CIS. Surgical excision, including endoscopic laser surgery and open partial laryngectomy, is a commonly used treatment modality for CIS. It offers good oncological control with low rates of recurrence and a high preservation of laryngeal function. However, non-surgical approaches, such as radiotherapy and photodynamic therapy, have also shown promising results in achieving tumor control, especially in patients with early-stage or inaccessible lesions. It is important to consider the patient's preferences, anatomical features, and potential functional outcomes when choosing the optimal treatment approach for CIS. Further studies are needed to determine the long-term outcomes and optimal management strategies for this disease.

Third ventricle cavernous angioma: report of two cases. A case report of two patients with third ventricle cavernous angioma is presented. Third ventricle cavernous angiomas are rare vascular malformations, with only a few cases reported in the literature. Both patients presented with headaches and visual disturbances. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a well-defined lesion with mixed signal intensity in the third ventricle. Surgical resection was performed in both cases. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of cavernous angioma. Both patients had good postoperative outcomes with resolution of symptoms. Third ventricle cavernous angiomas should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients with headaches and visual disturbances, and MRI is the imaging modality of choice for accurate diagnosis.

Psychological characteristics of children with Shwachman syndrome. Shwachman syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, bone marrow dysfunction, and metaphyseal dysostosis. While the physical manifestations of Shwachman syndrome have been well documented, little is known about the psychological characteristics of affected children. In this study, we aimed to investigate the psychological profile of children with Shwachman syndrome. A total of 30 children with confirmed Shwachman syndrome were assessed using standardized psychological measures including the Child Behavior Checklist and the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire. Results revealed higher rates of internalizing and externalizing problems compared to the general population, with emotional symptoms and conduct problems being particularly prevalent. However, strengths in the form of prosocial behavior were also observed. These findings highlight the need for comprehensive psychological assessment and intervention in children with Shwachman syndrome, particularly targeting emotional and behavioral difficulties. By gaining a better understanding of the psychological profile in Shwachman syndrome, healthcare professionals can provide more targeted support and improve overall outcomes for affected children.

Murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 contains factors that can activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. The ability of the murine erythroleukemia cell line GM979 to activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes was investigated in this study. The researchers examined the potential factors within GM979 cells that could induce gene activation. They found that the expression of gamma-globin genes was significantly increased in human fetal liver cells after co-culture with GM979 cells. Furthermore, they identified the presence of specific factors in the conditioned medium of GM979 cells that were responsible for this induction. This suggests that GM979 cells contain factors that have the ability to activate silent chromosomal human gamma-globin genes. These findings may have significant implications in the treatment of hemoglobinopathies, such as sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia, as the activation of gamma-globin genes can lead to increased levels of fetal hemoglobin. Further research is warranted to elucidate the specific factors involved in this process and explore their therapeutic potential.

Access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment. Access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment is a crucial aspect of reducing the burden of cancer worldwide. This abstract aims to explore the current status of access to these services in various settings and populations. In high-income countries, access to cancer prevention measures such as vaccination against human papillomavirus (HPV) and hepatitis B, as well as screening programs for breast, cervical, and colorectal cancers, is generally well-established. However, there are still disparities within these countries, with certain populations, such as low-income individuals and racial/ethnic minorities, facing barriers to access. In low- and middle-income countries, access to cancer prevention and screening is often limited due to resource constraints and lack of infrastructure. Additionally, access to cancer treatment, including surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, is a major challenge in many parts of the world. Efforts to improve access to cancer prevention, detection, and treatment should focus on addressing barriers such as financial constraints, lack of awareness, and limited healthcare resources. Collaborative efforts between governments, healthcare professionals, and international organizations are essential to ensure equitable access to cancer care for all individuals.

Point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the erythropoietin receptor resulting in hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. A point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of the erythropoietin receptor (EpoR) can lead to hormone-independent activation and tumorigenicity. EpoR is a transmembrane protein involved in erythropoiesis and promotes cell survival and proliferation in response to erythropoietin (Epo) stimulation. However, rare mutations in the exoplasmic domain of EpoR can result in constitutive receptor activation, leading to uncontrolled cellular growth and tumorigenesis. 

This study aimed to investigate the effects of a specific point mutation in the exoplasmic domain of EpoR, known as EpoR-HNS, on receptor signaling and cellular behavior. The researchers found that EpoR-HNS exhibited constitutive activation and promoted cell proliferation, survival, and tumorigenicity in both in vitro and in vivo models. Importantly, EpoR-HNS-mediated signaling bypassed the need for Epo stimulation, indicating hormone-independent activation of the receptor. These findings highlight the importance of the exoplasmic domain of EpoR in maintaining proper receptor function and suggest that mutations in this domain can contribute to the development and progression of certain types of tumors.

How selective is selective posterior rhizotomy? Although selective posterior rhizotomy has become an increasingly utilized surgical treatment for spasticity, the procedure is unstandardized and is performed differently at various medical centers. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) is a surgical treatment option for spasticity that has gained popularity in recent years. However, there is currently no standardized approach to performing the procedure, leading to variations in technique across medical centers. This lack of standardization raises questions about the level of selectivity achieved with SPR. Selectivity refers to the ability to accurately target and divide only the abnormal sensory nerve fibers while preserving the normal ones. The extent of selectivity achieved during SPR can have significant implications for patient outcomes. This review aims to explore the degree of selectivity achieved with SPR by examining the available literature and reported experiences from various medical centers. Understanding the selectivity of SPR is crucial for optimizing patient outcomes and guiding future research and development in this field.

An objective score to predict upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia.  Bladder dysfunction in myelodysplasia may present a significant hazard to the upper tract and a threat to kidney function. Bladder dysfunction in patients with myelodysplasia can lead to upper tract deterioration and potential kidney damage. The identification of reliable predictive markers for monitoring upper tract deterioration is crucial in managing these patients. This study aimed to develop an objective scoring system to predict upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia. Data from 100 patients with myelodysplasia were analyzed, and various clinical and radiological parameters were assessed. The final scoring system included factors such as previous renal surgery, history of urinary tract infection, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux. This scoring system demonstrated good predictive accuracy, with a sensitivity of 80% and a specificity of 85%. Implementation of this scoring system could help identify high-risk patients who require closer monitoring and intervention to prevent upper tract deterioration in myelodysplasia.

Cerebrospinal fluid eicosanoid levels: endogenous PGD2 and LTC4 synthesis by antigen-presenting cells that migrate to the central nervous system. This study examined the synthesis of endogenous prostaglandin D2 (PGD2) and leukotriene C4 (LTC4) by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that migrate to the central nervous system (CNS) through cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF samples were collected from 20 patients with CNS disorders. APCs were isolated from CSF and stimulated with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) to induce PGD2 and LTC4 synthesis. It was found that APCs in CSF were capable of synthesizing both PGD2 and LTC4 upon LPS stimulation. These findings suggest a potential role for endogenous PGD2 and LTC4 in the modulation of immune responses within the CNS and warrant further investigation.

Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract.  Report of a case and literature review. Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract is an extremely rare malignancy, with less than 60 cases reported in the literature. We present a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Radiological investigations revealed a mass in the right main bronchus. Bronchoscopic biopsy revealed poorly differentiated malignant melanoma. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the diagnosis of melanoma, with positive staining for S100, HMB-45, and Melan-A. Further staging investigations ruled out metastatic disease. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and immunotherapy. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient developed metastatic disease to the liver and bone after 10 months of follow-up. Primary malignant melanoma of the lower respiratory tract carries a poor prognosis, with a median survival of less than a year. Early diagnosis and aggressive multimodal treatment strategies are essential in improving outcomes in this rare and aggressive malignancy.

Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid. Solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid are rare, benign thyroid lesions that can present with various clinical features. This retrospective study aims to analyze the clinicopathological characteristics of these lesions in a cohort of 36 patients. The majority of patients were female (75%), with a mean age of 45.4 years. Thyroid nodules were the most common presentation (77.8%), followed by incidental findings on imaging studies (19.4%). Histopathological examination revealed solid nodules in 66.7% of cases and cystic lesions in 33.3% of cases. Immunohistochemistry showed positive calcitonin staining in all cases, confirming the origin from ultimobranchial body remnants. No cases of malignancy or recurrence were observed during the follow-up period. Therefore, the presence of solid and cystic ultimobranchial body remnants in the thyroid can be considered as a benign and clinically non-aggressive condition. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal management and long-term outcomes in these patients.

New active analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity. New analogues of vitamin D with low calcemic activity were developed and studied in vitro and in vivo. The analogues were designed to retain the biological activity of vitamin D while minimizing its calcemic effects. In vitro studies showed that the analogues were able to activate the vitamin D receptor and induce gene expression similar to natural vitamin D. In vivo studies in rats demonstrated that the analogues had reduced effects on calcium metabolism compared to natural vitamin D. Furthermore, the analogues showed improved metabolic stability, making them potential candidates for further development as therapeutic agents with low calcemic activity. These findings suggest that these new analogues of vitamin D have the potential to be used in the treatment of vitamin D deficiency and related disorders with reduced risk of hypercalcemia.

Meropenem pharmacokinetics and penetration into an inflammatory exudate.  The pharmacokinetics and penetration into a cantharidine-induced inflammatory exudate of meropenem was studied in six volunteers following a single 1-g intravenous dose. A study was conducted to examine the pharmacokinetics and penetration of meropenem into a cantharidine-induced inflammatory exudate in six volunteers. Each volunteer received a single 1-g intravenous dose of meropenem. The pharmacokinetic parameters, including plasma and exudate concentrations, were determined over a specific time period. The results revealed that meropenem exhibited good penetration into the inflammatory exudate, with concentrations in the exudate reaching similar levels to those in plasma. These findings suggest that meropenem may be an effective treatment option for infections associated with inflammatory exudates. Further research is needed to evaluate its clinical efficacy in this context.

Granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma. Granulomatous prostatitis is an uncommon inflammatory condition of the prostate gland that can mimic prostate carcinoma clinically and histologically. We present a case of a 62-year-old male with a history of urinary symptoms who underwent a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy. Histopathological analysis revealed granulomatous prostatitis with prominent multinucleated giant cells and epithelioid granulomas. However, concurrent poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma was also identified in a separate biopsy core. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the prostatic origin of the poorly differentiated carcinoma. The coexistence of granulomatous prostatitis and poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma is a rare finding, and their occurrence in the same patient emphasizes the importance of careful histopathological evaluation and consideration of coexistent pathology. This case underscores the need for comprehensive management strategies that take into account the potential for concurrent diseases when evaluating patients with prostatic lesions.

Multiple gunshot wounds of the head: an anthropological view.  A decomposed body was judged at the scene to have two gunshot wounds of the thorax and three of the head. This report presents a case of a decomposed body with multiple gunshot wounds, including two in the thorax and three in the head. An anthropological view is provided, focusing on the examination of the head wounds. The location and characteristics of the gunshot wounds are discussed, highlighting their potential causes and implications. Additionally, forensic analysis techniques used in evaluating the wounds are described. The findings from this case emphasize the importance of careful examination and documentation of gunshot wounds, as they can provide valuable information regarding the circumstances and manner of death. Further research and expertise in forensic anthropology can aid in the interpretation of such cases.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory infections in young children from Thailand. Acute respiratory infections (ARIs) are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in young children worldwide, particularly in developing countries. This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology of ARIs in children aged 鈮5 years in Thailand. Data from a retrospective review of medical records of children admitted to a tertiary hospital with a diagnosis of ARI between January 2015 and December 2019 were analyzed. A total of 2,563 cases were included in the analysis. The mean age of the children was 19 months, and 55% were male. The most common presenting symptoms were cough (78%), fever (69%), and nasal congestion (53%).
