The majority of cases (62%) were diagnosed as viral ARIs, with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) being the most commonly identified viral pathogen (45% of viral cases). Bacterial infections accounted for 16% of cases, with Streptococcus pneumoniae being the most prevalent bacterial pathogen (37% of bacterial cases). Overall, the findings highlight the burden of ARIs in young Thai children and the importance of both viral and bacterial pathogens in causing these infections.

Arterial responses during migraine headache. Migraine headache is a complex neurological disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. While the pathophysiology of migraine is still not fully understood, it is believed that abnormal arterial responses may play a role in the development and progression of this condition. This study aimed to investigate the arterial responses during a migraine headache by analyzing arterial blood flow velocities using Doppler ultrasound. A total of 50 patients with a history of migraine headaches were recruited, and their arterial blood flow velocities were measured during a migraine attack and compared to baseline measurements. The results showed a significant increase in blood flow velocity in the middle cerebral artery during a migraine attack compared to baseline, suggesting that aberrant arterial responses may contribute to the pathophysiology of migraine headache. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted therapeutic interventions for migraine patients.

Expression of P-glycoprotein in adult T-cell leukemia cells. P-glycoprotein (P-gp) is a membrane transporter protein that plays a crucial role in multidrug resistance (MDR) in cancer cells. Adult T-cell leukemia (ATL) is an aggressive form of T-cell lymphoma that is often refractory to chemotherapy due to MDR. This study aimed to investigate the expression of P-gp in ATL cells and its potential as a therapeutic target. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that P-gp was highly expressed in ATL cells compared to normal T cells. Moreover, immunohistochemistry staining confirmed P-gp expression in ATL patient samples. Inhibition of P-gp using specific inhibitors resulted in increased sensitivity of ATL cells to chemotherapy drugs. These findings suggest that P-gp contributes to MDR in ATL and targeting P-gp could enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy in ATL treatment.

Effect of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of indomethacin on the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis in rabbits. Meningitis was induced by intracisternal injection of Streptococcus pneumoniae. The rabbits were divided into two groups: a control group and an indomethacin-treated group. Indomethacin was administered intraperitoneally. The results showed that indomethacin treatment significantly reduced cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leukocyte count, CSF protein concentration, and blood-brain barrier permeability compared to the control group. Additionally, indomethacin treatment attenuated the increase in CSF lactate levels and reduced brain edema. These findings suggest that indomethacin may have beneficial effects in the pathophysiology of experimental meningitis by reducing inflammation and improving blood-brain barrier integrity. Further investigations are needed to explore its potential therapeutic implications in human meningitis.

Anti-Kveim monoclonal antibody.  New monoclonal antibody reacting to epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. The diagnosis of sarcoidosis is often challenging and relies on histologic examination of biopsy specimens. Currently, there are no specific immunohistochemical markers for the identification of sarcoid granulomas. In this study, the authors describe the development of a new monoclonal antibody, called Anti-Kveim, that reacts specifically with epithelioid cells in sarcoid granulomas. Immunohistochemical analysis using Anti-Kveim antibody was performed on biopsy specimens from 20 patients with suspected sarcoidosis and 10 control patients with other granulomatous diseases. The results showed that Anti-Kveim antibody staining was positive in 18 out of 20 sarcoidosis cases, with strong staining intensity observed specifically in epithelioid cells within the granulomas. Importantly, no staining was detected in the control group. These findings suggest that Anti-Kveim antibody may serve as a valuable diagnostic tool for the identification of sarcoid granulomas, helping to differentiate sarcoidosis from other granulomatous diseases. Further studies are warranted to validate its efficacy in larger patient cohorts.

Speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing before and after orthognathic surgery.  Articulation, voice, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were examined in 34 patients before and 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after orthognathic surgery. This study aimed to assess the impact of orthognathic surgery on speech, velopharyngeal function, and hearing in 34 patients. Articulation, voice quality, resonance, hearing sensitivity, and middle ear function were evaluated preoperatively and at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months postoperatively. The results showed significant improvements in speech and velopharyngeal function at all postoperative time points. Articulation and voice quality were found to be significantly improved at 3 months and continued to show improvements over time. Resonance also showed improvements at all postoperative time points, with the greatest improvement observed at 6 months. Hearing sensitivity remained stable throughout the study period, and there were no significant changes in middle ear function. These findings suggest that orthognathic surgery has beneficial effects on speech and velopharyngeal function, with early improvements seen in articulation and voice quality. However, no significant changes were observed in hearing sensitivity or middle ear function.

Effect of hydrocele on testis and spermatogenesis. Hydrocele, a common condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the scrotum, has been associated with adverse effects on testis and spermatogenesis. This study aimed to assess the impact of hydrocele on testicular function. A total of 50 patients with hydrocele and 50 age-matched controls were included in the study. Testicular volume, serum levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), testosterone, and sperm parameters were evaluated. The results revealed a significantly decreased testicular volume and sperm count in patients with hydrocele compared to controls. Furthermore, FSH and LH levels were significantly elevated, while testosterone levels were significantly decreased in hydrocele patients. These findings suggest that hydrocele adversely affects testicular function and spermatogenesis.

Lymph node metastasis from papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma in young patients.  A total of 117 patients under 20 years of age with papillary and/or follicular thyroid cancer presented to the M. Lymph node metastasis is an important factor in determining the prognosis and management of papillary-follicular thyroid carcinoma (PTC) in young patients. In this study, 117 patients under 20 years of age with PTC were examined. The presence of lymph node metastasis was evaluated using preoperative imaging and confirmed by histopathological examination. The overall rate of lymph node metastasis was found to be 63.2%. Furthermore, the metastatic rate was significantly higher in patients with multifocal tumors compared to those with unifocal tumors. The presence of lymph node metastasis was also associated with a higher risk of recurrence and distant metastasis. These findings highlight the importance of thorough staging and surveillance in the management of PTC in young patients.

Urogenital dysfunction after abdominoperineal resection for carcinoma of the rectum. Urogenital dysfunction is a common complication following abdominoperineal resection (APR) for carcinoma of the rectum. This study aims to evaluate the incidence and risk factors associated with urogenital dysfunction in patients undergoing APR. The authors conducted a retrospective analysis of patients who underwent APR for rectal carcinoma between 2010 and 2019. Urogenital dysfunction, including urinary incontinence and sexual dysfunction, was assessed using validated questionnaires. Of the 150 patients included in the study, 45% reported urinary incontinence and 56% reported sexual dysfunction. The risk factors significantly associated with urogenital dysfunction were female gender, advanced age, tumor location, and neoadjuvant radiotherapy. These findings highlight the importance of comprehensive preoperative counseling, patient education, and close follow-up for urogenital dysfunction in patients undergoing APR for rectal carcinoma.

A blood-liquid interface for prolonged extracorporeal oxygenation with excellent antithrombogenicity. Extracorporeal oxygenation is a medical technique used to provide prolonged oxygen support for patients with respiratory failure. However, a major limitation is the risk of clot formation and subsequent thrombosis, which can cause significant complications. In this study, a novel blood-liquid interface was developed for extracorporeal oxygenation, aiming to improve antithrombogenicity. The interface was created using a combination of surface modification techniques, introducing a hydrophilic coating and antiplatelet agent. The performance of the interface was evaluated in vitro using human blood samples, showing excellent antithrombogenicity and reduced clot formation compared to conventional interfaces. This promising result suggests the potential of this blood-liquid interface for safer and more effective extracorporeal oxygenation in clinical settings.

A topographical relationship between Helicobacter pylori and gastritis: quantitative assessment of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa.  A topographical relationship between the number of Helicobacter pylori in the gastric mucosa and the histological severity of gastritis was studied in 902 pairs of biopsy specimens taken from 314 patients. This study aimed to assess the topographical relationship between the number of Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) in the gastric mucosa and the severity of gastritis. A total of 902 pairs of biopsy specimens from 314 patients were analyzed. The results showed a significant correlation between the density of H. pylori and the extent of gastritis. The number of H. pylori was higher in areas with severe gastritis compared to areas with mild gastritis. Furthermore, the distribution of H. pylori was not uniform throughout the gastric mucosa, with higher density observed in the antrum compared to the corpus. These findings suggest that the quantitative assessment of H. pylori can provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis and management of gastritis.

Evaluation of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of argon laser surgery in children under 13 years of age. A total of 50 pediatric patients with various pathologies underwent argon laser surgery, including vascular malformations, hemangiomas, and vocal cord lesions. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia, with the use of a fiberoptic bronchoscope or endoscope for better visualization. The outcomes were assessed based on intraoperative and postoperative complications, as well as disease recurrence. The results demonstrated an overall success rate of 92%, with minimal complications reported, including minimal bleeding and transient voice changes. No significant recurrence was observed during the follow-up period. Thus, argon laser surgery appears to be a safe and effective treatment modality for various pathologies in children under 13 years of age.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a challenging procedure in liver surgery, often associated with a high risk of thrombosis and subsequent complications. The use of antithrombogenic catheter technology may help reduce this risk. In this study, we present a case series of seven patients who underwent portal vein resection using a new antithrombogenic catheter. The catheter was composed of a heparin-coated silicone material, designed to minimize the formation of thrombi. The patients were carefully monitored for postoperative complications, including thrombosis and liver dysfunction. No thrombotic events were observed, and all patients had optimal liver function postoperatively. Additionally, no catheter-related complications were reported. These preliminary results suggest that the use of this new antithrombogenic catheter may be a safe and effective approach to reduce the risk of thrombosis in patients undergoing portal vein resection. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings.

Pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules.  A report of a case with immunohistochemical study. We report a case of pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with pseudosarcomatous mural nodules and provide an immunohistochemical study for further characterization. The patient, a 52-year-old female, presented with non-specific abdominal pain and imaging revealed a cystic mass in the pancreas. The histopathological examination revealed the presence of mucinous cystadenocarcinoma with focal pseudosarcomatous mural nodules showing spindle cell morphology. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated positive staining for cytokeratin, CA19-9, and MUC1, confirming the epithelial origin of the tumor cells. Additionally, the spindle cells within the pseudosarcomatous nodules showed positivity for vimentin and smooth muscle actin, suggesting a myofibroblastic differentiation. This case highlights the rare occurrence of pseudosarcomatous mural nodules in pancreatic mucinous cystadenocarcinoma and emphasizes the importance of immunohistochemistry in confirming the diagnosis and understanding the histogenesis of such lesions. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the clinical significance and potential therapeutic implications of these nodules in pancreatic neoplasms.

Argon green (514 nm) versus krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation for diffuse diabetic macular edema. Diabetic macular edema is a common complication of diabetes that can lead to significant vision loss. Laser photocoagulation has been a standard treatment, with different laser wavelengths used to target the affected area. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of argon green (514 nm) and krypton red (647 nm) modified grid laser photocoagulation in the treatment of diffuse diabetic macular edema. 

A total of 60 patients with clinically significant diffuse diabetic macular edema were included in this randomized controlled trial. The patients were divided into two groups: one group underwent argon green laser treatment, while the other group received krypton red laser treatment. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central macular thickness (CMT) were measured at baseline and at 6-month and 12-month follow-up visits.

Results showed significant improvements in BCVA and reduction in CMT in both groups after treatment. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in terms of BCVA improvement or CMT reduction at any of the follow-up visits.

In conclusion, both argon green and krypton red laser photocoagulation were effective in improving vision and reducing macular thickness in patients with diffuse diabetic macular edema. The choice of laser wavelength may not significantly impact treatment outcomes in this population. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

The febrile alcoholic in the emergency department. The febrile alcoholic is a common presentation in the emergency department and poses a diagnostic challenge. This retrospective study aimed to determine the clinical characteristics, etiology, and outcomes of febrile alcoholic patients presenting to the emergency department. A total of 250 patients were included in the study. The most common clinical characteristics were fever (100%), altered mental status (72%), and respiratory distress (60%). The main etiology of fever was infection, with pneumonia being the most common source. Other etiologies included cellulitis, urinary tract infection, and bacteremia. Overall, the mortality rate was 14%. The study highlighted the importance of prompt diagnosis and appropriate management in febrile alcoholic patients, as it can significantly impact outcomes. Further research is needed to identify strategies for early recognition and intervention in this population.

Effect of felbamate on plasma levels of carbamazepine and its metabolites.  Felbamate (FBM) is a novel antiepileptic drug (AED) currently undergoing clinical evaluation in the United States. The effect of felbamate (FBM) on plasma levels of carbamazepine (CBZ) and its metabolites was studied in individuals with epilepsy. FBM is a new antiepileptic drug that is being evaluated clinically in the US. CBZ, an established AED, is commonly used to control seizures. Drug-drug interactions are a major concern when combining multiple AEDs. The study found that FBM significantly reduced plasma levels of CBZ and its active metabolite, carbamazepine-10,11-epoxide (CBZ-E). This decrease was attributed to FBM inducing hepatic enzymes responsible for CBZ metabolism. The interaction between FBM and CBZ may have important clinical implications, as subtherapeutic levels of CBZ can lead to breakthrough seizures, while excessive CBZ levels can cause toxicities. Close monitoring of plasma CBZ levels and adjusted dosing may be necessary when co-administering FBM with CBZ. Further research is needed to fully understand the clinical significance of this interaction and optimize dosing regimens.

Cortical tremor: a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus. Cortical tremor is a rare form of movement disorder characterized by involuntary rhythmic contractions of muscles, primarily affecting the limbs. This study presents a case series of 12 patients diagnosed with cortical tremor. All patients exhibited rhythmic, high-frequency tremors, which were predominantly asymmetrical and occurred during voluntary movement. Electromyography showed rhythmic bursts of activity, suggesting a cortical origin of the tremors. None of the patients had a family history of movement disorders. Pharmacological treatment with antiepileptic drugs provided partial symptomatic relief in most cases. The findings of this study suggest that cortical tremor may represent a variant of cortical reflex myoclonus, highlighting the importance of differentiating these conditions for optimal management and treatment outcomes.

Angioedema from angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors: a cause of upper airway obstruction. Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are commonly used for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. Although generally well tolerated, they can rarely cause angioedema, which can lead to upper airway obstruction and potential respiratory compromise. This case report describes a patient who developed angioedema shortly after starting treatment with an ACE inhibitor. The angioedema primarily affected the patient's lips, tongue, and uvula, leading to difficulty in swallowing and breathing. Prompt recognition and management of this adverse event is crucial to prevent potential life-threatening complications. In severe cases, airway management and supportive measures such as administration of epinephrine and corticosteroids may be necessary. It is important for healthcare providers to be aware of this potential complication when prescribing ACE inhibitors to prevent delay in diagnosis and appropriate management of angioedema.

Transbronchial biopsies in children after heart-lung transplantation.  Sixty transbronchial biopsies have been performed in eight children after heart-lung transplantation. Transbronchial biopsies are commonly performed in adults after heart-lung transplantation to monitor for rejection and other complications. However, limited data exist on the utility and safety of this procedure in children. In this retrospective study, we examine the experience of transbronchial biopsies in eight pediatric patients who underwent heart-lung transplantation. A total of sixty biopsies were performed in these patients. The procedure was technically feasible and well-tolerated, with no major complications reported. Histopathological analysis of the biopsies revealed evidence of acute cellular rejection in 25% of cases. Additionally, other findings included interstitial fibrosis, bronchiolitis obliterans, and infections. Our findings suggest that transbronchial biopsies can be safely performed in children after heart-lung transplantation, providing valuable information regarding rejection and other pulmonary complications. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and efficacy of this procedure in this specific population.

Optimal interpretation of the supine exercise electrocardiogram in patients with right bundle branch block. Patients with right bundle branch block (RBBB) often present challenges in interpreting exercise electrocardiograms (ECGs). This study aimed to determine the optimal interpretation of supine exercise ECGs in patients with RBBB. A total of 100 patients with RBBB were included in the study and underwent a supine exercise stress test. ECGs were analyzed for changes in ST segment, T wave, QRS morphology, and heart rate response. The results showed that 60% of patients with RBBB exhibited changes in ST segment and T wave during exercise. These changes were primarily seen in leads V2-V6. It was also observed that 30% of patients had an abnormal QRS morphology during exercise. The heart rate response in patients with RBBB varied, with some patients demonstrating an exaggerated response and others showing a blunted response. Based on these findings, it can be concluded that careful interpretation of ST segment, T wave, QRS morphology, and heart rate response is essential in identifying potential ischemic changes in patients with RBBB during exercise.

Use of a knee-brace for control of tibial translation and rotation. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a knee-brace in controlling tibial translation and rotation. Twenty-five patients with symptomatic knee instability were included in the study. Kinematic analysis was performed during walking and running, both with and without the knee-brace. The results showed that the knee-brace significantly reduced tibial translation and rotation during both activities. The average reduction in tibial translation was 3.5mm during walking and 4.2mm during running, while the average reduction in tibial rotation was 4.1° during walking and 5.3° during running. These findings suggest that the use of a knee-brace can effectively control tibial translation and rotation, providing stability and potentially reducing symptoms in patients with knee instability.

Limitation of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization using iodized oil for small hepatocellular carcinoma. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) using iodized oil is a common treatment option for small hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). However, its effectiveness and limitations are not well understood. This study aimed to evaluate the limitations of TACE using iodized oil for small HCC. A total of 50 patients with small HCC underwent TACE using iodized oil and were followed up for a median of 18 months. The results showed that TACE using iodized oil had a limited effect on tumor eradication, with only 54% of patients achieving complete response. The major limitation was the occurrence of liver damage, with 24% of patients developing liver dysfunction. In conclusion, TACE using iodized oil is limited in its effectiveness and can lead to liver damage in patients with small HCC. Alternative treatment modalities should be considered for better outcomes.

Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction presenting as ascites: the importance of clinically assessing central venous pressure. Ascites is a common finding in patients with liver disease, but it can also be caused by other conditions such as heart failure. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction, characterized by impaired relaxation and filling of the left ventricle, is a known cause of ascites. However, its diagnosis can be challenging as symptoms may be subtle or nonspecific. We present a case of a patient with ascites who was found to have left ventricular diastolic dysfunction on echocardiography. Importantly, we highlight the significance of clinically assessing central venous pressure as it can help differentiate between liver-related and cardiac-related ascites. This case underscores the need for a comprehensive evaluation of patients with ascites to accurately diagnose and manage the underlying cause.

Cutaneous manifestations of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy that often presents with bone pain, anemia, and renal insufficiency. Cutaneous involvement is uncommon, occurring in approximately 4% of cases. The most common cutaneous manifestation is plasmacytomas, which are solitary or multiple reddish-purple nodules or plaques. In addition, amyloid deposition may lead to skin findings such as purpura, ecchymosis, and subcutaneous nodules. Other less common cutaneous manifestations include bullous lesions, acquired ichthyosis, and scleromyxedema. These cutaneous findings can be an important clue to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma, particularly in cases where the systemic symptoms are subtle or absent. Dermatologists should be familiar with these manifestations in order to aid in early recognition and appropriate management of multiple myeloma.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. Acute childhood diarrhea is a common condition that requires appropriate dietary management for optimal recovery. This study aimed to investigate the optimal timing of feeding and the appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the management of acute childhood diarrhea. A total of 200 children aged 6 months to 5 years were included in the study. The children were randomly assigned to two groups: an early feeding group and a delayed feeding group. The early feeding group received a regular diet with milk immediately after rehydration, while the delayed feeding group received a gradual introduction of diet after 24 hours of rehydration. The results showed that the early feeding group had a significantly shorter duration of diarrhea compared to the delayed feeding group (p<0.05). Additionally, the type of milk used did not have a significant impact on the duration of diarrhea. In conclusion, early feeding with a regular diet and milk after rehydration is beneficial in managing acute childhood diarrhea.

Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis: is there a generalised autoimmune gut disorder? Children with protracted diarrhoea, circulating enterocyte autoantibodies, and an enteropathy showing features of inappropriate HLA molecule expression on the jejunal crypt epithelium, often present with persistent blood and mucus in their stools. Autoimmune enteropathy and colitis are conditions characterized by persistent diarrhea, blood, and mucus in stools, along with the presence of circulating enterocyte autoantibodies. These conditions are often observed in children and are associated with inappropriate expression of HLA molecules on the jejunal crypt epithelium. This suggests the existence of a generalized autoimmune gut disorder. However, the pathogenesis and underlying mechanisms of these conditions remain unclear. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and develop effective treatments for these debilitating gastrointestinal disorders. Recognition of these conditions is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis and to provide appropriate management for affected individuals.

Renal effects of cyclosporine. Cyclosporine is commonly used as an immunosuppressive agent in organ transplantation. However, its use is associated with various adverse effects, including renal dysfunction. To evaluate the renal effects of cyclosporine, we conducted a study involving 20 renal transplant recipients who had been on cyclosporine therapy for at least 6 months. Renal function was assessed by measuring serum creatinine levels and calculating creatinine clearance. The results showed a significant decline in renal function in the study population, with a mean decrease in creatinine clearance of 23% and a mean increase in serum creatinine of 0.4 mg/dL. These findings indicate that cyclosporine therapy is associated with renal dysfunction in renal transplant recipients, highlighting the importance of close monitoring and careful management of renal function in patients receiving this medication.

Indications of the carbon dioxide laser in tracheobronchial pathology of the infant and young child: 14 cases.  Fourteen children aged between 6 months and 7 years (mean age = 3. This study presents 14 cases of infants and young children with tracheobronchial pathology where the carbon dioxide laser was used as a treatment modality. The patients, with a mean age of 3.9 years, presented with various conditions such as granulation tissue, tracheal stenosis, and tracheobronchomalacia. The carbon dioxide laser was found to be effective in treating these pathologies, achieving successful outcomes in all cases. The laser provided precise tissue ablation with reduced risk of thermal injury, leading to improved airway patency and symptom resolution. In addition, the carbon dioxide laser allowed for enhanced visualization and accessibility in the pediatric airway. This study highlights the indications and benefits of using the carbon dioxide laser as a valuable tool in the management of tracheobronchial pathology in infants and young children.

Ciliary motility in two patients with yellow nail syndrome and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Yellow nail syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by yellowish discoloration and impaired growth of the nails, along with lymphedema and respiratory abnormalities. We report two cases of yellow nail syndrome presenting with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and investigate ciliary motility in these patients. In both cases, nasal brushing samples were obtained and ciliary beat frequency (CBF) was measured using high-speed video microscopy. Both patients demonstrated decreased CBF compared to healthy controls, indicating impaired ciliary motility. These findings suggest that ciliary dysfunction may contribute to the respiratory manifestations in yellow nail syndrome. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic interventions for improving ciliary function in these patients.

Interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress in young adults.  The interaction of sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity was studied in white and black young adults aged 18-23 years. This study investigated the interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity in young adults aged 18-23 years. Both white and black individuals were included in the study. Sodium sensitivity refers to the body's response to changes in sodium intake, which can affect blood pressure and cardiovascular health. Stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity refers to the body's response to stressors, which can also impact cardiovascular function. The results of the study showed that there was a significant interaction between sodium sensitivity and stress-induced cardiovascular reactivity. This suggests that individuals who are sodium sensitive may experience a greater cardiovascular response to stress. These findings may have implications for understanding and managing cardiovascular health in young adults.

Familial trigeminal neuralgia and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. Familial trigeminal neuralgia (TN) and Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy (CMT) are two distinct neurological disorders that have been reported to coexist within families. We present a case of a patient with both familial TN and CMT, highlighting the potential overlap and genetic implications of these conditions. The patient presented with typical TN symptoms, including paroxysmal facial pain, and was subsequently diagnosed with CMT based on bilateral foot drop and characteristic electromyography findings. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the CMT-associated gene, suggesting a possible genetic link between the two conditions. This case underscores the importance of considering a multidisciplinary approach in the evaluation and management of patients with familial TN and CMT, as well as the need for further research to elucidate the genetic mechanisms underlying the coexistence of these disorders.

Clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy. The intratesticular arterial anatomy plays a crucial role in testicular function and can have significant clinical implications. This study aimed to investigate the clinical significance of intratesticular arterial anatomy in male patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 patients who underwent scrotal color Doppler ultrasound examination. The intratesticular arterial anatomy was assessed, and correlations with various clinical parameters were analyzed. The results showed significant associations between specific patterns of intratesticular arterial anatomy and testicular function, including testosterone levels, spermatogenesis, and testicular volume. Additionally, abnormal intratesticular arterial anatomy was found to be associated with certain testicular pathologies, such as testicular torsion and male infertility. These findings highlight the importance of assessing intratesticular arterial anatomy in the evaluation and management of male patients with testicular disorders. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential therapeutic implications of targeted interventions based on intratesticular arterial anatomy.

Impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. Enteritis necroticans is a severe and potentially lethal infection caused by Clostridium perfringens type C. This study aimed to assess the impact of active immunisation against enteritis necroticans in Papua New Guinea. A total of 500 individuals, aged 1-30 years, were included in the study. Vaccination was performed using a C. perfringens type C toxoid vaccine. Participants were followed up for a period of 3 years to assess the incidence and severity of enteritis necroticans. The results showed a significant reduction in the incidence of enteritis necroticans in the vaccinated group compared to the control group. Furthermore, the severity of the disease was milder in vaccinated individuals. These findings suggest that active immunisation against enteritis necroticans can have a substantial impact on reducing the burden of this infection in Papua New Guinea.

Increased MEPP frequency as an early sign of experimental immune-mediated motoneuron disease. Delayed metastases of cutaneous melanoma are rare but well-documented in the literature. Only 24 cases, including our own, have been clearly reported. We present a case of a 56-year-old woman with a 1.2 mm acral lentiginous melanoma on the right hand, who developed a subcutaneous metastasis in the right arm 13 years after excision and postoperative irradiation. One year later, the patient succumbed to disseminated bone metastases. This case, similar to others with delayed metastases, shares common characteristics such as being female, having a primary tumor thickness between 1.2 and 2.5 mm, and the metastasis occurring in a location other than the back, arm, neck, or scalp. These findings emphasize the need for long-term surveillance and monitoring of patients with invasive cutaneous melanoma, even after apparently successful treatment, particularly in those with specific risk factors.

Definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates.  Mandibular defects following radical cancer surgery continue to provide challenges to head and neck surgeons. Mandibular defects resulting from radical cancer surgery present ongoing challenges for head and neck surgeons. This study aimed to assess the efficacy and outcomes of definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent mandibular resection due to cancer and subsequent primary mandibular reconstruction using reconstruction plates. Functional outcomes, complications, and patient satisfaction were evaluated. Of the 30 patients included in the study, all experienced improvement in function and aesthetic appearance following surgery. However, complications such as plate exposure, infection, and implant failure were observed in a subset of patients. Despite these complications, patient satisfaction remained high. In conclusion, definitive mandibular replacement using reconstruction plates can provide favorable functional and aesthetic results for patients with mandibular defects. However, careful consideration should be given to potential complications and appropriate patient selection.

Auras and subclinical seizures: characteristics and prognostic significance. Auras and subclinical seizures have been recognized as important clinical manifestations of epilepsy, serving as potential predictors of seizure activity and overall prognosis. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics and prognostic significance of auras and subclinical seizures in patients with epilepsy. A total of 150 patients were included in this prospective cohort study, and their clinical data were collected over a period of 2 years. Results showed that auras were reported by 70% of patients, with the most common aura types being visual, auditory, and somatosensory sensations. Subclinical seizures were observed in 45% of patients, predominantly manifesting as automatisms and altered consciousness. The presence of auras and subclinical seizures was associated with a significantly higher risk of developing generalized tonic-clonic seizures and a poorer overall seizure control. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing and monitoring auras and subclinical seizures in patients with epilepsy, as they can provide valuable insights into the disease course and aid in the management and prognosis of the condition.

Auditory-evoked responses in benign intracranial hypertension syndrome. Benign intracranial hypertension syndrome (BIHS) is a condition characterized by increased intracranial pressure without an identifiable cause. This study aimed to investigate auditory-evoked responses in patients with BIHS. Thirty-five patients with BIHS and 30 healthy controls underwent auditory brainstem response (ABR) testing. The ABR waveforms were analyzed for wave V latency, interpeak latency I-V, and amplitude ratio I/V. The results showed significantly prolonged wave V latency and interpeak latency I-V in patients with BIHS compared to controls. However, there was no significant difference in the amplitude ratio I/V between the two groups. These findings suggest that BIHS is associated with delayed neural conduction in the auditory pathway. ABR testing may be useful in the diagnosis and monitoring of BIHS. Further research is warranted to explore the potential role of auditory-evoked responses in the management of BIHS.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. The aim of this study was to evaluate the outcomes of partial patellectomy in the treatment of displaced patellar fractures. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent partial patellectomy for displaced patellar fractures between 2010 and 2015. A total of 35 patients were included in the study. The mean follow-up period was 28 months. Clinical and radiological evaluations were performed to assess the outcomes of the procedure. The results showed that partial patellectomy led to satisfactory functional outcomes in the majority of cases. Union was achieved in all patients, with an average time of 12 weeks. However, complications such as knee pain, extensor lag, and limited range of motion were observed in a subset of patients. Overall, partial patellectomy showed promising results in the management of displaced patellar fractures, but careful patient selection and close postoperative monitoring are crucial to minimize complications and optimize outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Prolonged confusion following convulsions due to generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus.  Among patients with a prolonged confusional state after convulsive seizure, we diagnosed 8 cases as generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus. In patients with prolonged confusion following convulsions, a diagnosis of generalized nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) was made in 8 cases. NCSE is a condition where seizure activity occurs without overt motor manifestations and may present as altered mental status. The clinical presentation can vary, making diagnosis challenging. Electroencephalography (EEG) is a valuable tool in confirming the diagnosis. Prompt recognition and treatment of NCSE are crucial as it can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if left untreated. Antiepileptic medications, such as intravenous benzodiazepines and antiepileptic drugs, are key in the management of NCSE. Further studies are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize treatment strategies for this condition.

Clinical and manometric aspects of diffuse esophageal spasm in a cohort of subjects evaluated for dysphagia and/or chest pain. Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder characterized by uncoordinated muscle contractions in the esophagus. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and manometric aspects of DES in a cohort of individuals presenting with dysphagia and/or chest pain. A total of 58 subjects were included in the study and underwent high-resolution esophageal manometry. The most common presenting symptom was dysphagia, followed by chest pain. Manometric findings showed simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus in 67% of cases, with a mean distal contractile integral of 573.9 卤 336.4 mmHg路cm路s. Atypical chest pain was more frequently associated with DES compared to dysphagia alone. In conclusion, DES is a common cause of dysphagia and chest pain, with manometric findings revealing simultaneous contractions. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and management of this condition.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. Portal vein resection is a challenging surgical procedure often complicated by thrombosis. We present a case of successful portal vein resection using a novel antithrombogenic catheter. The patient, a 57-year-old male with hepatocellular carcinoma involving the portal vein, underwent tumor resection and portal vein reconstruction. To prevent thrombosis, we utilized a newly developed catheter coated with a heparin-binding peptide. The catheter effectively deterred clot formation, as demonstrated by absence of thrombus on imaging studies postoperatively. Additionally, the patient did not experience any thromboembolic complications during the perioperative period. This case demonstrates the feasibility and potential benefits of using antithrombogenic catheters during portal vein resection. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the effectiveness of this technique in preventing thrombosis and improving patient outcomes in larger cohorts.

T cell subsets (Tc, Th, Ts, Tsi) and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of alcoholic hepatitis. Alcoholic hepatitis (AH) is a severe form of liver disease characterized by inflammation and necrosis, and it is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The immune response in AH is thought to play a crucial role in disease progression. T cell subsets, including cytotoxic T cells (Tc), T helper cells (Th), regulatory T cells (Ts), and IL2 receptor-bearing cells (Tsi), may have different impacts on the immune response and disease outcomes in AH. In this study, we examined the percentages and absolute counts of these T cell subsets and IL2 receptor-bearing cells in the peripheral blood of patients in the acute phase of AH. Our findings provide insights into the immune dysregulation in AH and may have implications for future therapeutic interventions.

Biology of basal cell carcinoma (Part I). Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer. This review article aims to provide an overview of the biology of BCC, focusing on its development and progression. BCC arises from basal cells in the epidermis and is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation. Multiple genetic and environmental factors contribute to its development, including mutations in tumor suppressor genes and chronic exposure to ultraviolet radiation. The Hedgehog signaling pathway plays a critical role in the growth of BCC, and targeted therapies that inhibit this pathway have been effective in treating advanced BCC. Understanding the underlying biology of BCC is essential for the development of new strategies for prevention and treatment.

Ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging in Leigh disease. Leigh disease is a rare neurological disorder that primarily affects infants and young children. This study aimed to determine the diagnostic value of ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in identifying characteristic brain abnormalities in Leigh disease. Twenty-three patients diagnosed with Leigh disease underwent both ultrasonography and MRI. Ultrasonography revealed hyperechoic lesions in the basal ganglia and brainstem, while MRI showed symmetrical T2 hyperintensities in the basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellar white matter. The concordance rate between ultrasonography and MRI findings was 91.3%. In conclusion, both ultrasonography and MRI are valuable imaging modalities for diagnosing Leigh disease, with ultrasonography being particularly useful in initial screening due to its convenience and cost-effectiveness.

Subtrochanteric fractures treated with interlocking nailing.  In a prospective study of 31 subtrochanteric fractures treated with Grosse-Kempf interlocking nails with a followup period of at least 1 year, there was a 87. 1% (27/31) union rate, and a union period of 4. A prospective study was conducted to evaluate the outcomes of Grosse-Kempf interlocking nailing for the treatment of subtrochanteric fractures. Thirty-one patients with subtrochanteric fractures were followed up for at least 1 year. The union rate was 87.1% (27/31), indicating successful bone healing. The average union period was 4.4 months, demonstrating a relatively short time for bone fusion. This suggests that interlocking nailing is an effective treatment option for subtrochanteric fractures, leading to a high rate of union and a relatively quick recovery. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings and assess long-term outcomes. Overall, interlocking nailing shows promise in the management of subtrochanteric fractures.

Isolated calf venous thrombosis: diagnosis with compression US. Isolated calf venous thrombosis (ICVT) is a common condition that can lead to serious complications if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Compression ultrasound (US) has emerged as a reliable method for the diagnosis of ICVT. This study aimed to determine the diagnostic accuracy of compression US in detecting ICVT. A total of 120 patients with suspected ICVT were included in the study. Compression US was performed on all patients, and the results were compared to the gold standard of venography. The sensitivity and specificity of compression US for detecting ICVT were 94% and 98%, respectively. The positive predictive value was 95% and the negative predictive value was 97%. These findings demonstrate that compression US is an effective tool for the diagnosis of ICVT, allowing for early intervention and prevention of potentially serious complications.

Life-threatening complications during anaesthesia in a patient with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):241] A 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt is described. We present a case of a 6-year-old patient with hydrocephalus who underwent revision of a ventriculo-atrial shunt. The patient had a pre-existing condition of pulmonary hypertension. During anesthesia, the patient experienced life-threatening complications. Although a detailed description of the complications is not provided in the abstract, this case highlights the potential risks associated with anesthesia in patients with a ventriculo-atrial shunt and pulmonary hypertension. This case report serves as a reminder for anesthesiologists to carefully consider the potential complications and manage these patients with caution to ensure patient safety.

Resting metabolic rate and energy balance in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic runners. The resting metabolic rate (RMR) and energy balance were examined in amenorrheic and eumenorrheic female runners. Fifteen amenorrheic and 15 eumenorrheic runners were enrolled in the study. RMR was measured using indirect calorimetry, and energy balance was determined by comparing dietary intake and exercise expenditure. The amenorrheic runners had a significantly higher RMR compared to the eumenorrheic runners. However, there was no significant difference in energy balance between the two groups. The amenorrheic runners consumed more calories than the eumenorrheic runners, but also had higher exercise expenditure. The findings suggest that the increased RMR in amenorrheic runners does not lead to a higher energy balance, as they compensate for the increased energy expenditure by consuming more calories. These results highlight the importance of considering both energy intake and expenditure in understanding the metabolic differences between amenorrheic and eumenorrheic female runners.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. Periurethral colonic-type polyps are rare benign lesions that can present with urethral symptoms, resembling urethral caruncles. We present a case of a 60-year-old female who presented with urinary frequency and dysuria. Physical examination revealed a periurethral mass resembling a caruncle. Cystoscopy showed a polypoid lesion arising from the posterior urethral wall. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a periurethral colonic-type polyp. These polyps are thought to arise from ectopic colonic tissue through embryological remnants. They can present with lower urinary tract symptoms such as frequency, dysuria, and hematuria. The diagnosis can be challenging due to the overlapping clinical features with other urethral lesions. Awareness of this entity is important to avoid misdiagnosis and ensure appropriate management. Treatment options include transurethral resection or excision of the polyp with good outcomes reported. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal management approach for periurethral colonic-type polyps.

Achieving pH control in the critically ill patient: the role of continuous infusion of H2-receptor antagonists. pH control is crucial in critically ill patients, and H2-receptor antagonists (H2RAs) are often used as prophylaxis or treatment for stress-related mucosal damage. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of continuous infusion of H2RAs in achieving pH control in critically ill patients. A retrospective analysis of 100 patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) was performed. The majority of patients (85%) achieved pH control with continuous infusion of H2RAs. Duration of ICU stay and mortality were not significantly different between the pH-controlled and non-pH-controlled groups. Adverse effects related to H2RA use were minimal. Continuous infusion of H2RAs may be a safe and effective option for achieving pH control in critically ill patients. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease secondary to a generalized venulopathy: a new syndrome presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. This case report describes a rare syndrome involving fatal pulmonary venoocclusive disease and generalized venulopathy. The patient initially presented with facial swelling and was later found to have pericardial tamponade. Autopsy revealed extensive involvement of small venous vessels throughout the body, including the lungs and heart. Histopathological examination showed fibrous thickening and luminal narrowing of the venous vessels. This newly described syndrome highlights the importance of considering venulopathy in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with facial swelling and pericardial tamponade. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential treatment options for this condition.

Complications in hyperthermia treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Of 435 patients treated with local hyperthermia to the prostate 27 had 29 complications, for an over-all complication rate of 6. Among 435 patients treated with local hyperthermia for benign prostatic hyperplasia, 27 experienced a total of 29 complications, resulting in an overall complication rate of 6%. The most common complication was acute urinary retention, occurring in 14 patients. Other complications included urinary tract infection, urinary incontinence, urinary obstruction, and urethral stricture. The majority of complications (72.4%) occurred within the first week after treatment. Age and prostate volume were found to be significant risk factors for complications. This study highlights potential complications associated with hyperthermia treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia and emphasizes the importance of careful patient selection and monitoring during and after the procedure.

Leukemias of indeterminant lineage. Leukemias of indeterminant lineage are a group of hematologic malignancies with ambiguous or mixed phenotypic features. These leukemias present a diagnostic challenge due to their overlapping characteristics with other types of leukemia. Patients typically present with variable clinical manifestations, including fatigue, fever, pallor, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory findings commonly include leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Immunophenotyping by flow cytometry is crucial in establishing a diagnosis, as it helps identify aberrant markers and determine the lineage of leukemic cells. Molecular and cytogenetic studies further aid in risk stratification and treatment selection. Due to their heterogeneity, the prognosis and optimal treatment approach for leukemias of indeterminant lineage remain uncertain, necessitating further research and personalized management strategies.

Thyrotoxicosis induced by topical iodine application. Topical iodine application is a common practice for preoperative skin preparation in various surgeries. However, thyrotoxicosis has rarely been reported as a complication of this treatment. We present a case of a 52-year-old male who developed thyrotoxicosis after repeated application of povidone-iodine solution for wound preparation. Laboratory investigations confirmed hyperthyroidism with elevated thyroid hormone levels and suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone. Thyroid scintigraphy revealed increased iodine uptake. The patient was diagnosed with iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis and managed with antithyroid medications. The use of topical iodine has been associated with various adverse effects, but thyrotoxicosis is a rare complication. This case highlights the importance of considering iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis as a possible diagnosis in patients presenting with unexplained hyperthyroidism following topical iodine application.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome associated with L-tryptophan ingestion. A case of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) associated with L-tryptophan ingestion is presented. The patient developed symptoms of progressively severe muscle pain, skin rash, and peripheral eosinophilia one month after starting L-tryptophan supplementation. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated eosinophil count, elevated creatine kinase levels, and myopathic changes on electromyography. The patient had no other identifiable cause for eosinophilia or myalgia. L-tryptophan was discontinued and supportive measures were initiated. The patient's symptoms gradually improved over several weeks, and peripheral eosinophilia resolved. EMS is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition associated with the use of L-tryptophan supplements. The pathogenesis of EMS is not completely understood, but it is thought to involve a complex interplay of immune dysregulation and toxic metabolites. Prompt recognition and discontinuation of L-tryptophan supplementation is crucial in managing patients with EMS. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and identify risk factors for this syndrome.

Growth velocity before sudden infant death. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is a devastating event with unknown causes. This study aimed to investigate the association between growth velocity and SIDS. The study included infants who died suddenly and unexpectedly (cases) and living infants (controls) matched by age, sex, and gestational age. Growth velocity, measured as weight gain per month, was calculated using weight measurements from birth until the age of six months. The results showed that cases had a significantly higher growth velocity compared to controls. After adjusting for potential confounders, the association remained significant. These findings suggest that rapid growth velocity in the first few months of life may be a risk factor for SIDS. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential preventive strategies.

Palliation of malignant esophageal obstruction. Malignant esophageal obstruction is a debilitating condition that significantly affects patient quality of life. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of palliative treatment options for this condition. A systematic review was conducted, including randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, and case series. The main palliative interventions evaluated were self-expanding metal stents (SEMS), laser therapy, and photodynamic therapy (PDT). Overall, SEMS placement was found to be the most effective and safe method for relieving dysphagia and improving quality of life in patients with malignant esophageal obstruction. Laser therapy and PDT were also found to provide symptomatic relief, although they were associated with higher rates of adverse events. In conclusion, palliative treatment options such as SEMS, laser therapy, and PDT can effectively alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life in patients with malignant esophageal obstruction.

How long can a coronary reperfusion catheter be placed in acute coronary occlusion following failed transluminal coronary angioplasty? A case report. This case report describes a patient with acute coronary occlusion following a failed transluminal coronary angioplasty, in whom a coronary reperfusion catheter was successfully placed. The patient presented with chest pain and inferior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. After failed attempts at angioplasty, a reperfusion catheter was inserted and left in place for an extended period of time due to persistent symptoms. The catheter remained well-positioned and resulted in successful reperfusion of the occluded vessel, leading to symptom resolution and improved myocardial function. In this case, the catheter was left in place for a total of 48 hours, which is longer than the typical duration. This case highlights the potential for prolonged placement of a reperfusion catheter in cases of acute coronary occlusion following failed angioplasty, but further studies are needed to determine the optimal duration and associated risks of this approach.

Molecular and hematologic characterization of Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia. Scottish-Irish type (epsilon gamma delta beta)zero thalassemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence of beta-globin gene expression due to a deletion of the epsilon, gamma, and delta genes from the beta-globin gene cluster. This leads to severe anemia and ineffective erythropoiesis. In this study, we aimed to provide a comprehensive molecular and hematologic characterization of this type of thalassemia. Through genetic analysis, we identified the specific deletions responsible for this condition. Additionally, we analyzed hematologic parameters and observed markedly reduced levels of hemoglobin and red blood cell indices. Our findings contribute to the understanding of the pathophysiology of this rare thalassemia subtype and may aid in the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.

Diagnostic significance of carcinoembryonic antigen in the differential diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) has been widely used as a tumor marker for several malignancies. However, its diagnostic significance in differentiating malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies remains uncertain. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the diagnostic potential of CEA in distinguishing malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies. A total of 120 patients with suspected mesothelioma were included, and serum levels of CEA were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis was performed to determine the diagnostic accuracy. Our results showed that the CEA levels were significantly elevated in malignant mesothelioma compared to other malignancies. The ROC analysis revealed a fair diagnostic accuracy of CEA in differentiating malignant mesothelioma (area under the curve = 0.75, 95% confidence interval: 0.65-0.85). Therefore, CEA can be considered as a potential diagnostic marker for distinguishing malignant mesothelioma from other malignancies. Further validation studies are warranted to establish its clinical utility and optimal cutoff value for accurate diagnosis.

The anatomy and physiology of nerve injury. Nerve injury can significantly impact the anatomy and physiology of various bodily systems. This review aims to provide an overview of the relationship between nerve injury and the resulting anatomical and physiological changes. Nerve injury can occur due to trauma, compression, or disease and can affect both peripheral and central nerves. 

At the anatomical level, nerve injury can lead to alterations in the structure and function of the affected nerves. This can include changes in nerve conduction velocity, axonal degeneration, and demyelination. Additionally, the surrounding tissues can undergo remodeling and scarring, further exacerbating the nerve injury. 

The physiological consequences of nerve injury are vast and can affect multiple systems in the body. Motor function can be impaired, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis. Sensory function may be compromised, resulting in altered perception or numbness. Autonomic dysfunction is also common, leading to issues such as impaired regulation of blood pressure or abnormal sweating patterns. 

Understanding the anatomical and physiological changes associated with nerve injury is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. Advances in neuroimaging techniques and nerve regeneration research have provided valuable insights into these mechanisms. Further research is needed to develop effective interventions aimed at restoring normal anatomy and physiology in individuals with nerve injuries.

Combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion for spinal canal surgery in children and adolescents. Spinal canal surgery is a common procedure in children and adolescents with spinal conditions. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion in improving clinical outcomes in this population. A total of 25 patients underwent the surgery and were followed up for an average of 2 years. Pre- and postoperative assessments included clinical examination, radiographic evaluation, and assessment of spinal function. Results showed significant improvements in both clinical symptoms and radiographic parameters postoperatively. The mean visual analog scale score for back pain decreased from 7.8 to 2.3, and the mean Oswestry Disability Index score improved from 63.4% to 18.2%. Additionally, the mean Cobb angle decreased from 44.7° to 22.1°, indicating successful correction of spinal deformity. No major complications were observed, and all patients reported satisfaction with the surgery. In conclusion, combined laminoplasty and posterolateral fusion is an effective and safe surgical option for spinal canal surgery in children and adolescents, leading to significant improvements in clinical outcomes.

Bleeding ectatic vascular lesion involving the sigmoid colon, endoscopically indistinguishable from angiodysplasia, in an 8-yr-old boy. We report a case of an 8-year-old boy with a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion in the sigmoid colon, which appeared endoscopically similar to angiodysplasia. The patient presented with recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. Colonoscopy revealed a vascular lesion in the sigmoid colon, exhibiting ectatic and fragile vessels. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a bleeding ectatic vascular lesion. This case highlights the importance of considering this rare entity in the differential diagnosis of gastrointestinal bleeding in children, especially when angiodysplasia is suspected. Although endoscopic appearance may be similar to angiodysplasia, histopathological examination is necessary for confirming the diagnosis. Treatment options include endoscopic interventions or surgical resection, depending on the severity and location of the lesion. Further research is needed to understand the etiology and optimal management of these vascular lesions in pediatric patients.

Pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. We present a case of pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. A 62-year-old male presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and was found to have pelvic lipomatosis on imaging studies. Transurethral resection of bladder (TURB) revealed cystitis glandularis as well as areas suspicious for malignancy. Subsequent radical cystectomy with urinary diversion was performed. Pathological examination confirmed the presence of cystitis glandularis, characterized by metaplastic changes of the urothelial lining with glandular formation. Additionally, a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma was identified in the bladder. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of pelvic lipomatosis associated with cystitis glandularis and adenocarcinoma of the bladder. Our findings highlight the importance of considering concurrent pathologies in the evaluation and management of bladder tumors.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a leading cause of sudden death worldwide. To assess the relationship between IHD and sudden death, a cohort study was conducted. A total of 3,471 participants were followed for an average of 10 years, during which 258 cases of sudden death were identified. The incidence rate of sudden death among individuals with IHD was found to be significantly higher compared to those without IHD (incident rate ratio = 2.15, 95% confidence interval 1.78-2.59, p < 0.001). Furthermore, age, male gender, smoking, and previous myocardial infarction were identified as independent predictors of sudden death in individuals with IHD. These findings emphasize the importance of early identification and management of IHD to prevent sudden death.

Possible mechanisms of abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels and the development of hypertension in spontaneously hypertensive rats. The mechanism underlying abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) is not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate possible mechanisms contributing to the development of hypertension in SHR. Results showed that SHR exhibited increased norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity in resistance vessels compared to normotensive rats. This was associated with altered alpha-adrenergic receptor expression and signaling pathways, enhanced oxidative stress, and reduced nitric oxide availability. These findings suggest that abnormal norepinephrine sensitivity and reactivity of resistance vessels contribute to the development of hypertension in SHR through multiple mechanisms, highlighting potential therapeutic targets for hypertension treatment.

Psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome. The relationship between psychological stress and the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome was investigated. A total of 40 patients diagnosed with fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome and 40 control subjects without the syndrome were assessed for psychological stress using the Beck Depression Inventory and the Life Events Inventory. The results showed that patients with the syndrome reported significantly higher levels of psychological stress compared to the control group. Furthermore, within the patient group, higher levels of stress were associated with increased severity of symptoms. These findings suggest a strong association between psychological stress and the development and exacerbation of the fibrositis/fibromyalgia syndrome. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and to develop targeted interventions for managing stress in patients with the syndrome.

Recurrent lateral rectus palsy in childhood. Recurrent lateral rectus palsy is a rare condition in childhood characterized by the repeated paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, resulting in limited abduction of the affected eye. This case study presents two pediatric patients with recurrent lateral rectus palsy, outlining their clinical features, diagnostic workup, and management. Both patients experienced recurrent episodes of lateral rectus palsy with no other associated neurologic or systemic abnormalities. Neuroimaging studies, including MRI, were performed and showed no structural abnormalities. Management involved treatment with patching and/or prism glasses to correct the ocular misalignment during episodes. The etiology of recurrent lateral rectus palsy is not well understood, and further studies are needed to determine the underlying cause and optimal management strategies for this condition in children.

Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. This study presents the outcomes and complications of deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. A retrospective analysis of patients who underwent this procedure between 2010 and 2019 was conducted. Primary patency rates, limb salvage rates, and complication rates were assessed. The mean follow-up time was 29 months. The results showed a primary patency rate of 68% at 2 years and 58% at 5 years. Limb salvage rates were 85% at 2 years and 74% at 5 years. Complications included wound infections, graft occlusion, and ischemic ulcers. This study highlights the efficacy and potential complications of deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass as a salvage procedure for failed femoropopliteal reconstructions.

Hazards of internal fixation in the treatment of slipped capital femoral epiphysis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder in adolescents that requires surgical treatment with internal fixation. However, there are potential hazards associated with this procedure. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the complications and outcomes of internal fixation in SCFE patients. A total of 92 patients who underwent internal fixation were included. The most common complication was avascular necrosis (19.6%), followed by screw cut-out (15.2%) and osteoarthritis (9.8%). Other complications included infection and deep vein thrombosis. Patients who experienced complications had significantly worse functional outcomes compared to those without complications. Age, weight, and severity of the slip were identified as risk factors for complications. Therefore, while internal fixation is an effective treatment for SCFE, surgeons should be aware of the potential hazards to minimize complications and optimize patient outcomes. Further research is needed to develop strategies to mitigate these risks.

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score in patients with cerebrovascular disease and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score has been used as an indicator of increased neutrophil activity in various diseases. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the LAP score in patients with cerebrovascular disease (CVD) and in patients with primary and metastatic brain tumors. A total of 100 patients were included in the study, with 50 patients diagnosed with CVD and 50 patients diagnosed with brain tumors. The LAP score was significantly higher in patients with CVD compared to patients with brain tumors (p<0.001). Among the brain tumor patients, those with metastatic tumors had a significantly lower LAP score compared to those with primary tumors (p<0.05). Our findings suggest that the LAP score may serve as a potential biomarker for differentiating between CVD and brain tumors, as well as for distinguishing between primary and metastatic brain tumors. Further investigations are warranted to validate these findings.

Monocortical miniplate fixation of mandibular angle fractures.  Noncompression monocortical miniplate fixation of mandibular fractures has become a reliable method of providing rigid fixation and eliminating the need for intermaxillary fixation. Monocortical miniplate fixation has become a widely accepted technique for the treatment of mandibular angle fractures, providing stable fixation and eliminating the need for intermaxillary fixation. In this study, we evaluated the outcomes of 42 patients who underwent noncompression monocortical miniplate fixation for mandibular angle fractures. The mean age of the patients was 29 years, with a male-to-female ratio of 3:1. All fractures achieved satisfactory occlusion and there were no cases of nonunion or malocclusion. The average time for bone healing was 6 weeks. Complications, such as infection and plate removal, were encountered in a few cases. Overall, noncompression monocortical miniplate fixation proves to be an effective technique for the treatment of mandibular angle fractures, offering stable fixation and reducing patient discomfort.

Helicobacter pylori infection: a simplified diagnostic approach.  We evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of endoscopic finding of nodular antritis and rapid urease test (RUT) in order to simplify the approach to the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori (H.  pylori) infection. This study aimed to assess the diagnostic accuracy of endoscopic findings of nodular antritis and the rapid urease test (RUT) as a simplified approach for diagnosing Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. A total of [number] patients undergoing endoscopy were included in the study. Endoscopic findings of nodular antritis were noted, and RUT was performed. The presence of H. pylori infection was confirmed using a gold standard method (e.g., histology, urea breath test, or culture). Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of nodular antritis and RUT were calculated. The results showed that nodular antritis had a sensitivity of [value], specificity of [value], positive predictive value of [value], and negative predictive value of [value]. RUT had a sensitivity of [value], specificity of [value], positive predictive value of [value], and negative predictive value of [value]. In conclusion, the combination of endoscopic findings of nodular antritis and RUT provides a simplified approach for diagnosing H. pylori infection, with [value]% sensitivity and [value]% specificity.

Transient neuromuscular impairment resulting from prolonged inhalation of halothane and enflurane. We investigated the occurrence of transient neuromuscular impairment following prolonged inhalation of halothane and enflurane in a series of 500 patients. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either halothane or enflurane anesthesia for a duration of six hours or longer. Neuromuscular function was evaluated by measuring the time necessary for recovery of thumb adductor motor responses to supramaximal stimuli of the ulnar nerve at the adductor pollicis muscle. Our findings showed that 16% of patients experienced neuromuscular impairment, characterized by prolonged recovery time and reduced response amplitude. The impairment was more pronounced in patients who received enflurane compared to those who received halothane. These results suggest that prolonged inhalation of enflurane and halothane can lead to transient neuromuscular impairment, which should be taken into consideration when selecting anesthesia options for long-duration procedures.

Race, nutritional status, and survival from breast cancer. This study examined the relationship between race, nutritional status, and survival from breast cancer. It was found that race played a significant role in determining nutritional status and subsequently, survival rates. African American women were more likely to have lower nutritional status compared to Caucasian women, which may explain the higher mortality rates in this group. Factors such as socioeconomic status, healthcare access, and cultural dietary practices may contribute to these disparities. Additionally, nutritional interventions targeting these populations should be developed to improve survival outcomes. Strategies to address racial disparities in breast cancer survival should consider the impact of nutrition and develop culturally sensitive interventions to improve nutritional status and ultimately, survival rates. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions.

Clinical observation on the association of gallstones and colorectal cancer.  A possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer was investigated. This study aimed to investigate the possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer. A total of 2,405 patients who underwent surgery for gallstone disease were included in the study.
