Isolated ventral pancreatitis in a patient with pancreas divisum. This case report presents a patient with isolated ventral pancreatitis who was found to have pancreas divisum. Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly characterized by the failure of fusion between the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts. Isolated ventral pancreatitis is a rare manifestation of this condition. The patient presented with abdominal pain and elevated pancreatic enzymes. Imaging studies revealed a normal main pancreatic duct but drainage of the ventral part of the pancreas through the accessory duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography confirmed the diagnosis and therapeutic measures, including stenting of the accessory duct, were performed. This case highlights the importance of considering pancreas divisum as a cause of isolated ventral pancreatitis and highlights the role of endoscopic intervention in its management.

The UCLA-University of Utah epidemiologic survey of autism: the etiologic role of rare diseases. The UCLA-University of Utah epidemiologic survey of autism aimed to investigate the role of rare diseases in the etiology of autism. A total of 404 consecutive admissions to the medical ICUs at a university medical center were analyzed to assess patterns of resource consumption. The study revealed that a small percentage (8 percent) of patients consumed as many ICU resources as the majority (92 percent). Additionally, 41 percent of admissions were for monitoring only and accounted for less than 10 percent of ICU resource consumption. This suggests that reducing the number of patients admitted for monitoring would have a limited impact on hospital charges. Furthermore, the study highlighted that improved prognosis understanding and better physician-patient communication may decrease the proportion of critical care resources utilized for futile treatment, as over 70 percent of high-cost patients ultimately died.

Mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in the Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome was investigated in this study. A total of 38 patients who presented with intermittent preexcitation on electrocardiogram were included. Electrophysiological studies were performed to identify the mechanism of the intermittent preexcitation. The results showed that 22 patients had intermittent conduction through an accessory pathway, while 16 patients had intermittent antegrade conduction via the atrioventricular node. In patients with intermittent accessory pathway conduction, the mechanism was found to be related to varying refractoriness of the accessory pathway, with shorter refractoriness leading to preexcitation. On the other hand, in patients with intermittent atrioventricular node conduction, the mechanism was attributed to a slow pathway that intermittently conducted impulses. These findings suggest that the mechanism of intermittent preexcitation in WPW syndrome can vary and may be dependent on either accessory pathway or atrioventricular node conduction. Further studies are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and implications for management.

Multimodality cisplatin treatment in nonresectable alpha-fetoprotein-positive hepatoma.  Twenty-eight patients with alpha-fetoprotein-positive (AFP+) nonresectable hepatoma have been enrolled in a new multimodality Phase I, II program. This study assessed the efficacy and safety of multimodality cisplatin treatment in patients with nonresectable hepatoma positive for alpha-fetoprotein (AFP+). A total of 28 patients were enrolled in a Phase I, II program. The treatment regimen consisted of cisplatin in combination with other therapeutic modalities. The objective was to evaluate the response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival of patients. The results showed that multimodality cisplatin treatment was effective in reducing tumor size and AFP levels in the majority of patients. The median progression-free survival and overall survival were also improved compared to historical controls. Additionally, the treatment was well-tolerated with manageable side effects. These findings suggest that multimodality cisplatin treatment is a promising therapeutic approach for patients with nonresectable AFP+ hepatoma. Further studies are warranted to validate these results and optimize the treatment protocol.

Prevention and changing demographics. Traumatic intracranial aneurysms (TICAs) caused by missiles are rare, with only 30 cases reported to date. Here, we present an additional 15 cases, bringing the total to 45. Missile TICAs are often located in secondary branches of the middle cerebral artery and are frequently accompanied by intracerebral hematoma (80%) or acute subdural hematoma (26%). The majority of TICAs in our cases (14 out of 15) were caused by shrapnel injuries, with only one resulting from a bullet. None of the injuries were through-and-through. TICAs may progressively enlarge over time and, although initially asymptomatic, they can suddenly rupture and lead to fatal outcomes. Histological analysis of the seven cases studied revealed all TICAs to be false aneurysms. The preferred treatment for TICAs is trapping and excision. Patient outcomes depend on their preoperative level of consciousness and overall condition. The potential indications for angiography are also discussed. Preventive measures and changing demographics are important considerations in managing TICAs. (156 words)

Sclerotherapy for esophageal varices.  Endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS) frequently is used for patients with esophageal varices, both for controlling acute hemorrhage and for prophylaxis. Endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS) is a commonly employed treatment for acute hemorrhage control and prophylaxis in patients with esophageal varices. This medical abstract aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of EIS for this purpose. Several studies conducted between 1990 and 2010 were analyzed, involving a total of 2,000 patients with esophageal varices. EIS showed a high rate of initial hemostasis, ranging from 80% to 95%, and a low risk of recurrent bleeding in the following years, ranging from 5% to 15%. Additionally, EIS was found to be effective in preventing variceal bleeding, with a significant reduction in the incidence of bleeding episodes. However, complications related to EIS were reported, including esophageal ulcers and strictures, with an incidence ranging from 1% to 10%. Despite the risk of adverse events, EIS remains a valuable therapeutic option for the management of esophageal varices.

Relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcome. This study aimed to compare the relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcomes. Data from 200 patients with either traumatic brain injury (TBI) or non-brain injuries were analyzed. The patients underwent comprehensive neuropsychological testing and psychosocial assessments. Results showed that TBI patients had significantly worse neuropsychological outcomes compared to non-brain injury patients. Specifically, TBI patients exhibited deficits in attention, memory, and executive functioning. However, there were no significant differences in psychosocial outcomes between the two groups. These findings suggest that brain injuries have a greater impact on cognitive functioning, while non-brain injuries may have a comparable effect on psychosocial functioning. Further research is needed to better understand the specific mechanisms underlying these differential effects and to develop appropriate interventions for individuals with brain versus non-brain injuries.

Endoscopic retrograde brush cytology. Endoscopic retrograde brush cytology (ERBC) is a minimally invasive technique used to obtain cytological samples from the biliary and pancreatic ducts. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic yield and clinical impact of ERBC in patients with suspected biliary or pancreatic neoplasms. A total of 92 patients who underwent ERBC between 2015 and 2018 were included in the analysis. The overall diagnostic yield of ERBC was 72%, with a sensitivity and specificity of 68% and 89%, respectively. ERBC had a high negative predictive value (88%) but a moderate positive predictive value (51%). In addition, ERBC had a significant impact on patient management, as 46% of patients underwent a change in treatment plan based on the cytological findings. These results suggest that ERBC is a valuable tool in the evaluation of patients with suspected biliary or pancreatic neoplasms, providing accurate diagnosis and influencing clinical decision-making.

The role of the iliolumbar ligament in the lumbosacral junction.  The biomechanical function of the iliolumbar ligament in the human lumbosacral junction was investigated by analyzing the three-dimensional movements of the whole lumbar and lumbo-sacral-ilium specimens. The iliolumbar ligament plays a crucial role in the biomechanics of the lumbosacral junction. Through the analysis of three-dimensional movements in lumbar and lumbo-sacral-ilium specimens, the function of this ligament was investigated. Results showed that the iliolumbar ligament significantly restricts lumbar flexion and rotation, while allowing limited lateral bending. It acts as a stabilizer, preventing excessive movement in the lumbosacral junction and maintaining proper alignment of the lumbar vertebrae. Dysfunctional iliolumbar ligament may lead to lumbar instability and contribute to lower back pain. This study highlights the importance of the iliolumbar ligament in maintaining the stability and function of the lumbosacral junction and provides insights into its biomechanical role. Further research is needed to explore potential treatments for iliolumbar ligament dysfunction and its implications in clinical practice.

Epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections among young children in Kenya.  The epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infection (ARI) was investigated in a rural community 80 km north of Nairobi, Kenya. The epidemiology of acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) was examined in a rural community located 80 km north of Nairobi, Kenya. A total of 384 young children were included in the study, with an age range of 0-5 years. The incidence rate of ARI over a one-year period was found to be 15.6 cases per 100 child-years. The majority of ARI cases occurred in children under the age of 2, with a peak incidence observed in those aged 6-11 months. The most common symptoms reported were cough (82.3%), fever (70.8%), and difficulty breathing (34.4%). Risk factors associated with ARI included overcrowding, low socioeconomic status, and exposure to indoor smoke from biomass fuel combustion. This study highlights the high burden of ARI in young children in rural Kenya and emphasizes the need for preventive measures such as improved living conditions and access to clean energy sources.

Gastrointestinal intraluminal pH in normal subjects and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. The study aimed to investigate the intraluminal pH levels in the gastrointestinal tract of normal individuals and those with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma. Ambulatory pH monitoring was performed on 30 healthy subjects, 25 patients with colorectal adenoma, and 20 patients with colorectal carcinoma. The pH levels were measured at various locations in the gastrointestinal tract, including the stomach, duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon. It was found that there were no significant differences in pH levels between the normal individuals and the patients with colorectal adenoma or carcinoma in any of the examined locations. These findings suggest that intraluminal pH is not a reliable indicator for the presence of colorectal adenoma or carcinoma.

Congenital cyst of common bile duct: an unusual cause of obstructive jaundice. Congenital cyst of the common bile duct is a rare but important cause of obstructive jaundice. It presents challenges in diagnosis and management due to its atypical symptoms and imaging findings. A high index of suspicion is necessary for prompt recognition and appropriate intervention. Imaging modalities, such as ultrasound and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, are helpful in establishing the diagnosis. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice to prevent complications and alleviate symptoms. However, careful consideration should be given to the risks and benefits of surgery in individual patients, especially in those with comorbidities or advanced age. Overall, early identification and timely intervention are crucial for successful management of this uncommon entity.

Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy with visual rehabilitation by a triple procedure. Mycobacterium chelonei keratopathy is a rare and challenging ocular infection that can lead to severe visual impairment. We present a case of a 62-year-old patient with M. chelonei keratopathy who underwent a triple procedure comprising of corneal debridement, amniotic membrane transplantation, and bandage contact lens application. This approach resulted in rapid resolution of the infection and visual rehabilitation. Follow-up examinations showed good visual acuity and absence of recurrence. The triple procedure appears to be an effective treatment option for M. chelonei keratopathy, highlighting the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate intervention in managing this rare ocular infection. Further studies are warranted to validate the efficacy of this approach.

Radiology for cochlear implants. This retrospective study aimed to assess the utility of radiological imaging in the evaluation of cochlear implant candidates. A total of 300 patients who underwent preoperative radiographic evaluations were included. The study utilized computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess cochlear anatomy and associated pathologies. Surgical outcomes and postoperative complications were also evaluated. Results showed that CT provided detailed information on cochlear anatomy and was particularly useful in identifying abnormalities such as cochlear hypoplasia or ossification. MRI, on the other hand, provided valuable information on soft tissue pathology, such as cochlear nerve abnormalities or labyrinthitis ossificans. Furthermore, the study demonstrated that radiological findings significantly influenced preoperative counseling and surgical planning. Overall, 90% of the patients who underwent cochlear implantation had successful outcomes, with a low rate of postoperative complications. These findings suggest that radiological evaluation plays a crucial role in assessing cochlear implant candidacy and optimizing surgical outcomes.

Approach to the patient with genital ulcer disease. Genital ulcer disease (GUD) poses a diagnostic challenge due to its various etiologies. This article aims to provide a comprehensive approach to the patient with GUD, with a focus on differentiating between primary syphilis, genital herpes, and chancroid. A thorough history and physical examination are crucial in guiding further investigations. Laboratory tests such as serological tests for syphilis, nucleic acid amplification tests for herpes simplex virus, and culture for Haemophilus ducreyi can aid in diagnosis. In cases where the diagnosis remains uncertain, a biopsy may be warranted. Treatment should be tailored based on the specific etiology, with penicillin being the drug of choice for syphilis, antiviral medications for HSV, and azithromycin or ceftriaxone for chancroid. Close follow-up is necessary to monitor for treatment response and to address any potential complications. Proper patient education, partner notification, and safe sexual practices are essential in preventing further spread of GUD.

Coracoclavicular screw fixation for unstable fractures of the distal clavicle. Coracoclavicular (CC) screw fixation is a surgical technique commonly used for the treatment of unstable fractures of the distal clavicle. This abstract provides an overview of the procedure and its effectiveness in achieving stable fixation. A review of the literature revealed several studies reporting favorable outcomes with CC screw fixation, including high rates of union, good functional outcomes, and low complication rates. However, the optimal technique for screw placement and the choice of implant remain debated. In addition, the potential for hardware-related complications, such as screw migration or breakage, should be carefully considered. Overall, CC screw fixation offers a reliable and effective treatment option for unstable fractures of the distal clavicle.

Chordoma: a 20-year clinicopathologic review of the experience at Groote Schuur Hospital, Cape Town.  Eighteen chordomas (11 females and 7 males) were seen over a 20-year period; 61% of the tumors occurred in the sphenoid region. This study aimed to review the clinicopathologic features of chordomas over a 20-year period at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. Eighteen cases of chordomas were identified, with 11 females and 7 males. The sphenoid region was the most common location for these tumors, accounting for 61% of cases. The mean age at diagnosis was 46 years, with a range of 21 to 69 years. Clinical symptoms included cranial nerve involvement, headache, and visual disturbances. Histopathologic examination revealed typical features of chordomas, including physaliphorous cells and chondroid matrix. Treatment modalities included surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy, with varying success rates. This study provides a detailed analysis of the clinicopathologic characteristics of chordomas at a single institution, contributing to the understanding and management of this rare tumor.

Nasopalatine duct cyst: an analysis of 334 cases.  The nasopalatine duct cyst (NPDC) is the most common cyst of nonodontogenic origin in the maxilla. This study aimed to analyze 334 cases of nasopalatine duct cyst (NPDC), the most prevalent nonodontogenic cyst in the maxilla. The mean age at presentation was 43.6 years, with a male predominance (59.3%). Most cases (85.9%) were symptomatic, presenting with pain and swelling in the anterior maxilla. Radiographically, the cysts were well-defined, oval-shaped radiolucencies located between the maxillary central incisors. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis in all cases. Treatment involved enucleation and curettage in the majority (83.8%) of cases. Histopathological analysis revealed inflammation, epithelial hyperplasia, and cystic lining in most cases. There were no postoperative complications, and recurrence occurred in only two cases. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of NPDC, highlighting its clinical and radiographic features, as well as its management. Increased awareness among clinicians can aid in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of NPDC.

Factors associated with binocular single vision in microtropia/monofixation syndrome.  We reviewed the charts of 398 patients with microtropia/monofixation syndrome to determine what factors influence the level of binocularity attained. A retrospective chart review of 398 patients with microtropia/monofixation syndrome was conducted to identify factors influencing the level of binocularity achieved. The analysis revealed that age at diagnosis, pre-treatment strabismus angle, and type of treatment received were significantly associated with the development of binocular single vision (BSV). Patients diagnosed at a younger age and with smaller pre-treatment strabismus angles were more likely to attain BSV. Additionally, those who received early occlusion therapy or surgical intervention had a higher likelihood of achieving BSV compared to those who received no treatment or later interventions. These findings emphasize the importance of early diagnosis and prompt intervention to optimize visual outcomes in microtropia/monofixation syndrome patients.

Short-term radiotherapy as palliative treatment in patients with transitional cell bladder cancer. Transitional cell bladder cancer is commonly found in elderly patients and often presents with advanced disease. Palliative treatment aims to alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life. Short-term radiotherapy has shown promise in achieving these objectives. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of short-term radiotherapy as palliative treatment in patients with transitional cell bladder cancer. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 50 patients who received short-term radiotherapy for symptomatic relief. The response rate was assessed using clinical and radiological criteria, and adverse effects were documented. Our findings demonstrate that short-term radiotherapy provides significant pain relief in the majority of patients and improves overall quality of life. Adverse effects were generally mild and well-tolerated. Short-term radiotherapy is a viable option for palliative treatment in patients with transitional cell bladder cancer, offering effective symptom control without compromising safety. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these results and identify optimal treatment protocols.

Immunohistochemical study of erythropoietin in cerebellar hemangioblastomas associated with secondary polycythemia.  Although cerebellar hemangioblastomas are known to be associated with secondary polycythemia, the cellular derivation of erythropoietin (EPO) in hemangioblastomas still remains obscure. This study aimed to investigate the cellular origin of erythropoietin (EPO) in cerebellar hemangioblastomas associated with secondary polycythemia. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed on tissue samples from 10 patients with cerebellar hemangioblastomas. The results showed positive staining for EPO in the tumor cells in all cases. Additionally, EPO expression was found in the stromal cells and vascular endothelial cells surrounding the tumor. These findings suggest that the tumor cells themselves are capable of producing EPO in cerebellar hemangioblastomas associated with secondary polycythemia. This finding provides further insights into the pathogenesis of secondary polycythemia in these tumors and may have implications for targeted therapies. Further studies are warranted to explore the mechanisms underlying EPO production in these tumors and evaluate the potential therapeutic strategies targeting EPO signaling in cerebellar hemangioblastomas.

Right-to-left shunting through a patent foramen ovale caused by pulmonary hypertension associated with rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome: a case report. We present a case of right-to-left shunting through a patent foramen ovale (PFO) in a patient with pulmonary hypertension associated with rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome. The patient presented with exertional dyspnea and hypoxemia, and further investigations revealed significant pulmonary artery hypertension. Transesophageal echocardiography confirmed the presence of a PFO and demonstrated paradoxical emboli. The coexistence of pulmonary hypertension and autoimmune diseases raises concerns regarding the management of these patients. Early identification and appropriate treatment of PFO may help prevent systemic embolization and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the association between pulmonary hypertension, autoimmune diseases, and PFO.

Predicting treatment outcome in nocturnal enuresis. Nocturnal enuresis, or bedwetting, is a common childhood condition that can persist into adulthood. The aim of this study was to assess the ability of various factors to predict treatment outcome in patients with nocturnal enuresis. A total of 120 patients with primary nocturnal enuresis were included in the study. All patients underwent a comprehensive evaluation, including medical history, physical examination, urinalysis, and urodynamic studies. Treatment options included alarm therapy, desmopressin, and combination treatment. Treatment outcomes were assessed based on the number of dry nights per week and the frequency of bedwetting episodes. The results showed that younger age at onset, positive family history, and higher number of wet nights per week were significantly associated with poor treatment response. Urodynamic studies and urinalysis did not have a predictive value for treatment outcome. Alarm therapy was found to be the most effective treatment option, with a success rate of 80%. In conclusion, various factors can help predict treatment outcome in patients with nocturnal enuresis, and alarm therapy should be considered as the first-line treatment.

Cauda equina syndrome after continuous spinal anesthesia. Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is a rare but serious complication of continuous spinal anesthesia (CSA). This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and risk factors associated with CES following CSA. A retrospective analysis of patients who developed CES after CSA was conducted from January 2010 to December 2018. Among the 15,782 patients who underwent CSA during this period, 10 cases of CES were identified, resulting in an incidence rate of 0.06%. The mean onset of symptoms after CSA was 17.8 hours. Risk factors associated with CES included prolonged CSA duration and increased number of attempts during needle insertion. Severe neurological deficits were observed in all cases, necessitating surgical decompression. Although CES is a rare complication, clinicians should be aware of its potential occurrence after CSA, especially in patients with prolonged CSA duration or multiple attempts at needle insertion. Early recognition and prompt surgical intervention are crucial to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

Chondrosarcoma of bone in children.  Chondrosarcoma of bone rarely occurs in children. Chondrosarcoma of bone is a rare occurrence in pediatric patients. We present a retrospective analysis of cases diagnosed with chondrosarcoma of bone in children. A total of 25 cases were identified from a database of pediatric bone tumors over a 10-year period. The median age at diagnosis was 12 years (range 6-17 years), with a slight male predominance (56%). The most common site of involvement was the long bones (64%), followed by the pelvis (16%) and ribs (12%). The majority of cases were low-grade tumors (76%) with no evidence of metastasis at diagnosis. Orthopedic surgery was the primary treatment modality, with adjuvant chemotherapy used in select cases. Overall survival at 5 years was 84%. In conclusion, chondrosarcoma of bone in children is a rare entity, typically presenting as low-grade tumors with excellent overall survival.

Glucagonoma syndrome is an underdiagnosed clinical entity. Glucagonoma syndrome is a rare and often underdiagnosed clinical condition characterized by the presence of a glucagon-secreting neuroendocrine tumor, known as a glucagonoma. This syndrome typically presents with a classic triad of symptoms, including dermatitis, glossitis, and weight loss. However, these symptoms can vary and may not always be present, leading to delayed or missed diagnoses. Glucagonoma syndrome can have a range of systemic effects, including glucose dysregulation, venous thromboembolism, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Timely recognition and diagnosis of glucagonoma syndrome are crucial to initiate appropriate treatment and improve patient outcomes. This abstract highlights the importance of raising awareness among healthcare professionals about this often overlooked condition and emphasizes the need for further research to enhance early detection and management strategies.

Hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and consumption coagulopathy. Hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma is a rare benign tumor of the liver that can present with various complications. We report a case of a 45-year-old female presenting with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and consumption coagulopathy due to a hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma. The patient initially presented with jaundice and malaise, and laboratory investigations revealed evidence of hemolysis and coagulation abnormalities. Imaging studies showed a large hepatic mass consistent with a cavernous hemangioma. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, which resulted in resolution of the hemolytic anemia and coagulopathy. Hepatic giant cavernous hemangioma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and consumption coagulopathy, as surgical resection can lead to complete resolution of these complications. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of this condition.

Diagnosis of oral hairy leukoplakia by ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens.  Lingual exfoliative cytologic specimens (scrapings) were obtained from 18 patients positive for human immunodeficiency virus with clinical oral hairy leukoplakia. Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL) is commonly seen in individuals infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). This study aimed to evaluate the utility of ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens for the diagnosis of OHL. Lingual exfoliative cytologic specimens were collected from 18 patients with clinical signs of OHL and confirmed HIV infection. The specimens were examined using electron microscopy to identify characteristic viral changes. The study found that all 18 patients showed consistent morphologic characteristics of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, confirming the diagnosis of OHL. This ultrastructural examination of exfoliative cytologic specimens proved to be a reliable and non-invasive method for the diagnosis of OHL in HIV-positive individuals. The findings of this study support the use of electron microscopy in the diagnostic workup of OHL.

Urinary tract re-functionalization after long-term diversion.  A 20-year experience with 177 patients. We present a study encompassing a 20-year experience with 177 patients who underwent urinary tract re-functionalization following long-term diversion. The majority of patients had undergone urinary diversion due to malignancies or neurogenic bladder dysfunction. Different surgical techniques were employed for re-functionalization, including uretero-intestinal anastomosis and continent urinary diversion procedures. Complications were observed in 21% of cases, most commonly urinary tract infections and metabolic disturbances. Success rates were high, with 80% of patients achieving satisfactory bladder capacity and continence. Long-term follow-up revealed improvements in quality of life and patient satisfaction. Our findings suggest that urinary tract re-functionalization is a viable option for patients with long-term urinary diversion, offering improved functional outcomes and overall well-being.

Muscle relaxation rates in individuals susceptible to malignant hyperthermia. Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a potentially life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic drugs, characterized by uncontrolled skeletal muscle hypermetabolism. This study aimed to investigate muscle relaxation rates in individuals susceptible to MH. Sixty MH-susceptible patients and 60 non-MH-susceptible patients were included in the study. The patients were administered succinylcholine and the time taken for relaxation of the masseter muscle was recorded. The mean time for relaxation in MH-susceptible patients was significantly longer compared to non-MH-susceptible patients (p < 0.001). Additionally, the percentage of MH-susceptible patients who exhibited delayed relaxation (>10 minutes) was significantly higher compared to non-MH-susceptible patients (p < 0.001). Furthermore, MH-susceptible patients had a higher incidence of adverse events during anesthesia compared to non-MH-susceptible patients (p < 0.001). Our findings suggest that MH-susceptible individuals have slower muscle relaxation rates and are more prone to adverse events during anesthesia. These results highlight the importance of identifying MH susceptibility prior to anesthesia administration to ensure appropriate precautions are taken to minimize the risk of MH and optimize patient safety.

Increased serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations in hyperthyroid states.  Serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations were determined in 21 untreated hyperthyroid patients (12 with Graves' disease, and nine with toxic nodular adenoma) and in 20 healthy controls. Hyperthyroidism is a condition characterized by excess production of thyroid hormones. This study aimed to investigate the levels of serum beta 2-microglobulin, a marker of immune activation and inflammation, in untreated hyperthyroid patients compared to healthy controls. The study included 21 untreated hyperthyroid patients, divided into two groups (Graves' disease and toxic nodular adenoma), and 20 healthy controls. Serum beta 2-microglobulin concentrations were measured in all participants. The results showed significantly higher levels of serum beta 2-microglobulin in hyperthyroid patients compared to healthy controls. This suggests a potential role of immune activation and inflammation in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of these findings.

Esophageal motility, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux: variations in clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia. Esophageal dysphagia can manifest in various ways, including esophageal motility disorders, heartburn, and gastroesophageal reflux. We analyzed the clinical presentation of esophageal dysphagia in a cohort of patients and identified different variations in symptoms. A total of 150 patients with esophageal dysphagia were included in the study. Among these, 60% had abnormal esophageal motility patterns, 35% presented with heartburn as the primary symptom, and 5% had gastroesophageal reflux disease. Patients with abnormal motility patterns exhibited symptoms such as chest pain, regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing, while those with heartburn complained of burning sensation in the chest and acid regurgitation. The few patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease reported symptoms such as recurrent heartburn and sour taste in the mouth. Our findings highlight the diverse clinical presentations of esophageal dysphagia, indicating the need for a comprehensive assessment to accurately diagnose and manage this condition. Understanding these variations can aid physicians in tailoring treatment approaches and improving patient outcomes.

Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction during long-term hemodialysis. Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction is a rare complication observed in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis. This condition is characterized by the development of a mass lesion in the region of the craniocervical junction, leading to compression of surrounding structures and subsequent neurologic deficits. The pathogenesis of this pseudotumor remains unclear, but it is believed to be associated with chronic inflammation and fluid shifts commonly observed in hemodialysis patients. Diagnostic imaging techniques, such as magnetic resonance imaging, play a crucial role in confirming the diagnosis and assessing the extent of the lesion. Surgical intervention is often required to decompress the affected area and provide relief of symptoms. Long-term management involves optimizing hemodialysis parameters, such as fluid balance and dialysate composition, to prevent further exacerbation of the pseudotumor. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors, pathophysiology, and optimal management strategies for this rare complication in the hemodialysis population.

Fungal brain abscesses (aspergillosis/mucormycosis) in two immunosuppressed patients. This case report describes two immunosuppressed patients who developed fungal brain abscesses, specifically aspergillosis and mucormycosis. Both patients presented with symptoms of headache, fever, and altered mental status. Imaging studies revealed single or multiple brain lesions. Diagnosis was confirmed through biopsy or surgical resection, with culture identifying Aspergillus or Mucor species. Treatment involved a combination of antifungal therapy, such as amphotericin B, and surgical intervention to remove the abscesses. Despite treatment, both patients experienced complications and required long-term management. This report highlights the importance of considering fungal infections in immunosuppressed individuals presenting with brain abscesses and emphasizes the need for early diagnosis and intervention to improve outcomes.

Rigid fixation of internal orbital fractures.  When large portions of the internal orbit are destroyed (two to four walls), standard bone-grafting techniques for immediate and late orbital reconstruction may not yield predictable eye position. This study aimed to determine the effectiveness of rigid fixation in treating internal orbital fractures involving two to four walls. Twenty-five patients with substantial internal orbital destruction were evaluated. Immediate and late orbital reconstruction using standard bone-grafting techniques was performed, and eye position was assessed. The results demonstrated that these techniques did not consistently achieve a predictable eye position. Rigid fixation, however, proved to be an effective alternative. This technique provided stable and reliable positioning of the eye in the majority of cases. Rigid fixation should be considered as a valuable option for treating internal orbital fractures with extensive tissue damage.

Oral labetalol in hypertensive urgencies. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oral labetalol in the management of hypertensive urgencies. A total of 50 patients with hypertensive urgencies were included and treated with oral labetalol. Blood pressure was measured before and after administration of labetalol. The results showed a significant reduction in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after labetalol administration (p<0.05). Additionally, there was a significant decrease in heart rate (p<0.05). No serious adverse effects were observed. These findings suggest that oral labetalol is effective in rapidly reducing blood pressure and heart rate in patients with hypertensive urgencies. Further studies are warranted to explore the long-term effects and safety profile of labetalol in this patient population.

Lack of association between keratoconus, mitral valve prolapse, and joint hypermobility. Keratoconus is a corneal disorder characterized by thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea, while mitral valve prolapse (MVP) refers to the abnormal displacement of the mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole. Joint hypermobility is a common feature in various connective tissue disorders. This study aimed to investigate the possible association between these three conditions. A total of 100 patients with keratoconus were evaluated for the presence of MVP and joint hypermobility. The results revealed no significant association between keratoconus and either MVP or joint hypermobility (p>0.05). These findings suggest that keratoconus may not share a common pathogenesis or underlying genetic predisposition with MVP or joint hypermobility. Further research is needed to elucidate the etiology of keratoconus and its relationship with other connective tissue disorders. Understanding these associations could contribute to improved diagnostic and management strategies for patients with keratoconus.

A rapid, effective technique for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis using standard coronary catheters Retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis can be challenging even to experienced angiographers. Valvular aortic stenosis is a challenging condition to treat, particularly when attempting retrograde crossing using standard coronary catheters. This study aimed to develop a rapid and effective technique for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis. A total of 50 patients with symptomatic aortic stenosis were included in the study. The technique involved utilizing a J-tip guidewire inserted into the left subclavian artery, which was then advanced into the aorta and across the stenotic valve. Success was achieved in 48 out of 50 cases, with a high rate of procedural success and minimal complications. This technique offers a practical and reliable alternative for retrograde crossing of valvular aortic stenosis using standard coronary catheters.

Prochlorperazine and transdermal scopolamine added to a metoclopramide antiemetic regimen.  A controlled comparison. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of adding prochlorperazine and transdermal scopolamine to a metoclopramide antiemetic regimen in the treatment of nausea and vomiting. A total of 100 patients were randomly assigned to one of three treatment groups: metoclopramide alone, metoclopramide with prochlorperazine, or metoclopramide with transdermal scopolamine. The primary outcome measure was the proportion of patients achieving complete resolution of symptoms within 24 hours. Secondary outcome measures included the severity of nausea and vomiting, need for rescue antiemetics, and adverse effects. The results showed that both the combination of metoclopramide and prochlorperazine and the combination of metoclopramide and transdermal scopolamine were more effective than metoclopramide alone in achieving complete resolution of symptoms within 24 hours. There were no significant differences in the severity of nausea and vomiting or the need for rescue antiemetics among the three groups. However, the combination therapy groups had a higher incidence of adverse effects compared to metoclopramide alone. Therefore, the addition of prochlorperazine or transdermal scopolamine may be considered in patients who do not achieve adequate symptom control with metoclopramide alone, although close monitoring for adverse effects is warranted.

Homeobox gene expression plus autocrine growth factor production elicits myeloid leukemia.  In the murine myelomonocytic leukemia WEHI-3B, proviral insertions have induced expression of the Hox-2. The overexpression of homeobox genes and autocrine growth factors has been implicated in the development of myeloid leukemia. This study focused on the murine myelomonocytic leukemia cell line WEHI-3B, where proviral insertions were found to induce the expression of the Hox-2 homeobox gene. The overexpression of Hox-2 resulted in increased proliferation and differentiation of WEHI-3B cells, leading to the development of myeloid leukemia. Additionally, increased autocrine growth factor production was observed, further promoting leukemia progression. These findings suggest that the dysregulation of homeobox gene expression and autocrine growth factor signaling play crucial roles in the pathogenesis of myeloid leukemia and provide potential targets for therapeutic intervention. Further investigations are necessary to fully understand the underlying mechanisms involved in this process.

Repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy improve the results of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy on the outcomes of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia. A retrospective review of patients who underwent this procedure was conducted. A total of 85 patients were included in the analysis. The results showed that the use of repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy significantly improved the outcomes of endocardial resection. The incidence of recurrent ventricular tachycardia was reduced, and the overall success rate of the procedure was significantly higher. Additionally, the procedure was found to be safe, with a low incidence of complications. These findings suggest that repetitive intraoperative mapping and cryotherapy should be considered as adjunctive techniques to enhance the efficacy of endocardial resection for ventricular tachycardia.

Vascular entrapment of intra-aortic balloon after short-term balloon counterpulsation. Vascular entrapment of intra-aortic balloon (IAB) is a rare complication of short-term balloon counterpulsation. We report a case of IAB entrapment in a 62-year-old male who underwent IAB insertion for acute myocardial infarction. Despite appropriate placement and function, the IAB became entrapped between the aortic wall and the femoral artery during deflation. Emergent surgical intervention was required to release the entrapment and prevent further complications. This case highlights the importance of careful monitoring and prompt recognition of potential complications associated with IAB use. Clinicians should be aware of this possible complication when managing patients undergoing short-term balloon counterpulsation to minimize risks and optimize patient outcomes.

Pancreatic ascites presenting in infancy, with review of the literature. Pancreatic ascites is a rare condition presenting in infancy characterized by the accumulation of pancreatic fluid in the peritoneal cavity. We present a case of a 6-month-old infant with pancreatic ascites and review the literature on this condition. The infant presented with abdominal distension, vomiting, and failure to thrive. Abdominal ultrasound revealed the presence of free fluid and further investigations confirmed the diagnosis of pancreatic ascites. Conservative management was initiated with total parenteral nutrition and somatostatin analog therapy, resulting in a gradual improvement in symptoms and complete resolution of the ascites. Although rare, pancreatic ascites should be considered in the differential diagnosis of abdominal distension in infants. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management can lead to favorable outcomes in these patients. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of this condition.

Localization of calcitonin gene-related peptide in human esophageal Langerhans cells. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) is a neuropeptide that has been implicated in various physiological and pathological processes. Langerhans cells (LCs) are professional antigen-presenting cells located in the skin and mucosal tissues, and they play a crucial role in immune responses. However, the presence of CGRP in LCs of the human esophagus has not been thoroughly investigated. In this study, we aimed to determine the localization of CGRP in LCs of the human esophagus. Immunofluorescence staining revealed the presence of CGRP in LCs scattered throughout the esophageal epithelium. Dual immunofluorescence staining further demonstrated co-localization of CGRP and LC-specific marker CD1a in these cells. Moreover, confocal microscopy analysis confirmed the presence of CGRP-containing vesicles in LCs. These findings suggest that LCs in the human esophagus contain CGRP, which may have implications for immune regulation and potential therapeutic applications. Further studies are needed to elucidate the functional significance of CGRP in LCs and its role in esophageal immune responses.

Death and functional outcome after spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. In this study, we aimed to investigate the association between deaths and functional outcomes after spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). The study included 200 patients who were admitted to the hospital with spontaneous ICH. The patients were followed up for a period of one year. At the end of the follow-up period, 50% of the patients had died, while the remaining 50% had varying degrees of functional disability. Older age, higher initial Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, larger hematoma volume, and presence of intraventricular hemorrhage were found to be predictors of both death and poor functional outcome. Additionally, patients with hypertension had a higher risk of death, while patients with a lower GCS score at admission were more likely to have a poor functional outcome. These findings highlight the importance of early identification of risk factors in patients with spontaneous ICH in order to improve their outcomes and reduce mortality rates.

Hypercalcemia with excess serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D in lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma. This case report describes a patient with lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma who presented with hypercalcemia and excess serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D levels. The patient was a 58-year-old male who initially presented with generalized symptoms, including fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats. Laboratory tests revealed hypercalcemia and elevated serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D levels. Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of lymphomatoid granulomatosis/angiocentric lymphoma. The patient received treatment with chemotherapy, leading to a significant improvement in his symptoms and normalization of serum calcium and 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D levels. This case emphasizes the importance of considering lymphomatoid granulomatosis as a potential cause of hypercalcemia and highlights the potential role of excess serum 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D in this condition.

Meningeal involvement in Bence Jones multiple myeloma. We report a case of a patient with Bence Jones multiple myeloma who developed meningeal involvement. The patient presented with neurological symptoms including severe headache, visual disturbances, and lower limb weakness. Lumbar puncture revealed the presence of abnormal monoclonal proteins in the cerebrospinal fluid, confirming meningeal involvement. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spine showed diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement. The patient underwent high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation. He subsequently experienced a significant improvement in his neurological symptoms and resolution of the meningeal enhancement on imaging. Meningeal involvement in Bence Jones multiple myeloma is a rare manifestation of the disease, and prompt recognition and treatment are crucial for optimal patient outcomes. High-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplantation may be an effective therapeutic option in these cases.

Spinal cord decompression via a modified costotransversectomy approach combined with posterior instrumentation for management of metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine. Metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine often lead to spinal cord compression and significant neurological deficits. A new surgical technique combining spinal cord decompression via a modified costotransversectomy approach with posterior instrumentation was evaluated in 25 patients. The procedure involves resection of the involved costotransverse joint followed by en bloc resection of the tumor and involved vertebral body. Posterior instrumentation was then utilized to stabilize the spine and maintain alignment. The surgical technique resulted in significant improvement in pain scores and neurological function in all patients. Additionally, no intraoperative complications or cases of implant failure were reported. This combined surgical approach provides effective management for metastatic neoplasms of the thoracic spine, resulting in improved patient outcomes.

Vertical partial laryngectomy: a critical analysis of local recurrence. Vertical partial laryngectomy (VPL) is a surgical procedure commonly used for the treatment of early-stage laryngeal cancer. However, the risk of local recurrence remains a concern. In this study, we aimed to critically analyze the incidence of local recurrence following VPL. 

A total of 76 patients who underwent VPL for laryngeal cancer were included in the analysis. The mean follow-up period was 45 months. Local recurrence was defined as the presence of tumor at or adjacent to the previous resection site. 

The overall incidence of local recurrence was found to be 10.5%. Among the variables examined, only positive surgical margins were significantly associated with an increased risk of local recurrence (p=0.012). Tumor grade, depth of invasion, and lymph node involvement did not have a significant impact on local recurrence rates. 

In conclusion, VPL is an effective treatment option for early-stage laryngeal cancer, with a low incidence of local recurrence. Positive surgical margins should be carefully managed to minimize the risk of recurrence. Further studies are warranted to explore additional factors that may influence local recurrence rates following VPL.

Growth abnormalities in children with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. Children with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JRA) often experience growth abnormalities, which can have long-term consequences on their overall health and development. This abstract explores the potential causes and implications of these growth abnormalities in JRA patients. Factors such as chronic inflammation, corticosteroid use, and decreased physical activity may contribute to impaired growth and skeletal maturation. Studies have shown that growth retardation is more common in severe forms of JRA, particularly those with systemic features. Early diagnosis and appropriate management of JRA, including aggressive control of inflammation and optimization of growth and bone health, are crucial in preventing long-term growth impairments and optimizing the overall well-being of these children. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and potential therapeutic interventions for growth abnormalities in children with JRA.

Complications of nasotracheal intubation in neonates, infants and children: a review of 4 years' experience in a children's hospital.  A computerized database was set up to study the incidence and outcome of complications of nasotracheal intubation in a paediatric hospital. To investigate complications of nasotracheal intubation in neonates, infants, and children, we conducted a retrospective analysis of a computerized database from a pediatric hospital over a 4-year period. The study aimed to assess the incidence and outcomes of these complications. A total of XX patients were included in the analysis. The most common complications observed were epistaxis, laryngotracheal edema, and displacement of the endotracheal tube. The incidence of complications varied across age groups, with neonates exhibiting the highest rate. While most complications were minor, a few cases required intervention, such as tube repositioning or surgical intervention. This analysis highlights the importance of careful monitoring and management of nasotracheal intubation in pediatric patients.

Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. This retrospective study aims to investigate the incidence and progression of fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. Medical records of 127 children who underwent radical surgery for craniopharyngiomas between 2000 and 2010 were reviewed. Out of these, 33 children (26%) developed fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery. The mean time from surgery to the appearance of dilatation was 3.7 years. Progressive dilatation was observed in 21 cases (63.6%) during the follow-up period ranging from 2 to 10 years. No significant association was found between the occurrence of dilatation and age, sex, tumor size, or surgical approach. However, the presence of hydrocephalus and the need for ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement were significantly associated with a higher risk of developing fusiform dilatations. In conclusion, children who undergo radical surgery for craniopharyngiomas should be closely monitored for the development and progression of fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery, particularly those with hydrocephalus or requiring ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement.

Cholesterol cysts of the temporal bone: diagnosis and treatment.  Cholesterol cyst (or granuloma) of the temporal bone, a recognized clinical entity distinct from cholesteatoma, is more common than previously thought. Cholesterol cyst (or granuloma) of the temporal bone is a distinct clinical entity that is more common than previously believed. It is different from cholesteatoma and requires accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment. This study aims to review the diagnosis and treatment of cholesterol cysts of the temporal bone. Diagnostic methods, including computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), are discussed, along with their limitations and advantages. Surgical management options, such as cyst marsupialization or excision, are also described. The importance of complete cyst removal to prevent recurrence and complications is emphasized. Additionally, the potential complications of cholesterol cysts, such as erosion of adjacent structures and hearing loss, are outlined. Overall, early recognition and appropriate management of cholesterol cysts are essential for optimal patient outcomes.

Acute porphyria presenting with hyperamylasemia. Acute porphyria, a group of rare metabolic disorders, can present with various atypical symptoms including hyperamylasemia, elevated levels of amylase enzyme in the blood. We report a case study of a 45-year-old female presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated serum amylase levels. The patient had a history of acute intermittent porphyria, and subsequent investigations confirmed the diagnosis. Acute porphyria can lead to abdominal symptoms mimicking pancreatitis, resulting in a misdiagnosis and delayed treatment. Awareness of this atypical presentation and consideration of porphyria in the differential diagnosis is crucial to facilitate prompt management and prevent complications. Early recognition and appropriate treatment are essential for improving clinical outcomes in patients with acute porphyria presenting with hyperamylasemia.

Delayed hearing loss after neurovascular decompression. Neurovascular decompression (NVD) is a surgical procedure commonly performed to alleviate symptoms associated with cranial nerve compression. While NVD is generally considered safe and effective, delayed hearing loss has been reported as a rare but significant complication. A retrospective analysis of 56 patients who underwent NVD for various indications revealed delayed hearing loss in 5 patients (8.9%) at a median follow-up of 7 years. The etiology of this delayed hearing loss remains unclear, but vascular injury, inflammatory response, and direct trauma to the cochlear nerve have been proposed as potential mechanisms. Given the potential for this rare complication, patients undergoing NVD should be counseled appropriately, and long-term audiological surveillance may be warranted to facilitate early detection and intervention for delayed hearing loss.

Long term follow-up of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral bypass.  A prospective study of 26 patients undergoing descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass was conducted over a 13-year period with an average follow up of 53 months. This prospective study evaluated the long-term outcomes of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass in 26 patients over a 13-year period. The average follow-up duration was 53 months. The study aimed to assess the efficacy and durability of this bypass procedure. Patency rates, limb salvage rates, and overall survival were analyzed. The results showed a favorable patency rate of 92.3%, with 1-year and 5-year limb salvage rates of 92.3% and 88.5%, respectively. Overall survival rates at 1 year, 3 years, and 5 years were 92.3%, 77%, and 61.5% respectively. The study demonstrates the long-term effectiveness of DTAI/F bypass in maintaining satisfactory blood flow and preventing limb loss in patients with descending thoracic aortic disease.

Comparative clinical pharmacology of calcium channel blockers. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a commonly used class of antihypertensive medications with varying pharmacological properties. There are three main subclasses of CCBs: dihydropyridines (DHPs), non-dihydropyridines (non-DHPs), and dual-action agents. DHPs primarily act on vascular smooth muscle, leading to peripheral vasodilation, while non-DHPs have additional effects on cardiac tissue, resulting in negative chronotropic and inotropic effects. Dual-action agents combine the properties of both DHPs and non-DHPs. Several comparative clinical trials have been conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of different CCBs. Overall, the efficacy of CCBs in lowering blood pressure is similar among the subclasses, but individual responses may vary. Adverse effects such as peripheral edema, flushing, and constipation are more commonly seen with DHPs, while non-DHPs are associated with more negative cardiovascular effects, such as bradycardia and heart block. Careful consideration of patient characteristics and comorbidities is necessary when selecting the appropriate CCB subclass for individual patients.

Intercostal arteriovenous fistula due to pleural biopsy A 32 year old woman had a pleural biopsy for a left pleural effusion, which showed caseating granuloma typical of tuberculosis. A 32-year-old woman underwent a pleural biopsy to investigate a left pleural effusion. The biopsy revealed a caseating granuloma consistent with tuberculosis. Following the biopsy, the patient developed an intercostal arteriovenous fistula. This rare complication involves an abnormal connection between an artery and vein in the intercostal area of the chest. It is likely that the biopsy procedure caused injury to nearby blood vessels, resulting in the fistula formation. The patient's condition was managed through surgical repair of the fistula. This case highlights the importance of considering such complications in patients undergoing pleural biopsy and the need for prompt diagnosis and treatment.

Ultrasonographic detection of the second-trimester fetus with trisomy 18 and trisomy 21. This study aimed to assess the accuracy of ultrasonographic detection of fetuses with trisomy 18 and trisomy 21 during the second trimester of pregnancy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 200 pregnant women who underwent ultrasound examination between 18 and 24 weeks of gestation. Of the 200 fetuses, 10 were diagnosed with trisomy 18 and 15 with trisomy 21. The ultrasound findings were compared to the final diagnosis obtained after genetic testing. The detection rate for trisomy 18 was 80% and for trisomy 21 was 93.3%. The most common ultrasound findings in trisomy 18 were increased nuchal translucency, structural abnormalities, and growth retardation. In trisomy 21, the most frequent findings were increased nuchal translucency, echogenic intracardiac focus, and shortened long bones. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of ultrasound in detecting trisomy 18 were 75%, 98%, 83.3%, and 97.4% respectively, while for trisomy 21, these values were 86.7%, 99.4%, 92.9%, and 99.3% respectively. In conclusion, ultrasonographic evaluation during the second trimester can be an effective tool in detecting fetuses with trisomy 18 and trisomy 21.

Idiopathic sclerosing peritonitis in a man. Idiopathic sclerosing peritonitis (ISP) is a rare condition characterized by fibrosis and inflammation of the peritoneum. It predominantly affects women of childbearing age and is associated with endometriosis, but cases in men are extremely rare. We report a case of ISP in a 45-year-old man with no history of previous abdominal surgery or endometriosis. He presented with abdominal pain, ascites, and small bowel obstruction. Computed tomography scan revealed thickening of the peritoneum and sclerotic changes. Diagnostic laparoscopy confirmed the presence of extensive fibrous adhesions throughout the peritoneum. Histopathological examination demonstrated dense fibrosis and chronic inflammation. The patient was treated conservatively with immunosuppressive therapy and experienced partial symptom relief. This case highlights the diagnostic challenge and management options for ISP in men, emphasizing the need for a thorough evaluation in cases of unexplained peritoneal thickening and adhesions.

Malignant potential of juvenile polyposis coli. Juvenile polyposis coli (JPC) is a rare hereditary condition characterized by the development of multiple gastrointestinal polyps. While most JPC cases are benign and have a favorable prognosis, a subset of patients may develop malignant transformations within their polyps. This study aimed to assess the malignant potential of JPC by analyzing a cohort of 50 patients with confirmed JPC diagnosis. The majority of patients (90%) had polyps confined to the colon and rectum. Histopathological examination revealed that 10% of patients had polyps showing dysplasia, while 8% had polyps demonstrating overt malignancy. These findings indicate that a small but significant proportion of JPC cases may progress to malignancy, necessitating close monitoring and appropriate management in these patients.

Dental enamel defects in first-degree relatives of coeliac disease patients. Coeliac disease (CD) is known to be associated with dental enamel defects, but whether first-degree relatives of CD patients are also at risk is unclear. In this study, dental enamel defects were examined in first-degree relatives (n = 127) of CD patients and a control group (n = 106). The presence and severity of dental enamel defects were assessed using clinical examination and photographs. Statistical analysis revealed a significantly higher prevalence of dental enamel defects in first-degree relatives of CD patients compared to controls (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that there may be a genetic predisposition for dental enamel defects in individuals with a family history of CD. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and implications of these findings.

Impact of anatomical radical prostatectomy on urinary continence. We investigated the impact of anatomical radical prostatectomy on urinary continence in a cohort of patients. A total of 99 patients who underwent this procedure were included in the study. The mean age of the patients was 62.5 +/- 6.2 years. Following surgery, patients were followed for a median period of 24 months. At the end of the follow-up period, 84% of patients achieved complete continence, defined as no use of any pad or protection. Among the remaining patients, 10% reported minimal use of pads, while 6% required the use of pads for moderate to severe incontinence. Our findings demonstrate that anatomical radical prostatectomy can lead to favorable urinary continence outcomes in the majority of patients, highlighting the effectiveness of this surgical intervention in managing prostate cancer-related urinary incontinence.

Spinal accessory nerve palsy: an unusual complication of coronary artery bypass The neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery have been well documented, with a reported incidence of 61% in one large study.  Most injuries to the peripheral nervous system involve the brachial plexus. Spinal accessory nerve palsy is an uncommon complication of coronary artery bypass surgery. This case study presents a patient who developed spinal accessory nerve palsy following surgery. The patient initially presented with weakness and atrophy of the trapezius muscle, which affected shoulder movement and caused significant functional impairment. Diagnosis was confirmed through electromyography and nerve conduction studies. Treatment options included physical therapy, pain management, and surgical intervention. This case highlights the need for early recognition and appropriate management of spinal accessory nerve palsy in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery to optimize outcomes and prevent long-term disability.

Coagulation factor abnormalities as possible thrombotic risk factors after Fontan operations. Coagulation factor abnormalities have been suggested as potential risk factors for thrombotic complications after Fontan operations. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of coagulation factor abnormalities in Fontan patients and their association with thrombotic events. The study included 78 Fontan patients who underwent comprehensive coagulation testing, including measurement of factor VIII, von Willebrand factor antigen, and antithrombin III levels. Thrombotic events were recorded during a follow-up period of 5 years. The results showed that a significant proportion of Fontan patients had coagulation factor abnormalities, with elevated factor VIII levels being the most common abnormality. Additionally, a positive correlation was found between coagulation factor abnormalities and the occurrence of thrombotic events. These findings highlight the importance of screening for coagulation factor abnormalities in Fontan patients and suggest potential strategies for preventing thrombotic complications post-operation. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms underlying these abnormalities and their impact on patient outcomes.

Current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. Duplex Doppler ultrasound is a widely used modality for examining the abdominal vasculature. This review presents the current status of its application in clinical practice. The technique combines real-time B-mode ultrasound with Doppler assessment to provide information on both anatomical structure and blood flow characteristics. Duplex Doppler ultrasound offers several advantages, including non-invasiveness, absence of ionizing radiation exposure, and the ability to assess both arterial and venous circulations. It has shown utility in the evaluation of various abdominal vasculopathies, such as atherosclerosis, aneurysms, arterial stenosis, and venous thrombosis. Additionally, it can be used to guide interventional procedures, such as angioplasty and stent placement. However, there are limitations to consider, such as operator dependency and challenges in imaging obese patients or those with bowel gas. Despite these limitations, duplex Doppler ultrasound remains a valuable tool for initial screening, follow-up monitoring, and guiding interventions in patients with abdominal vascular diseases. Further advancements in technology and standardization of protocols are expected to improve its diagnostic accuracy and broaden its clinical applications.

Community lifestyle characteristics and risk of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia in children. This study aimed to investigate the association between community lifestyle characteristics and the risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children. The study included 236 cases of ALL and 446 controls matched by age, sex, and residential area. Data on community lifestyle characteristics, such as population density, smoking prevalence, air pollution levels, and access to green spaces, were collected. Logistic regression analysis was conducted to assess the association between these characteristics and ALL risk. The results showed that higher population density and smoking prevalence were significantly associated with an increased risk of ALL in children. Moreover, increased exposure to air pollution and a lack of access to green spaces were also associated with a higher risk of ALL. These findings suggest the importance of community lifestyle factors in the development of pediatric ALL and highlight the need for targeted interventions to reduce these risk factors.

Mapping of the locus for X-linked cardioskeletal myopathy with neutropenia and abnormal mitochondria (Barth syndrome) to Xq28.  X-linked cardioskeletal myopathy with neutropenia and abnormal mitochondria is clinically characterized by congenital dilated cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, recurrent bacterial infections, and growth retardation. Barth syndrome, an X-linked disorder, is characterized by various clinical manifestations including congenital dilated cardiomyopathy, skeletal myopathy, recurrent bacterial infections, and growth retardation. This study aimed to map the locus for Barth syndrome to the Xq28 region. Through genetic analysis and linkage mapping in affected families, the Xq28 region was identified as the locus for Barth syndrome. This finding provides valuable insights into the genetic basis of the disorder and paves the way for further investigations into the underlying molecular mechanisms. Understanding the genetic and molecular factors involved in Barth syndrome can lead to improved diagnostic methods, better management strategies, and potential therapeutic interventions for patients with this X-linked condition.

Topical fibronectin and aprotinin for keratectomy wound healing in rabbits. This study evaluated the effects of topical fibronectin and aprotinin on wound healing following keratectomy in rabbits. Thirty-two New Zealand White rabbits were divided into four groups: control, fibronectin, aprotinin, and combined fibronectin-aprotinin. After keratectomy, the rabbits received topical administration of saline (control group), fibronectin, aprotinin, or both fibronectin and aprotinin twice daily for 7 days. The rabbits were then euthanized, and the corneas were histologically examined and evaluated for epithelial defect area, corneal neovascularization, collagen deposition, and inflammatory response. The fibronectin group showed significantly reduced epithelial defect area and corneal neovascularization compared to the control group. Collagen deposition was significantly increased in both the fibronectin and aprotinin groups compared to the control group. The combined fibronectin-aprotinin group exhibited the best overall wound healing with significantly reduced epithelial defect, corneal neovascularization, and inflammatory response compared to the other groups. These findings suggest that topical administration of fibronectin and aprotinin may enhance wound healing following keratectomy in rabbits, with the combined treatment showing the most significant effects. Further studies are needed to explore the mechanisms underlying these effects.

Translocation breakpoint of acute promyelocytic leukemia lies within the retinoic acid receptor alpha locus. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is characterized by a specific genetic translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17, resulting in the fusion gene PML-RARA. This study aimed to determine the precise location of the translocation breakpoint within the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) locus on chromosome 17. Using various molecular techniques, including fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR), the translocation breakpoint was identified within intron 3 of the RARA gene. This breakpoint generates a fusion protein that disrupts normal cellular differentiation and leads to the development of APL. The identification of the specific location of the translocation breakpoint provides valuable insights into the pathogenesis of APL and may have implications for targeted therapeutic interventions. Further studies are needed to elucidate the functional consequences of this fusion protein and to develop rational therapeutic strategies for APL based on the understanding of its underlying molecular mechanisms.

Hepatocellular carcinoma with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium: report of a successful resection with the use of cardiopulmonary bypass. We present a case report of a successful resection of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with tumor thrombus extending into the right atrium. A 60-year-old male with multiple liver masses and dyspnea was diagnosed with HCC and tumor thrombus involving the right hepatic vein extending into the right atrium. The patient underwent surgical resection with the aid of cardiopulmonary bypass and hypothermic circulatory arrest. The tumor thrombus was removed from the right atrium, and complete tumor resection was achieved. The patient recovered well postoperatively without any complications. This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive surgical intervention in selected patients with HCC and tumor thrombus involving the right atrium. The use of cardiopulmonary bypass provides adequate hemodynamic support and allows for complete tumor resection, leading to improved outcomes in these complex cases.

Antithrombotic efficacy of continuous extradural analgesia after knee replacement.  We have studied the effect of extradural analgesia on postoperative venous thrombosis in patients undergoing knee arthroplasty. In this study, we investigated the antithrombotic efficacy of continuous extradural analgesia in patients undergoing knee replacement surgery. A total of 100 patients were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either continuous extradural analgesia or standard postoperative analgesia. The occurrence of postoperative venous thrombosis was assessed using Doppler ultrasound on postoperative days 3 and 7. 

The results showed that the incidence of postoperative venous thrombosis was significantly lower in the extradural analgesia group compared to the standard analgesia group (14% vs 34%, p < 0.05). Furthermore, the extradural analgesia group had a lower incidence of proximal deep vein thrombosis (4% vs 16%, p < 0.05). 

Our findings suggest that continuous extradural analgesia provides an effective antithrombotic effect in patients undergoing knee replacement surgery. This technique may be considered as a valuable adjunct in the prevention of postoperative venous thrombosis in this patient population. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and determine the optimal duration and dosage of extradural analgesia.

Brainstem auditory evoked response and subcortical abnormalities in autism. Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impairments in communication, social interaction, and restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior. Previous studies have suggested that individuals with autism may have subcortical abnormalities and auditory processing deficits. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between brainstem auditory evoked responses (BAER) and subcortical abnormalities in autism. BAER measurements were taken from 30 individuals with autism and 30 age- and gender-matched typically developing controls. Magnetic resonance imaging scans were also obtained to assess subcortical abnormalities. The results revealed significantly delayed latencies and reduced amplitudes of BAER components in the autism group compared to controls, indicating impaired auditory processing. Additionally, individuals with autism showed significantly smaller volumes in various subcortical regions compared to controls. These findings provide further evidence of auditory processing deficits and subcortical abnormalities in autism, highlighting the importance of understanding these underlying neural mechanisms for better diagnosis and treatment of the disorder.

Repeat hepatic resection for primary and metastatic carcinoma of the liver. Repeat hepatic resection is a viable treatment option for patients with primary and metastatic carcinoma of the liver. We present a retrospective analysis of 50 patients who underwent a second hepatic resection for recurrent disease. The median time between the initial and repeat resection was 18 months.
