The overall survival rate at 1, 3, and 5 years after the second resection was 80%, 55%, and 40% respectively. Factors associated with improved survival included solitary hepatic recurrence, absence of extrahepatic disease, and tumor-free resection margins. Repeat hepatic resection was well-tolerated with low rates of morbidity and mortality. Our findings support the use of repeat hepatic resection as a potentially curative treatment option for selected patients with recurrent liver carcinoma.

Extrahepatic metabolism of morphine occurs in humans.  The pharmacokinetics of morphine was studied in six patients in whom a radiologic localization of an insulinoma was to be performed under general anesthesia. In this study, the extrahepatic metabolism of morphine in humans was investigated in six patients undergoing general anesthesia for radiologic localization of an insulinoma. Following the administration of morphine, plasma levels of the drug and its metabolites were measured at regular intervals. The results showed that morphine undergoes significant extrahepatic metabolism in humans, as evidenced by the detection of both morphine-6-glucuronide and morphine-3-glucuronide in plasma samples. The pharmacokinetics of morphine exhibited inter-individual variability, with clearance rates ranging from 0.29 to 1.08 L/min. No significant adverse effects were observed during the study period. These findings highlight the importance of considering extrahepatic metabolism in the pharmacokinetics of morphine and suggest that individualized dosing regimens may be necessary in patients undergoing anesthesia for insulinoma localization.

Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm: an indication for the retroperitoneal approach. Inflammatory abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention. The retroperitoneal approach has been proposed as a preferred surgical technique due to its advantages in these cases. This study aims to evaluate the outcomes of the retroperitoneal approach in patients with inflammatory AAA. A retrospective analysis of 35 patients who underwent surgery for inflammatory AAA was conducted. The retroperitoneal approach was used in all cases, and perioperative outcomes were analyzed. The results showed that the retroperitoneal approach was associated with lower rates of postoperative complications, shorter hospital stay, and improved overall outcomes compared to other surgical approaches. This study highlights the importance of considering the retroperitoneal approach as the preferred surgical technique for patients with inflammatory AAA. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and determine the long-term outcomes of this approach.

Bilateral vocal cord teflon injection. This case report describes a 37-year-old Japanese man with abdominal lumps who had previously undergone proctocolectomy for familial polyposis coli (FPC) with rectal cancer. Tumors were found in the abdominal wall, mesentery, and retroperitoneum during laparotomy and were identified as desmoid tumors. Administration of prednisolone at doses ranging from 20 to 5 mg/day resulted in subjective symptom improvement and gradual regression of the desmoid tumors. However, the patient developed bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to retroperitoneal fibrosis, which is an uncommon complication in FPC. This case highlights the characteristics of desmoid tumors in FPC and Gardner's syndrome and discusses management strategies. Additionally, the abstract briefly mentions bilateral vocal cord teflon injection without further details.

Streptococcal antibody cross-reactivity with HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes. This study investigated the cross-reactivity of streptococcal antibodies with HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes. The results showed that streptococcal antibodies had a significant cross-reactivity with HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes, suggesting a potential link between streptococcal infections and autoimmune diseases associated with HLA-DR4. The study provides important insights into the mechanism underlying the development of autoimmune diseases following streptococcal infections, and highlights the role of HLA-DR4 in this process. Further research is warranted to fully understand the implications of these findings and to develop potential therapeutic interventions targeting the cross-reactivity between streptococcal antibodies and HLA-DR4+VE B-lymphocytes.

Prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 ratio in arteriogenic impotence. The prostacyclin-to-thromboxane A2 (PGI2/TXA2) ratio in arteriogenic impotence was investigated as a potential marker for endothelial dysfunction. The study enrolled 38 male patients with arteriogenic impotence and 20 age-matched healthy controls. Serum levels of PGI2 and TXA2 were measured by enzyme immunoassay, and the PGI2/TXA2 ratio was calculated. The arteriogenic impotence group showed significantly lower PGI2 levels and a lower PGI2/TXA2 ratio compared to the control group. There was a negative correlation between the PGI2/TXA2 ratio and the severity of impotence, as assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function questionnaire. These findings suggest that a decreased PGI2/TXA2 ratio may be indicative of endothelial dysfunction in arteriogenic impotence. Further research is needed to explore the potential of this ratio as a diagnostic marker and therapeutic target in this patient population.

Cerebral venography with MR.  The authors describe a two-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance (MR) angiography technique to create projection venograms of the head. In this study, the authors present a novel two-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance (MR) angiography technique for creating projection venograms of the head, referred to as cerebral venography with MR. The technique was applied to 28 patients with alpha-fetoprotein-positive (AFP+) nonresectable hepatoma who were enrolled in a multimodality Phase I, II program. The induction therapy involved intravenous cisplatin followed by irradiation to the tumor volume, and hepatic arterial infusion of cisplatin was administered at monthly intervals. Out of the 28 patients, 21 completed the induction therapy and at least two cycles of hepatic arterial infusion. The 12-month cumulative survival rate was 52% for all patients and 69% for those who completed the treatment. The response rate was 36% overall and 48% among patients who completed the treatment. The study suggests that the integration of new modalities for therapy may further improve survival outcomes, considering the minimal hematologic toxicity observed in this series of patients.

Hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin in patients on dialysis.  Eighteen patients on chronic hemodialysis with renal anemia were treated with recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). We studied the hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia in 18 patients on dialysis using recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). Pre-treatment hemoglobin levels were below 9 g/dL in all patients. After 12 weeks of r-HuEPO therapy, hemoglobin levels increased significantly to a mean of 11.5 g/dL. Cardiac output and systemic vascular resistance remained unchanged, and there were no significant changes in blood pressure or heart rate. However, there was a slight but significant increase in mean arterial pressure. These findings suggest that partial correction of chronic anemia with r-HuEPO in patients on dialysis does not significantly affect hemodynamic parameters, indicating its safety and efficacy in managing renal anemia.

Genitourinary cancer in the elderly. This study aims to analyze the clinicopathologic features and prognosis of chordomas based on a 20-year review at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. The study identified 18 cases of chordomas, with a slight female predominance (11 females and 7 males), occurring mostly in the sphenoid region (61%). The youngest patient was 3 years old and with a family history of chordoma. Histological analysis revealed two variants, classical (epithelial) and chondroid, which did not significantly impact the outcome. Treatment modalities included surgery, radiotherapy, and neutron beam therapy, with surgical resection offering the best chance of survival. The mean survival in this series was 73.4 months, with a 50% survival rate. Chordomas, despite being amenable to surgical resection, carry a poor prognosis due to their propensity to metastasize.

Late luteal phase dysphoric disorder in young women. Late luteal phase dysphoric disorder (LLPDD) is a cyclical mood disorder experienced by some young women during the late phase of their menstrual cycle. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence, severity, and associated factors of LLPDD. A sample of 238 women aged 18-30 years completed self-report questionnaires assessing LLPDD symptoms, depressive symptoms, premenstrual symptoms, and stress levels. 28% of participants met the diagnostic criteria for LLPDD, with significant associations found between LLPDD and depressive symptoms, premenstrual symptoms, and stress levels. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing and addressing LLPDD in young women, as it can significantly impact their quality of life and mental health.

Reference values for the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) in octo- and nonagenarians The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) was used in a population survey of all inhabitants of Leiden, the Netherlands, over 85 years (n = 1258). The reference values for the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) were determined for individuals over the age of 85 in a population survey in Leiden, the Netherlands. A total of 1258 octo- and nonagenarians participated in the study. The mean MMSE score was found to be 24.2 (range 0-30), with a standard deviation of 4.9. Age and education level were significantly associated with MMSE scores. These reference values provide a useful tool for clinicians and researchers in assessing cognitive function in elderly individuals, particularly those over the age of 85. Further research is needed to validate these reference values in other populations.

Olfactory neuroblastoma: clinicopathologic and immunohistochemical characterization of four representative cases. Olfactory neuroblastoma is a rare malignant tumor arising from the olfactory epithelium. Here, we present a clinicopathologic and immunohistochemical characterization of four representative cases of olfactory neuroblastoma. The patients, three males and one female, presented with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and anosmia. Radiological imaging revealed a mass in the nasal cavity in all cases. Microscopically, the tumors exhibited a variety of growth patterns, including nested, trabecular, and rosette-like structures. Immunohistochemical analysis showed consistent expression of neuroendocrine markers, such as synaptophysin and chromogranin. Additionally, all cases exhibited strong expression of CD56 and pancytokeratin. S100 protein staining was positive in three cases, while CK7 staining was positive in two cases. The Ki-67 proliferation index ranged from 10-25%. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma was confirmed in all cases. In conclusion, this study provides further insight into the clinicopathologic features and immunohistochemical profile of olfactory neuroblastoma, aiding in accurate diagnosis and management of this rare tumor.

Reversal of colchicine-induced mitotic arrest in Chinese hamster cells with a colchicine-specific monoclonal antibody.  The ability of a high-affinity colchicine-binding monoclonal antibody to reverse the effects of colchicine on Chinese hamster ovary cells was investigated. This study aimed to assess the potential of a colchicine-specific monoclonal antibody in reversing the mitotic arrest induced by colchicine in Chinese hamster ovary cells. Colchicine is known to interfere with microtubule assembly, leading to cell cycle arrest. The study utilized a high-affinity monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to colchicine. Results showed that the monoclonal antibody effectively reverted the mitotic arrest in the cells, indicating its potential as an antidote for colchicine-induced toxicity. This finding highlights the therapeutic potential of using targeted monoclonal antibodies to reverse the adverse effects of colchicine and potentially improve patient outcomes. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical applications of this antibody in the treatment of colchicine toxicity.

The justification for surgical treatment of metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract.  Fifty-six patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) treated surgically at the Sydney Melanoma Unit between 1974 and 1989 were reviewed. This study aimed to evaluate the rationale for surgical treatment in patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). A total of 56 patients who underwent surgery at the Sydney Melanoma Unit between 1974 and 1989 were included in the review. Results showed that surgical treatment provided palliation of symptoms and improved survival in selected patients. The median survival after surgery was 13 months, with a 5-year survival rate of 21%. Gastrointestinal bleeding was the most common symptom, followed by obstruction and perforation. Surgery was associated with low morbidity and mortality rates. Therefore, surgical intervention should be considered as a valuable treatment option for patients with symptomatic metastatic melanoma of the GIT.

Fourth branchial pouch anomaly. Fourth branchial pouch anomalies are rare congenital anomalies that result from the incomplete obliteration of the fourth branchial pouch during embryonic development. We present a case of a 32-year-old female who presented with recurrent neck abscess and was diagnosed with a fourth branchial pouch anomaly. She underwent surgical excision of the cystic lesion and definitive treatment involved ligation of the fistulous communication between the pharynx and the cyst. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and has remained asymptomatic during follow-up. This case highlights the importance of considering fourth branchial pouch anomalies in the differential diagnosis of recurrent neck abscess and emphasizes the effectiveness of surgical excision as the treatment of choice for this condition.

Plasma exchange in chronic progressive multiple sclerosis: a long-term study. Plasma exchange has been used as a therapeutic intervention in patients with chronic progressive multiple sclerosis (MS), although its long-term effectiveness remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the efficacy of plasma exchange in a long-term follow-up period for patients with chronic progressive MS. Thirty-five patients with confirmed chronic progressive MS were enrolled in the study and underwent plasma exchange treatment. Clinical and radiological assessments were performed before and after plasma exchange, and patients were followed up for a minimum of five years. Results showed that plasma exchange led to significant improvements in neurological disability and disease progression in the short-term. However, these effects were not sustained in the long-term follow-up period, with a gradual decline in the clinical response observed over time. These findings suggest that while plasma exchange may provide temporary benefits for patients with chronic progressive MS, alternative and more effective treatment options should be explored for long-term management of the disease.

Mastalgia refractory to drug treatment. Mastalgia, or breast pain, is a common complaint among women, and its management can be challenging. This medical abstract discusses the case of a patient with refractory mastalgia who did not respond to conventional drug treatment. The patient was a 45-year-old female who had been experiencing severe breast pain for over six months. She had previously been treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and hormonal therapies, but her symptoms persisted. The patient underwent a thorough evaluation, including a physical examination, mammography, and breast ultrasound, which did not reveal any underlying pathology. Considering the lack of response to drug therapy and absence of any identifiable cause, alternative treatment options were considered. These included non-drug approaches such as lifestyle modifications, dietary changes, and supportive measures like proper bra fitting and psychological counseling. Additionally, complementary and alternative therapies like acupuncture, evening primrose oil, and vitamin E supplementation were explored. The patient's pain gradually improved with a combination of these interventions, highlighting the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in managing refractory mastalgia.

Solitary fibromatosis of bone.  A rare variant of congenital generalized fibromatosis. Solitary fibromatosis of bone is a rare variant of congenital generalized fibromatosis characterized by the presence of a single fibrous lesion within the bone. We report a case of a 50-year-old female who presented with pain and swelling in the left forearm. Radiological evaluation revealed a well-defined lytic lesion involving the proximal ulna. Histopathological examination of the lesion showed a fibrous proliferation with no evidence of malignancy. Further immunohistochemical staining confirmed the diagnosis of solitary fibromatosis of bone. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of solitary fibromatosis of bone in the ulna. Surgical excision was performed and the patient had an uneventful recovery with no recurrence at the six-month follow-up. Awareness of this rare entity is important to avoid unnecessary aggressive treatment.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the reliability of emergency center ultrasonography in detecting hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma. A total of 72 patients were included in the study. Ultrasonographic detection of hemoperitoneum was assessed. The results showed that ultrasonography had a high sensitivity (92%) and specificity (89%) in detecting hemoperitoneum. The positive predictive value was 94%, and the negative predictive value was 85%. This study suggests that emergency center ultrasonography is a reliable tool for detecting hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. It can aid in early diagnosis and prompt management of this potentially life-threatening condition.

Role of surgery in antibiotic-induced pseudomembranous enterocolitis. This study aimed to investigate the role of surgery in the management of antibiotic-induced pseudomembranous enterocolitis (AIPE). A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on patients diagnosed with AIPE who underwent surgical intervention. Data regarding patient demographics, clinical presentation, surgical procedures, outcomes, and complications were collected. A total of 46 patients were included in the study. The most common surgical procedure performed was colectomy (n=36), followed by ileostomy (n=8), and colostomy (n=2). The overall mortality rate was 21.7%. Complications were observed in 34.8% of the patients, with the most common being wound infection (10.9%) and anastomotic leakage (8.7%). Surgical intervention was found to be beneficial in cases of severe AIPE, especially when conservative management failed. However, it is important to consider the risks and potential complications associated with surgery in the context of AIPE. Further research is needed to optimize the surgical approach in these patients.

Chronic otitis media: the significance of nasal obstruction. Chronic otitis media is a common ear condition characterized by persistent inflammation of the middle ear. This study aimed to investigate the significance of nasal obstruction in the development and progression of chronic otitis media. A total of 100 patients with chronic otitis media were included in the study. The presence and severity of nasal obstruction were assessed using clinical examination and nasal endoscopy. Results showed that nasal obstruction was present in 82% of patients. The severity of otitis media was found to be significantly higher in patients with nasal obstruction compared to those without. Additionally, patients with severe nasal obstruction had a higher incidence of complications such as mastoiditis and sensorineural hearing loss. These findings suggest that nasal obstruction plays a significant role in the pathogenesis and progression of chronic otitis media and should be carefully managed to prevent complications.

Secondary femoral-distal bypass.  Thirty-nine secondary femoral-distal (femorotibial and femoroperoneal) bypasses were reviewed and compared to 89 primary femoral-distal bypasses (done during the same time period) to investigate the efficacy of secondary femoral-distal bypass. We reviewed 39 cases of secondary femoral-distal bypasses and compared them to 89 cases of primary femoral-distal bypasses to determine the efficacy of the secondary procedure. The results showed no significant differences in patency rates between the two groups at one year (63% for secondary vs 70% for primary) and three years (44% for secondary vs 50% for primary). The secondary group had a shorter mean time to graft occlusion (4.2 years) compared to the primary group (6.3 years), though this was not statistically significant. Complications, including infection, graft thrombosis, and limb loss, occurred at similar rates in both groups. Our findings suggest that secondary femoral-distal bypass can be a viable option for patients who have failed a primary procedure. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these results.

Late recurrence of a hepatocellular carcinoma in a patient with incomplete Alagille syndrome. We present a case of a late recurrence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a patient with incomplete Alagille syndrome. The patient, a 42-year-old male, underwent a liver transplant for HCC at the age of 29. Despite regular follow-up and surveillance, a new HCC lesion was identified 13 years post-transplantation, necessitating a second transplantation. Alagille syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by intrahepatic cholestasis, cardiac anomalies, and skeletal abnormalities, was diagnosed in the patient based on the characteristic clinical features and genetic testing. This case highlights the importance of long-term HCC surveillance in patients with Alagille syndrome who have undergone liver transplantation.

Artificial urinary sphincter insertion in congenital neuropathic bladder. Congenital neuropathic bladder is a condition commonly associated with spinal cord defects that result in inadequate bladder emptying and control. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) insertion in patients with this condition. A retrospective analysis of 25 patients who underwent AUS insertion for congenital neuropathic bladder was conducted. The mean follow-up period was 31 months. The results showed that AUS insertion resulted in significant improvement in urinary continence, with 96% of patients achieving complete continence. Complications were observed in 12% of patients, including erosion, infection, and urethral atrophy. However, these complications were manageable and did not require device removal in any of the cases. In conclusion, AUS insertion is a safe and effective treatment option for patients with congenital neuropathic bladder, providing excellent urinary continence with manageable complications.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV: diagnosis and therapy of associated bowel perforation. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome type IV (EDS-IV) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in collagen synthesis. We report a case of a 32-year-old male with EDS-IV who presented with acute abdominal pain and was diagnosed with bowel perforation. Diagnostic workup revealed a known mutation in the COL3A1 gene, confirming the diagnosis of EDS-IV. Prompt surgical intervention with resection of the affected bowel segment and primary anastomosis was performed, leading to a successful outcome. The management of bowel perforation in EDS-IV is challenging due to the inherent fragility of the affected tissues. Close monitoring and early surgical intervention are vital in preventing complications such as sepsis and death. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly treating bowel perforation in patients with EDS-IV.

Emerging techniques in the diagnosis of sinusitis. Purpose. This review aims to explore the emerging techniques in the diagnosis of sinusitis, a common inflammatory condition affecting the paranasal sinuses. Methods. A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify studies published within the past five years on novel diagnostic techniques for sinusitis. Results. Various emerging techniques were identified including nasal endoscopy, computed tomography (CT) imaging, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasound. Nasal endoscopy allows direct visualization of the sinuses, facilitating the identification of anatomical abnormalities and presence of polyps. CT imaging provides detailed images of the sinuses, helping to differentiate between various types of sinusitis and aiding in treatment planning. MRI is particularly useful in cases where complications or structural abnormalities are suspected. Ultrasound offers a non-invasive option for assessing sinus pathology and can be used for real-time guidance during sinus procedures. Conclusion. Emerging techniques in the diagnosis of sinusitis provide clinicians with valuable tools for accurate and efficient evaluation of this condition. Further research is needed to determine their optimal utilization and potential impact on patient outcomes.

Variceal rebleeding after portosystemic shunting. Variceal rebleeding is a common complication following portosystemic shunting procedures aimed at reducing portal hypertension in patients with liver cirrhosis. We conducted a retrospective study to assess the risk factors associated with variceal rebleeding after portosystemic shunting. The study included 150 patients who underwent portosystemic shunting for variceal bleeding. The incidence of variceal rebleeding was found to be 23.3%, with a median time to rebleeding of 13 months. The presence of large varices, Child-Pugh class C, and previous variceal bleeding were identified as independent risk factors for rebleeding. Additionally, patients who had undergone surgical shunting were more likely to experience rebleeding compared to those who had undergone transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt placement. These findings highlight the importance of careful patient selection and post-procedural management to prevent variceal rebleeding in this population.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. A review of 1000 consecutive autopsies was conducted to examine the characteristics of natural death as viewed by medical examiners. The autopsies were performed on individuals who died of natural diseases. Various factors such as age, sex, cause of death, and presence of comorbidities were analyzed. The study found that the most common natural disease-related deaths were cardiovascular diseases, followed by respiratory diseases and cancer. The majority of individuals were over 60 years old and had multiple comorbidities. Additionally, the study identified various pathological findings associated with different natural diseases. Understanding the patterns and characteristics of natural deaths can aid in improving medical diagnosis and management of diseases.

Infective dermatitis of Jamaican children: a marker for HTLV-I infection In Jamaican children infective dermatitis is a chronic eczema associated with refractory nonvirulent Staphylococcus aureus or beta-haemolytic streptococcus infection of the skin and nasal vestibule. Infective dermatitis is a chronic eczema seen in Jamaican children and is linked to infection with Human T-cell Leukemia Virus type 1 (HTLV-I). It is characterized by persistent Staphylococcus aureus or beta-haemolytic streptococcus infection of the skin and nasal vestibule that is resistant to treatment. This condition is considered a marker for HTLV-I infection in Jamaican children and serves as an important diagnostic clue. The presence of HTLV-I infection in these children highlights the need for early detection and appropriate management to prevent complications associated with this retroviral infection. Further research is necessary to determine the exact mechanisms underlying the association between infective dermatitis and HTLV-I infection in this population.

Evaluation of antral mast cells in nonulcer dyspepsia. Nonulcer dyspepsia (NUD) is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by recurring pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen without any evidence of ulceration. The pathophysiology of NUD remains unclear, but several studies have suggested a role for mast cells in the development of symptoms. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the presence and activation of antral mast cells in patients with NUD. A total of 50 patients with NUD and 50 healthy controls were included in the study. Antral biopsies were obtained during endoscopy, and mast cells were identified and quantified using histological staining techniques. Our results showed a significantly higher number of mast cells in the antrum of NUD patients compared to controls. Furthermore, a higher proportion of mast cells in NUD patients exhibited signs of degranulation, indicating their activation. These findings suggest a potential role for mast cells in the pathogenesis of NUD and provide a basis for future research investigating targeted therapies aimed at modulating mast cell activation in this patient population.

Multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an arteriovenous malformation in a patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is frequently associated with underlying vascular abnormalities. Here we present a case of SAH in a patient with multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an arteriovenous malformation (AVM). The patient presented with sudden-onset severe headache and was diagnosed with SAH on imaging studies. Further evaluation revealed the presence of multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple intracranial aneurysms, and an AVM. The management of SAH in patients with multiple arterial fenestrations, multiple aneurysms, and an AVM is challenging and requires a multidisciplinary approach. This case highlights the importance of thorough vascular imaging and careful consideration of treatment options in patients with complex vascular abnormalities associated with SAH.

Relevance of focal cerebral ischemia models. Focal cerebral ischemia models are essential tools for studying the mechanisms and potential treatments of stroke. This review aims to discuss the relevance and importance of currently available focal cerebral ischemia models. Animal models, particularly rodents, have been widely used in this field due to their similarity to human physiology. Various methods have been developed to induce focal cerebral ischemia, including intraluminal middle cerebral artery occlusion, embolic stroke models, and photothrombotic models. These models allow researchers to mimic different aspects of stroke pathology, such as ischemia-reperfusion injury, thrombotic events, and neuroinflammation. By utilizing these models, researchers can investigate the complex molecular and cellular responses to ischemic insults and evaluate potential neuroprotective interventions. Furthermore, these models can be used to assess neurobehavioral deficits and test the efficacy of novel therapeutics. However, it is crucial to choose an appropriate model that closely resembles the human condition and adequately captures the pathophysiological processes of stroke. Overall, focal cerebral ischemia models play a critical role in advancing our understanding of stroke mechanisms and developing effective treatments.

Functional outcome measures in stroke rehabilitation. Stroke rehabilitation often focuses on improving functional outcomes for patients. This study aimed to assess the relationship between functional outcome measures and stroke rehabilitation interventions. A total of 314 patients with stroke were included in the study. Various functional outcome measures, such as motor function, activities of daily living, and quality of life, were assessed. Rehabilitation interventions included physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy. Results showed that all functional outcome measures significantly improved following rehabilitation interventions. Specifically, motor function and activities of daily living showed the greatest improvement. Patients who received a combination of physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy had better functional outcomes compared to those who only received one or two of these interventions. These findings highlight the importance of multidisciplinary stroke rehabilitation approaches to optimize functional outcomes for patients.

Extrageniculate vision in hemianopic humans: saccade inhibition by signals in the blind field. In hemianopic humans, extrageniculate vision allows for saccade inhibition by signals in the blind field. This study aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon. Eight hemianopic patients were instructed to saccade towards target stimuli presented in the intact visual field while ignoring stimuli presented in the blind field. Results showed that the saccade to the intact field was significantly slower when a stimulus was simultaneously presented in the blind field. This suggests that the extrageniculate visual system can inhibit saccades towards stimuli in the blind field, possibly through interactions between the intact and blind visual fields. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and implications of extrageniculate vision in hemianopic patients.

The relation of serum cholesterol to risk of coronary heart disease: implications for the elderly. There is ongoing debate regarding the association between serum cholesterol levels and the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD), particularly in elderly individuals. This study aims to evaluate the implications of serum cholesterol levels on the risk of CHD in the elderly population. A comprehensive literature review was conducted to identify relevant studies. Meta-analyses were performed to calculate pooled risk estimates and assess the overall relationship between serum cholesterol and CHD risk in older adults. Our findings suggest that high serum cholesterol levels are associated with an increased risk of CHD in the elderly. However, the magnitude of the association appears to be smaller compared to younger age groups. Furthermore, the benefits of cholesterol-lowering therapies in the elderly population remain uncertain. This study emphasizes the need for further research to better understand the complex relationship between serum cholesterol and CHD risk in older adults, which can guide clinical decision-making and public health strategies targeted towards this age group.

Detection of loss of heterozygosity in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tumor specimens by the polymerase chain reaction. Loss of heterozygosity (LOH) is a common event in tumorigenesis and can be indicative of the presence of tumor suppressor gene mutations. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility of detecting LOH in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor specimens using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). FFPE tumor specimens from 40 patients with various types of cancer were analyzed for LOH at 11 polymorphic microsatellite markers. LOH was successfully detected in 29 out of the 40 specimens (72.5%). The highest frequency of LOH was observed at marker DCC on chromosome 18 (55%). Additionally, eight common regions of LOH were identified across multiple tumor types. These findings suggest that PCR-based analysis of LOH in FFPE tumor specimens is a feasible and reliable method for detecting genetic alterations associated with tumorigenesis and could potentially be utilized for diagnostic or prognostic purposes. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm these results.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. To investigate the association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) HEp-2 adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhoea, we conducted a retrospective study. Stool samples from patients with diarrhoea were collected and tested for E. coli HEp-2 adherence patterns. Adherence patterns were classified as localized, aggregative, diffuse, or non-adherent. The type and duration of diarrhoea were recorded for each patient. Our results showed a significant association between E. coli HEp-2 adherence patterns and the type of diarrhoea. Patients with localized adherence pattern had a higher frequency of acute watery diarrhoea, while those with aggregative and diffuse adherence patterns were more likely to have persistent or chronic diarrhoea. However, no significant association was found between adherence patterns and the duration of diarrhoea. Our findings suggest that E. coli HEp-2 adherence patterns may be useful as a diagnostic marker for differentiating between acute and persistent/chronic diarrhoea.

Vertical partial laryngectomy on demand. Vertical partial laryngectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat early-stage laryngeal cancer. However, it is often associated with functional and cosmetic impairments, including speech and swallowing difficulties. In this study, we propose a novel approach, "vertical partial laryngectomy on demand," which aims to preserve laryngeal function and minimize postoperative complications. This technique involves careful patient selection and close monitoring during tumor resection to ensure optimal functional outcomes. We present a case series of patients who underwent vertical partial laryngectomy on demand and achieved satisfactory speech and swallowing function postoperatively. This technique may offer a promising alternative for selected patients with early-stage laryngeal cancer.

Effects of medical and surgical treatment on cerebral perfusion and cognition in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia. This study aimed to investigate the effects of medical and surgical treatment on cerebral perfusion and cognition in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia. A total of 80 patients were included in the study and divided into two groups: medical treatment group (n=40) and surgical treatment group (n=40). Cerebral perfusion was measured using single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and cognitive function was assessed using standardized neuropsychological tests. The results showed that both medical and surgical treatment significantly improved cerebral perfusion in the affected regions compared to baseline measurements (p<0.001). However, the surgical treatment group had a significantly greater improvement in cerebral perfusion compared to the medical treatment group (p=0.017). In terms of cognition, both groups showed significant improvement in cognitive function after treatment (p<0.001), with no significant difference between the two groups (p=0.408). In conclusion, both medical and surgical treatment can improve cerebral perfusion and cognition in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia, with surgical treatment showing a greater effect on cerebral perfusion.

The long-distance effects of brain lesions: visualization of myelinated pathways in the human brain using polarizing and fluorescence microscopy. Brain lesions can have widespread effects on the human brain, including long-distance effects on myelinated pathways. In this study, we utilized polarizing and fluorescence microscopy techniques to visualize these pathways in the human brain. By analyzing brain tissue samples, we observed changes in myelinated pathways associated with brain lesions. Polarizing microscopy allowed us to visualize the structure and arrangement of myelinated fibers, while fluorescence microscopy enabled us to specifically identify these fibers using immunohistochemical staining. Our findings revealed alterations in the organization and integrity of myelinated pathways in areas remote from the lesion site, indicating the long-distance effects of brain lesions. This study highlights the importance of understanding the impact of brain lesions on myelinated pathways and provides valuable insights into the underlying pathophysiology. Further investigations are warranted to explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting these long-distance effects.

Retrograde nephrostolithotomy in management of complex renal calculi. Complex renal calculi pose a challenge in management due to their size and location. Retrograde nephrostolithotomy has emerged as a viable technique to tackle these calculi. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of retrograde nephrostolithotomy in the management of complex renal calculi. The study included 50 patients with complex renal calculi who underwent retrograde nephrostolithotomy between January 2018 and December 2019. The success rate of stone clearance, operation time, postoperative complications, and patient satisfaction were assessed. The results showed a high success rate of stone clearance (96%), with a low complication rate (4%). The mean operation time was 105 minutes. Patient satisfaction was reported to be high, with 92% of patients reporting improvement in symptoms and overall quality of life. Retrograde nephrostolithotomy appears to be a safe and effective technique for managing complex renal calculi, offering high success rates and patient satisfaction. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess long-term outcomes.

Clinical and anatomic considerations for surgery in tibial disease and the results of surgery. In this study, we investigated the clinical and anatomic considerations for surgery in tibial disease and evaluated the outcomes of surgical interventions. A total of 62 patients with tibial disease underwent surgery, and their medical records were retrospectively reviewed. The most common indications for surgery were tibial fractures, osteomyelitis, and nonunion. Preoperative assessments included radiographic evaluation, laboratory investigations, and clinical examinations. Surgical procedures varied according to the underlying disease and included open reduction and internal fixation, bone grafting, debridement, and amputation. Postoperative complications were observed in 18% of the patients, with infection being the most common. At a mean follow-up duration of 2 years, satisfactory outcomes were achieved in the majority of patients, emphasizing the importance of appropriate surgical management in tibial disease.

Incidence of myocarditis.  A 10-year autopsy study from Malmo, Sweden. The incidence of myocarditis was evaluated through a 10-year autopsy study conducted in Malmo, Sweden. A total of X autopsies were included in the analysis. Myocarditis was observed in Y cases, resulting in an overall incidence rate of Z per year. The study found that the incidence of myocarditis varied by age, with the highest rates observed in individuals between the ages of A and B. Additionally, there was a higher incidence of myocarditis in males compared to females. The most common cause of myocarditis was viral infection, accounting for X% of cases. Other causes included autoimmune disorders and drug-induced myocarditis. The study underscores the importance of recognizing and diagnosing myocarditis, as it can have serious implications for patient outcomes. Further research is needed to explore preventive measures and treatment options for this condition.

Tumors of the shoulder girdle.  Technique of resection and description of a surgical classification. This study focuses on tumors of the shoulder girdle, presenting the technique of resection and a surgical classification. The authors performed a retrospective analysis of patients with shoulder girdle tumors who underwent surgical resection. The surgical technique involved en bloc resection of the tumor with adequate margins. A total of 35 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 52 years. The most common tumor types were chondrosarcoma and osteosarcoma. The authors proposed a novel surgical classification system for tumors of the shoulder girdle based on the location of the tumor, involvement of adjacent structures, and the extent of resection required. The classification system provides valuable information for preoperative planning, intraoperative decision-making, and postoperative management. This study contributes to the understanding and management of tumors affecting the shoulder girdle.

Cofactors in male-female sexual transmission of human immunodeficiency virus type 1.  In a study of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1)-uninfected African prostitutes, 83 (67%) of 124 seroconverted to HIV-1.  Oral contraceptive use (odds ratio [OR], 3. 1; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1. 1-8. This study aimed to investigate co-factors involved in the sexual transmission of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) between males and females. The study focused on African prostitutes who were HIV-1-uninfected at the beginning of the study. Out of 124 participants, 83 (67%) seroconverted to HIV-1. The use of oral contraceptives was found to be a significant factor in the transmission of HIV-1, with an odds ratio of 3.1 and a 95% confidence interval of 1.1-8.6. This suggests that oral contraceptive use increases the risk of HIV-1 transmission. Other potential co-factors were not mentioned in this abstract. These findings highlight the importance of considering oral contraceptive use as a potential co-factor in the male-female sexual transmission of HIV-1 and the need for further research to explore other possible co-factors.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. In this study, the performance of large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts used for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery was evaluated. A total of 50 patients who underwent aortic aneurysm replacement with ePTFE grafts were included in the analysis. Postoperative complications, graft patency rates, and patient outcomes were assessed over a follow-up period of 5 years. The results showed a high overall success rate of graft implantation, with 96% of patients experiencing successful graft integration without any major complications. The graft patency rate was found to be 93%, indicating the durability and effectiveness of ePTFE grafts in maintaining blood flow in the aorta. Additionally, patient outcomes were favorable, with a low mortality rate and improved quality of life reported among the study cohort. These findings support the use of large diameter ePTFE grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.

Changes in intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves after acoustic neurinoma excision confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging. Acoustic neurinoma excision can lead to changes in the intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves. This study aimed to confirm these changes using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Thirty patients who underwent acoustic neurinoma excision were included in the study. MRI scans were performed before and after surgery to evaluate the intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves. Analysis of the MRI findings revealed significant changes in the morphology and signal intensity of the nerves postoperatively. In addition, there was a significant decrease in the size of the intracanalicular nerves compared to the preoperative scans. These findings suggest that acoustic neurinoma excision causes alterations in the intracochlear and intracanalicular nerves, which can be visualized by MRI. Understanding these changes may help in assessing the functional outcomes and potential complications following acoustic neurinoma excision.

Anaesthetic management of the brain dead for organ donation. Organ transplantation has become an increasingly important therapeutic option for patients with end-organ failure. The brain-dead donor is a vital source for organ transplantation. Anesthetic management of brain-dead patients for organ donation presents unique challenges. In this review, we discuss various aspects of anesthetic management in brain-dead patients, including hemodynamic stabilization, ventilatory management, temperature control, and metabolic and endocrine derangements. The potential complications associated with the process of donation after brain death are also reviewed. In addition, we highlight the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving intensivists, anesthesiologists, surgeons, and other healthcare professionals in optimizing the organ donation process and improving outcomes for both donors and recipients. A thorough understanding of the anesthetic considerations in brain-dead patients is crucial for successful organ transplantation.

Retroviral transduction of protein kinase C-gamma into cytotoxic T lymphocyte clones leads to immortalization with retention of specific function. Protein kinase C-gamma (PKC-纬) plays a crucial role in T lymphocyte activation and function. In order to investigate the potential role of PKC-纬 in the immortalization and maintenance of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), we performed retroviral transduction of PKC-纬 into CTL clones. Our results demonstrated that transduction of PKC-纬 led to the immortalization of CTL clones, as evidenced by their continued proliferation and survival. Importantly, the PKC-纬-transduced CTL clones preserved their specific function, as demonstrated by their ability to recognize and kill target cells. These findings suggest that PKC-纬 may be involved in the long-term survival and functionality of CTLs. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the potential therapeutic implications of targeting PKC-纬 in immune responses.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate are normal, as are brain contents of cysteine. This study aimed to investigate the fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate, as well as the brain contents of cysteine, in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The study included 32 ALS patients and 36 healthy controls. Results showed that the fasting plasma levels of cysteine and inorganic sulfate were within normal ranges in both ALS patients and controls. Similarly, the brain contents of cysteine were found to be normal in ALS patients. These findings suggest that abnormalities in cysteine metabolism do not contribute to the pathogenesis of ALS. Further research is needed to unravel the complex mechanisms underlying this devastating neurological disorder.

Childhood deaths from toy balloons. This study aimed to analyze the morphology of plaques and associated pathological changes in arteries of patients who underwent coronary balloon angioplasty. Autopsy findings from 28 patients with 40 coronary arteries subjected to balloon angioplasty were evaluated. The presence of various histologic features including plaque concentricity/eccentricity, calcification, fibrous/fibropultaceous plaque, medial disruption, luminal thrombus, and inflammation were assessed. Pathologic success was observed in 14 arteries and failure in 26 arteries. Results showed that eccentric plaques were more successfully dilated than concentric lesions. Fibropultaceous plaques had a higher rate of successful dilation compared to fibrous plaques. Moderate to severe calcification did not hinder morphologic success. Medial stretching or dissection were more frequently associated with successful outcomes. These findings suggest that plaque morphology may play a crucial role in determining the pathologic outcome after coronary angioplasty. By better understanding plaque characteristics, interventions such as angioplasty can be optimized to achieve favorable results.

Pharynx: value of oblique projections for radiographic examination. Oblique projections have become an increasingly utilized technique in radiographic examination of the pharynx. This study aimed to assess the value of oblique projections compared to traditional frontal and lateral views in diagnosing pharyngeal abnormalities. A total of 100 patients with suspected pharyngeal abnormalities were included in this retrospective study. Each patient underwent frontal, lateral, and oblique radiographic examinations of the pharynx. The images were reviewed by two experienced radiologists who were blinded to the clinical history. The results showed that oblique projections provided additional diagnostic information in 72% of cases, compared to frontal and lateral views alone. The most common pathology detected using oblique projections was pharyngeal wall asymmetry (43% of cases). Other abnormalities identified included mucosal irregularities, masses, and foreign bodies. Overall, oblique projections significantly improved the sensitivity and specificity of pharyngeal abnormality detection. These findings suggest that incorporating oblique projections into routine pharyngeal radiographic examinations can enhance diagnostic accuracy and aid in the management of patients with suspected pharyngeal pathology.

Normal pituitary gland: coronal MR imaging of infundibular tilt. Coronal MR imaging was performed to study the normal anatomy of the pituitary gland, specifically focusing on the infundibular tilt. A total of 20 subjects, without any significant pituitary pathology or endocrine disorders, were included in this study. The infundibular tilt angle, defined as the angle between the long axis of the infundibulum and the pituitary gland, was measured. The mean infundibular tilt angle was found to be 12.4 degrees, with a range of 9.7 to 15.8 degrees. There was no significant difference in the tilt angle between males and females. Understanding the normal anatomy and variations of the pituitary gland can aid in the diagnosis and management of pituitary disorders. Further studies with a larger sample size are needed to validate these findings.

A follow-up study of intractable seizures in childhood.  One hundred forty-five children with seizures that were refractory to medical therapy for at least 2 years were followed 5 to 20 years after onset. This study aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes and predictors of intractable seizures in childhood. One hundred forty-five children who had seizures resistant to medical treatment for a minimum of 2 years were included in the study. Follow-up assessments were conducted at intervals of 5 to 20 years since seizure onset. The outcomes measured included seizure frequency, cognitive function, and quality of life. The results showed that a significant number of children continued to experience seizures, with only a small proportion achieving complete remission. Several predictors of poor outcomes were identified, including early age of seizure onset, presence of intellectual disability, and structural brain abnormalities. Additionally, the study found that intractable seizures had a significant negative impact on cognitive function and overall quality of life. These findings suggest the need for early and aggressive interventions in children with intractable seizures to improve long-term outcomes.

Long term follow-up of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral bypass.  A prospective study of 26 patients undergoing descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass was conducted over a 13-year period with an average follow up of 53 months. A prospective study was conducted to evaluate the long-term outcomes of descending thoracic aorto-iliac/femoral (DTAI/F) bypass in 26 patients over a 13-year period. The average follow-up duration was 53 months. The study aimed to assess the efficacy and durability of this surgical procedure. The results showed that DTAI/F bypass had a high success rate, with 92.3% of patients experiencing improved blood flow and relief of symptoms. However, complications were observed in 23% of cases, including graft occlusion and infection. The long-term patency rate of the bypass graft was 76.9%, and the overall survival rate was 80.8% during the follow-up period. These findings suggest that DTAI/F bypass is a viable option for treating aorto-iliac/femoral disease, although careful patient selection and close postoperative surveillance are crucial to avoid complications.

Risk factors for gestational diabetes in black population. Gestational diabetes is a significant health concern during pregnancy, particularly in black populations where the risk factors are less understood. This study aimed to identify risk factors associated with gestational diabetes in a black population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of black pregnant women who were diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Demographic, clinical, and laboratory data were collected and compared with a control group of black pregnant women without gestational diabetes. The results showed that advanced maternal age, family history of diabetes, pre-pregnancy overweight or obesity, and previous history of gestational diabetes were significant risk factors for gestational diabetes in this population. Additionally, higher fasting blood glucose levels were observed in the gestational diabetes group. These findings highlight the importance of early identification and targeted interventions for black women with these risk factors to prevent the development of gestational diabetes and its associated complications.

Tumor factors predicting for prognosis in metastatic breast cancer.  The presence of P24 predicts for response to treatment and duration of survival. The prognosis of metastatic breast cancer is highly variable, making it important to identify tumor factors that can help predict treatment response and survival duration. This study aimed to determine the role of P24, a protein involved in cell cycle regulation, as a prognostic indicator in metastatic breast cancer patients. The research involved analyzing tumor samples from 150 patients with metastatic breast cancer who received standard treatment. Results showed that the presence of P24 was associated with a significantly higher response rate to treatment and longer survival duration. Patients with P24-positive tumors had a 60% response rate compared to only 25% in P24-negative tumors. Furthermore, the median survival duration was 14 months in P24-positive tumors compared to 9 months in P24-negative tumors. These findings suggest that P24 may serve as a useful prognostic marker in metastatic breast cancer, aiding in treatment decision-making and predicting patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to validate these results and explore potential therapeutic implications.

Surgical resection of cor triatriatum in a 74-year-old man. We present a case of surgical resection of cor triatriatum in a 74-year-old man. Cor triatriatum is a rare congenital cardiovascular anomaly characterized by the presence of a fibromuscular membrane dividing the left atrium into two chambers. The patient presented with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion, palpitations, and fatigue. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis of cor triatriatum. The patient underwent successful surgical resection of the membrane, resulting in the elimination of the left atrial obstruction. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient experienced significant improvement in symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering cor triatriatum as a possible cause of symptoms in adults and demonstrates the feasibility and efficacy of surgical intervention even in the elderly population.

Relationship among level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between the level of distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals. In the study, animals were exposed to different levels of distraction, and evoked potentials were measured. The results showed that a higher level of distraction was associated with decreased evoked potentials, indicating impaired neural function. Additionally, spinal cord ischemia and integrity were assessed, and it was found that higher levels of distraction were associated with increased spinal cord ischemia and impaired integrity. Furthermore, the animals' clinical status was evaluated, and it was observed that higher levels of distraction correlated with worsened clinical outcomes. These findings suggest a clear relationship between distraction, evoked potentials, spinal cord ischemia and integrity, and clinical status in animals, highlighting the importance of minimizing distraction in clinical settings.

The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap in composite defects of the oral cavity involving bone, skin, and mucosa. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap is a viable option for reconstructing composite defects of the oral cavity that involve bone, skin, and mucosa. This study evaluates the outcomes of 15 patients who underwent reconstruction using this flap. The flap provides adequate vascular supply and bulk, allowing for the restoration of contour and volume. The internal oblique-iliac crest free flap also offers the advantage of preserving function and minimizing donor site morbidity. Overall, this technique proves to be a reliable and effective method for reconstructing complex oral defects, providing satisfactory functional and aesthetic outcomes.

Acute sensorineural deafness in Lassa fever A prospective audiometric evaluation of 69 hospitalized febrile patients in Sierra Leone, West Africa, revealed a sensorineural hearing deficit (SNHD) in 14 (29%) of 49 confirmed cases of Lassa fever and in 0 of 20 febrile controls. This study conducted in Sierra Leone, West Africa, aimed to evaluate the occurrence of acute sensorineural deafness (SNHD) in Lassa fever patients. The results showed that out of the 69 hospitalized febrile patients, 14 (29%) confirmed Lassa fever cases had a SNHD, while none of the 20 febrile controls exhibited this deficit. These findings emphasize the association between Lassa fever infection and SNHD. Future studies should focus on further understanding the pathogenesis and potential treatment options for SNHD in Lassa fever patients. Early recognition and intervention are crucial to prevent long-term auditory complications in these individuals.

Experience with photocoagulation in Behcet's disease. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of photocoagulation in the management of Behcet's disease. A retrospective analysis was carried out on 20 patients with ocular involvement due to Behcet's disease who underwent photocoagulation. The mean age of the patients was 36 years, and the mean duration of disease prior to treatment was 5 years. Photocoagulation was performed using a variety of laser techniques, including argon, diode, and Nd:YAG lasers. The mean follow-up period was 18 months. After photocoagulation, 75% of the patients experienced improved visual acuity, while 20% remained stable. Recurrence of ocular inflammation occurred in 15% of the patients. Complications associated with photocoagulation were minimal, with only one patient experiencing a retinal scar. In conclusion, photocoagulation appears to be a safe and effective treatment modality for ocular involvement in Behcet's disease.

A double-masked evaluation of lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) used to alleviate the pain of retrobulbar injection A randomised, placebo controlled, double-masked study was undertaken in 115 patients undergoing cataract surgery to assess the efficacy of the anaesthetic cream EMLA (eutetic mixture of local anaesthetic, lignocaine-prilocaine) in alleviating the pain of retrobulbar injection. A double-masked evaluation was conducted on lignocaine-prilocaine cream (EMLA) to determine its effectiveness in reducing pain during retrobulbar injection in patients undergoing cataract surgery. The study consisted of 115 patients and utilized a randomised, placebo-controlled design. Results showed that the EMLA cream significantly alleviated the pain associated with retrobulbar injection compared to the placebo. This suggests that EMLA can be considered as a potential option for pain management during cataract surgery.

Deterioration following delay in performing femoral angioplasty.  It is not uncommon for a delay to occur between assessment arteriography and angioplasty attempt. Delay in performing femoral angioplasty after assessment arteriography can lead to deterioration in patient outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of such delays on patient prognosis. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent femoral angioplasty following assessment arteriography. The time interval between these two procedures was recorded for each patient. Results demonstrated that a longer delay was associated with a higher likelihood of deterioration in patient outcomes. Specifically, patients who experienced a delay of more than X hours showed a significant increase in complications such as ischemia and limb loss. Timely initiation of femoral angioplasty following assessment arteriography is crucial in ensuring optimal patient outcomes and should be prioritized in clinical practice.

Brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic evaluation of patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.  We compared brain magnetic resonance imaging and neuropsychologic performance in 20 neurologically asymptomatic patients suffering from idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age 41 [range 18-49] years) and 20 age-matched controls (mean age 38 [range 28-49] years).  Patients exhibited a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts (20% versus 0%, p less than 0. In this study, we aimed to compare brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings and neuropsychologic performance between neurologically asymptomatic patients with idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (IDC) and age-matched controls. The study included 20 patients with IDC (mean age 41 years) and 20 controls (mean age 38 years). The results showed a significantly higher rate of cerebral infarcts in patients with IDC compared to controls (20% versus 0%, p < 0.05). However, there were no significant differences in neuropsychologic performance between the two groups. These findings suggest that patients with IDC may be at increased risk for cerebral infarcts, highlighting the importance of early detection and management to prevent potential cognitive impairment.

Parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation for peptic duodenal stricture.  Gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic duodenal stricture (pyloric stenosis) was treated with parietal cell vagotomy and dilatation of the stricture in 32 patients.  Follow-up is in the range of 5 years in 37. Parietal cell vagotomy along with dilatation of the peptic duodenal stricture was performed on 32 patients with gastric outlet obstruction. Follow-up data for these patients was obtained for a period of 5 years in 37 patients. The procedure resulted in successful relief of symptoms and improvement in gastric emptying in all patients. There were no major complications reported during the follow-up period. Parietal cell vagotomy combined with stricture dilatation appears to be an effective treatment option for peptic duodenal stricture and can provide long-term relief for patients with gastric outlet obstruction.

Trends in conserving treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females. The purpose of this study was to examine trends in the conservation treatment of invasive carcinoma of the breast in females. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 500 patients who were diagnosed and treated between 2000 and 2010. Data on patient demographics, tumor characteristics, and treatment modalities were collected and analyzed. Results showed that there was a significant increase in the use of breast conservation therapy (BCT) over the study period, with a shift away from mastectomy as the primary treatment option. Factors associated with the use of BCT included smaller tumor size, absence of lymph node involvement, and younger age. The study also identified a decrease in the use of adjuvant radiation therapy for patients undergoing BCT, which may have implications for long-term outcomes and survival rates. These findings highlight the evolving trends in the management of invasive breast carcinoma and provide valuable insights for treatment decision-making.

The effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation.  The properties of the omentum and its effect on spinal neurologic disease was investigated. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of omental pedicle graft transfer on spinal microcirculation and laminectomy membrane formation in patients with spinal neurologic disease. A total of 20 patients underwent laminectomy and omental pedicle graft transfer. Microcirculation was assessed using laser Doppler flowmetry, and laminectomy membrane formation was assessed using histological examination. The results showed a significant improvement in microcirculation following omental pedicle graft transfer. Histological examination also revealed a decrease in laminectomy membrane formation in the majority of patients. These findings suggest that omental pedicle graft transfer can positively affect spinal microcirculation and reduce laminectomy membrane formation, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic option for spinal neurologic disease. Further research is warranted to validate these results and explore potential mechanisms of action.

Successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. We present a case of successful liver transplantation in a patient with a thrombosed portomesenteric system after multiple failed shunts. The patient, a 58-year-old male with end-stage liver disease, had previously undergone multiple attempts at portosystemic shunts for management of portal hypertension. However, due to persistent thrombosis of the portomesenteric system, these procedures were unsuccessful. As a last resort, the patient underwent liver transplantation. The surgery was successful, with no intraoperative complications. Postoperatively, the patient had an uneventful recovery and showed significant improvement in liver function. This case highlights the feasibility and effectiveness of liver transplantation in patients with thrombosed portomesenteric systems and refractory portal hypertension.

Late relapse with nodular lymphoma after treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. This study reports on cases of late relapse with nodular lymphoma in patients who had previously undergone treatment for diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The study aimed to investigate the risk factors and outcomes associated with late relapse. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a group of patients who experienced a late relapse with nodular lymphoma after a previous diagnosis of diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The results showed that late relapse with nodular lymphoma was associated with a longer duration since initial diagnosis, higher International Prognostic Index score at the time of initial diagnosis, and lower response rates to initial treatment. These findings highlight the need for close monitoring and early intervention in patients with a history of diffuse non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

The freckle sign--an endoscopic feature of the cecum. The freckle sign is a characteristic endoscopic finding in the cecum. It is described as small, brownish-red spots that resemble freckles on the colonic mucosa. This sign has been associated with an increased risk of colorectal neoplasms, especially adenomas and adenocarcinomas. Several studies have demonstrated a positive correlation between the presence of the freckle sign and the presence of neoplastic lesions in the cecum. Therefore, recognition of this endoscopic feature can aid in identifying individuals at higher risk for colorectal cancer and guide further diagnostic and management strategies. Further research is needed to determine the accuracy and clinical significance of the freckle sign in the cecum.

Lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia. Cancer cachexia is a multifactorial syndrome characterized by weight loss, muscle wasting, and metabolic abnormalities. Lipolysis, the breakdown of fat, is a key process contributing to the development of cancer cachexia. In recent years, several lipolytic factors have been identified and implicated in the pathogenesis of cancer cachexia in both murine models and human patients. These factors include adipose tissue lipases, such as hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL), as well as cytokines and hormones, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-伪) and the adipokine leptin. Understanding the mechanisms by which these lipolytic factors promote fat breakdown in cancer cachexia is crucial for the development of targeted therapeutic interventions to prevent or reverse weight loss and muscle wasting in cancer patients. This review aims to provide an overview of the current knowledge regarding lipolytic factors associated with murine and human cancer cachexia and their potential as therapeutic targets.

Molteno implants and operating microscope-induced retinal phototoxicity. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of retinal phototoxicity induced by Molteno implants and the operating microscope. A total of 20 patients who underwent Molteno implantation surgery were included in the study. The retinas of the patients were examined using fundus photography and optical coherence tomography (OCT) before and after the surgery. The results showed that 12 out of 20 patients (60%) developed retinal phototoxicity following the surgery. The most common findings were macular edema and retinal pigment epithelial changes. The severity of phototoxicity was positively correlated with the duration of surgery and the power of the operating microscope. These findings suggest that precautions should be taken to minimize the risk of retinal phototoxicity during Molteno implantation surgery, such as reducing the duration of surgery and using lower power settings on the operating microscope.

Otitis media in day-care children. Otitis media is a common infection in day-care children, leading to significant morbidity. The etiology is multifactorial, with viral upper respiratory tract infections playing a major role. Risk factors include young age, group child care, exposure to cigarette smoke, and bottle feeding. The clinical presentation varies from mild symptoms to severe pain, fever, and hearing loss. Diagnosis is made based on history, physical examination, and otoscopic findings, which may reveal a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with middle ear effusion. Treatment options include observation, antibiotic therapy, and myringotomy with tube placement in refractory cases. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent complications such as mastoiditis and hearing loss. Prevention strategies such as hand hygiene, avoidance of passive smoking, and influenza vaccination are recommended. Education of parents and caregivers regarding early recognition of symptoms and appropriate management can help reduce the burden of otitis media in day-care settings.

Micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components. This study investigated the micromotion of cemented and uncemented femoral components in total hip arthroplasty. Thirty patients underwent unilateral total hip arthroplasty with either cemented or uncemented femoral components. Micromotion of the femoral component was measured using radiostereometric analysis during weight-bearing activities at six-month intervals for two years. The results showed significantly greater micromotion in the uncemented group compared to the cemented group. Micromotion in both groups decreased over time but remained higher in the uncemented group throughout the study period. The findings suggest that cemented femoral components provide greater stability and reduced micromotion compared to uncemented components. These results have implications for the selection of femoral components in total hip arthroplasty to optimize long-term implant stability and patient outcomes.

Posterior transfer of the adductors in children who have cerebral palsy.  A long-term study. This long-term study aimed to analyze the outcomes of posterior transfer of the adductors in children with cerebral palsy. A total of 50 children (mean age: 7.2 years) were included in the study and followed for a mean duration of 6.5 years. Outcome measures included hip abduction angle, range of motion, gait analysis, and functional assessments. The results showed significant improvements in hip abduction angle (mean increase of 28.6 degrees), range of motion, and gait parameters at all follow-up time points. Functional assessments also demonstrated improvements in activities of daily living and overall quality of life. No major complications or adverse effects were observed. Overall, posterior transfer of the adductors is a safe and effective long-term treatment option for children with cerebral palsy, leading to improved hip abduction, gait, and functional outcomes.

Amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen.  Leptomyxid ameba. We report a case of amebic meningoencephalitis in a patient with AIDS caused by a newly recognized opportunistic pathogen, Leptomyxid ameba. The patient presented with neurological symptoms including headache, altered mental status, and seizures. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis revealed elevated protein and decreased glucose levels. Magnetic resonance imaging showed multiple brain lesions. Initial empirical treatment for bacterial and fungal meningoencephalitis was ineffective. Amebic meningoencephalitis was suspected based on the clinical presentation and a positive result on a polymerase chain reaction test for Acanthamoeba species. Further testing identified Leptomyxid ameba as the causative agent. Treatment with a combination of antimicrobial agents including miltefosine and amphotericin B was initiated, resulting in partial improvement of the neurological symptoms. Leptomyxid ameba is a rarely reported but emerging pathogen in immunocompromised patients.
