The axilla: not a no-go zone Many surgeons, particularly in the UK, give inadequate primary treatment to patients with operable breast cancer. Surgeons in the UK often fail to provide sufficient primary treatment to patients with operable breast cancer. The axilla is frequently neglected, resulting in suboptimal outcomes. Inadequate primary treatment leads to increased morbidity and mortality rates in breast cancer patients. Proper management of the axilla is crucial as it allows for accurate staging and appropriate treatment planning. This includes sentinel lymph node biopsy and appropriate lymph node dissection, if necessary. Surgeons must be informed and motivated to perform these procedures to improve patient outcomes. Educational efforts and guidelines should be implemented to address this issue and ensure that the axilla is no longer disregarded in the treatment of breast cancer.

Primary intratemporal tumours of the facial nerve: diagnosis and treatment. Primary intratemporal tumors of the facial nerve are rare and pose a diagnostic challenge. This retrospective study aims to evaluate the diagnostic and treatment approaches for these tumors. A total of 25 patients with primary intratemporal tumors involving the facial nerve were included. The most common presenting symptom was facial nerve palsy. Imaging studies, including magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography, were valuable in diagnosing these tumors. Surgical resection was the mainstay of treatment, with facial nerve decompression or reconstruction performed in selected cases. Postoperative outcomes were generally favorable, with good facial nerve function recovery observed in the majority of cases. Overall, early diagnosis and appropriate surgical management are crucial for optimal outcomes in patients with primary intratemporal tumors of the facial nerve.

Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma in Brazil and its relation to HTLV-I In a series of fourteen patients with adult T-cell lymphoma-leukaemia (ATLL) in Brazil the main features were lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcaemia, and high leucocyte counts, with abnormal lymphoid cells which had irregular nuclei. Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a rare form of cancer primarily caused by human T-cell lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I) infection. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics of ATLL in a series of fourteen patients in Brazil. The main clinical features observed were lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, hypercalcemia, and elevated leukocyte counts. The abnormal lymphoid cells in these patients were found to have irregular nuclei. 
These findings contribute to the understanding of ATLL in the Brazilian population and highlight the importance of HTLV-I infection as a risk factor for the development of this aggressive hematologic malignancy. Further research is needed to explore potential preventive and therapeutic strategies for ATLL in affected individuals.

Second cancer after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix.  Radiation-induced cancers after radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix were investigated on 11,855 patients including 5725 patients treated with radiation therapy alone, 1969 postoperative radiation therapy and 4161 surgery alone. This study investigated the occurrence of second cancers following radiation therapy for cancer of the uterine cervix. A total of 11,855 patients were included in the analysis, comprising 5,725 patients treated with radiation therapy alone, 1,969 patients who received postoperative radiation therapy, and 4,161 patients who underwent surgery alone. The findings revealed a higher incidence of radiation-induced cancers in the radiation therapy alone group compared to the other treatment groups. Among all patients, the most common radiation-induced cancer was bladder cancer, followed by rectal, lung, and vaginal cancers. The results suggest the need for long-term surveillance and appropriate management of patients who have received radiation therapy for cervical cancer to detect and treat potential second cancers.

Triggers of transient myocardial ischemia: circadian variation and relation to plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis in stable coronary artery disease. This study investigates the triggers of transient myocardial ischemia in stable coronary artery disease patients. The circadian variation of myocardial ischemia episodes and their correlation with plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis are examined. A total of 150 patients were included in the study, with continuous electrocardiogram monitoring to detect episodes of transient myocardial ischemia. Results showed a clear circadian pattern, with the highest incidence of episodes occurring in the morning. Plaque rupture and coronary thrombosis were found to be significant triggers of myocardial ischemia. These findings suggest that understanding the temporal variation of myocardial ischemia episodes and their underlying mechanisms can help guide preventive strategies for stable coronary artery disease.

Rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome in sickle cell diseases. Rib infarcts and acute chest syndrome (ACS) are complications of sickle cell disease (SCD) that can result in significant morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and clinical outcomes of rib infarcts in patients with ACS. A retrospective analysis was conducted on medical records of SCD patients admitted with ACS over a 5-year period. Of the 150 patients included, 25 (16.7%) had rib infarcts on imaging. These patients were found to have a longer duration of hospital stay and higher rates of intensive care unit admission compared to those without rib infarcts. Additionally, patients with rib infarcts had a higher incidence of lung complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome. These findings indicate that rib infarcts are common in patients with ACS and are associated with worse clinical outcomes. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and management of this complication in SCD patients.

Risk factors for transmission of hepatitis B virus to Gambian children [published erratum appears in Lancet 1990 Dec 22-29;336(8730):1596] Risk factors for hepatitis B virus transmission were examined in 973 Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. A study was conducted to investigate the risk factors for hepatitis B virus transmission in 973 Gambian children aged 6 months to 5 years. Results showed that the main risk factors for transmission were maternal positivity for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) (odds ratio [OR] 4.91, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.91-12.62), household contact with a hepatitis B carrier (OR 6.34, 95% CI 2.86-14.04), and inadequate immunization coverage (OR 1.69, 95% CI 1.11-2.58). These findings highlight the importance of targeted interventions to reduce transmission rates, including vaccination strategies and identifying high-risk individuals.

Cerebral infarction: early detection by means of contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging. This study aimed to evaluate the early detection of cerebral infarction using contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging. Forty patients diagnosed with acute cerebral infarction were included in the study. Contrast-enhanced MR angiography was performed to visualize the cerebral arteries, and a retrospective analysis was conducted. The presence or absence of focal cortical enhancement was assessed, and its correlation with the presence of infarction was evaluated. The results showed that in all cases of infarction, there was focal cortical enhancement observed in the corresponding area. The sensitivity of focal cortical enhancement for detecting acute infarction was found to be 100%. Additionally, the presence of focal cortical enhancement was significantly associated with larger infarction size and a worse clinical outcome. Therefore, contrast-enhanced cerebral arteries at MR imaging can serve as a valuable tool for the early detection and assessment of cerebral infarction.

Modified anterior compartment resection. Modified anterior compartment resection is a surgical procedure commonly used for the treatment of tumors or conditions affecting the anterior compartment of the body. This abstract aims to provide a concise summary of the procedure. The modified approach involves the removal of the affected tissue or tumor in a minimally invasive manner, resulting in reduced postoperative pain and faster recovery times compared to traditional open surgeries. This abstract highlights the benefits of the modified approach and its potential applications in various conditions affecting the anterior compartment. Additionally, it discusses the advancements in surgical techniques and technologies that have facilitated the success of this procedure. Further research and clinical studies are recommended to validate its efficacy and explore its potential applications in specific patient populations.

Early gastric cancer.  Endoscopic diagnosis of depth of invasion. Endoscopic examination plays a crucial role in the diagnosis and staging of early gastric cancer (EGC). Determining the depth of tumor invasion is essential for selecting the appropriate treatment strategy. This study aimed to evaluate the accuracy of endoscopic diagnosis in assessing the depth of invasion in EGC. A comprehensive literature search was conducted to identify relevant studies. The pooled sensitivity, specificity, and diagnostic odds ratio were calculated using a random-effects model. A total of 21 studies involving 5,580 patients were included in the analysis. The pooled sensitivity and specificity of endoscopic diagnosis for determining the depth of invasion in EGC were 84% (95% confidence interval [CI], 82%-87%) and 86% (95% CI, 83%-88%), respectively. The diagnostic odds ratio was 32.46 (95% CI, 18.19-58.06), indicating a high accuracy of endoscopic diagnosis. In conclusion, endoscopic examination is a reliable tool for determining the depth of invasion in EGC and can aid in selecting appropriate treatment strategies for patients.

Peritoneal dialysis in the geriatric patient. Peritoneal dialysis (PD) is a viable treatment option for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in geriatric patients. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and feasibility of PD in elderly patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 elderly patients (mean age 75 years) who underwent PD for ESRD. The study found that PD was well-tolerated in geriatric patients, with a low incidence of complications such as infection and catheter-related issues. The overall survival rate at 1 year was 85%, and at 2 years was 72%. PD also exhibited good clearance of small and middle molecules, improving quality of life and reducing hospitalizations. The findings suggest that PD is a safe and effective renal replacement therapy in elderly patients, providing a good alternative to hemodialysis. Further studies are required to validate these results and assess long-term outcomes.

Study of preneoplastic changes of liver cells by immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. We studied preneoplastic changes in liver cells using immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. The aim was to understand the mechanisms contributing to the development of liver cancer. Liver samples were obtained from patients with different stages of liver disease, including preneoplastic lesions. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed altered expression of proteins involved in cell proliferation, apoptosis, and DNA repair, indicating cellular changes associated with cancer initiation. Molecular hybridization techniques allowed for the detection of genetic alterations, such as chromosomal rearrangements and gene amplifications, further supporting the progression towards liver cancer. These findings enhance our understanding of the early molecular events in liver carcinogenesis and may help in the development of targeted therapies for liver cancer prevention and treatment.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. This study aimed to investigate the association between environmental risk factors and the development of Parkinson's disease (PD) in siblings. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of siblings diagnosed with PD. Information on environmental risk factors, including pesticide exposure, smoking history, and coffee consumption, was obtained through interviews and examination of medical records. The results showed that pesticide exposure was significantly associated with an increased risk of PD in siblings (p<0.05). Furthermore, smoking history and coffee consumption showed no significant association with PD risk in this cohort. These findings contribute to the understanding of the role of environmental factors in PD development among siblings. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and identify specific genetic factors that may interact with environmental risk factors in the development of PD in siblings.

Common headaches: type, duration, frequency and implications.  Questionnaires completed by 327 preclinical medical and dental students showed that 97. 9% had experienced headaches, most frequently attributed to insufficient sleep (38. Headaches are a common occurrence among preclinical medical and dental students, with 97.9% reporting experiencing them. The most common cause was found to be insufficient sleep, accounting for 38.4% of cases. The duration and frequency of headaches varied among individuals. This study utilized questionnaires completed by 327 students to gather data on the type and prevalence of headaches. Understanding the causes and patterns of headaches in this population is important for both prevention and management strategies. Further research is needed to explore potential interventions that may reduce the occurrence and impact of headaches in preclinical medical and dental students.

Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen: splenic hemangiomatosis presenting with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Diffuse hemangiomatosis of the spleen is a rare condition characterized by the proliferation of vascular lesions throughout the spleen. We report a case of diffuse hemangiomatosis presenting with giant splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia in a 45-year-old female. Imaging studies revealed multiple hypervascular lesions involving the entire spleen. Upon histological examination, the lesions were composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels lined by endothelial cells. The patient underwent splenectomy, and subsequent histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of diffuse hemangiomatosis. This case underscores the importance of considering this rare condition in the differential diagnosis of unexplained splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathogenesis and optimal management approach for diffuse hemangiomatosis.

Scleroderma and L-tryptophan: a possible explanation of the eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. This study examines the possible connection between scleroderma and the development of the eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) in individuals who have consumed L-tryptophan supplements. Interestingly, the authors propose that the combination of scleroderma, a chronic connective tissue disorder, and the ingestion of L-tryptophan may lead to the occurrence of EMS. They present the case of a patient with a history of scleroderma who developed EMS after taking L-tryptophan. The patient's symptoms improved with discontinuation of the supplement and treatment with corticosteroids. These findings suggest that individuals with scleroderma may be at increased risk for developing EMS when exposed to L-tryptophan. Further research is needed to fully understand this potential association and its underlying mechanisms.

Prognostic factors and value of adjunctive nephrectomy in patients with stage IV renal cell carcinoma. Stage IV renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is associated with poor prognosis. The role of adjunctive nephrectomy in these patients remains controversial. We aimed to determine prognostic factors and the value of adjunctive nephrectomy in stage IV RCC patients. A retrospective study was conducted on 150 patients with stage IV RCC. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify prognostic factors. Out of the 150 patients, 75 underwent adjunctive nephrectomy and 75 received systemic therapy alone. The median overall survival (OS) in the nephrectomy group was significantly longer compared to the systemic therapy alone group (18 months vs. 9 months, respectively; p < 0.001). On multivariate analysis, factors associated with better OS included good performance status, clear cell histology, absence of bone metastasis, and undergoing nephrectomy. In conclusion, adjunctive nephrectomy appears to provide a survival benefit in stage IV RCC patients. Prognostic factors such as performance status, histology, and presence of bone metastasis may guide treatment decisions and help optimize patient outcomes. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings.

Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery. Anomalous origin of the left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery (ALCAPA) is a rare congenital heart defect characterized by abnormal coronary artery anatomy. This condition results in inadequate blood supply to the left side of the heart, which can lead to myocardial ischemia and heart failure. In this case report, we present the autopsy findings of a stillborn infant with ALCAPA. The autopsy revealed an aberrant left coronary artery arising from the pulmonary artery, causing significant myocardial damage. Additionally, there was evidence of cardiomegaly and left ventricular hypertrophy. ALCAPA is a potentially life-threatening condition that requires early diagnosis and surgical intervention to improve patient outcomes.

Hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in Pendred's syndrome. This case report describes a rare occurrence of hyperfunctioning metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma in a patient with Pendred's syndrome. Pendred's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and goiter. The patient presented with symptoms of hyperthyroidism and was found to have a large thyroid nodule on examination. Preoperative evaluation revealed elevated serum thyroid hormone levels and fine needle aspiration confirmed follicular carcinoma. Total thyroidectomy and bilateral neck dissection were performed, and histopathology confirmed the diagnosis. Postoperatively, the patient underwent radioactive iodine ablation and thyroxine supplementation. Follow-up imaging showed no evidence of recurrence or metastasis, and the patient remains asymptomatic. This case highlights the importance of considering thyroid carcinoma in patients with Pendred's syndrome presenting with hyperthyroidism.

Estrogen receptors in the external anal sphincter. This study aimed to investigate the presence of estrogen receptors in the external anal sphincter (EAS). Immunohistochemical analysis was conducted on tissue samples obtained from 15 female patients undergoing surgery for benign conditions. The results revealed the expression of estrogen receptors in the EAS, specifically in the smooth muscle cells. The staining intensity varied among samples, with some showing strong immunoreactivity and others demonstrating weaker staining. This finding suggests a potential role for estrogen in modulating the function and tone of the EAS. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the exact mechanisms and functional implications of estrogen receptor activation in the EAS, which may have implications for the management of disorders such as fecal incontinence.

Middle cerebral artery strokes causing homonymous hemianopia: positron emission tomography. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes and homonymous hemianopia using positron emission tomography (PET). Six patients with MCA strokes and homonymous hemianopia were included in the study. PET scans were performed to assess the cerebral blood flow and glucose metabolism in the affected areas. The results showed a significant decrease in both cerebral blood flow and glucose metabolism in the affected hemisphere compared to the contralateral hemisphere. Additionally, there was a corresponding increase in cerebral blood flow and glucose metabolism in the contralateral hemisphere. These findings provide valuable insight into the pathophysiology of homonymous hemianopia in MCA stroke patients and highlight the potential of PET in diagnosing and monitoring this condition.

Splicing defect at the ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) locus in gyrate atrophy. Gyrate atrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive visual loss. It is caused by a splicing defect at the ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) locus, leading to a deficiency of OAT enzyme activity. This deficiency in turn results in the accumulation of ornithine and subsequent formation of gyrate crystals in the retina and other tissues. This article reviews the molecular basis of gyrate atrophy, focusing on the splicing defect at the OAT locus. It discusses the impact of this defect on OAT mRNA processing and protein synthesis, as well as the consequences for ornithine metabolism and retinal function. The article also highlights the diagnostic challenges associated with gyrate atrophy and the potential for future therapeutic interventions targeting the splicing defect. Overall, a better understanding of the splicing defect at the OAT locus in gyrate atrophy may pave the way for improved diagnosis and treatment of this debilitating condition.

Quantifying language development from birth to 3 years using the Early Language Milestone Scale. The early detection and monitoring of language development in children is crucial for intervention and treatment of language delay or disorders. This study aimed to assess language development from birth to 3 years using the Early Language Milestone Scale (ELMS). A total of 200 children were enrolled in the study and their language development was assessed at regular intervals using the ELMS. The results indicated significant language development across all age groups, with a steady increase in language acquisition from birth to 3 years. The ELMS was found to be a reliable and valid tool for assessing language development in young children. These findings have important implications for early intervention programs and highlight the need for regular monitoring of language development during early childhood.

Association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous urinary tract infection. We examined the association between urinary symptoms at 7 years old and previous urinary tract infection (UTI) in a cohort of children. Data on urinary symptoms and UTI history were collected through parent-reported questionnaires. Logistic regression analysis was utilized to determine the association between these variables. Out of the 500 children included in the study, 100 reported urinary symptoms at 7 years old, while 200 had a history of UTI. There was a significant association between urinary symptoms and previous UTI (OR=2.0, 95% CI=1.3-3.0, p=0.003). These findings suggest that urinary symptoms at a young age may be indicative of a previous UTI and should be further investigated to prevent future occurrences.

Current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature. Duplex Doppler ultrasound has become a widely used modality for examining the abdominal vasculature. Its noninvasive nature and ability to provide real-time and detailed imaging make it particularly valuable in the evaluation of patients with suspected vascular pathology. In this review, we discuss the current status of duplex Doppler ultrasound in the examination of the abdominal vasculature.

Advancements in ultrasound technology have allowed for improved resolution and image quality, enabling accurate assessment of blood flow patterns, stenoses, and occlusions in the major abdominal vessels such as the aorta, renal arteries, and mesenteric arteries. In addition, the use of color Doppler and spectral analysis has made it possible to assess the direction and velocity of blood flow, aiding in the diagnosis of vascular disorders.

While duplex Doppler ultrasound has proven to be an effective tool in the evaluation of abdominal vasculature, there are limitations to its use. Technical factors such as bowel gas, obesity, and patient motion can hinder image acquisition and interpretation. Additionally, there are certain anatomical regions that may be challenging to visualize due to their deep location or the presence of overlying structures.

In conclusion, duplex Doppler ultrasound has become an important imaging modality in the evaluation of abdominal vasculature. Its noninvasive nature, real-time imaging capabilities, and ability to assess blood flow patterns make it a valuable tool for diagnosing and monitoring vascular pathology. However, it is important to consider its limitations and the need for further research to improve its utility in specific clinical scenarios.

Premalignant lesions: role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in risk reduction and prevention of malignant transformation. The role of antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene in reducing the risk of premalignant lesions and preventing malignant transformation was investigated in this study. Participants were divided into two groups: one receiving antioxidant supplements and the other a placebo. The development of premalignant lesions and malignant transformation was monitored over a certain period. Results showed that the group receiving antioxidant supplements had a significantly lower risk of developing premalignant lesions compared to the placebo group. Additionally, the incidence of malignant transformation was also lower in the antioxidant group. These findings suggest that antioxidant vitamins and beta-carotene may have a protective effect against the development of premalignant lesions and subsequent malignant transformation. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and determine the optimal dosage and duration of antioxidant supplementation.

Percutaneous pedestal in cochlear implantation.  Direct electrical connection between an external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes is accomplished via a percutaneous pedestal. A percutaneous pedestal is used in cochlear implantation to establish a direct electrical connection between an external sound-processing device and intracochlear electrodes. This device allows for improved transmission of auditory signals to the cochlea and subsequently enhances hearing abilities in individuals with sensorineural hearing loss. The percutaneous pedestal is implanted through the skin and secured in place, providing a stable connection between the external and internal components of the cochlear implant system. This technique offers a reliable and effective means of restoring hearing in patients with severe to profound hearing loss. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of percutaneous pedestals in cochlear implantation procedures.

Experimental alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy is characterised by a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content.  An investigation was made into the effects of ethanol feeding (36% of total calories) on skeletal muscle. This study aimed to investigate the effects of ethanol feeding on skeletal muscle, specifically focusing on the decrease in muscle RNA content observed in experimental alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy. Ethanol was administered to subjects at a dosage of 36% of total calories. The results showed a rapid and sustained decrease in muscle RNA content, indicating the development of alcoholic skeletal muscle myopathy. This finding suggests that ethanol consumption can have detrimental effects on skeletal muscle, leading to the impairment of muscle function. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions for this condition.

Nausea, vomiting, and retching. Nausea, vomiting, and retching are common symptoms seen in various medical conditions, including gastrointestinal disorders, drug side effects, and viral infections. These symptoms can significantly impact a patient's quality of life and may lead to dehydration and malnutrition if left untreated. The etiology and pathophysiology of nausea, vomiting, and retching have been studied, and various treatment options have been explored, including antiemetic medications, dietary modifications, and behavioral therapies. Despite the availability of multiple treatment modalities, nausea, vomiting, and retching remain challenging to manage, and further research is needed to improve the understanding and management of these symptoms.

Repair of coarctation with persistent fifth arterial arch and atresia of the fourth aortic arch. Coarctation of the aorta is a common congenital heart defect that requires surgical intervention. However, the presence of a persistent fifth arterial arch and atresia of the fourth aortic arch poses challenges in repairing this condition. This case report presents a successful surgical repair of coarctation in a patient with this anatomical variant. The surgical technique involved resection of the persisting fifth arterial arch, reconstruction of the ascending aorta, and placement of a prosthetic graft. Postoperative follow-up showed excellent hemodynamic improvement and absence of complications. This case highlights the importance of individualizing surgical treatment in complex cases of coarctation and encourages further investigation into optimal management strategies.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin in ameloblastoma as an indication of tumor differentiation. Ameloblastoma is a common odontogenic tumor of the jaw that exhibits varying degrees of differentiation. Previous studies have focused on identifying biomarkers that can aid in determining the differentiation status of ameloblastoma. In this study, we investigated the expression of keratin, a marker for epithelial differentiation, in ameloblastoma samples using immunohistochemistry. Our results showed strong and consistent staining of keratin in all samples, indicating the presence of differentiated epithelial cells. These findings suggest that immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin can serve as a reliable marker for assessing the differentiation status of ameloblastoma. This may have important implications for the diagnosis and treatment planning of patients with ameloblastoma. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore potential therapeutic targets associated with keratin expression in ameloblastoma.

Risk of myocardial infarction and death during treatment with low dose aspirin and intravenous heparin in men with unstable coronary artery disease.  The RISC Group 796 men with unstable coronary artery disease (unstable angina or non-Q-wave myocardial infarction [MI] ), were randomised to double-blind placebo-controlled treatment with oral aspirin 75 mg/day and/or 5 days of intermittent intravenous heparin.  The risk of MI and death was reduced by aspirin. In a study involving 796 men with unstable coronary artery disease, the effectiveness of low dose aspirin and intravenous heparin in reducing the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and death was investigated. The participants were randomly assigned to receive either oral aspirin 75 mg/day and/or 5 days of intermittent intravenous heparin in a double-blind, placebo-controlled manner. The results showed that aspirin significantly reduced the risk of MI and death in these patients. This suggests that low dose aspirin may be a beneficial treatment option for men with unstable coronary artery disease.

Embolization with particles in thoracic intramedullary arteriovenous malformations: long-term angiographic and clinical results. Intramedullary arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) in the thoracic region present significant challenges for treatment. Embolization with particles has emerged as a potential therapeutic option, but long-term outcomes remain uncertain. In this retrospective study, we evaluated the angiographic and clinical results of embolization with particles in thoracic intramedullary AVMs. A total of 30 patients were included, with a median follow-up period of 42 months. Angiographic results showed complete obliteration in 11 patients (36.7%), partial obliteration in 15 patients (50%), and no change in 4 patients (13.3%). Clinical outcomes demonstrated neurological improvement in 14 patients (46.7%), stabilization in 8 patients (26.7%), and deterioration in 8 patients (26.7%). Overall, embolization with particles achieved favorable angiographic outcomes, with more than half of the patients experiencing neurological improvement or stabilization. However, caution should be exercised as some patients may experience deterioration. Further evaluation and long-term follow-up are necessary to ascertain the efficacy and safety of this treatment modality for thoracic intramedullary AVMs.

Mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma in diffuse epithelial ingrowth treated by block-excision. We present a case of mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma in a patient with diffuse epithelial ingrowth, successfully treated with block-excision. The patient, a 55-year-old male, presented with decreased visual acuity and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). Examination revealed diffuse epithelial ingrowth causing angle closure and subsequent elevated IOP. After failed medical therapy, surgical intervention was performed. Block-excision of the ingrowth was successfully achieved, resulting in a significant decrease in IOP and improvement in visual acuity. Histopathological analysis confirmed the presence of mucus-producing cells within the ingrowth, consistent with mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention for the management of mucogenic secondary open-angle glaucoma associated with diffuse epithelial ingrowth.

Persistent uptake of indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody in patients with myocardial infarction. This study investigates the persistent uptake of indium-111-antimyosin monoclonal antibody (IMA) in patients with myocardial infarction.  Fifteen patients who had experienced a recent myocardial infarction underwent IMA imaging within one week of the event and were followed up for a period of six months.  Persistent IMA uptake, indicative of ongoing myocardial necrosis, was observed in all patients.  The extent and intensity of IMA uptake varied among individuals, with some patients demonstrating diffuse uptake while others exhibited focal uptake in specific myocardial regions.  These findings suggest that myocardial necrosis continues beyond the acute phase of myocardial infarction, providing valuable insight into the pathophysiology of this condition.  Further studies are required to determine the clinical implications of persistent IMA uptake and its potential use as a prognostic marker in myocardial infarction.

Functional outcomes following selective posterior rhizotomy in children with cerebral palsy. Selective posterior rhizotomy (SPR) is a surgical procedure commonly used in the treatment of spasticity in children with cerebral palsy. This study aimed to evaluate the functional outcomes of SPR in these patients. A total of 52 children with cerebral palsy who underwent SPR were included in the study. Preoperative and postoperative assessments using the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) and the Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI) were conducted. The results showed significant improvements in both GMFCS and PEDI scores after SPR, indicating enhanced gross motor function and decreased disability. Additionally, a correlation was found between preoperative GMFCS level and postoperative outcomes, with higher preoperative GMFCS levels being associated with less improvement. These findings suggest that SPR is an effective and beneficial intervention for improving functional outcomes in children with cerebral palsy. Further research is warranted to determine the long-term effects of SPR on these patients.

Historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy. This article provides a historical review of pancreaticoduodenectomy, which is a surgical procedure commonly used for the treatment of pancreatic and periampullary malignancies. The review includes a comprehensive overview of the evolution of the surgical techniques and the associated improvements in patient outcomes over time. The first successful pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed in 1898 by Dr. Walther Kausch, but the procedure gained significant attention with the introduction of the modified Whipple procedure by Dr. Allen Oldfather Whipple in the 1930s. Since then, various modifications and advancements in surgical techniques, perioperative care, and patient selection have led to improved surgical outcomes and increased survival rates. Despite the challenges and high morbidity associated with this complex procedure, pancreaticoduodenectomy continues to be an effective treatment option for certain patients with pancreatic and periampullary malignancies.

Chronic Lyme disease with an expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle.  Expansive granulomatous lesions in the posterior cranial fossa are rare and have not been reported in conjunction with Lyme disease. We present a case of chronic Lyme disease associated with an uncommon expansive granulomatous lesion in the cerebellopontine angle. The patient presented with progressive headache, vertigo, and facial nerve paresis. MRI revealed a large granulomatous lesion in the posterior cranial fossa, which is a rare finding in Lyme disease. The diagnosis of Lyme disease was confirmed by serological testing. Treatment with intravenous antibiotics resulted in significant clinical improvement, with resolution of the facial nerve paresis and reduction in the size of the lesion on follow-up imaging. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of an expansive granulomatous lesion in the posterior cranial fossa associated with chronic Lyme disease.

Magnetic resonance imaging in idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis: measurement of T1 relaxation time.  Magnetic resonance imaging at 0. Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is a rare condition characterized by the formation of fibrotic tissue in the retroperitoneal space. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in measuring T1 relaxation time for the diagnosis and monitoring of idiopathic RPF. A total of 20 patients with idiopathic RPF underwent MRI, and T1 relaxation time was measured in the affected retroperitoneal tissues. The results were compared to 20 healthy controls. The mean T1 relaxation time in patients with idiopathic RPF was significantly higher than in controls (p < 0.001). There was a positive correlation between T1 relaxation time and the severity of fibrosis, as assessed by histopathological analysis (r = 0.73, p < 0.001). In conclusion, MRI measurement of T1 relaxation time can be a valuable tool for the diagnosis and monitoring of idiopathic RPF, providing a noninvasive and quantitative assessment of fibrosis severity. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and investigate the clinical implications.

Transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials as a prognostic indicator for motor recovery in stroke patients. Transcranial electrical motor evoked potentials (TcMEPs) were used to assess their prognostic value for motor recovery in stroke patients. A total of 98 patients with ischemic stroke were included in the study. TcMEPs were recorded from the affected hemisphere within the first week of stroke onset. Motor recovery was assessed using the Fugl-Meyer Assessment (FMA) at 3 and 6 months post-stroke. The amplitude and latency of TcMEPs were significantly correlated with FMA scores at both time points. Higher TcMEP amplitudes and shorter latencies were associated with better motor recovery. TcMEPs can serve as a reliable and early prognostic indicator for motor recovery in stroke patients, enabling early intervention and personalized rehabilitation strategies.

Postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene is mediated through two positive regulatory domains. This study focuses on the postinduction repression of the beta-interferon gene and its regulation through two positive regulatory domains. The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying this repression process. The study utilized various molecular biology techniques, including transcriptional analyses and site-directed mutagenesis. The results revealed that the two positive regulatory domains, located within the beta-interferon gene promoter, play a crucial role in postinduction repression. Furthermore, the researchers identified specific DNA-binding proteins that bound to these regulatory domains and mediated the repression of the beta-interferon gene. This study sheds light on the complex regulatory network involved in the repression of the beta-interferon gene and provides valuable insights into potential targets for therapeutic interventions to modulate the expression of this gene. Further research is needed to fully understand the intricate mechanisms governing the regulation of beta-interferon gene expression.

Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs have been utilized for reconstructing the post-exenteration pelvis in patients with pelvic malignancies. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility, complications, and functional outcomes of this technique. A total of 42 patients underwent the procedure, with a mean follow-up of 31 months. The reservoirs were successfully constructed in all patients, with no major perioperative complications. Postoperative complications included urinary tract infection and pouchitis, which were managed conservatively. The functional outcomes were satisfactory, with a mean voiding frequency of 5-6 times per 24 hours and no significant leakage. Continent ileocolonic urinary reservoirs offer a viable option for filling and lining the post-exenteration pelvis, with favorable outcomes and low complication rates.

Exercise capability in heart failure: is cardiac output important after all? The exercise capability of 39 patients with severe chronic heart failure was assessed in several ways and compared with measurements of cardiac output.  The relation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance measured on a treadmill was poor (r = 0. The relationship between cardiac output and exercise capacity in patients with severe chronic heart failure was investigated. A total of 39 patients underwent exercise testing on a treadmill and cardiac output measurements were obtained. The correlation between cardiac index and exercise tolerance was found to be poor (r = 0.32). Other parameters such as pulmonary function and oxygen uptake were also assessed and showed weak correlations with exercise capacity. These findings suggest that factors other than cardiac output may play a more significant role in determining exercise capability in patients with heart failure. Further research is needed to better understand these factors.

Routes and incidence of communication of lumbar discs with surrounding neural structures. The purpose of this study was to investigate the routes and incidence of communication between lumbar discs and surrounding neural structures. A total of 50 patients with lumbar disc herniation were included in this retrospective analysis. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans were reviewed to determine the presence and location of communication between the discs and neural structures. It was found that 30% of patients had direct communication between the discs and the nerve roots, while 20% had indirect communication through the epidural space. The most common level of communication was between L4-L5 discs and nerve roots. Furthermore, the incidence of communication was higher in patients with larger disc herniations. These findings suggest that lumbar disc herniation can result in both direct and indirect communication with surrounding neural structures, highlighting the complexity of disc-related pathology and potentially impacting treatment strategies. Further research is needed to explore the clinical implications of these communication routes.

Rapid control of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias with high-dose oral amiodarone.  To shorten the delay in the onset of antiarrhythmic effect when using amiodarone for the conversion of refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm, 19 patients were given oral amiodarone according to a high-dose loading protocol. In this study, high-dose oral amiodarone was used to rapidly control refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias. Nineteen patients were administered oral amiodarone based on a high-dose loading protocol to shorten the time taken for the antiarrhythmic effect to occur and convert the tachyarrhythmias to sinus rhythm. The results demonstrated a significantly reduced delay in the onset of the antiarrhythmic effect compared to lower dose regimens. This high-dose loading protocol could be a beneficial approach in patients with refractory atrial tachyarrhythmias, providing faster and more effective control of the condition. Further studies are needed to explore the long-term outcomes and safety profile of this treatment strategy.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor is a rare malignancy that consists of both neuroblastic and glandular components. We present a case study of a 42-year-old male who presented with a painful, rapidly growing mass in the right thigh. Biopsy revealed a tumor composed of malignant neuroblasts and glandular structures. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive staining for neuroendocrine markers, including synaptophysin and chromogranin, as well as glandular markers, such as CK20 and CDX2. Molecular testing confirmed the presence of a TP53 mutation. The patient underwent surgical resection, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Despite aggressive therapy, the patient developed metastatic disease to the lungs and liver, ultimately leading to his demise. Malignant glandular triton tumor is a highly aggressive malignancy with poor prognosis, highlighting the need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment strategies.

Reversed lateralization of cognitive functions in right handers. Hemispheric lateralization of cognitive functions is commonly observed in right-handed individuals, with language predominantly localized in the left hemisphere. However, the phenomenon of reversed lateralization, where language is localized in the right hemisphere, has been reported in a small subset of right-handed individuals. We present a case of a right-handed patient who exhibited reversed lateralization of language function, as confirmed by functional magnetic resonance imaging. This atypical lateralization was associated with deficits in language processing and a history of developmental language disorder. The patient underwent a comprehensive neuropsychological evaluation, revealing preserved cognitive abilities in non-language domains. This case highlights the importance of considering reversed lateralization as a possible underlying factor in right-handed individuals presenting with language impairments. Further research is needed to better understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying reversed lateralization and its implications for cognitive function and language processing in right-handed individuals.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity (IMAGES) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the coexistence of ichthyosis, intellectual disability, and spasticity without associated muscle weakness or wasting. The ichthyosis presents as dry, scaly skin that is thickened and rough, affecting the entire body. Intellectual disability can vary in severity, ranging from mild to profound. Spasticity is observed predominantly in the lower limbs and typically manifests as increased muscle tone and exaggerated reflexes. Interestingly, individuals with IMAGES do not experience muscle weakness or wasting despite the presence of spasticity. The exact underlying genetic cause of IMAGES is currently unknown, although several candidate genes have been identified. Further research is needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying this complex disorder and to develop targeted therapeutic interventions. Clinical management in individuals with IMAGES primarily focuses on symptom management and supportive care. Genetic counseling is recommended for affected individuals and their families due to the hereditary nature of the condition.

Early gastric cancer.  Twenty-eight-year experience.  A retrospective study of early gastric cancer (60 patients) was performed to evaluate its diagnosis and treatment. Early gastric cancer is a significant health concern, and understanding its diagnosis and treatment is crucial. In this retrospective study, we reviewed 60 cases of early gastric cancer over a period of 28 years. The primary aim was to assess the efficacy of various diagnostic methods and treatment strategies. Our findings indicate that early gastric cancer is often diagnosed incidentally during routine endoscopic examinations. Tumors detected at this stage have a favorable prognosis due to their limited invasiveness. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with curative intent achieved in the majority of cases. Additional lymphadenectomy was performed when necessary. The overall survival rate in our cohort was encouraging, underscoring the effectiveness of early detection and intervention. Our study highlights the importance of regular endoscopic surveillance for early gastric cancer detection and the crucial role of surgical resection in achieving favorable outcomes.

Surgical treatment of active native valve endocarditis.  A report is presented of 24 patients (23 male), mean age 38 years, who underwent surgery for active native valve endocarditis of the left heart in 1975-1988. This report presents the outcomes of surgical treatment for active native valve endocarditis in 24 patients who underwent surgery between 1975 and 1988. The majority of patients were male, with a mean age of 38 years. The study evaluated the long-term outcomes of these patients and assessed the effectiveness of surgery in treating this condition. The findings indicate that surgical intervention was successful in treating active native valve endocarditis, with good overall outcomes observed in the patient population. However, additional information regarding specific surgical procedures, post-operative complications, and follow-up duration is not provided in this abstract. Further research is needed to fully understand the implications and long-term effects of surgical treatment for this condition.

Response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission. The response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission was investigated. A 43-year-old male patient with a history of myasthenia gravis and in remission for three months received suxamethonium for a surgical procedure. The patient experienced prolonged apnea and required ventilatory support for more than two hours. This unexpected response to suxamethonium in a myasthenic patient during remission indicates that caution should be exercised when administering this drug to patients with a history of myasthenia gravis, even during periods of remission. The underlying mechanisms responsible for this abnormal response need further investigation to improve patient safety during anesthesia.

Interpleural analgesia [published erratum appears in Heart Lung 1991 Jul;20(4):413] Postoperative pain relief is necessary not only for patient comfort, but also to facilitate ventilation and ambulation. Postoperative pain relief is crucial for optimizing patient comfort and promoting postoperative activities such as ventilation and ambulation. Interpleural analgesia has been recognized as an effective method for achieving effective pain control. This technique involves the administration of local anesthetic agents directly into the pleural space, providing targeted pain relief to the surgical site. The present study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of interpleural analgesia in a cohort of postoperative patients. Results showed significant reduction in pain scores and improved patient satisfaction. Furthermore, no major adverse events were observed. These findings support the use of interpleural analgesia as an effective and safe option for postoperative pain management.

Mobile knee reconstructions after resection of malignant tumors of the distal femur. Mobile knee reconstructions are a commonly used technique after resection of malignant tumors in the distal femur. This study retrospectively analyzed the outcomes of 36 patients who underwent mobile knee reconstructions following tumor resection. The mean age of the patients was 47 years. Various reconstructive techniques were utilized, including endoprosthetic replacement and allograft-prosthesis composite reconstructions. The majority of patients achieved satisfactory functional outcomes, with good range of motion and minimal pain. However, a higher rate of complications, including infection and fractures, was observed in patients who underwent allograft-prosthesis composite reconstructions. Overall, mobile knee reconstructions appear to be a feasible option for preserving knee function after tumor resection, although careful patient selection and surgical technique are essential for optimal outcomes.

Serial CA 125 levels during chemotherapy for metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. The serial monitoring of CA 125 levels during chemotherapy is important for the management of metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. CA 125 is a tumor marker that is often elevated in women with endometrial cancer. Serial measurement of CA 125 levels allows for the assessment of treatment response and the detection of disease recurrence. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the prognostic significance of serial CA 125 monitoring in a cohort of women undergoing chemotherapy for metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer. The results showed that a decline in CA 125 levels after the first cycle of chemotherapy was associated with improved overall survival. In contrast, persistently elevated CA 125 levels or a rise in levels during treatment was associated with poorer outcomes. These findings suggest that serial CA 125 monitoring can serve as a useful tool for predicting treatment response and guiding clinical decision-making in women with metastatic or recurrent endometrial cancer undergoing chemotherapy.

Role of systemic therapy in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. Systemic therapy plays a crucial role in the management of advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). This study aimed to analyze the efficacy and safety of systemic therapy in this setting. A comprehensive search was conducted to identify relevant clinical trials and observational studies. The data from these studies were then analyzed to determine the outcomes of systemic therapy in terms of overall survival, progression-free survival, response rate, and adverse events. The results showed that systemic therapy significantly improved overall survival and progression-free survival compared to best supportive care alone. Additionally, a higher response rate was observed in patients receiving systemic therapy. However, it was also associated with a higher incidence of adverse events, emphasizing the need for careful patient selection and monitoring during treatment. In conclusion, systemic therapy has become a cornerstone in the management of advanced NSCLC, providing meaningful clinical benefits while considering the associated toxicities.

An inner city cancer prevention clinic. This study aims to assess the effectiveness of an inner city cancer prevention clinic in promoting early detection and prevention of cancer. Data was collected from patient records over a five-year period, and outcomes such as cancer diagnoses, stage at diagnosis, and treatment outcomes were analyzed. Results showed that the clinic played a crucial role in early detection, with a high proportion of cancers being diagnosed at an early stage. Additionally, the clinic's preventive measures, including education and screenings, contributed to a reduction in the incidence of certain cancers in the target population. However, challenges such as limited resources and access to care were noted. Overall, the clinic demonstrated promising results in the prevention and early detection of cancer in the inner city population.

Unusual blink reflex with four components in a patient with periodic ataxia. Periodic ataxias are a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by episodes of ataxia and associated symptoms. This case report describes a 32-year-old male with periodic ataxia presenting with an unusual blink reflex. The blink reflex typically consists of two components, the early and late responses. However, in this patient, an additional two components were observed, resulting in a four-component blink reflex. The first component was an early reflex that appeared with a short latency, followed by a late response similar to the normal blink reflex. The third and fourth components were unique to this patient and had longer latencies compared to the early and late responses. This atypical blink reflex may be attributed to the underlying pathophysiology of periodic ataxia. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms behind this unusual finding and its implications for the diagnosis and management of periodic ataxias.

Ischaemic heart disease among men in Norway during the period 1966-1985: two counties with different mortality time trends.  We have examined regional differences in mortality from ischaemic heart disease, including sudden, unexpected death (IHD/SUD), among Norwegian men aged 30-69 years, during the period 1966-1985. This study investigated regional differences in mortality from ischaemic heart disease (IHD), including sudden unexpected death (SUD), among Norwegian men aged 30-69 years between 1966 and 1985. Two counties with distinct mortality time trends were analyzed. The results revealed varying mortality rates in the two counties, with one county experiencing an overall decline in IHD/SUD mortality and the other exhibiting a fluctuating pattern. The study suggests that factors contributing to these differences may include variations in risk factor prevalence, healthcare services, and socioeconomic status. Understanding regional disparities in IHD/SUD mortality can provide valuable insights for targeting interventions and improving cardiovascular health outcomes.

pH-adjustment and discomfort caused by the intradermal injection of lignocaine [published erratum appears in Anaesthesia 1991 Mar;46(3):242] One hundred adult day-case patients who required intravenous access had cannulae inserted using local anaesthesia with 1% lignocaine, 1% lignocaine with adrenaline or the corresponding pH-adjusted solutions. This study aimed to assess the discomfort caused by intradermal injection of lignocaine, comparing the use of lignocaine alone, lignocaine with adrenaline, and pH-adjusted solutions of both. One hundred adult day-case patients requiring intravenous access were included. Cannulae insertion using the different solutions was performed, and the degree of discomfort experienced by each patient was recorded. The results showed that the pH-adjusted solutions significantly reduced the discomfort caused by lignocaine injection compared to the non-pH-adjusted solutions. The findings suggest that pH-adjustment of lignocaine solutions can effectively alleviate discomfort during intradermal injection, improving patient experience in clinical settings.

Histochemical demonstration of 5'-nucleotidase activity in inflammatory muscle disease. Inflammatory muscle diseases (IMDs) are a group of disorders characterized by muscle inflammation. The authors of this study aimed to determine if histochemical demonstration of 5'-nucleotidase activity can be used as a diagnostic marker for IMDs. They examined muscle biopsies from patients with different types of IMDs and compared them to control muscle samples. The results showed a significant increase in 5'-nucleotidase activity in the muscle fibers of patients with IMDs compared to controls. This increase was observed in both polymyositis and dermatomyositis, suggesting that 5'-nucleotidase activity may be a useful marker for these conditions. The findings provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis and diagnosis of IMDs and may aid in the development of targeted therapeutic approaches.

An epidemic outbreak of cryptosporidiosis: a prospective community study from Guinea Bissau.  In the first year of a prospective community study of childhood diarrhea conducted in a semiurban area in the capital of Guinea Bissau, Cryptosporidium sp. An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred during a one-year prospective community study on childhood diarrhea in Guinea Bissau. Cryptosporidium sp. was identified as the causative agent in a significant number of cases. The study was conducted in a semiurban area in the capital city. Analysis of stool samples revealed the presence of Cryptosporidium oocysts in affected individuals. The outbreak was characterized by an increased incidence of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and dehydration. Factors such as poor sanitation and limited access to clean water were identified as potential contributors to the epidemic. This study highlights the importance of public health measures in preventing and controlling outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis in resource-limited settings.

Prediction of cognitive change as a function of preoperative ability status among temporal lobectomy patients seen at 6-month follow-up. The aim of this study was to investigate the predictive value of preoperative cognitive abilities on cognitive changes in patients who underwent temporal lobectomy. A total of 68 patients were included in the study and assessed for cognitive functioning before surgery and at a 6-month follow-up. The results showed that patients with lower preoperative cognitive abilities had a greater decline in cognitive functioning post-surgery compared to those with higher preoperative cognitive abilities. Specifically, patients with lower preoperative abilities in memory, language, and executive function showed significant declines in these domains at the 6-month follow-up. Moreover, patients who had a longer duration of epilepsy and a higher degree of hippocampal sclerosis were also more likely to experience cognitive decline post-surgery. These findings suggest that preoperative cognitive abilities can serve as a predictive factor for cognitive changes following temporal lobectomy, highlighting the importance of considering individual characteristics when evaluating surgical candidacy and postoperative outcomes.

Antiepileptic drugs, cognitive function, and behavior in children: evidence from recent studies.  The effects of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children are reviewed on the basis of published studies. This review examines the impact of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) on cognitive function and behavior in children, based on recent studies. The findings from published research are summarized. AEDs are commonly used to manage seizures in pediatric patients, but their potential adverse effects on cognitive function and behavior are a concern. The reviewed studies indicate that certain AEDs, such as valproate and phenobarbital, may be associated with cognitive impairments and behavioral problems in children. However, other AEDs, such as lamotrigine and levetiracetam, are found to have a more favorable profile regarding cognitive function and behavior. It is important for clinicians to consider these potential effects when selecting an appropriate AED treatment for children with epilepsy.

Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage: imaging and management. Spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage is a rare condition that presents with sudden flank pain and can lead to potentially life-threatening situations. We conducted a retrospective analysis of 95 cases of spontaneous perinephric hemorrhage in order to evaluate the imaging findings and management strategies. CT scans were performed in all cases, revealing perinephric hematoma in 87 patients (91.6%) and extravasation of contrast in 35 patients (36.8%). Angiography was performed in 32 patients, with active bleeding identified in 22 cases (68.8%). The most common underlying etiology was renal tumor rupture, accounting for 44 cases (46.3%). Conservative management was successful in 67 patients (70.5%), while 28 patients (29.5%) required intervention including embolization or surgical exploration. Overall mortality rate was 6.3%, with death attributed to sepsis in the majority of cases. In conclusion, CT scans are effective in diagnosing perinephric hemorrhage and determining the location and severity of the bleed. Conservative management is often successful, but prompt intervention is necessary in selected cases to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

New horizons in the treatment of coronary artery thrombosis. Coronary artery thrombosis is a potentially life-threatening condition that requires prompt and effective treatment. This study aimed to explore new horizons in the management of this condition. Various treatment approaches were investigated, including novel pharmacological agents, percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) techniques, and mechanical thrombectomy devices. Additionally, the role of adjunctive therapies such as antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants was examined. The study found promising results with the use of newer antithrombotic agents, such as direct oral anticoagulants and novel platelet inhibitors, which demonstrated improved efficacy and safety profiles compared to traditional therapies. Furthermore, advances in PCI techniques, such as aspiration thrombectomy and stent retrievers, showed potential for better restoration of coronary flow. These findings suggest exciting new directions for the treatment of coronary artery thrombosis, with the potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce long-term complications.

Threshold perimetry in tilted disc syndrome.  Twelve consecutive patients (17 eyes) with tilted disc syndrome underwent quantified visual field examination with the G1 Octopus program (Interzeag AG, Schlieren, Switzerland). Tilted disc syndrome is a condition characterized by an abnormal tilting of the optic disc, resulting in visual field defects. This study aimed to evaluate the use of threshold perimetry in diagnosing and monitoring this syndrome. Twelve patients with tilted disc syndrome (17 eyes) underwent visual field examination using the G1 Octopus program. The results showed characteristic visual field defects, including arcuate scotomas, nasal steps, and blind spots. These defects were predominantly located inferiorly and nasally, corresponding to the tilting of the optic disc. The quantified visual field examination provided valuable information on the extent and progression of visual field defects in tilted disc syndrome. The findings of this study suggest that threshold perimetry using the G1 Octopus program is a useful tool for diagnosing and monitoring patients with tilted disc syndrome. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore the potential of this technique in managing this condition.

Long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. This article examines the long-term medical consequences of incest, rape, and molestation. The psychological impact of these traumatic experiences has been well-documented, but little attention has been given to the physical health effects. Studies have shown that survivors of sexual abuse are at increased risk for a range of medical conditions, including chronic pain, gastrointestinal disorders, sexually transmitted infections, and reproductive health problems. Furthermore, there is evidence of a link between childhood sexual abuse and the development of chronic conditions such as fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, and autoimmune disorders. Understanding and addressing the physical health consequences of sexual abuse is crucial for the comprehensive care of survivors and the prevention of further harm.

The electrocardiogram in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. This article reviews the electrocardiogram (ECG) findings in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). COPD is a common respiratory disorder associated with significant cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. The ECG is a non-invasive tool that can provide important information about cardiac function and rhythm abnormalities in these patients. The main ECG findings observed in COPD include right axis deviation, right ventricular hypertrophy, P-pulmonale, and T-wave abnormalities. These ECG changes are thought to reflect the underlying pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction that occur in COPD. Understanding the ECG findings in COPD can aid in the diagnosis and management of cardiovascular complications in these patients.

Isolated trigeminal sensory loss secondary to a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm: case report.  A previously healthy 25-year-old woman suddenly developed right-sided facial numbness and a headache. We present a case of isolated trigeminal sensory loss in a 25-year-old woman who developed right-sided facial numbness and a headache. Neurological examination revealed diminished sensation in the distribution of the right ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed a distal anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) aneurysm compressing the trigeminal nerve at the root entry zone. The patient underwent craniotomy and clipping of the aneurysm, resulting in complete resolution of her symptoms. Isolated trigeminal sensory loss is a rare manifestation of AICA aneurysms, and prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent further neurological deficits. This case highlights the importance of considering vascular lesions as a possible etiology for trigeminal sensory loss.

Umbilical cord hematoma following diagnostic funipuncture. Umbilical cord hematoma (UCH) is a rare complication following diagnostic funipuncture. We present a case report and review the literature on this condition. A full-term newborn developed a UCH after diagnostic funipuncture performed for genetic testing. The hematoma presented as a painless, firm, and pulsatile mass at the umbilical cord insertion site. Ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of UCH. The patient was closely monitored for signs of infection or further complications. The hematoma resolved spontaneously within two weeks without any intervention. UCH is a rare but potentially significant complication of funipuncture. It is important for healthcare providers to be aware of this complication and for parents to be informed about the potential risks associated with the procedure. Further research is needed to better understand the incidence, risk factors, and optimal management of UCH.

Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch".  The fiberoptic endoscope has never gained popularity among neurosurgeons although it is ideally suited for navigating within the cerebral ventricles. Endoscopic ventricular fenestration using a "saline torch" is an innovative technique for neurosurgeons to navigate within the cerebral ventricles. The fiberoptic endoscope, despite its suitability for this purpose, has not been widely adopted among neurosurgeons. This technique involves the use of a saline torch, which provides illumination and allows for visualization during the fenestration procedure. This abstract presents a case series of patients who underwent endoscopic ventricular fenestration using the saline torch. The procedure was successful in improving intraventricular communication, resulting in improved cerebrospinal fluid flow and decreased hydrocephalus. This novel technique demonstrates the potential of the fiberoptic endoscope in neurosurgical procedures and highlights the need for further exploration and adoption of this tool among neurosurgeons.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. We report two cases of neurinoma in the cavernous sinus, a rare location for such tumors. In case 1, a 55-year-old female presented with right-sided proptosis, diplopia, and headache. In case 2, a 60-year-old male complained of left-sided proptosis and vision loss. Both patients underwent magnetic resonance imaging, which revealed a well-defined lesion in the cavernous sinus. Surgical resection was performed in both cases, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of neurinoma. The patients had complete resolution of symptoms postoperatively and remained asymptomatic during follow-up. Neurinoma should be considered in the differential diagnosis of cavernous sinus masses, and surgical resection can be a successful treatment option for these tumors.

Intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head. We present a case of a rare intraosseous lipoma within the femoral head. A 45-year-old male patient complained of hip pain and restricted range of motion. Radiological imaging revealed a well-defined radiolucent lesion within the femoral head. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a fat-suppressed lesion with characteristic high signal intensity on T1-weighted images. The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an intraosseous lipoma. Intraosseous lipomas are uncommon benign tumors, accounting for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors. They typically present as asymptomatic lesions and are incidentally discovered on radiographs or during surgery for unrelated conditions. Surgical excision is recommended to alleviate symptoms and prevent further complications.

Infarct of the conus medullaris simulating a spinal cord tumor: case report. We present a case report of a patient who initially presented with symptoms suggestive of a spinal cord tumor but was ultimately diagnosed with infarct of the conus medullaris. This case highlights the importance of considering infarct as a potential etiology in patients with neurological deficits, even in the absence of risk factors such as vascular disease or trauma. The patient underwent an extensive workup, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which revealed a lesion in the conus medullaris. However, histopathological examination of the resected tissue confirmed the diagnosis of infarct. Awareness of this rare condition is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Delayed recognition of conus medullaris infarct can result in unnecessary interventions and potential complications.

Unusual aspects of aortovenous fistulas associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. Aortovenous fistulas (AVF) associated with ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are rare but life-threatening conditions. This study aimed to investigate the unusual aspects of AVF in AAA patients. The medical records of 20 patients with AVF were retrospectively analyzed. The mean age was 67 years, and all patients presented with hemodynamic instability. Unusual aspects were observed in three cases. In one patient, the AVF resulted in a high-output cardiac failure due to a persistent left superior vena cava draining into the left atrium. In another patient, the AVF led to duodenal ischemia due to compromised mesenteric blood flow. The last case had a retroperitoneal hematoma, which caused spinal cord compression and paraplegia. Prompt diagnosis and management of AVF are crucial to improve patient outcomes. Surgeons should be aware of these rare but potentially life-threatening presentations of AVF in AAA patients.

Genetic diagnosis of Lynch syndrome II in an extended colorectal cancer-prone family. Lynch syndrome II, a hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome, was diagnosed in an extended family with a high incidence of colorectal cancer. By using a combination of genetic testing and clinical evaluation, a diagnosis was made in multiple family members. The proband initially presented with colorectal cancer at a young age and a family history suggestive of a hereditary component. Genetic testing for Lynch syndrome-associated mutations revealed a pathogenic variant in the MSH2 gene. Further evaluation of affected family members confirmed the presence of this mutation, substantiating the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome II. This diagnosis has important implications for the affected individuals and their families, as surveillance and preventive strategies can be implemented to detect and manage cancer at an early stage. Additionally, genetic counseling and testing can be offered to at-risk family members to aid in their clinical management and decision-making processes. The identification of Lynch syndrome II in this family highlights the importance of genetic testing and counseling in individuals with a strong family history of colorectal cancer.

Epstein-Barr virus associated oesophageal ulcers in AIDS. Oesophageal ulcers due to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection are a rare finding in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). We present a case of a 34-year-old male with AIDS who was admitted with dysphagia and odynophagia. Endoscopy revealed multiple discrete ulcers throughout the entire length of the oesophagus. Histopathological examination showed characteristic features of EBV infection. The patient was started on antiretroviral therapy and treated with supportive measures including proton pump inhibitors, analgesics, and antifungal agents. Following treatment, the patient reported a significant improvement in symptoms and repeat endoscopy showed complete healing of the ulcers. This case highlights the importance of considering EBV infection as a potential cause of oesophageal ulcers in patients with AIDS and the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in managing such cases.

Recurrence rate after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy in alveolar echinococcosis (preliminary results).  The recurrence rate was investigated in 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of a long-term therapy with mebendazole (average treatment 4. The aim of this study was to determine the recurrence rate of alveolar echinococcosis after discontinuation of long-term mebendazole therapy. The study included 19 patients with non-resectable alveolar echinococcosis who had undergone an average treatment duration of 4.7 years.
