The system utilized a combination of artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to provide accurate and timely diagnostic outputs. A dataset of colonic lesion images was used to train and validate the system, which achieved high diagnostic accuracy and sensitivity. The expert system exhibited great potential in the diagnosis of colonic lesions, offering an alternative or adjunct to traditional diagnostic methods. Implementing this system in clinical practice could significantly improve the efficiency and accuracy of colonic lesion diagnoses, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes.

Pharmacologic stress imaging. Pharmacologic stress imaging is a non-invasive procedure used to evaluate myocardial perfusion and identify coronary artery disease (CAD) in patients who are unable to perform exercise stress testing. This imaging technique involves the administration of pharmacologic stress agents such as adenosine, dipyridamole, or dobutamine, which induce coronary vasodilation or increase myocardial oxygen demand. The stress agents are combined with myocardial perfusion imaging using single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) or positron emission tomography (PET) to assess blood flow to the heart muscle. Pharmacologic stress imaging has shown high diagnostic accuracy for CAD detection and risk stratification. It has the advantage of being able to evaluate patients with physical limitations or comorbidities that prevent exercise stress testing. This abstract highlights the importance of pharmacologic stress imaging as a valuable tool in the diagnosis and management of CAD, allowing for appropriate risk stratification and treatment planning.

A histopathologic study of spinal cord ischemia using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. Spinal cord ischemia is a devastating complication that can occur after surgery or trauma. To better understand the pathophysiology of this condition, a histopathologic study was conducted using an isohistogenic rat upper-half-body transplantation model. In this model, the spinal cord of an isohistogenic donor rat was transplanted into the upper half of the body of another isohistogenic recipient rat. The spinal cord was then subjected to ischemia for a specified period of time. Histopathologic examinations were performed to assess the degree of ischemic injury and to identify potential therapeutic targets. The results of this study provide valuable insights into the cellular and tissue changes that occur during spinal cord ischemia, and may help guide the development of novel treatment strategies for this devastating condition.

The incidence of deep vein thrombosis after cementless and cemented knee replacement. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a common complication following knee replacement surgery. The incidence of DVT varies depending on the type of knee replacement, with conflicting evidence regarding the risk associated with cementless and cemented prostheses. We conducted a retrospective study to compare the incidence of DVT following cementless and cemented knee replacement in a cohort of 426 patients. The overall incidence of DVT was 10.3%, with 6.5% in the cementless group and 13.1% in the cemented group. There was a statistically significant difference in the incidence of DVT between the two groups (p=0.034). Our findings suggest that cementless knee replacement may be associated with a lower risk of DVT compared to cemented knee replacement. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm these results and determine the underlying mechanisms.

Reduction in bleeding after heart-lung transplantation.  The importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis. Posterior mediastinal bleeding is a common complication following heart-lung transplantation, contributing to increased morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of posterior mediastinal hemostasis in reducing bleeding in these patients. A retrospective analysis of 120 heart-lung transplantation surgeries was conducted, with patients divided into two groups: those who underwent posterior mediastinal hemostasis (n=60) and those who did not (n=60). The results showed a significant reduction in postoperative bleeding in the hemostasis group compared to the control group (p<0.001). Moreover, the hemostasis group had a lower incidence of reoperation due to bleeding (p=0.003). These findings underscore the importance of posterior mediastinal hemostasis in achieving hemostasis and reducing bleeding complications after heart-lung transplantation. Further studies are needed to determine the optimal technique for posterior mediastinal hemostasis and its impact on long-term outcomes.

Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of vater. Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater is a rare and aggressive tumor with poor prognosis. We present a case of a 55-year-old male diagnosed with neuroendocrine carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. The patient presented with abdominal pain and jaundice. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the ampullary region. Surgical resection with regional lymphadenectomy was performed, and the tumor was histologically confirmed as neuroendocrine carcinoma. Postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy was administered. The patient remained disease-free at the 6-month follow-up. Due to the rarity and aggressive nature of this tumor, further studies are warranted to optimize treatment strategies and improve patient outcomes.

Co-trimoxazole for childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. This article examines the use of co-trimoxazole, an antibiotic, in the treatment of childhood febrile illness in malaria-endemic regions. The study focuses on the benefits of co-trimoxazole, including its potential to reduce malaria-related mortality and morbidity in children. The research highlights the importance of early initiation of co-trimoxazole treatment for febrile illness, as it has been shown to reduce the incidence of malaria. Furthermore, the article discusses the potential side effects and limitations of using co-trimoxazole, such as antimicrobial resistance and adverse reactions. Despite these considerations, the study suggests that co-trimoxazole treatment remains a valuable intervention in malaria-endemic regions for preventing febrile illness and reducing the burden of malaria in children.

Immunohistochemical investigations of estrogen receptors in normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva. Estrogen receptors (ER) play a crucial role in the development and progression of various diseases, including cancer. Squamous epithelium of the vulva is susceptible to neoplastic transformation, and the role of estrogen receptors in this process remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the expression of estrogen receptors in both normal and neoplastic squamous epithelium of the vulva using immunohistochemical analysis. A total of (number) vulvar tissue samples were included in this study, consisting of (number) samples of normal squamous epithelium and (number) samples of neoplastic squamous epithelium. The expression and localization of estrogen receptors were evaluated and compared between the two groups. Our findings shed light on the potential involvement of estrogen receptors in the pathogenesis of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma and may provide insights into novel therapeutic strategies targeting these receptors.

Spinal accessory nerve palsy: an unusual complication of coronary artery bypass The neurologic complications of coronary artery bypass surgery have been well documented, with a reported incidence of 61% in one large study.  Most injuries to the peripheral nervous system involve the brachial plexus. Spinal accessory nerve palsy is a rare complication of coronary artery bypass surgery. In a large study, the reported incidence of neurologic complications after the surgery was 61%, with most involving the brachial plexus. However, spinal accessory nerve palsy is an uncommon occurrence. This case report highlights a patient who developed spinal accessory nerve palsy after coronary artery bypass surgery. The importance of recognizing this unusual complication and providing appropriate management and rehabilitation strategies is emphasized. Further research is needed to better understand the risk factors and preventive measures for spinal accessory nerve palsy in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery.

Preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells can be extracted from uterine leiomyoma tissues. This study aims to investigate the presence of mitogenic activity in uterine leiomyoma tissues. Tissue samples were collected from patients with uterine leiomyoma and subjected to various extraction methods. Results showed that a preferential mitogenic activity for myoblast-like cells was extracted from the leiomyoma tissues. This suggests the potential involvement of this mitogenic activity in the pathogenesis of uterine leiomyoma. Further studies are needed to explore the specific mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets associated with this mitogenic activity. Understanding the factors contributing to the development and growth of uterine leiomyoma could lead to improved treatment strategies for this common gynecological disorder.

Levels of mRNA for a putative kainate receptor are affected by seizures. Seizures have a significant impact on gene expression, including the regulation of mRNA levels for various receptors. This study investigates the effect of seizures on mRNA levels for a putative kainate receptor. Kainate receptors are known to play a role in excitatory synaptic transmission and contribute to the pathophysiology of epilepsy. Using animal models and molecular techniques, the researchers observed a significant upregulation of mRNA for the putative kainate receptor following seizures. This finding suggests that the expression of kainate receptors is influenced by seizure activity, potentially contributing to the development and progression of epilepsy. Further investigations into the functional implications of altered kainate receptor mRNA levels during seizures may provide insights into novel therapeutic targets for the management of epilepsy.

Evaluating oxygen delivery and oxygen utilization with mixed venous oxygen saturation monitoring: a case study approach. Monitoring mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) provides valuable information about oxygen delivery and utilization in critically ill patients. We present a series of case studies to evaluate the clinical utility of SvO2 monitoring in different scenarios. Case 1 involves a patient with septic shock, demonstrating the role of SvO2 in guiding resuscitation efforts and identifying tissue hypoxia despite adequate systemic oxygen delivery. Case 2 explores a patient with severe heart failure, highlighting the correlation between SvO2 and cardiac output, as well as its usefulness in guiding therapeutic interventions. Case 3 focuses on a patient undergoing major surgery, illustrating how SvO2 monitoring helps assess global tissue oxygenation and guide perioperative management. We emphasize that SvO2 monitoring provides valuable insights into oxygen balance and should be considered in critically ill patients for optimizing patient care and improving outcomes.

Association of Escherichia coli HEp-2 adherence patterns with type and duration of diarrhoea. This study aimed to investigate the association between Escherichia coli (E. coli) HEp-2 adherence patterns and the type and duration of diarrhea in patients. A total of 200 patients with acute diarrhea were included in the study. Stool samples were collected and analyzed for E. coli strains using standard laboratory methods. Adherence patterns were determined using the HEp-2 adherence assay. The results showed that 75% of the patients had E. coli infection, with the majority (65%) exhibiting localized adherence (LA) pattern. Diffuse adherence (DA) and aggregative adherence (AA) patterns were observed in 24% and 11% of the patients, respectively. Patients with LA pattern had a shorter duration of diarrhea compared to those with DA and AA patterns (p < 0.05). No significant association was found between adherence patterns and the type of diarrhea. In conclusion, E. coli HEp-2 adherence patterns, particularly the LA pattern, may play a role in the duration of diarrhea in patients, highlighting the importance of understanding the pathogenesis of E. coli infection for better management of diarrheal diseases.

The Van Nes tibial rotationplasty. Van Nes tibial rotationplasty is a limb salvage procedure used in the treatment of selected lower limb malignancies. This procedure involves the rotational repositioning of the distal tibia to serve as a functional knee joint after removal of the affected bone segment. This case study reports the successful use of Van Nes tibial rotationplasty in a 15-year-old patient with osteosarcoma of the distal femur. Postoperatively, the patient achieved excellent functional outcomes and demonstrated good psychological adaptation to the procedure. Van Nes tibial rotationplasty offers a unique solution for patients who require amputation and provides them with improved functional and psychosocial outcomes compared to traditional prosthetic limbs. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and patient satisfaction.

Acute oculogyric crisis after administration of prochlorperazine. We report a case of acute oculogyric crisis (AOC) occurring after the administration of prochlorperazine in a 43-year-old female patient. AOC is a dystonic reaction characterized by forced and sustained upward deviation of the eyes, often accompanied by other dystonic movements. It is a rare side effect of certain medications, including antipsychotics like prochlorperazine. The patient presented with sudden onset of AOC shortly after receiving intravenous prochlorperazine for the treatment of nausea. The symptoms resolved completely within 48 hours after discontinuation of the medication and administration of diphenhydramine. This case highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly managing AOC as a potential adverse reaction to prochlorperazine and other similar medications.

Choroid plexus tumors in the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Choroid plexus tumors (CPTs) are rare neoplasms that most commonly occur in the brain, but they have also been reported in other locations such as the breast. The breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome is a hereditary condition characterized by the development of both breast cancer and sarcoma in affected individuals. We report a case of CPTs in a patient with this syndrome, which has not been previously described in the literature. The patient presented with multiple breast tumors, and histopathological examination revealed CPTs. Genetic testing confirmed the presence of a pathogenic variant in the breast cancer gene BRCA1. This case highlights the importance of considering CPTs in the differential diagnosis of breast tumors in patients with the breast cancer-sarcoma syndrome. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms of CPT development in this syndrome.

Simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck in congenital Brown's syndrome. Congenital Brown's syndrome, a characterized by limited elevation in adduction and intorsion, can be challenging to treat. We present a case of a 9-year-old boy with congenital Brown's syndrome in his right eye. Simultaneous superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck surgery was performed to correct the condition. The patient's preoperative and postoperative ocular motility measurements were documented. Postoperative follow-up showed complete resolution of the strabismus and improvement in elevation in adduction and intorsion. The simultaneous combination of superior oblique sheathectomy and inferior oblique tuck surgery proved to be effective in treating congenital Brown's syndrome, providing satisfactory motility outcomes in our patient. This surgical technique offers merits of stability, less risk of recurrence, and minimal residual torsion as compared to other surgical procedures. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up are warranted to validate the results of this surgical approach.

Oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis. The relationship between oral contraceptives, lipoproteins, and atherosclerosis was examined in a retrospective study. A total of 500 women aged 20-45 years, who were using oral contraceptives for at least one year, were included. Lipoprotein levels, including total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglycerides, were measured. The presence and severity of atherosclerosis were assessed using carotid artery ultrasound. The results showed that women using oral contraceptives had significantly higher levels of total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and triglycerides compared to non-users. Furthermore, higher levels of these lipoproteins were associated with increased severity of atherosclerosis. Interestingly, there was a negative correlation between high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels and the presence of atherosclerosis. These findings suggest that oral contraceptives may contribute to dyslipidemia and promote the development of atherosclerosis. Further research is warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential strategies for reducing cardiovascular risk in women using oral contraceptives.

Clinical observation on the association of gallstones and colorectal cancer.  A possible association between gallstones, colorectal cancer, and gastric cancer was investigated. This study aimed to investigate the potential association between gallstones and colorectal cancer, as well as gastric cancer. Clinical observations were conducted to explore the relationship between these conditions. The results indicated a possible association between gallstones and colorectal cancer, as well as gastric cancer. The association appeared to be significant, suggesting that individuals with gallstones may have an increased risk of developing colorectal and gastric cancer. These findings have important implications for clinical practice, as they highlight the need for increased surveillance and screening in individuals with gallstones. Early detection and appropriate management of these conditions could potentially lead to improved outcomes and reduced mortality rates. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying mechanisms and to develop effective preventive strategies for individuals at risk.

Warner-Lambert/Parke-Davis Award lecture. The treatment of Peyronie's disease can be challenging, especially in patients who do not respond to conservative therapies. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and patient satisfaction of penile implants in the management of advanced Peyronie's disease. A total of 35 patients underwent penile prosthesis implantation following failed conservative therapy. Prior to surgery, 55% of the patients were unable to engage in sexual intercourse due to pain or penile angulation, and 25% had complete erectile dysfunction. After a mean follow-up period of 6.9 years, 88% of the patients reported successful intercourse and were satisfied with the results. These findings suggest that penile prosthesis implantation is a highly effective and satisfactory option for the treatment of Peyronie's disease in selected patients. Further research is needed to validate these results.

Celiac disease, brain atrophy, and dementia. Celiac disease (CD) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by gluten intolerance and small intestine inflammation. Recent studies have suggested an association between CD and neurological disorders, such as brain atrophy and dementia. This abstract aims to review the current literature on the link between CD, brain atrophy, and dementia. Several case reports and cohort studies have reported an increased prevalence of brain atrophy and dementia in CD patients, especially in those with late-onset disease. Histopathological findings have shown neuronal loss, gliosis, and deposition of amyloid proteins in CD patients. However, the exact mechanisms underlying these associations are still unclear and further research is needed. Recognition of these neurological manifestations in CD patients is crucial for early diagnosis and appropriate management.

Toward a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis, a debilitating condition resulting from inflammation of the arachnoid membrane, lacks a standardized therapeutic approach. This abstract proposes a rational therapeutic strategy for arachnoiditis. The proposed strategy involves a combination of non-pharmacological and pharmacological interventions. Non-pharmacological interventions include physical therapy, exercise, and cognitive-behavioral therapy, aimed at improving functional capacity and managing chronic pain. Pharmacological interventions include the use of anti-inflammatory medications, such as corticosteroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, to reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms. Additionally, neuropathic pain medications, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, may be utilized for pain management. In severe cases, surgical interventions, such as the implantation of spinal cord stimulators or targeted drug delivery systems, may be considered. Overall, this rational therapeutic strategy emphasizes a multidisciplinary approach, addressing both physical and psychological aspects of arachnoiditis to improve patient outcomes.

Increasing the cancer screening of the medically underserved in south Florida. This article discusses the initiative to increase cancer screening among the medically underserved population in south Florida. The study aims to address the disparities in cancer screening rates and outcomes among this population. The authors highlight the importance of early detection and prevention in reducing cancer morbidity and mortality. They outline the barriers faced by the medically underserved, such as lack of access to healthcare facilities and financial constraints, which contribute to the low screening rates. The study proposes a multifaceted approach to improving cancer screening rates, including community outreach programs, patient education, and collaboration with local healthcare providers. Additionally, the authors emphasize the need for culturally appropriate and linguistically tailored interventions to effectively reach and engage the target population. The article concludes by highlighting the potential impact of these efforts in reducing disparities and improving cancer outcomes among the medically underserved in south Florida.

Use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate in patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation. The use of intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate was evaluated in patients with prostatic carcinoma who did not respond to conventional hormonal manipulation. A total of 10 patients were included in the study. Stilbestrol diphosphate was administered in a dose of 5 mg daily for a period of 6 weeks. Response to treatment was assessed using prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels and clinical examination. Of the 10 patients, 4 showed a decrease in PSA levels and improvement in clinical symptoms, while the remaining 6 patients did not show any significant response. The side effects observed were mild and included hot flashes and nausea. These findings suggest that intravenous stilbestrol diphosphate may be a potential treatment option for patients with prostatic carcinoma refractory to conventional hormonal manipulation, although further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these results.

Outcome of cataract surgery in central India: a longitudinal follow-up study. In this longitudinal follow-up study, the outcomes of cataract surgery in a central Indian population were evaluated. A total of 200 eyes from 150 patients who underwent cataract surgery were included in the study. The average age of the patients was 63 years. The mean preoperative visual acuity was 0.86, which improved significantly to 0.35 postoperatively. The visual acuity remained stable over the 1-year follow-up period. Complications occurred in 10% of the eyes, including posterior capsular opacification and endophthalmitis. The majority of the complications were successfully managed with appropriate interventions. Patient satisfaction was high, with 90% reporting improved vision and quality of life. 

This study highlights the positive outcomes of cataract surgery in the central Indian population, with significant improvements in visual acuity and high patient satisfaction. However, it also emphasizes the importance of postoperative monitoring and management of complications to ensure optimal results.

Computed tomography staging of the paranasal sinuses in chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis. Chronic hyperplastic rhinosinusitis (CHRS) is a chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by thickening of the sinus mucosa and the presence of nasal polyps. Computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating the extent of disease and planning surgical intervention in these patients. This study aimed to assess the utility of CT staging in CHRS patients. A retrospective analysis of CT scans was performed on 75 patients diagnosed with CHRS. A modified staging system was used to categorize the extent of disease based on the involvement of individual sinuses. The results showed a significant correlation between CT stage and clinical symptoms, endoscopic findings, and surgical outcomes. CT staging provided valuable information for preoperative planning and predicting treatment outcomes in CHRS patients. Therefore, CT staging can be an essential tool in the management of CHRS to achieve optimal surgical outcomes and improve patient quality of life.

Depression after acute myocardial infarction.  The role of primary care physicians in rehabilitation. Depression is a common complication following acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and can impact the rehabilitation process. This study aimed to assess the role of primary care physicians (PCPs) in managing depression in post-AMI patients. A total of 250 post-AMI patients were included and followed for six months. The prevalence of depression was found to be 30%. PCPs played a crucial role in identifying, diagnosing, and managing depression in these patients. Collaborative care involving PCPs, cardiologists, and mental health professionals significantly improved depression outcomes and patient adherence to secondary prevention strategies. PCPs should be actively involved in post-AMI care to ensure comprehensive management of depression and optimize patients' cardiovascular health.

Dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women.  In 1980, 88,837 women aged 34-59 y completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire and were followed for 4 y. This study aimed to examine the dietary predictors of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women. A total of 88,837 women aged 34-59 years completed a semiquantitative food frequency questionnaire in 1980 and were followed up for 4 years. Symptoms of gallstones were assessed through questionnaires. Dietary intake was analyzed and multivariate relative risks were calculated. During the 4-year follow-up, 2,680 women developed symptomatic gallstones. High intake of animal protein and cholesterol was positively associated with the risk of gallstones. In contrast, higher intake of vitamin C, magnesium, and vegetable protein was inversely associated with the risk. Furthermore, a high glycemic index, high glycemic load, and low dietary fiber intake were positively associated with gallstone risk. These findings suggest that dietary factors, such as animal protein, cholesterol, vitamin C, magnesium, vegetable protein, glycemic index, glycemic load, and dietary fiber, may influence the development of symptom-associated gallstones in middle-aged women. Further dietary interventions may be beneficial in preventing this condition.

Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. Ureteral obstruction and ureteral fistulas are rare but serious complications that can occur after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery. Obstruction of the ureters can result from compression or kinking of the ureters by the graft or surrounding scar tissue. Ureteral fistulas, on the other hand, are abnormal connections between the ureters and the graft or surrounding structures. These complications can lead to urinary tract obstruction and infection, as well as kidney dysfunction if not promptly recognized and treated. Several factors can contribute to the development of ureteral obstruction and fistulas, including surgical technique, patient anatomy, and postoperative complications such as infection or tissue ischemia.  Treatment options include surgical revision, stent placement, or percutaneous nephrostomy, depending on the severity and location of the obstruction or fistula. Awareness of these potential complications is crucial to ensure timely diagnosis and appropriate management of ureteral obstruction and fistulas after aortofemoral or aortoiliac bypass surgery.

Patient-controlled analgesia in children.  We report our experience in introducing patient-controlled analgesia at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.  Twenty-five children used the technique after orthopaedic or general surgery using the Graseby system. This study aimed to evaluate the implementation of patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) in children at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow. Twenty-five children underwent orthopaedic or general surgery and were provided with the Graseby system for PCA. The effectiveness of PCA in managing postoperative pain was assessed. Results showed that PCA was well-received by both patients and healthcare professionals, with a high level of patient satisfaction reported. The use of PCA resulted in improved pain control, reduced opioid consumption, and shorter hospital stays. However, a small number of patients experienced technical issues with the Graseby system, highlighting the need for regular equipment maintenance. Overall, the introduction of PCA in children at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children proved to be a successful method for managing postoperative pain and improving patient outcomes.

Occurrence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane in breast cancer patients.  The residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds in breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 women free of cancer were determined. The study aimed to determine the presence of beta-hexachlorocyclohexane (beta-HCH) in breast cancer patients. The breast fat of 44 breast cancer patients and 33 cancer-free women was analyzed for residues of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) and neutral organochlorine compounds. The results showed that beta-HCH was detected in all breast fat samples from both groups. The levels of beta-HCH in breast cancer patients were significantly higher compared to cancer-free women. This suggests a potential association between beta-HCH exposure and breast cancer. Further research is warranted to investigate the role of beta-HCH in the development and progression of breast cancer and its implications for prevention and treatment strategies.

Increased cholecystectomy rates in Saudi Arabia Gallstones have become increasingly prevalent in Saudi Arabia, where cholecystectomy is now one of the commonest major abdominal operations. The rate of cholecystectomy, a surgical procedure to remove the gallbladder, has significantly increased in Saudi Arabia due to the rising prevalence of gallstones. This procedure has become one of the most commonly performed major abdominal surgeries in the country. Gallstones have become increasingly prevalent in the Saudi Arabian population, likely due to changes in lifestyle and dietary habits. Cholecystectomy is considered the standard treatment for symptomatic gallstones, providing relief from pain and reducing the risk of complications. The increasing rates of cholecystectomy highlight the burden of gallstone-related diseases in Saudi Arabia and the need for effective preventive strategies and early detection to manage this condition.

Chronic pain in primary care.  Identification and management of psychosocial factors. Chronic pain is a common condition encountered in primary care, and it often involves complex interactions between biological, psychological, and social factors. Identifying and managing psychosocial factors is crucial in the successful management of chronic pain. This literature review aims to summarize current evidence on the identification and management of psychosocial factors in primary care settings. The review highlights the importance of a comprehensive biopsychosocial assessment to identify potential psychosocial factors contributing to chronic pain. Various psychosocial interventions, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, acceptance and commitment therapy, and interdisciplinary pain management programs, have shown promising results in improving patient outcomes. However, challenges such as limited resources and the need for interdisciplinary collaboration hinder the widespread implementation of these interventions in primary care. Further research is needed to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of psychosocial interventions in primary care settings to inform clinical practice and improve patient care.

Transoesophageal echocardiogram may fail to diagnose perioperative myocardial infarction.  We report a case in which a 55-yr-old man undergoing aortocoronary bypass was monitored with electrocardiogram and transoesophageal echocardiogram. Transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE) is commonly used to monitor patients undergoing cardiac surgery for perioperative myocardial infarction (MI). However, it is not infallible in detecting this complication. We present a case of a 55-year-old male who underwent aortocoronary bypass surgery and was monitored with both electrocardiogram (ECG) and TOE. Despite the continuous monitoring, the patient developed a perioperative MI that was not detected by the TOE. This case highlights the limitations of relying solely on TOE for the diagnosis of perioperative MI. It emphasizes the importance of incorporating other modalities, such as ECG, to ensure accurate detection of this potentially life-threatening event. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of TOE in detecting perioperative MI, and to determine the most effective multimodal approach for monitoring cardiac patients during surgery.

Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation: a complication of anterior spine surgery.  Stabilization of the cervical spine is often accomplished via an anterior cervical approach. Anterior cervical spine surgery is commonly performed for cervical spine stabilization. However, it can result in rare complications such as delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation. We present a case report of a 42-year-old male who developed this complication three weeks after undergoing anterior cervical spine surgery. The patient presented with dysphagia, odynophagia, and subcutaneous emphysema. Imaging studies revealed a pharyngoesophageal fistula and pneumomediastinum. He underwent immediate surgical repair and made a satisfactory recovery. Delayed pharyngoesophageal perforation is a recognized complication of anterior spine surgery. Surgeons and patients should be aware of this potential complication and consider it when evaluating post-operative symptoms. Early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention can lead to successful outcomes.

A new method for mapping hepatic subsegment: counterstaining identification technique. In liver surgery, accurate identification of hepatic subsegments is crucial for successful outcomes. We developed a new method called the counterstaining identification technique to better visualize and map the hepatic subsegments. This technique involves the use of a specific counterstain that selectively stains the subsegment boundaries, allowing for improved visualization and differentiation between adjacent subsegments. In a study involving 50 patients undergoing liver resection, we found that the counterstaining identification technique resulted in accurate identification of hepatic subsegments in 98% of cases. Furthermore, the technique was easy to perform and did not require additional equipment or expertise. This novel method has the potential to improve surgical planning, reduce intraoperative complications, and enhance postoperative outcomes in liver surgery. Further validation studies are warranted to confirm these findings and assess the long-term benefits of this technique.

Effects of nimodipine on cerebral blood flow and neuropsychological outcome after cardiac surgery. In a randomized controlled trial, 60 patients undergoing cardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive either nimodipine or placebo preoperatively and for 72 hours postoperatively. Cerebral blood flow was measured using single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) before surgery and on postoperative day 3. Neuropsychological assessments were conducted preoperatively, postoperatively, and at 6 months follow-up. Analysis of the data showed that patients in the nimodipine group had significantly higher cerebral blood flow compared to the placebo group at postoperative day 3. Additionally, the nimodipine group exhibited significantly better neuropsychological outcomes at both the immediate postoperative period and the 6-month follow-up. These findings suggest that nimodipine administration may improve cerebral blood flow and contribute to better neuropsychological outcomes in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. Further research is warranted to confirm these results and determine the optimal dose and duration of nimodipine treatment.

Physiologic and pathologic alterations associated with ultrasonically generated shock waves. Ultrasonic shock waves are commonly used in medical procedures for therapeutic purposes. However, they can also induce physiological and pathological alterations in tissues. This study aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasonically generated shock waves on various tissues. Animals were exposed to shock waves and subsequently examined for tissue changes. It was found that shock waves caused alterations in vascular permeability, tissue edema, and cellular damage in different organs. These effects were more pronounced in tissues with higher water content, such as the liver and kidney. Additionally, shock waves induced inflammatory responses, including leukocyte infiltration and activation of immune cells. These findings highlight the potential risks and side effects associated with the use of ultrasonic shock waves in medical procedures.

Efficacy and complications of radiotherapy of anterior visual pathway tumors. Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for anterior visual pathway tumors, although the optimal dose and technique remain uncertain. This review aimed to assess the efficacy and complications associated with radiotherapy in the management of these tumors. A comprehensive literature search identified studies reporting outcomes and adverse events of radiotherapy in patients with anterior visual pathway tumors. The results demonstrated high rates of tumor control, with local control rates ranging from 83% to 100%. However, visual function preservation varied, with rates of preservation ranging from 32% to 84%. Complications were generally low, although radiation-induced optic neuropathy and radiation retinopathy were reported in some cases. Further studies are needed to establish optimal radiotherapy techniques and doses for anterior visual pathway tumors.

Mechanical measures in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in total knee arthroplasty. Postoperative thromboembolism is a common complication following total knee arthroplasty. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mechanical measures in preventing postoperative thromboembolism in 428 patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty. Mechanical measures included the use of pneumatic compression devices and early mobilization. The incidence of postoperative thromboembolism was significantly lower in patients who received mechanical measures compared to those who did not (p < 0.001). Additionally, the use of mechanical measures was associated with a lower incidence of deep vein thrombosis (p = 0.005) and pulmonary embolism (p = 0.012). These findings suggest that mechanical measures, such as pneumatic compression devices and early mobilization, play an important role in the prophylaxis of postoperative thromboembolism in total knee arthroplasty patients. Further studies are needed to explore their optimal use and potential benefits.

Cardiomyopathy associated with the smoking of crystal methamphetamine. Crystal methamphetamine use has been associated with various cardiovascular complications, including cardiomyopathy. This medical abstract aims to explore the relationship between crystal methamphetamine smoking and cardiomyopathy. Studies have shown that chronic crystal methamphetamine use can lead to structural changes in the heart, including fibrosis and hypertrophy. Mechanistically, crystal methamphetamine can cause oxidative stress, inflammation, and mitochondrial dysfunction, all of which contribute to the development of cardiomyopathy. Additionally, the drug's vasoconstrictive effects and increased sympathetic activity can lead to myocardial ischemia and subsequent cardiac damage. Furthermore, the synergistic effects of crystal methamphetamine with other illicit substances and co-existing risk factors, such as hypertension and HIV infection, can further increase the risk of cardiomyopathy. Early recognition of these cardiovascular complications is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further deterioration.

Photochemotherapy improves chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease.  We have used oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) to treat four patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease of the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had responded only partially to long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone, cyclosporine, azathioprine). In this study, we evaluated the effectiveness of oral psoralen photochemotherapy (PUVA) in treating chronic cutaneous graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Four patients with lesions involving the skin, oral mucosa, and liver, who had previously shown partial response to long-term immunosuppressive therapy, were enrolled. PUVA treatment led to significant improvements in all patients, including resolution of skin lesions, reduction in oral mucosal inflammation, and normalization of liver function tests. Furthermore, the patients were able to decrease or discontinue their immunosuppressive medications. These findings support the use of PUVA as an effective therapeutic option for chronic cutaneous GVHD, particularly in cases where traditional immunosuppressive therapy has been inadequate.

Spontaneous sump syndrome: Successful treatment by duodenoscopic sphincterotomy. Spontaneous sump syndrome is a rare complication of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, characterized by reflux of bile into the gastric remnant causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. We present a case of a 46-year-old female patient who developed spontaneous sump syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. She was successfully treated with duodenoscopic sphincterotomy, which involved incision of the remnant gastric outlet ring. The procedure resulted in immediate relief of symptoms and resolution of bile reflux. Duodenoscopic sphincterotomy appears to be an effective and minimally invasive treatment option for patients with spontaneous sump syndrome, providing symptom relief and improving quality of life. Further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of this procedure.

Aneuploidy in pancreatic insulinomas does not predict malignancy. The presence of aneuploidy in pancreatic insulinomas has been suggested as a potential marker for malignancy. In this study, we aim to determine if aneuploidy is a reliable predictor of malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas. We analyzed the karyotypes of 40 pancreatic insulinomas and compared them to the clinical outcomes of the patients. Surprisingly, we found that the presence of aneuploidy did not correlate with malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas. Out of the 40 cases analyzed, 15 were aneuploid and 25 were diploid. However, no significant difference in the rates of recurrence, metastasis, or overall survival was observed between the aneuploid and diploid tumors. These findings suggest that aneuploidy is not a reliable predictive marker for malignancy in pancreatic insulinomas and further investigations are needed to identify alternative markers for assessing the aggressive potential of these tumors.

Structural and ultrastructural study of the ovary in childhood leukemia after successful treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the structural and ultrastructural changes in the ovary of childhood leukemia patients after successful treatment. Ovarian tissue specimens were obtained from eleven female patients (age range 6-15 years) who had achieved complete remission following chemotherapy. The specimens were analyzed using light microscopy and electron microscopy. Histological analysis showed no evidence of leukemia infiltration in the ovaries. However, several structural abnormalities were observed, including a decreased number of primordial follicles and an increased number of atretic follicles. Ultrastructural analysis revealed alterations in the mitochondria and the presence of lipid droplets in the oogonia and granulosa cells. These findings suggest that successful treatment of childhood leukemia can lead to long-term ovarian damage, characterized by impaired folliculogenesis and mitochondrial dysfunction. Further research is needed to understand the consequences of these structural changes on fertility outcomes in these patients.

The management of postoperative chylous ascites. Chylous ascites is a rare but potentially serious complication following abdominal surgery. This study aimed to evaluate the management of postoperative chylous ascites and its outcomes. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 34 patients who developed chylous ascites after abdominal surgery. The majority of cases (61.8%) were due to oncologic procedures. Non-operative management, including dietary modification, octreotide, and total parenteral nutrition, was successful in 55.9% of cases, while 44.1% required surgical intervention. Of those who required surgery, thoracic duct ligation was the most common procedure performed (71.4%). The overall success rate of surgical management was 85.7%. There were no significant differences in outcomes based on the underlying etiology or type of surgical intervention. In conclusion, a conservative approach is effective in most cases of postoperative chylous ascites, with surgical intervention reserved for refractory cases.

Effects of supplemental oxygen administration in an infant with pulmonary artery hypertension. Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is a life-threatening condition characterized by increased blood pressure in the arteries that supply the lungs. Supplemental oxygen therapy has been used as a supportive treatment for PAH; however, its efficacy and optimal duration of administration remain unclear. Here we report a case of a 3-month-old infant with PAH who received supplemental oxygen therapy. The patient presented with severe respiratory distress and cyanosis, and was diagnosed with PAH based on echocardiography findings. Supplemental oxygen was administered via nasal cannula at a flow rate of 1 liter per minute, resulting in a significant improvement in the patient's oxygen saturation. A repeat echocardiogram after 24 hours of oxygen therapy showed a decrease in pulmonary artery pressure. However, the patient developed rebound hypoxemia when the oxygen therapy was discontinued. Continuous oxygen therapy was then resumed for a total duration of 5 days, during which the patient remained clinically stable. This case highlights the beneficial effects of supplemental oxygen therapy in the management of PAH in infants, and suggests that a longer duration of oxygen administration may be warranted to prevent rebound hypoxemia. Further research is needed to determine the optimal duration and titration of supplemental oxygen therapy in infants with PAH.

Local hypothermia to prolong safe tourniquet time.  Local hypothermia was studied as a method to safely prolong tourniquet time for reconstructive procedures of the upper extremity. The potential of local hypothermia in prolonging the safe duration of tourniquet application during upper extremity reconstructive procedures was investigated. Forty patients undergoing upper extremity surgery were randomly assigned to either the hypothermia group or the control group. In the hypothermia group, a cooling device was applied over the forearm and hand to achieve a local temperature of 15-18°C. Tourniquet time was significantly prolonged in the hypothermia group compared to the control group (mean of 50 minutes vs 33 minutes, p<0.001). Furthermore, no complications related to local hypothermia were observed during the study. Local hypothermia appears to be a safe and effective method to extend the duration of tourniquet application in upper extremity reconstructive procedures, allowing for improved surgical precision and reduced risk of complications. Further studies are warranted to optimize the cooling protocol and assess its long-term effects.

The vagus nerve, gastric secretions, and their relationship to peptic ulcer disease. This study examines the relationship between the vagus nerve, gastric secretions, and the development of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). It is well-established that the vagus nerve plays a role in regulating gastric acid secretion. Dysfunction of this nerve has been implicated in the pathogenesis of PUD. Furthermore, excessive production of gastric acid has long been associated with the development of ulcers. This review summarizes the existing literature on the subject, focusing on the mechanisms by which the vagus nerve influences gastric secretions and the subsequent impact on PUD. Additionally, potential novel therapeutic strategies targeting the vagus nerve for the treatment and prevention of PUD are discussed. Overall, a better understanding of the vagus nerve-gastric secretion relationship may lead to the development of more effective interventions for PUD management.

Factor XIIIa in nodular malignant melanoma and Spitz naevi. Factor XIIIa is an immunohistochemical marker used to differentiate between nodular malignant melanoma (NMM) and Spitz naevi. This study analyzed the expression of Factor XIIIa in 22 cases of NMM and 24 cases of Spitz naevi to determine its utility in distinguishing between the two entities. The results showed that Factor XIIIa expression was significantly lower in NMM compared to Spitz naevi. In addition, a higher percentage of NMM cases had absent or focal Factor XIIIa staining, while Spitz naevi cases exhibited diffuse and strong staining. Therefore, Factor XIIIa may serve as a valuable marker in differentiating NMM from Spitz naevi in dermatopathology practice.

Temporal bone findings in two cases of head injury. We present two cases of head injury in which temporal bone findings were identified. In the first case, a 28-year-old male sustained a severe head injury resulting in loss of consciousness. Temporal bone imaging revealed a fracture involving the petrous portion of the temporal bone with associated involvement of the otic capsule. In the second case, a 42-year-old female presented with mild head trauma and persistent hearing loss. Temporal bone computed tomography revealed a longitudinal fracture involving the temporal bone, extending from the squamous to the petrous portion. These cases highlight the importance of considering temporal bone involvement in patients with head injury, as it can have significant implications for hearing and other cranial nerve function.

Ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia: case report and review of the literature. We present the case of a patient with agnogenic myeloid metaplasia (AMM) who developed ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis. AMM is a rare myeloproliferative disorder characterized by bone marrow fibrosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis. Ascites is an uncommon manifestation of AMM and is rarely associated with hepatic involvement.

A 58-year-old female with a history of AMM presented with abdominal pain and distension. Abdominal imaging revealed massive ascites and liver nodules. A diagnostic paracentesis showed hematopoietic cells, and liver biopsy confirmed extramedullary hematopoiesis and peliosis.

The management of AMM with ascites involves symptomatic treatment and addressing the underlying cause. This may include supportive care, such as diuretics and paracentesis, and treatment of the myeloproliferative disorder. Liver transplantation may be considered in cases of severe liver involvement.

This case highlights the importance of considering AMM as a potential cause of ascites, especially in patients with a history of myeloproliferative disorders. Clinicians should be aware of the potential for hepatic involvement and the risk of peliosis in these patients. Further research is warranted to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare manifestation.

CV 205-502--effectiveness, tolerability, and safety over 24-month study.  Twenty hyperprolactinemic women (median prolactin [PRL] 2,989 mU/L, range 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L), previously unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine, were treated in a prospective study, for 3 to 24 months with the new, nonergot, long-acting, dopamine agonist, CV 205-502. A 24-month prospective study was conducted to assess the effectiveness, tolerability, and safety of CV 205-502, a nonergot, long-acting dopamine agonist, in the treatment of hyperprolactinemic women who had previously been unsuccessfully treated with bromocriptine. Twenty women with a median prolactin level of 2,989 mU/L (range 1,149 to 11,910 mU/L) were included in the study. The patients were treated with CV 205-502 for 3 to 24 months. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety profile of CV 205-502 as an alternative treatment option for hyperprolactinemia. Further analysis of the study results will provide insights into the therapeutic potential of CV 205-502 in this patient population.

Serum cholesterol levels and survival in elderly hypertensive patients: analysis of data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly.  The relation between serum cholesterol and mortality was investigated in 822 elderly hypertensive patients randomly assigned to treatment with diuretics, with or without methyldopa, or placebo. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between serum cholesterol levels and survival in elderly hypertensive patients. Data from the European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly was analyzed, including 822 patients who were randomly assigned to either diuretic treatment, diuretic with methyldopa treatment, or placebo. The analysis revealed a significant association between serum cholesterol levels and mortality in these patients. Higher cholesterol levels were found to be predictive of increased mortality risk. These findings emphasize the importance of managing cholesterol levels in elderly hypertensive patients to improve survival outcomes. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and develop effective interventions.

Chiari pelvic osteotomy for osteoarthritis. Chiari pelvic osteotomy is a surgical procedure performed to treat osteoarthritis in the hip joint. This procedure aims to improve the alignment of the hip joint, thereby reducing pain and improving function. The surgery involves cutting the pelvic bone to reposition the acetabulum, the cup-shaped socket of the hip joint. By repositioning the acetabulum, the surgeon aims to improve coverage and stability of the femoral head, leading to improved joint mechanics. Chiari pelvic osteotomy has shown promising results in reducing pain and improving hip function in patients with osteoarthritis. However, it is important to carefully select patients who are suitable candidates for this procedure and to consider potential complications such as nerve injury, infection, or blood vessel damage. Further research and long-term studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiari pelvic osteotomy in the management of osteoarthritis.

Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus: report of two cases. In this report, we present two cases of neurinoma occurring in the cavernous sinus. Both patients presented with similar symptoms including diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, and facial pain. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a mass in the cavernous sinus consistent with a neurinoma. Surgical resection was performed in both cases, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis. Postoperative course was uneventful, and both patients showed improvement in their symptoms. Neurinoma in the cavernous sinus is a rare entity that can present with distinctive clinical features. MRI is crucial for accurate diagnosis, and surgical resection is an effective treatment option with favorable outcomes.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency is known to cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including hepatic encephalopathy. In this report, we describe a case of overt hepatic encephalopathy in a patient with severe zinc deficiency. The patient presented with confusion, altered mental status, and abnormal liver function tests. Laboratory investigations revealed low serum zinc levels below the reference range. The patient was started on zinc supplementation, resulting in a gradual improvement in symptoms and normalization of liver function tests. Hepatic encephalopathy is a serious complication of liver disease and is typically associated with elevated ammonia levels. However, in this case, zinc deficiency was identified as the underlying cause. This case highlights the importance of considering zinc deficiency as a potential cause of hepatic encephalopathy, particularly in patients with liver dysfunction. Early recognition and appropriate treatment of zinc deficiency can lead to rapid improvement in symptoms and liver function.

Standards for analysis of ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography: a statement by a task force committee of the European Society of Cardiology, the American Heart Association, and the American College of Cardiology. This statement by a joint task force committee of the European Society of Cardiology, American Heart Association, and American College of Cardiology outlines the standards for analyzing ventricular late potentials using high-resolution or signal-averaged electrocardiography (ECG). Ventricular late potentials are considered a marker of increased risk for ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. The statement provides guidelines for electrode placement, ECG recording parameters, and signal processing techniques. Additionally, recommendations are given for interpreting abnormal findings and the use of ventricular late potential analysis in various clinical settings. These standards aim to standardize the measurement and interpretation of ventricular late potentials, facilitating consistent and accurate assessment of arrhythmia risk and informing clinical decisions regarding antiarrhythmic therapy and prophylactic interventions.

Angiocentric lymphoma with histologic features of neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. We describe a case of angiocentric lymphoma presenting with predominant respiratory and hematologic manifestations. A 52-year-old male presented with dyspnea, cough, and constitutional symptoms, as well as persistent leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. Imaging studies revealed bilateral pulmonary nodules and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Biopsies showed a neoplastic process within blood vessels with intravascular proliferation of atypical lymphoid cells, consistent with neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed positive staining for CD3, CD4, and CD5, suggesting a T-cell origin. The patient received chemotherapy along with rituximab and achieved a partial response. However, he experienced disease progression with subsequent involvement of the skin, central nervous system, and peripheral blood. Angiocentric lymphoma is a rare form of extranodal lymphoma, and its association with neoplastic angioendotheliomatosis and atypical clinical presentation make it even more challenging to diagnose and treat. This case highlights the importance of recognizing unusual presentations of lymphomas, as well as considering angiocentric lymphoma in the differential diagnosis of respiratory and hematologic manifestations.

A successful treatment of an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula by percutaneous embolization. Intrarenal arteriovenous fistula is a rare vascular abnormality that can lead to various complications such as hypertension, congestive heart failure, and renal insufficiency. Percutaneous embolization has emerged as a successful treatment option for this condition. We present a case of a 55-year-old patient with an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula causing uncontrolled hypertension, who underwent successful percutaneous embolization using coil and liquid embolic agent. The procedure resulted in complete occlusion of the fistula, with subsequent normalization of blood pressure and improvement in renal function. Percutaneous embolization offers a minimally invasive and effective treatment option for patients with intrarenal arteriovenous fistula. Further studies are needed to evaluate its long-term outcomes and compare it with other treatment modalities.

Lack of late skin necrosis in man after high-dose irradiation using small field sizes: experiences of grid therapy. Grid therapy is an innovative treatment technique for skin cancer using high-dose radiation delivered through small field sizes. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence of late skin necrosis in patients undergoing this therapy. A total of 54 patients with skin cancer were included in the study, and all received grid therapy. The occurrence of late skin necrosis was evaluated at regular follow-up visits. Remarkably, no cases of late skin necrosis were observed in any of the patients, suggesting that grid therapy using high-dose irradiation and small field sizes may be a safe and effective treatment option for skin cancer without the risk of long-term skin damage.

Deteriorating ischemic stroke: risk factors and prognosis.  To determine a risk profile of deterioration in cerebral infarction of less than 8 hours' duration, we studied prospectively a series of clinical and radiologic data in 98 patients. This prospective study aimed to identify risk factors and determine the prognosis of deteriorating ischemic stroke within 8 hours of onset. A total of 98 patients were included, and clinical and radiologic data were analyzed. Logistic regression analysis revealed that age over 65 years, hypertension, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and large vessel occlusion were significantly associated with stroke deterioration. Furthermore, a higher National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score and larger infarct volume were also predictive of worsening stroke. The 90-day mortality rate was significantly higher in patients with deteriorating stroke compared to those without deterioration. These findings emphasize the importance of early identification and aggressive management of risk factors in ischemic stroke patients to prevent deterioration and improve outcomes.

Peroneal nerve palsy after total knee arthroplasty.  The prognosis for peroneal palsy after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is poorly defined. Peroneal nerve palsy is a known complication following total knee arthroplasty (TKA), but the prognosis for this condition remains unclear. This retrospective study aims to investigate the prognosis of peroneal palsy after TKA. A total of 52 patients who developed peroneal nerve palsy after TKA were included in the study. The patients' medical records were reviewed to determine the outcomes of their condition. The majority of patients (65%) experienced complete resolution of peroneal palsy within six months following TKA. However, a small percentage of patients (10%) continued to have persistent palsy beyond six months, and some (8%) even required surgical intervention. The findings suggest that the prognosis for peroneal palsy after TKA is generally favorable, with most cases resolving within six months. However, further research is needed to identify factors that may contribute to persistent palsy and to develop appropriate management strategies.

Unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to the neck. Case report of a rare presentation of unknown primary squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) metastatic to the neck. A 65-year-old male presented with a painless, rapidly growing neck mass without any other symptoms. Imaging revealed a large lymphadenopathy in the left neck region. Fine-needle aspiration cytology confirmed the diagnosis of SCC. Extensive workup failed to identify the primary tumor site. The patient underwent radical neck dissection with excision of the affected lymph nodes. Histopathology confirmed metastatic SCC without evidence of primary tumor. Postoperative adjuvant radiotherapy was administered. Follow-up imaging and regular surveillance showed no evidence of recurrence at the primary site. This case highlights the challenge in identifying the primary tumor in metastatic SCC and the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in managing such cases. Further studies are warranted to understand the etiology and optimal management strategies for unknown primary SCC metastasis.

Tissue changes around loose prostheses. Tissue changes surrounding loose prostheses have been investigated in a study involving 50 individuals who underwent revision surgery for implant failure. Histopathological examination revealed various tissue reactions, including chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and necrosis. Additionally, the presence of metallic debris and wear particles was observed within the surrounding tissues. Notably, the severity of tissue changes correlated with the length of time the prostheses had been implanted. Furthermore, immunohistochemical analysis showed increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and markers of oxidative stress in the affected tissues. These findings indicate that the interaction between the implant and the surrounding tissues initiates a cascade of inflammatory responses and tissue damage. Understanding the mechanisms underlying these tissue changes is crucial for the development of strategies to prevent and treat prosthetic implant failure. Further research is warranted to elucidate the specific molecular pathways involved in this process and to identify potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia complicating multiple myeloma. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) is a severe opportunistic infection commonly associated with immunosuppression. The authors report a case of PCP in a patient with multiple myeloma, a hematologic malignancy characterized by abnormal plasma cell proliferation. PCP complicating multiple myeloma is a rare occurrence but can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if not promptly diagnosed and treated. The patient presented with fever, cough, and progressive dyspnea, and chest imaging revealed bilateral infiltrates consistent with PCP. Diagnosis was confirmed by bronchoalveolar lavage, which demonstrated the presence of Pneumocystis carinii organisms. Treatment with high-dose oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole led to a complete resolution of symptoms. Given the potential for PCP to occur in patients with multiple myeloma, prophylactic measures should be considered to prevent this life-threatening infection.

Movement disorders--limb movement and the basal ganglia. Movement disorders are a diverse group of neurologic conditions characterized by abnormal involuntary movements. The basal ganglia, a group of nuclei located deep within the brain, play a crucial role in the regulation of voluntary movements. Abnormalities in the basal ganglia circuitry can result in various movement disorders. This review focuses on limb movement disorders associated with dysfunction of the basal ganglia. Specifically, we discuss Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, dystonia, and tremor. Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor, while Huntington's disease is characterized by chorea and other hyperkinetic movements. Dystonia is defined by sustained or intermittent muscle contractions causing abnormal postures or repetitive movements, and tremor refers to rhythmic oscillatory movements. Understanding the pathophysiology and clinical features of these disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Additionally, emerging treatments targeting the basal ganglia circuitry show promise in improving motor symptoms and quality of life in patients with limb movement disorders. Further research is warranted to advance our understanding and treatment of these conditions.

Prospective study of a prosthetic H-graft portacaval shunt.  This study was undertaken to prospectively evaluate the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt. This prospective study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt in patients with portal hypertension. A total of 20 patients underwent the procedure and were followed up for a mean duration of 24 months. The primary endpoint was the patency rate of the shunt, while secondary endpoints included improvement in hepatic function and reduction in portal pressure. The results showed a high patency rate of 95% at the end of the follow-up period. There was also a significant improvement in liver function tests and a reduction in portal pressure in the majority of patients. Furthermore, postoperative complications were minimal, with no cases of shunt thrombosis or hepatic encephalopathy. In conclusion, the 8-mm Gore-Tex interposition H-graft portacaval shunt is a safe and effective option for the management of portal hypertension, providing good long-term patency and improved hepatic function. Further studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm these findings.

Florid refractory schizophrenias that turn out to be treatable variants of HLA-associated narcolepsy. This study examines the relationship between Florid refractory schizophrenias and HLA-associated narcolepsy. Patients diagnosed with Florid refractory schizophrenia were evaluated to determine if they actually had a treatable variant of HLA-associated narcolepsy. The study found that a subset of patients diagnosed with Florid refractory schizophrenia had symptoms consistent with narcolepsy and were responsive to treatments for narcolepsy. These patients exhibited characteristic symptoms of narcolepsy, such as excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy. Further analysis revealed a strong association between HLA alleles and the presence of narcolepsy symptoms in these patients. These findings suggest that a proportion of individuals diagnosed with Florid refractory schizophrenia may in fact have a treatable variant of HLA-associated narcolepsy, highlighting the importance of accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Small bowel enteroscopy: an early experience in gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin.  Peroral small intestinal enteroscopy was performed in 35 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin by using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope. Gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin is a challenging clinical problem that often requires invasive diagnostic procedures. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the utility of peroral small bowel enteroscopy using a prototypic Sonde-type enteroscope in 35 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin. The enteroscopy procedure successfully visualized the small intestine in all patients, allowing for direct examination and targeted interventions if necessary. The etiology of bleeding was identified in 62.9% of cases, with angioectasia being the most common finding. No procedure-related complications were encountered. Our findings suggest that peroral small bowel enteroscopy with the use of a Sonde-type enteroscope is a feasible and safe technique for evaluating patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown origin, offering a potential alternative to more invasive diagnostic procedures. Further studies are warranted to validate and establish the role of this procedure in clinical practice.

Parathyroid hormone-like peptide in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells. Parathyroid hormone-like peptide (PTHLH) has been demonstrated in various tissues and has diverse biological functions. However, its expression and role in mesothelial cells remain unclear. In this study, we investigated the expression of PTHLH in normal and neoplastic mesothelial cells. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that PTHLH expression was absent in normal mesothelial tissues. However, PTHLH was detected in neoplastic mesothelial cells, particularly in malignant mesothelioma. Moreover, PTHLH expression was associated with tumor stage and poor prognosis. In vitro experiments demonstrated that PTHLH knockdown inhibited cell proliferation and induced apoptosis in mesothelioma cells. Overall, our findings suggest that PTHLH plays a crucial role in neoplastic transformation of mesothelial cells, and may serve as a potential therapeutic target for malignant mesothelioma.

Acute pulmonary oedema on the Ruwenzori mountain range. A 45-year-old male climber developed sudden onset dyspnea and cough while ascending the Ruwenzori mountain range. On examination, he had tachycardia, tachypnea, and bilateral rales on lung auscultation. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. Oxygen saturation was reduced. The climber was promptly evacuated to a lower altitude and administered supplemental oxygen. In the subsequent days, his symptoms improved and oxygen saturation returned to normal. Acute pulmonary edema was attributed to high altitude exposure. Prompt recognition and descent to lower altitude remain the mainstay of treatment for high altitude pulmonary edema. Further studies are needed to evaluate risk factors and preventive strategies for this potentially life-threatening condition.

The modified superior based pharyngeal flap. This study evaluates the outcome of the modified superior based pharyngeal flap procedure in 32 patients with velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI). The technique involves creating a pharyngeal flap with a superior pedicle instead of the traditional posterior pedicle for better control of flap movement and speech outcomes. A multidimensional evaluation was conducted, including speech assessment, aerodynamic measurements, and perceptual evaluations. Results showed significant improvement in speech intelligibility, nasal resonance, and velopharyngeal function postoperatively. The flap movement was well-controlled, leading to reduced hypernasality. Dysphagia was minimal and resolved spontaneously. Complications were minimal, with no cases of flap necrosis or velopharyngeal obstruction. Overall, the modified superior based pharyngeal flap procedure offers a safe and effective surgical option with favorable outcomes for patients with VPI. Further studies with longer follow-up are warranted to confirm these findings.

Duplex Doppler examination of a perinephric abscess in a renal transplant. We present a case of a perinephric abscess in a renal transplant patient evaluated by duplex Doppler examination. The patient presented with fever, lower back pain, and elevated inflammatory markers. Duplex Doppler examination revealed a hypoechoic collection adjacent to the transplanted kidney with poor internal vascularity. Color Doppler imaging showed absence of flow within the collection. Spectral Doppler analysis demonstrated low resistance flow within the adjacent renal artery and vein. These findings were consistent with a perinephric abscess. The patient underwent percutaneous drainage, which confirmed the diagnosis and resulted in resolution of symptoms. Duplex Doppler examination proved to be valuable in the assessment and management of this perinephric abscess in a renal transplant patient, allowing for accurate diagnosis and appropriate intervention.

Obstructive sleep apnea presenting with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of partial or complete upper airway obstruction during sleep, leading to interrupted breathing and oxygen desaturation. This case report describes a patient who presented with nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death, which were ultimately attributed to OSA. A 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and occasional chest pain during sleep was admitted to the hospital after experiencing severe nocturnal chest pain and shortness of breath. Cardiac biomarkers and electrocardiogram findings were normal. However, a polysomnography test revealed severe OSA, with an apnea-hypopnea index of 55 events per hour. Treatment with continuous positive airway pressure significantly improved the patient's symptoms and prevented further cardiovascular events. This case highlights the importance of considering OSA as a potential underlying cause of nocturnal angina, heart failure, and near-miss sudden death in patients with cardiovascular risk factors. Early recognition and appropriate management of OSA can significantly improve patient outcomes.

A prospective evaluation of the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail in the treatment of traumatic and reconstructive problems of the femur. The AO/ASIF universal femoral nail has been widely used in the management of traumatic and reconstructive problems of the femur. However, there remains a lack of prospective evaluation on its efficacy and outcomes. This study aimed to assess the clinical and radiological outcomes of patients treated with the AO/ASIF universal femoral nail for traumatic and reconstructive femur injuries. A total of [number] patients were included in this prospective study, with [number] patients fulfilling the inclusion criteria. The results demonstrated satisfactory healing of fractures, with [percentage] of patients achieving union within [time period].
